description:
Popular & busy place.  We had to wait about 20 min.  Cramped tables.

Spring rolls:  Good size.  Very tasty.
Pho Bo:  Aromatic broth with good flavors.  Generous amount of beef.
Vegetarian pho:  Generous amount of vegetables.  We opted for beef broth rather than vegetable broth.

Overall, outstanding spot for pho worth seeking out.
author: j c.

description:
Ordered "Bun Bo Hue" which is rare beef, beef shank, pork sausage and belly, shrimp paste in spicy lemongrass broth ($12.50).
I could barely find any beef/pork in the soup, I had to keep digging into the soup. As if it was too much soup, but it was actually very little ingredients/meats in the soup.
Service is fast, this is the only good thing about it.
If I am craving for Vietnamese food, I don't think this is the restaurant to go for.
author: Irene X.

description:
I should've known better, but I let Yelp get the best of me. The PHO BO is fine if we're discussing the noodles and the broth.

But what's up with the BO, aka the BEEF?! It was ridiculously tough and chewy! I have never had such awful beef in my pho life. Pho realz. I took one for the team and basically swallowed the meat slices.

3 stars: decent broth, noodles, tripe, drinks, service, and short wait time.

Pro-Tip:
- They charge for tripe. GTFO.

All I can say is, I should've never betrayed my favorite spot, PPQ. Ranked in order of greatness: PPQ, Golden Star Vietnamese, Kevin's, everyone else.
author: Fanny W.

description:
I've only eaten here once, but I don't think I'd make the trip back. 

I came here right at dinner time with a friend and we were the second party to be seated. We ordered the grilled pork vermicelli (+egg roll $2.50) and the pho ga.

The grilled pork vermicelli had a ton of pork, which was awesome, but I couldn't help but feel like everything in my bowl was leftover from lunch time. If you've ever cooked vermicelli noodles, you know how they get dried out and tough if you leave them out for a while...these noodles had just that. The egg roll was fresh and tasty, but unfortunately I can't justify paying an additional $2.50 for it. I also had to ask for more fish sauce, as they barely gave any.

My friend said her pho ga was average, with the chicken being on the drier side.

Service here was very no nonsense - menus were thrown on the table and we received the check before we were ready to leave.
author: Shirley H.

description:
This was a last minute find, on a last minute trip to the city. Luckily we strolled in before 7:00 PM, which allowed us to get seated immediately. Within minutes after we were seated, the line continued to build outside of the entrance.

The restaurant is very small, and would probably struggle with larger groups. Our server (RJ) was AMAZING! He knew the menu like the back of his hand, and his recommendations were on point.

LINE-UP
*Hue Rolls / grilled lemongrass pork - The pork was cooked to perfection, and was packed with drooling flavor!
*Braised Pork / pork shoulder & pork belly - A few chunks of tender pork swimming in a pool flavorful bliss!
*Bun Thit Bo Nuong / grilled lemon grass beef rolls - Perfectly cooked and seasoned beef alongside super moist vermicelli noddles!
*Wonton Noodels / shrimp & pork wontons w/egg noodles - Flavorful broth, and probably the best wontons in the Bay!

Overall TVC executed from all angles. I'd say the dishes we tried racked up a solid 4.5 Stars, but with the excellent service, the .5 bump is well deserved. Looking forward to my next visit!
author: Robert H.

description:
Grabbed dinner here alone on a work trip after reading a few articles and searching yelp for a decent bowl of pho. I was not let down! This tiny nook is a bit off the beaten path from SoMa, but well worth the walk. 

I had a bowl of Pho Ga and spring rolls. Both were fresh and came out in ample time. Very tasty broth and personally enjoyed the pickled onions on the typical pho garnish plate.

A cute spot for a date night or to catch up with a friend. Small and intimate atmosphere.
author: Sabrina G.

description:
Food is definitely 5 stars. 
Service is 3 at its best. 

The reason why I am disappointed with the service was the way they put our food down, the way they responded when I told them were ready to order, the way they gave us our check when we weren't even finished. I mean, why are they in a rush. I only came here because there wasn't parking for dim sum. 

Ordered pho chicken and chicken wings 

The wings were not bad and the pho chicken was really good. I definitely enjoyed the food a lot.
author: Lisa E.

description: 3rd visit. I would say this place is a solid 4. The food is great, price is great. Authentic Vietnames flavors (for someone who isn't Vietnamese, at least). Definitely a spot I would keep coming back to when I'm craving some tasty Asian flavors. The only reason why I am not giving a 5 star review is because the service is a hit-and-miss. It's like they're always low staffed. It is a small restaurant, but 3 people working the floor (bussing, serving, taking orders, preparing to-go orders, etc) doesn't seem to be doing the trick. That being said, I'm not steered away by this. I still like their food and I'd still come back.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Great for those who are not experienced with Vietnamese cuisine as well as for those who are!  Came here on a weekday night late (around 9pm) with one other person and were able to get seating immediately (though the restaurant was still quite packed).

Venue / Services: a little dark inside, especially with the black walls and floor which gave the place a dimly-lit atmosphere.  Thankfully it wasn't so dark that you needed to whip out phones to read the menu.  A bit packed while we were there but not enough to feel claustrophobic (but think twice about bringing a large shopping bag or something).  The servers were pretty professional and quick at bringing food out, though we had to flag them down a few times for more water.

Food: my date had been to Vietnam and upon tasting some of the dishes (especially the broths), he commented that they were pretty close to food in Vietnam.  I liked how the menu was pretty expansive so there is (usually) something for everyone.
-- Canh Ga Chien (soy-garlic chicken wings, salt-pepper-lime dipping sauce)($9.50) - surprisingly tasty!  The skin wasn't super crunchy like you might expect from a fried chicken, but neither was it super flabby / icky.  Surprisingly wasn't too heavy in the stomach, especially after squeezing lime on top of them.  Great for sharing!

-- Bun Rieu (shrimp, crab and minced pork balls, fried tofu, shrimp, tomato, chicken tomato broth)($12.50) - wanted to try something other than pho, and wasn't disappointed!  It is a bigger portion than pho bo, so be wary if you have a small stomach.  Surprisingly, the broth was very savory and yet light with the tomato in it.  The rice noodles are thicker than that in pho, so it was slightly easier to pick up (though they still tend to break apart easily).  Lot of meat in this bowl, so I doubt anyone can go hungry with this option.  

My date ordered the Pho Bo (rare beef & brisket with rice noodles in beef broth)($10.50), which was also quite tasty.  He noted its flavors were very close to what he found in Vietnam, so I'll take that as a good sign.  Very savory broth and a decent portion (not as big as the bun rieu), so seems like a solid option.  

Great spot for Vietnamese cuisine; hopefully you can experience it without dealing with a huge line like we did.  Probably would be worth 15-25 min wait time if there was one.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Michelin recommended

Great food

long wait

crammed

Either the food took too long or we were served the wrong food. Overall a good place to go but I can't keep giving every business 5 stars. Let's set the bar a bit higher in our lives.
author: Tim C.

description:
Stopped in for a quick bite on a Tuesday night and was unfortunately greeted by a cluster of people waiting for a table outside the door. What ensued was a confusing and rather disorganized process. We stepped in to put our name on the list and stood there for a good five minutes before we realized that we were supposed to do it ourselves on a small notepad on a shelf. Perhaps ten minutes later a server came out to look for two parties of two to share a table - didn't seem like he was calling anyone in order of the waitlist on the notepad, but either way we were seated.

Anyways, on to the food! I ordered the lemongrass pork shoulder vermicelli bowl - nothing spectacular but was decently good (pro tip, it does not taste good the next day heated up as leftovers, I found out the hard way as I sadly sat at my desk and ate it). It had your usual flavors - a lil sweet, a lil salty, a lil fish saucey.

Their menu is quite expansive so I would definitely consider returning and trying some of their other stuff!
author: Linda M.

description:
The best cure for the sickies? A yummy bowl of pho! Having caught some nasty bug over the weekend, I had zero energy to cook, let alone go out for dinner. Thanks to the delivery option at Tín Vietnamese, I was able to rest my fatigued self while still getting a tasty bowl of pho. Unlike many pho places I frequent, Tín offers an extraordinary bowl of vegetarian pho. Filled with veggies like carrots, broccoli and bok choy, and supplemented with tasty and perfectly spongey pieces of tofu, I was stuffed, satisfied, and already feeling much better after my meal. Our delivery came with all the accompaniments and needed cutlery- well thought out service, in my opinion.
Thanks for the perfect cure!!
author: Roma R.

description:
Solid pho place. 

I ordered pho with brisket and the spring rolls. Very basic but good. The pho broth wasn't the best I've ever had but it was very decent/passable. I enjoyed the meal and everything was tasty. Service was noticeably very fast which was good because there was a line at the door of people waiting to be seated. 

It's not going to knock your socks off as the best place ever but if you're looking for some warm comforting goodness, it will deliver.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
Food is delicious!    

We ordered: 
-Spring rolls
-Firecracker Shrimp
-Pho Bo

The spring rolls were plump and tasted like they were freshly made.  The firecracker shrimp was crunchy on the outside and had a good texture on the inside (dip it in the sauce!).  The pho was definitely the star of the show for us.  The broth was super flavorful and tasty!  I don't particularly care for celery and they had little slices of crunchy celery in the broth, but my boyfriend seemed to really enjoy the extra texture!  It is slightly more expensive than other pho restaurants, but it was definitely worth the trip and we will be back very soon!
author: Lynne T.

description:
Any place that serves Bun Rieu already gives it one leg up from the average pho place. While I can't say the Bun Rieu is that great (I like the one from Ben Tre so much more!), this one is decent.

SF just doesn't have that many good Vietnamese places which is very unfortunate.

We ordered a bottle of wine, it was a moderately-priced Cab Franc, and it was pretty bad. Last time we'll ever get wine from a pho place, ha!

Considering the location of this place, it's a bit more expensive than I'd like to pay... for what I'm getting for the food. But, it's not a bad place, maybe 3.5 stars.
author: Cal C.

description:
I've been to Tin on a few trips to San Francisco, and each time, its pho is soul soothing.

On my most recent visit, I was staying at a hotel less than a block away and hungry for something comforting. Though summer, it was cool and breezy out, and I was nursing the last bits of a cold -- perfect time for pho.

But before I get to my order, let me first say how nice it was to order takeout via the Yelp app. I ordered in less than a few minutes, and then it was easy to pickup roughly 20 minutes after that. Easy peasy. 

And onto the food: I opted for Pho Ga, which is poached chicken with rice noodles in ginger-chicken broth. Love love love this broth. This soup came with large pieces of white chicken -- it did not skimp in any way in that regard. I also got sprouts, scallions and some more mix-ins. 

All in all, this was a delicious pho, but I do admit it is pretty basic. If you're new to pho, this will likely be right up your alley. I'm used to having a bit more in my soup, though. 

I also got spring rolls, which were stuffed with poached pork and shrimp, vermicelli and mint and came with a peanut dipping sauce. That peanut sauce is killer -- really a favorite. These rolls were a bit heavy on the mint, compared to other spring rolls I've had, but were pretty delicious regardless. 

Tin also packaged up the food nicely to where I was able to get it to my hotel without any spilling and was able to assemble the soup myself to where the noodles didn't get too mushy in transit. 

If you want pho, this is a good place to go!
author: Emily H.

description:
Well dang. My SF trip started off with a thud.

Tin Vietnamese is less than a block from my hotel, and the reviews made it sound like a clear must-eat. Maybe I was there on an off time, but I was pretty disappointed. 

I ordered the spring rolls, which I found to be pretty tough and chewy. My vermacelli with grilled shrimp didn't have much going on for it, either. Neither dish had much flavor. 

I suppose you can't win them all. Hopefully the rest of my meals over this trip are more memorable.
author: Matt E.

description:
Great food, prompt service, decent prices. 

We ordered the 5 spice quail and xiu mai for apps, bo kho ( beef stew) and bun bo hue for entrees. 

The apps were great, knocked it outta the park, 

so much flavor in the xiu mai, essentially pork and shrimp meatballs in a garlicky broth full of scallions with a side of baguette and herbs and pickles to make your own little sandwich, classic French influenced fusion.. that's not even considered fusion anymore cause these are staples from the indo China days. 

The 5 spice quail was my little piece of heaven, cause I love eating meat from bones. Served with a little lime salt and pepper dipping sauce, I revisited through the entire meal. Don't order this if you can't eat meat of the bone, it's unavoidable. 

Soup/entrees:

Bo kho with egg noodles was great, the only thing I'd want is a bit more richness in the broth and some fish concentrate, but everything else about it was fantastic not too much gristle.

Bun bo hue was amazing too, just a smooth savory broth with the thick noodles, Vietnamese ham and flank. So enjoyable and the broth wasn't overly salty which is something that happens whenever I order bun bo hue elsewhere. I really like that they have a vegetarian bun bo hue option because I love the flavor of it but not necessarily all the proteins. 

All in all out in under an hour, classic Vietnamese done right!
author: Megan K.

description:
Holy Thai! What a great find! 

This place is delicious! My first time at this family owned restaurant, and I promise you, it will not be my last! Tin Vietnamese has grown from a 0 to a 100 rating real quick-like seriously! This place is tiny, but is bursting with flavor! My friend and I decided to come here for our lunch and I am definitely happy we did! We arrived around 11:30 AM to beat the lunch crowd-such a great idea! By 12 PM, this place is packed like sardines. 

Everything looks good in pictures, it was such a hard decision to make. After a lot of back and forth, we decided to order to caramelized clay pot catfish and 5 spice chicken rice plate. Honestly, the food was so filling that we had so much leftover. However, everything was delicious! The food was seasoned so damn well; flavorful indeed! The food prices here are so darn reasonable for it to be in San Francisco. For two people, you're paying less than $20 a meal; steal deal! 

Don't expect something fancy....this place is not it! It's a simple hole in the wall food joint that serves delicious meals for a reasonable price. 

Now, moving on to customer service! First and foremost, big Thank You to the wonderful service we received from our server named, Shy. Shy was very efficient and quick. I swear it seemed that our food came out literally after we ordered-maybe it was because there weren't many people in the restaurant at the time we ordered?! Whatever it was, I enjoyed how quickly the food came out because I was HANGRY! 

Top food items to order: 
*The Tin Rolls
*Pho Kho 
*5 spice chicken rice plate
*Clay Pot dishes (Shrimp or Catfish)-both were super delicious! 

This place is relatively close to the Intercontinental hotel and the Moscone Conference Center. Make sure you beat the crowds, or you can walk into a line out the door!
author: Porsche C.

description:
So I've been here a few times now and although it isn't the best vietnamese food, something obviously keeps me coming back.  

First of all, street parking can be difficult but I never had a problem finding a space before they opened.  A line tends to start building up after 6pm or so.  Service is quick, efficient, and just friendly enough to make you feel welcome.  

Now as far as the food, it has been up and down depending on the dish.  

The tin rolls?  Definitely not authentic...but absolutely delicious and worth coming back just to eat those alone.  They're basically spring rolls with a sliced hard boiled egg which gives them a creamy, surprising texture that works really well.  

Bun bo hue...not very good.  Just isn't close to the quality of what you would expect from some of the best in San Jose.  Fresh?  Yes.  Flavor?  No.  I'd pass on this here.

Bun thit nuong with cha gio?  Huge.  Never-ending.  Pork was great.  Definitely a good dish to order here.  

Pho bo with beef balls.  Just ok.  Served piping hot, fresh...but the noodles were overcooked and I thought it was missing that long simmered flavor.  It'll get the job done though.

I'd give this spot a solid 4 stars and a return.
author: Jen W.

description:
This restaurant can be misleading, because even though the waiters and chefs don't seem to be Vietnamese, the food tastes pretty damn authentic.

I ordered the warm beef salad, since I had a lighter appetite that night. The beef was a little salty, but overall, the dish tasted really flavorful. What stood out the most was the lemongrass that was used to cook the beef. Lemongrass is one of my favorite spices! If you order the salad, though, I'd recommend asking for the dressing on the side. Otherwise, it might be too overwhelming when mixed with the beef.

Some other dishes I was able to sample from my fam: the claypot catfish was also delicious, but like the beef, it was on the saltier side. Lemongrass pork was a little underwhelming. Imo the pork was cut too thinly, was tough to chew, and slightly overcooked. Overall, though, I would come back here for Vietnamese food. It's a nice hole-in-the-wall restaurant in SoMa, and unlike other Vietnamese places, the place is kept really clean.
author: Connie X.

description:
I was excited to try this place because of the reviews, but this place fell way below my expectations.

We ordered the hue roll, bun bo hue, and pho bo. They pretty much forgot about our orders which was pretty sad. We kept trying to get the waiters attention but he seemed to be looking anywhere except us. We were seated about 15 minutes before a large part of 8 and even they got their food before the two of us. 

Hue roll: 4/5. It was like a fusion between spring rolls and the rice crepe rolls you get at dim sum. I thought they were only okay because I don't like cilantro, but my boyfriend loved it.

Pho bo: 3/5. Average pho, shallots were a plus.

Bun bo hue: 1/5. The broth was so flavorless and all I could really taste was the spice. I was seriously disappointed by this dish.

Overall, I would not go back to this place.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Came here on a Friday at about 11:45am for lunch. We were seated promptly.

I got the lemongrass pork bowl and it came within about 10-15 min of ya ordering. The pork was very flavorful, the noodles were tasty and the meal was quite filling.

The food is good, and if you get in early it's relatively quick. I've heard there's a wait but haven't experienced one personally. I'd definitely come back.

One gripe was that they play really loud music which seems totally unnecessary and is my larger gripe with many newer restaurants. I do actually want to talk to the people I'm with and don't like this trend. They'll get a whole extra star if they kill the music or turn it way down. It was really difficult to hear people in our group of 4.
author: Alex H.

description:
We live 1 min away from Tin and that's the best thing ever. When we first moved here, I had been smelling something super delicious every time I open the window but I didn't know what it was. 

Then one night, I saw Tin on Yelp. At the time, it didn't have so many reviews and wasn't recommended on Michelin Guide. We were just checking it out - you know, if it smells so delicious, it can't taste that bad, right? 

And it was AMAZING! Pho Bo was so delicious! Granted I was super hungry but the soup was just such a perfect mix of flavors. The beef was cooked by the hot soup to the right degree. And the noodles themselves were never too soft. So comforting and so filling. 

We've since brought many friends here and it never disappoints. Even though Pho Bo is a must do, we have also tried the Caramelized Claypot Cathfish, so tasty! It doesn't smell fishy and judging from the texture, the fish is very very fresh. The rolls are a good choice too, the Cha Gio is very rich in flavors and the Hue Rolls is full of good stuff, for some reason I really like the rice wrap on the non-fried one, it's smooth moist and thick and just tastes so clean and comforting. We've also had the Braised Pork, 5-Spice Chicken, and Sautéed Greens, all were very well made too! In short, Tin never disappoints. 

Being so awesome does have one drawback tho - with Tin being so popular today, it's hard to get seated and the service sometimes can slip a little. 

Still, Tin will always be my favorite.
author: Iris H.

description:
Came in at 8pm on a Saturday night for a party of two and was seated in 5 minutes. I ordered the pho bo ($10.50) with beef balls ($1.5). The broth could have been slightly hotter, but the pho was pretty good, flavorful (but there is def room for improvement here), with generous portions of meat. I really enjoyed the meatballs on top.

Hard to mess up pho, but I also have never had pho that has blown my mind away. This is a good place I wouldn't mind returning to.
author: Karanveer M.

description:
This place is a cool little spot in Soma and I definitely recommend it. 

I split the Pho Bo (Beef) and the Shaken Beef plate w/ my fiancé. Solid. I've definitely had better Pho, but it still hit the spot. The flavor was all there, but I wish the authentic oily Vietnamese kind. If you don't see a lot of oil in your pho, you know that it's decent, but not the top tier kind.

The Shaken Beef was really good. It came with salad, rice and of course the beef w/ a lemon pepper dipping sauce. The beef is cooked with onions, red bell peppers and they also surprise you with two cherry tomatoes lol. Random was a good surprise. 

Anyways, perfect for lunch or just a casual dinner with yourself, a date, or with a few friends.
author: Robin C.

description:
I ordered Pho Bo ($10.50) w/ beef balls ($1.50) & tripe ($1.50).
I came with a party of 6 people (7 initially) on a Friday night. The combination of a large party size and the restaurant being busy we waited about an hour and ten minutes.
The pho was savory and fragrant. The meat was fairly tender and the vegetables fresh and crisp.
The service was fast; the waitress came and immediately took our order after seating our party. The food came out shortly after (less than 15 minutes) with the rice dish (ordered by one of the people in my party) arriving first followed by the noodle soup dishes.
I would definitely come back and recommend Tin for Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Michael W.

description:
Quality you can taste. And healthy to boot!

It's not often that I'm super sold on spots immediately, but I guess you know it when you see it. I got the Pho Bo with tripe and tendon, and an order of Vietnamese spring rolls.

On its own, the pho bo broth was way too salty to drink, but it paired well with the noodles. Clear, yet infused with the hours that had gone into making the broth. The noodles were decently al dente, though I wish the tendon had been cooked a bit (actually, a lot) softer, but I can see this being a preference thing. They were pretty good about the topping to noodle ratio. Tripe and beef were both decent, although I do wish there had been a bit more pre-marination of both. 

The spring rolls were great! Healthy, with sliced shrimp and beef portioned evenly throughout the roll. I really like that they took the time to slice the meat thinly so you got a bit in every bite. The mint was pungent, and the rice roll wraps were the perfect thickness (this really stood out). If I had one complaint, it would be that the peanut butter sauce was a bit thick, but otherwise perfect flavor. 

Certainly not the least expensive Vietnamese spot in the city, but for a healthy meal in SF, it's certainly up there.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Brought my mom here for lunch the day she arrived back to SF. They don't have good Pho at all in Shanghai for some reason so its always the first thing she wants to eat. Was going to go to Miss Saigon but it was a freezing day and we didn't want to walk as far. We were five minutes before opening but they didn't let us in even though the door was open but thats okay. 

We were the first people in the door and happy we were early because the place was BEYOND packed by the time we finished eating. Literally people exploding out the door and packed in like sardines so come early if you don't want to wait.

We split the pho, quail, and shrimp appetizer. My mom loved the quail! By the end of her trip back, I asked her what her favorite restaurant she ate at was this time and she said Tin because of their quail. 

Our waiter was not friendly at all which is the only disappointment. The food here was good but I actually prefer Miss Saigon. Miss Saigon is way cheaper with nicer service. Tin would be the more upscale and cleaner version.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
A big group of us came here for lunch because we were craving Vietnamese food, and the experience was ok.  My disclaimer is we are Vietnamese, so our base standard for good Vietnamese food is perhaps higher than average.  With that being said, we really liked the beef banh cuon.  The fried egg rolls on the other hand were disappointing.  In our group we ordered bun bo hue, pho ga, five spice chicken, ca la vong, bun thit nuong with fried egg rolls, and banh xeo.

If you want to have an average Vietnamese food experience, then I think this place is worth a try.  Service was good, and the food came out quickly.
author: Krys T.

description: I wish this were back home and not 1000's of miles away. My sisters and I stopped here during our sister trip and the three of us could not stop talking about how great everything was. We ordered Pho Ga (this ginger and lemon grass base is the best Pho I have ever had) Bun Thit Nuong also delicious we also had spring rolls and the firecracker shrimp. Nothing here disappoints. If I ever find myself back in San Francisco this is a must stop.
author: Amber E.

description: The soup was pretty good to be honest. But it was a bit pricey for pho when it comes to just better soup. I know the soup is better than Miss Saigon but not worth the price difference. I will probably stick with Miss Saigon in the area but think this is a quality spot for the food they had.
author: Kuan H.

description:
I was excited to try this spot based on all the good reviews I had seen on Yelp, but my dish was disappointing. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing?

My group of 7 came here on a Saturday night around 7:30, and we were able to get seated pretty quickly, within 15-20 minutes or so. After perusing the menu, I went with the Canh Ga Chien ($9.50), or soy garlic wings, to start. For my entree, I ordered the Hu Tieu ($11.50), which is a noodle soup that comes with pork, chicken, and shrimp in a garlic-chicken broth.

The soy garlic wings, which came in a combination of wings and drummettes, were delicious, and my friends and I quickly gobbled them all up. 

I was very disappointed with my entree though. I was expecting a broth on the salty end of the spectrum, since it was described as a garlic chicken broth, but it was surprisingly sweet and not what I wanted at all. The meat was all overcooked and the chicken breast meat they used was some of the driest I've had in years, even after soaking in the broth for a while. I had a very hard time finishing this dish, but I tried hard to as I was raised to not waste food as much as possible.

Honestly I think I just ordered the wrong thing, so take my review with a grain of salt. The guy next to me ordered pho bo, your standard beef-based pho, and apparently that was delicious. If I find myself in the area again, I wouldn't mind stopping by for a bowl of pho.

Paid ~$30 after tax and tip.
author: Dianna H.

description: I came here for dinner with a friend and liked it. My drunken beef with rice had a delicious sauce and the right amount of garlic. My friend liked her pho, and I liked the pickled onions that came with it. Service was attentive and included timely tea refills. The setting was relaxed and not too crowded (on a Thursday evening). I hope to return!
author: Novelty B.

description:
The food was good. Got the bun Bo Hue, which was super tasty and the right amount of spice. I thought it was going to be too spicy. 

Walked in at 11:30am and the host/owner didn't seat me. This place was empty at that time, but without being seated, I awkwardly stood in the doorway as other customers were being served. My friend got a grilled pork dish and it was super tasty. ~$15 (incl tip) for lunch. It's not the cheapest, but definitely is a good semi-low cost option for food in the area.

Also - this place accidentally charged me for my lunch and separately for the entire bill. I had them reverse the charge, but watch your CC statement.
author: Christina L.

description:
Kept trying to come back year after the first visit in 2014. Kept trying but timing was always off (they're closed between lunch and dinner service). Finally went back in December 2017!

Food = delicious, clean & fresh tasting.  If you're wanting giant portions for dirt cheap - this isn't the place.  But if you're wanting clean food for moderate pricing and good service - stay and enjoy.

Hue rolls (grilled lemongrass pork, fresh herbs, fried shallots, steamed rice paper) = excellent. Been wanting this style of rice rolls for a long time and this place has them. Hit the spot! I wanted an order to go also but decided to not be a total glutton. I regret that decision the minute I left. Still wanting that 2nd order now. $10.00.

Hu Tieu (xa-xiu pork, chicken & shrimp, ground pork in garlic-chicken broth) = excellent.  Not greasy, clear broth and more than enough for one meal. Hearty portion. $11.00.

Pho Ga (poached chicken with rice noodles in ginger-chicken
broth) = excellent. Clear broth. Fresh ingredients. $10.00.

Vietnamese coffee = good. Strong. (I'd prefer it stronger.) $4.00 x2.

Service = friendly. They try to stay attentive even though this place gets slammed within 30 minutes of opening. 

Prices = moderate to expensive. Clean, high quality food for your buck. Lunch for two came out to under $46.00 (SF Mandate/Healthy SF tax applies.)  

Would prefer to not wait over 3 years for the next visit!
author: Fannie S.

description: I got the spicy vegetarian tofu noodle soup. The broth was very tasty and I appreciated the amount of veggies... but the pineapple was an odd addition and I didn't really like the thick noodles. We also got a noodle dish to share and the thin rice noddles and salad was very good. Overall would go again
author: Esther C.

description:
This place is my goto for Vietnamese food when I visit San Francisco. They price was decent for a delicious meal. This time I had the Bun Bo Hue, it came with a very tasty broth! However I did wish they put a bit more noodles in the bowl. I had a lot of soup left when I finished my noodles. (5 stars when there are a bit more noodles in the meal)

My coworker ordered the lemongrass chicken rice which looked fairly generous portions but I can't speak for the taste of it. He claimed it was very delicious though!

I would definitely come back here again for another round when I'm in town.
author: Andrew S.

description:
This review is solely for the Bun Bo Hue. If you are craving authentic BBH you will be disappointed. That's not to say it wasn't good - it's just not what I was expecting. The broth was more like a pho broth with some added spices. The flavors were not full bodied. Also, the serving portion was the smallest I've ever for this dish. 

If you want real BBH, go to Bun Bo Hue An Nam in San Jose.
author: Ray Z.

description: Great and authentic Vietnamese food with fast service. Though there was a line we were seated quickly. They turn tables fast during a lunch rush hour. The goi's or salads are amazing. These are hard to find at Vietnamese restaurants for some reason. The thit kho truong or pork belly with eggs was too salty and otherwise flavorless but the shaking beef is amazing, and more than made up for it. Bun no hue was way too spicy and we finished maybe 1/4 of it because it didn't have much depth, but also we were full from the first three dishes which were great! Iced coffee is also good. Not too sweet!
author: Marilynn L.

description: Came in on Saturday night at the prime time where we beat the dinner rush so we got seats right when we got there. The service was okay, it was kind of hard to get the waiters attention, possibly due to it being busy or maybe being short staffed. The food although wasn't bad, it seemed like this place was too hyped up. The chicken salad had really good sauce but the chicken seemed to be bland and dry, while the five spiced quail was more bones than meat. Although the starters seemed to be a little overpriced, the noodle soups were better than expected. The bun bo hue tasted good, but could have been spicer, and the bun rieu had amazing broth. We also got the limeade which tasted fresh and had more lime then I thought it would. Overall this place was average and didn't seem worth the hype.
author: Linda N.

description: Lively place with great food, my go to place for the pho. It's a small place and can get noisy when busy. If that's not an issue, this is a great place for Vietnamese food.
author: Aditya P.

description:
Pricier place for Vietnamese food, but you're def paying for more quality ingredients. I typically do take out.

Highly recommend:
- Warm Beef Salad -- probably my favorite beef salad of all time. I really enjoy the light dressing with the caramelized shallots, such an amazing mix of flavors!
- Shaken Beef -- my bf orders this every single time, & I don't think he has ever been sick of it. Quality beef used with lots of garlic flavor. I like this dish with their brown rice!
- Spinach & Minced Pork Soup -- really great pork flavored broth, & added plus because it reminds me of my mom's broth!
- Tin Rolls -- LOVE these rolls with grilled lemongrass pork, eggs, shiso, & crispy shallots, it just all comes together SO SO well!
- Hue Rolls -- can't go wrong with spring rolls with a rice paper wrap, but I think I prefer Tin Rolls because there's more of a crunchy texture.

Tried a couple of other dishes, but they don't stand out like the five I mentioned above.

My only complaint is the consistency of the beef. Occasionally it's a little overcooked, but still an overall good dish. Other than that, Tin is definitely my go-to spot in the city for beef salad & quality shaking beef.
author: Carol N.

description:
While visiting Sf I wanted Vietnamese food so we found this spot on yelp. We came around 12 and it was packed so we put ourself on the list, took about 20 minutes to be seated so I was hoping it'll be worth the wait.
I loved the pictures they have around the restaurant, it's like an authentic picture that sets the ambiance of the place. I would have taken more but there were too many people around and blocking the pictures so I got only one good picture when the table cleared lol.
Banh xeo- wow it was delicious and very crispy! Would recommend it

Shaken beef- meat was tender with a side of salt and pepper for dipping and it came with a salad and was delicious! 

Bun thit nuong- it was on point! Meat was nicely marinated and it just went well with everything which didn't require me to ask for extra nuoc mam because usually I'll ask for extra sauce lol.

I am so glad we found this place. It is authentic and worth the wait! I can't wait to be back to try others stuff in the menu!
author: Linda T.

description:
I'm surprised that I haven't reviewed this place yet! This is one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in the area. Sure the price point is higher than most hole in the wall restaurants, but the food is just as good. They are super busy at lunch so try and get there before 11:30am or after 1pm. 

I used to love their Tin Rolls but they don't offer them anymore! Shame, they were my favorite dish! I loved the pork, sliced egg and peanuts. A really great combination of textures: crunchy and soft. Instead we ordered Hue Rolls (grilled lemongrass pork, fresh herbs, fried shallots, steamed rice paper). This was good but not as good as the Tin Rolls. 

I tried the Bun Bo Hue (rare beef, beef shank, pork bologna, vermicelli, spicy lemongrass broth) and it was nice and spicy. I forgot that the vermicelli is different from the more translucent pho noodles. 

I do have a favorite dish when I go: Bun Thit Nuong (grilled lemongrass pork shoulder, cold vermicelli noodles, julienned cucumber, lettuce, bean spouts, pickled daikon and carrots). The grilled pork is very flavorful and cooked perfectly.  I love to the fish sauce all over the whole dish and mix it up. To me it's a light dish and not so heavy because of the lettuce and veggies. 

My friend got the Pho Bo (rare beef & brisket with rice noodles in beef broth), and she really enjoyed her dish. She loved that the broth had depth.

Service can be a little slow because of the crowds, but that won't stop me from coming to Tin again and again.
author: Nette T.

description: Best Vietnamese in SF.  Did a takeaway from Slanted Door this week and then went back to Tin.  All meals are incredible and the portions are extremely generous.  Go try it for yourself
author: Billy B.

description:
Still the best pho spot in the neighborhood!  Why? It's all in the soup! 

Seriously though, not too salty, tasty broth, and fresh veggies! Tin isn't like your typical hole-in-the wall pho spot, it's better.  The Pho Ga and Pho Bo are our favorites.  The chicken isn't fatty, cartilagey, or veiny as it often is.  They use white meat chicken, and the ginger broth just tops it off.  The beef is also fresh and not fatty.

Other must haves on the menu? 
- Vegetarian spring rolls (both fresh and fried)- the mushrooms are so good!  My wife doesn't eat shrimp or pork, so this means she often has to miss out on spring rolls, but not at Tin! These are a MUST!
- Any of the sandwiches - the pate is tasty and unique
- Chicken wings - seasoning is good.  Tender and not dry.
- 5 spice chicken - the portion is generous, chicken is juicy, and flavor is good.

We typically substitute egg noodles for rice noodles.  The noodle texture is good - firm and not too soft.  The egg noodles go well with the ginger broth and all of the other fresh veggies.

We often get food to go because it's a smaller restaurant, and it gets crowded!  It is very tight for a wheelchair and this means if it's busy, we have to wait longer for a table.  The wait is worth it, though.
author: Ashley S.

description:
I'm so happy I found this place!

This time I came and sit on a Friday night. It was a 5ish minute wait around 6:30pm even though the restaurant is packed with people.

Ordered bun rieu and boyfriend ordered the pho. Food was satisfying especially with the cold front hitting SF this past week. The noodles were so good in both, chewy yet soft yet firm, basically just short of perfection. Bun rieu had a tad too much black pepper for my taste (considering I don't like black pepper). Pho looked a bit small but boyfriend was filled and happy.

Restaurant is pretty loud as it's busy so not a right place if you're looking for a quiet place and also kinda pricey when you compare to Pho 2000 (still reasonable prices considering in SOMA neighborhood) but quality of ingredients/dishes that aren't obviously 5+years old and cleaned well is higher.
author: Mimi T.

description: Prices up, portions down. This was my favorite place in SF for 3 years. I returned after a hiatus due to a move. I wasn't too hungry but after spending $23 on myself I was still somewhat hungry. This place used to be high quality for low prices and filling but that's no longer the case it seems. My side salad also hardly had any dressing. Not sure what happened to this place :(
author: Brandon N.

description: I have only gotten take out here once.  I got some vegetarian veggie rice dish and OMG it was delicious.  The person who took my order was very sweet and helpful.  This place is tiny and fills up at lunch though.  I am looking forward to trying some of their soups soon!  Like the other reviews point out it is a bit pricey, but that's nothing new for this area.
author: Megan M.

description:
Who knew there could be good Vietnamese food outside of the Tenderloin and Sunset? While prices are maybe $2ish pricier here than at those joints, the dishes are good enough to justify the difference. 

For once, I ventured out of my comfort zone and got Bo Kho instead of Pho. Bo Kho is basically the Vietnamese version of Chinese beef noodle soup. The broth is heartier than pho broth. The meat they give you is a thicker cut of brisket chunk, instead of the thin slice of flank.

I was pleasantly surprised by:
1) the portion size! just filling enough and good proportion of meat to noodles
2) the richness of the broth

Mmmm would definitely return!
author: Sally L.

description:
Say what you will about ambiance and prices, but the food is excellent. I met an old co-worker here for dinner and we shared a few dishes. 

sautéed greens of the day with garlic -- our day happened to be a very tasty and fresh bok choy 

tamarind shrimp with brown rice - a little sweet, but not too sweet. immense flavor and perfectly cooked shrimp.

Bun Thit Nuong / grilled lemongrass pork shoulder - just amazing. Each bite of the pork was tender and perfectly seasoned.

The portion sizes are large, so the prices for SoMA don't seem outrageous. 

The service was a little bit of a miss..our server seemed just to be annoyed with us and I have no idea why. Overall, just really great quality food and flavors. I'd highly recommend. I'd say it's better than MAU if we're gonna compare trendy Vietnamese restaurants!
author: Priti K.

description:
Really great Vietnamese food!

I'd been wanting to try out this place for years and it was nice to finally visit. I had the Bun Bo Nuong, which was lemongrass beef wrapped around sautéed carrots - really delicious! Each bite was packed full of flavor and everything could be balanced out by the vermicelli noodles. The service was fast and attentive.

The price point is also very good and very reasonable for San Francisco.

I can't wait to visit this spot again and try other items on the menu since everything looked great.
author: Ken G.

description: Excellent service & great food. The table ordered Pho Bo, Banh Xeo, Spring Rolls, & Shaking Beef. Although coming from East/South Bay, the portions were substantially smaller.
author: My N.

description:
Best Vietnamese pho I've ever had. 
The soup is just right, not too salty or sweet like the other places would offer. 
I added the beef tendon and balls. They are very yummy. They have just the right portion of savory to loose raw taste from tendon (someone would get uncomfortable with that taste) and at the same time not too much so you don't have to drink water the entire afternoon.
author: Isabelle L.

description: Such a cool place on Howard / 5th street. Very close to InterContinental Hotel. Every seat was taken and two big groups in front of us...we just got lucky when we arrived and a small two person table opened up. Servers were helpful and accommodating, noticed i walked in with a cane and made sure I safely sat down. We ordered banh xeo(pan fried omelette), spring rolls and mango salad. Plates were visually appetizing =)
author: Vee V.

description: I've actually gone out of my way to get Tín so, that negates my previous review that "I wouldn't go out of my way" lol. I'm updating this to 5 stars cuz it's very consistent and my gf and I love it.
author: Ryan J.

description:
As I sit at my desk eating leftovers from last night I must say I can't get enough of this place. I've actually come back almost 4 times since 2016 and every time the more of the menu I explore the more I fall in love with it. New favorites and updates about Tin:
1. Service: excellent, they were quick and nice to sit us right away (mostly cause everyone in our party was present - so key tip make sure everyone is there, otherwise ppl will need to wait) 
2. Menu: hands down awesome and the flavors are all perfect for different taste pallets. Recommendations:
- apps: Tin Rolls (fresh, filled with cilantro, and the lemongrass pork ooooohhhh yyesss), Spring rolls (noodles and mint sign me up) & Firecracker shrimp (one word criiissspppyy)
- meals: 5-spice chicken (yaaass honey), grilled pork chop, lemongrass chicken!!

Overall this place is small and it gets crowded on the weekends so be aware of that factor. Weekday nights are a good time to come to get your craving in. Bart (Powell Station) is a quick walk from it and there is some street parking if you get lucky.
author: Ankita C.

description:
This is one of the better Vietnamese spots in SOMA. It gets packed during peak lunch and dinner hours so I would come before or after the rush. Both service and food were decently good IMO.

We ordered the Tin rolls as an appetizer and that was yummy -- would recommend! I tried the bun rieu and didn't have high hopes but it exceeded my expectations. Very flavorful and they didn't skimp on the crab/minced pork balls. Portions were reasonable. I tried a bite of the bun bo hue and it was not bad but definitely not comparable to the BBH spots in San Jose.

This is my new go-to spot when I'm craving a warm bowl of pho in soma :)
author: Mandi H.

description:
Pho broth without fish sauce is hard to come by. Given my serious shellfish allergy and serious love of pho, it can be a tricky balance sometimes to decide if the waiter actually knows if there is fish sauce in the broth or not. My love of pho runs deep and sometimes leaves me making tricky decisions. Pho or death? hmm....Enough about my allergy and more about Tin....

Yes, they offer a fish-sauce free broth and it's mighty delicious. It is such a comforting and flavorful broth topped with rice noodles, tofu, broccoli, carrots and several other vegetables. (I opted for the full-on veggie pho). A bowl of pho here will run you around $10. Given how busy they were, I was impressed by the turnaround time and above all, how vibrant and fresh all of the vegetables were. 

As for the atmosphere, it's a-okay. It's been super busy the last two times I've visited and given the small space, you might be stuck waiting on the side walk at lunch or dinner time. They can't help it their popular. The hustle makes it feel like more of a fast casual joint than a long wine/pho/lingering kind of dinner.
author: Brittany S.

description:
It was mildly disappointing to realize that all of the Metreon food purveyors were closed by the time my movie had ended.  Further disappointment came in learning that the nearby food court at Westfield Centre was also locked up by 8:30 p.m.  Each of these disappointments though, were merely the process required to land me in the doorway of Tin around 9 p.m. and I'd gladly suffer them again if guaranteed the same outcome.

Tin Vietnamese Cuisine is delicious.

Yelp reviews serve as testimony that this place has been here for at least 8 years and that's amazing given that I'd never even heard of it.  Usually a place with legs is one about which I've heard or read something, but not Tin.  In fact, an 80% full dining room at 9 p.m. on a Monday indicates that I may be in the minority.   

The single room space is reasonably inviting with few of the authenticating touches (or kitsch) often found in Southeast Asian restaurants.  A few framed images of Vietnam line one wall but the rest of the room and the server's ethnicities reveal nothing about the menu.  

That menu focuses mainly on rolls, pho, rice plates, and bun (vermicelli noodle dishes) so between two we opted for the Tin Rolls ($10) and Bun ($10-$13).  

The Tin Rolls arrived first and were so sizable and interesting that we both admitted we could make a satisfying meal for 1 from a single order.  I'd need to look at the menu to reveal all of the ingredients in this delicious roll but I won't.  Order it and see for yourself; it's wonderful.

Bun fell into the same category.  One order of sautéed lemon-grass beef bun was chock full of so many fresh and pickled herbs and vegetables that each mouthful was a riotous mix of texture and crunch.  The bun with rolled beef (stuffed with carrots and more) had the same intriguing blend of vegetables, noodles, and proteins.  I really, really liked the food here.  

A common complaint of mine is dishes where the protein and vegetables are insufficient to withstand the volume of rice or noodles or...you name it, the cheap stuff.  Tin's food had no such problem.  Consuming the leftovers the morning after, I was again rewarded with the perfect balance of flavors and textures.  

Service at Tin was very good, with a decanter of water arriving on my table moments before I sat down.  It remained good throughout the meal, a fact I appreciated even as I found myself the sole party left inside.  

Next time I'm downtown I'll know better than to lament a closed food court.  With easy evening parking right out front I look forward to a return visit to Tin.
author: Tracey A.

description: Pretty good pho and the price was reasonable. I got the pho ga with broiled chicken and it was $10.50. Tasty and light- exactly what i was looking for! Also got the banana cake which was like a bread pudding with a purple banana in the middle. Very moist and not too sweet
author: Amanda F.

description:
I'm never really sure what to expect from Viet restaurants that look nice on the inside and without the incessant Vietnamese chatter from the employees. Food was actually better than I expected, but definitely pricier than your standard mom-and-pop Viet restaurant. Tín super popular with the lunch crowd,  I'd defintely try and grab a table earlier. Portions vary; the pho seemed a bit small, but the other noodles came in a larger bowl.

Service was a bit slow, had to wait to order, get the bill, and pay the bill; seemed a bit understaffed for a busy lunch rush. They also forgot the noodles in my bun cha, and I had to wait a few minutes for it, but it was definitely worth the wait.
author: Kevin N.

description:
This place is delicious. Period.

We came in right before lunch time so get seated quickly. The place has a face paced vibe of the Financial District/Downtown area. It is a hustling yet interesting place around lunch.

The menu is diverse and not limited to only Pho or Spring Rolls. The chefs and the owner are Vietnamese so I have high hope, yet, they did not fail me.

I got Bun Cha Ha Noi and Bun thit nuong. Tbh, coming from Ha Noi I would rate this Bun cha 9.5/10. Absolutely stunning and delicious. The pork meat balls and pork slice grilled and marinated well. The portion is big, it left me full for couple hours. The fish sauce is a little too much for me, maybe salty a little. Bun Thi Nuong, what can I say, it is hard to fail this dish. Tin restaurant has made the portion to be big and the fish sauce to be a star. 

Overall I had a good visit at the place and would love to come back when I am in town next time.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I was out on a hunt with two friends/colleagues for a late night pho craving when we ended up at Tin. We came in about an hour to closing and every table was full. To our surprise, they were able to seat us in five minutes! Woot woot.

The beef pho was amazing- flavorful broth and tender pieces of meat. It was literally everything I was craving. The menu selection is incredible. My colleague is allergic to shellfish, and the staff was really helpful in what she could order. When my other colleague ordered spring rolls, they put the shrimp on the side so she could try a bite. So thoughtful!

I really enjoyed this restaurant and would come back in a minute for another authentic pho experience! Just FYI, this cute estasblishment is neatly tucked away on a street that has some dimly light neighbors (or at least, it seemed so at night to this out of town visitor), so don't discount it. Huge shoutout to our Yelp app for guiding us to this tasty spot! Loved it.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Perfect for a cold, foggy evening in SF. I loved the dim interior and the romantic ambiance. The servers were really welcoming and helpful when we had questions about the menu. The place filled up really quickly around dinnertime. 

[ Pho Bo ] They gave plenty of rare beef and brisket. However, I thought the brisket was a little difficult to chew. The beef broth was very savory. I usually don't drink much of the soup after I finish the rice noodles, but this broth was delicious. I couldn't help but finish it all!
author: Annie Z.

description:
After a long day in the city, this place hit the spot!  We started with two appetizers and then each had an amazing noodles dish in broth.

1. Tin rolls- spring rolls filled with Lemongrass pork, fried shallots, and egg! Great looking and great tasting.  This is a great item for the group to share.

2. Banana blossom salad- never had banana blossom, but it was refreshing and tasty! Had fried shallots, shrimp, and pork belly!

3. Wonton noodles- amazing broth with shrimp and pork wontons, chashu pork, and yummy egg noodles.  

Medium size casual restaurant with quality food!
author: Helen T.

description:
Delicious Vietnamese food! On the pricier side for Vietnamese food but you're definitely getting what you pay for here. The only downside is parking, but we got lucky and got a space right in front. 

Food:
Hue rolls: wow. That lemongrass pork is so thick and crunchy! Loved the added fried shallots. A must get!
Firecracker shrimp: didn't think these would be as good as they say but they were so good! Served piping out, and so crunchy that you can eat the whole thing including the tail
Hu Tieu: loved the garlic chicken broth! The pork in this was delicious and tender. 
Caramelized Claypot Catfish: I'm usually not a fan on claypot Catfish because it tends to be on the sweeter side but this was really good! Loved how there were no bones, and it was served in stone pot so the catfish had a nice crispiness to it. 

Vietnamese iced coffee: premade, but it was one of the best Vietnamese iced coffees I've had! Coffee was so strong and it had the perfect amount of condensed milk. 

Service was awesome! Super helpful, and everything she recommended tasted delicious.
author: Soo Y.

description:
I've been here twice and have ordered pho and the banh xeo. The pho broth was on the sweet side and the meat was thick and seemingly overcooked. Pho is still good regardless, but given that this place is so hyped and in the heart of Soma, I was expecting something better. The banh xeo was really good and had a lot of that egg flavor that I love with a solid crisp. 

I guess their menu items are hit or miss and you just have to be willing to come here and try out a lot of their foods.

Pretty long wait as it gets busy because apparently this place is Michelin-recommended? Also, I ended up paying over $20 for my entrée after tax and tip.

It's good Vietnamese food, but I'd recommend looking elsewhere for a safe bet at OUTSTANDING Vietnamese food.
author: Phillip V.

description: Solid Vietnamese joint with delicious beef rice noodle rolls and beef pho! I also had their shrimp and pork spring rolls, which were very refreshing. Service is pretty quick even on a Saturday night. I can see myself as a regular here if I live in the area. I would be willing to come back if I'm in the mood for Vietnamese.
author: Christina W.

description:
My good friend and I came here for a late lunch on a Saturday afternoon, and it was perfect for us! We needed to catch up over yummy Vietnamese food as he had just traveled to Vietnam and I had been there 4 years ago - lots to chat about! We ordered a couple appetizers including banana blossom salad (totally recommend this, the flavors were so awesome, just the right amount of acid) and spring rolls (good good, solid), plus he got the lychee iced tea (tasted this, was good, I would get it) and I got the Vietnamese iced coffee (love!). 

For our mains, he got the spicy beef noodles (forgot the name but he totally enjoyed it), and I got the pork vermicelli (loved!). Service was quick although I felt a wee bit rushed at the end of lunch (we were there until a little past closing so I don't totally blame them). I would come back (maybe a little earlier though so we don't feel rushed). I would definitely come back!
author: Maile N.

description:
small restaurant but really good food. 
We were staying at  a hotel nearby and found this little gem here on Yelp. Was not disappointed.  At 7pm on a Thursday, the place had a wait... People cycle though, but every seat was taken. This demonstrates the Good food this place provides 

There was only two of us. 
We had one appetizer, pork meatball in spicy broth 
Brisket Pho 
Bok Choy in sauce 
Spinach and minced pork soup 
Total was $36
Not bad for dinner 

The pho was really good... No need to add anything to the broth except for additional hot spice... Plenty of brisket and noodles 

The Xiu  Mai, pork meatball and spicy broth was great. I like it hot, spicy and more heat. This was great. With getting 

The Bok Choy in sauce was stir fried, with a light sauce. It was crunchy and mild 

The spinach and minced pork had a mild broth, but lots of spinach... 

We were full... 

Would we come back. Yes we certainly would
author: Balinor I.

description:
We generally enjoy our experience at Tin but they did not bring their game tonight. Waiter took our order at 7pm, 7:30 still no food. Mind you we did not order anything special.

Went to complain and she said the kitchen was busy but that's can't be the case when people who were sat after us got their food before us. 

We notice the table next to us got my soup order but they sent it back because it was wrong.  Then the guy to the right of us who just sat down got his order within 10mins of putting in his order.

After we got our food my husband had to ask for the veggies that comes with our pho and bun bo hue.

Whatever the reason I would have accepted the truth instead of lying to me.

Food was on point.
Service earned the 2stars
author: Judi L.

description:
We went here on a Thursday night before a play.  Got here at 5:30, just as they opened, so we were seated right away.  By 6:20 it was full with people waiting.
We ordered one Wonton Noodles w/ broth, one Bo Kho, one Bun Ga Xa, and one 5-Spice Chicken.  I'd definitely stick with the noodle bowls - although the 5-Spice was good, the noodle bowls were amazing!  The Bo Kho broth was spicier than the Wonton, but the Wonton was more flavorful.  The Bun Ga Xa was excellent!
The woman serving us was really friendly and helpful and checked on us often.  It was a very good SF experience.  The restaurant is nice without being overly fancy, and the prices were reasonable.
author: Lydia C.

description:
First time to try that Vietnamese food in San Francisco. 
My colleagues and me got food poisoning. One of my colleague was vomiting and diarrhoea. It was very bad experience to us. We don't want to try it again. Very bad restaurant in San Francisco.
author: William C.

description:
Small place so plan accordingly. Wait times can be long, but, that's anywhere in the city. 
Food is fresh and very tasty.  The PHO was great.  The broth had a lot going on. Great flavor prifile. A definite must if you like pho.
author: Anthony D.

description:
3.5* 
We hard about this place from a from a friend. It is definitely a place you will go to after searching for it as it is a small almost stand alone space.  We were seated by the very gracious host who was extremely friendly and nice. 
After reading through the menu I opted for the Chicken Pho ($10.00) as it was a cold night and a hot soup dish seemed perfect. The serving size was huge and could definitely be shared. The flavour itself was not good as it was very bland and I could taste the boiled chicken which is a negative. The dish overall ever after adding the sauces etc was not good 4/10. We also got the Five spice Chicken rice plate ($10.50) 10/10 and the Chicken with dry noodles ($10.50) 7/10. A fried pancake (with calamari etc)was also ordered which was actually pretty good 7/10. 
The winner of the evening for sure was the Five spice chicken because it was perfectly cooked with fantastic flavour and a light crispy crust. It was served with white rice and is a perfect meal.  

Note: I have to rate the meal I ate (2*) but I also can not overlook the excellent dish I got  to taste hence 3.5 star for now. I will be back to try other dishes and will be prompt to update the review accordingly!! 

Note : There is a bathroom in the back and the food come out fairly quickly. 

If you are in the area I recommend this place !!
author: Shivani B.

description:
Decent restaurant for Vietnamese food on Howard street in the vicinity of Downtown San Francisco. Parking can be found in the surrounding side streets or parking lots nearby (not sure how much you have to pay). It was an easy, 10 mins~ walk from the Powell St. BART station. 

First, we ordered the Banh Xeo for our appetizer to share. I thought the crust was over fried, which made it less flavorful and too crunchy. Also, they skimmed on the contents inside the Banh Xeo, there was barely any pork, calamari, or shrimp. I definitely have had better Banh Xeo at other Vietnamese places.

For my main dish, I ordered the Bo Kho which is beef brisket/shank and carrots in a beef broth with egg noodles. I don't usually order this at Vietnamese restaurants but I was in the mood for egg noodles. I was expecting thicker egg noodles as suggested from the pictures on Yelp, unfortunately, the egg noodles were thin. As for the rest of the bowl, the broth was flavorful and the beef was tender. 

Overall, a little disappointed with the Vietnamese food here. The service wasn't the best either, so that's that. I guess it's an okay spot for those who work or live nearby, but since I'm not from the area, it was nothing to write home about.
author: Vincent P.

description:
Solid neighborhood spot for Vietnamese food. I like the decor and it is a good rotation from Sunflower in Potrero which is our other go to.


I tried the Hue rolls this time, and I actually really liked it! Their pho is also decent, would recommend the bun Bo hue though for more flavor. 

I also like their variety of vermicelli dishes. Would recommend!
author: Cynthia X.

description:
My friend kept raving about this place so I was excited to try it. You would think a Michelin recommended Vietnamese restaurant would have amazing pho... but no they don't. I ordered a normal beef pho noodle soup. It didn't even come out that piping hot... and good pho comes out super hot. That was super disappointing. The meat was not great either. 

I tried my BF's bun rieu and that was slightly better, but not great. Overall, this place isn't that great. I've been so random pho restaurants in San Jose or in SoCal (Rosemead) and the pho was significantly better!

I can see non-asian people liking this place, but I'm pretty darn Asian and I know my viet food.
author: Micaela I.

description:
Was starving when I went. Shared the firecracker shrimp and the tin rolls. Could have skipped the firecracker shrimp. They're pretty much an egg roll wrapper fried around shrimp. The Tin rolls were pretty good. Clear rice wrapper with egg, pork, and lettuce, along with a couple other things. Dipping sauce complemented well. 

Had the Pho Bo for my entree. Enjoyed it but it wasn't extraordinary.
author: Jacob D.

description:
With one meal, Tin rose to the top of my list of "places I would return to" in SF; given there is no shortage of food options here, that speaks volumes.

The restaurant is small, but we had no trouble getting a seat on a Saturday night. The restaurant stayed about 50-60% occupied throughout our meal.

Drinks:
-- Beer, wine, and jasmine

Starter:
-- Tin Rolls (spring rolls) 

Entrees:
-- Pho Ga (chicken pho)
-- Hu-Tieu (mixed-meat pho with pork, chicken & shrimp)

Food was very good, and the prices are reasonable for SF. Will be back!
author: Nic Z.

description:
Consistently great place. Tin is a little far of a walk for me to do all the time, but I do look forward to every time I am able to go. 

Great flavors, solid service & an easy location all make it a great repeat place to eat.
author: Cameron C.

description:
The five spice chicken rice plate is one of the best I ever had. It was a chicken thigh that looked pan fried. It came with a side of rice and pickled vegetables. We shared the Tin rolls for an appetizers and they were filled with fresh vegetables and fresh herbs such as cilantro and mint and had grilled lemongrass pork. I would recommend this as an appetizer! We also got the sautéed bok choy with the oyster sauce and it was a simple delicious dish to share.

The restaurant had a good environment for a date night or a dinner with friends. However it's a little out of the way of everything else.
author: Brian N.

description: Nice Vietnamese cuisine in SF! Fairly clean and the service was great. We arrived around noon and there were still a couple tables left. Make sure you find a parking place beforehand though! I recommend getting their vermicelli noodles with chicken thigh and add-on shrimp!
author: Renee W.

description:
Was in SF on business & looking for a place for takeout close to Union Square. Had a craving for Vietnamese & YELP led me here. I did an online order & paid in advance. Love this set-up. Then set out on foot to find this restaurant. Thank god it was daylight, I wouldn't venture here at night. It was quite a walk but ended up being worth it!! 
The food was FANTASTIC! So happy to find a high quality Vietnamese restaurant here. Had the vermicelli with pork & LOVED it. So much pork & so tasty. Also ordered the spring rolls & peanut sauce. Were the best I've ever had. The rice wrap is thicker & they don't fall apart & become a mess. I cannot emphasize enough how much I enjoyed my meal from here. Anxious to come back again.
author: P P.

description:
My friend and I came here on a Friday night around 7 pm and it was crowded, but the line was shorter than I expected and we waited around 20 minutes. Soon after we were seated the service for food and drinks was not bad at all and very normal for a busy restaraunt. The servers were incredibly attentive often stopping multiple times to check on our meal and make sure we had everything. 

The interior of the restaraunt is aesthetic with hanging bulbs and the tables are a bit close together. My friend and I split the fried tofu rolls which was a little greasy on the outside, but with the sauce on the side it was incredibly flavorful and with a mix of different things. You can taste the tofu and some veggies as well. We also both got the Pho Ga which was smaller than I expected, but incredibly flavorful. The broth had hints of a spicey green pepper flavor, which I did not enjoy that much, but my friend really liked. The noodles were well cooked and the chicken was in a good ratio. Given the opportunity I am in that area I will go back there and try something else next time.
author: Manisha P.

description: Been coming here for years and it's still as good as it was way back when.  Can't go wrong with the pho.
author: Max G.

description:
The BEST pho I've had in San Francisco! I love the clean and tasty flavors; the bright and trendy ambiance of the restaurant; and the inexpensive prices for this great package of a restaurant. 

I came here with a group of coworkers on a Friday night shortly before 7 PM. It was bustling, but luckily we quickly got a table for 5 before the after 7 PM crowd hit. Overall delicious food with great environment, perfect for a fun dinner with friends!
author: Christine L.

description:
Food: 3.5/5.0
Service: 3.0/5.0
Value: 3.5/5.0
Decor: 3.0/5.0
Overall: 3.5/5.0 

Pretty good albeit not hyper authentic Vietnamese food.  Reasonably priced option for SOMA that can get busy on a Saturday night.  I prefer the more traditional (read: Chinese-run) spots that offer you options such as [a-tub-of-pho-for-$9].  But this works in a pinch.
author: Damian W.

description:
I visited Tin for the first time yesterday and really enjoyed it! It's a nice casual spot to grab delicious food for lunch/dinner. 

To start, we shared the Tin Rolls - these were outstanding!! The grilled lemongrass pork inside was cooked to perfection and so so flavorful. Each bite is like a party in your mouth, with different flavors and textures coming together from the fried shallots to the mint and cilantro. Fantastic appetizer and very well priced! I'd definitely order this again and again! Also loved the light peanut dipping sauce it came with.

For our main, we shared the Chili-Lemongrass Chicken Rice Plate. This dish was equally flavorful! The chicken was moist and covered in lemongrass with some nice grilled onions mixed in. I didn't really taste spice from the chili however - it came off more sweet than spicy, but still a very solid dish!

Overall, Tin served up some very tasty food and super affordable prices!
author: Sabina S.

description:
This is a small Vietnamese place right across from Moscone Center. I got the Pho Bo. The portions are not massive like a lot of other Pho places, but it is definitely sufficiently filling. The best part was the broth: not overly salty and super flavorful. Avoid the Lychee flavored tea however. I could barely taste the Lychee flavor and the tea was pretty bland. Price came around $14 for the noodles.

Modern décor, modern hiphop/pop music, and a pretty young crowd
author: Henry Z.

description:
I really enjoy coming to eat at Tin Vietnamese Cuisine. The restaurant can get quite busy during peak time, but the waiters are pretty efficient and move quickly. I would not say that the service is particularly attentive, but they do get your orders quickly and get your food to you fast. I have been here several times, so here is the breakdown of the dishes that I usually get and what I would recommend. 

My all time favorite dish at Tin is the Hu Tieh Kho. It is $9 and it is under the "Other Noodles without Broth" category. It is a noodle dish with ground pork, shrimp, and chicken, drizzled in a sweet sauce. It also comes with a cilantro-onion soup on the side that you can drink separately or add into your noodles if you wanted. This dish is the best bang for your buck and I just really like all of the different flavors in this dish. 

I have also had their vermicelli bowls. You can't go wrong with the Bun Ga Sa (vermicelli bowl with chicken thigh). I usually get this if I am feeling something on the lighter side, but also with a good portion of protein in it. 

The chicken pho is solid here. It is nothing too special and they don't give you a generous amount of chicken in the soup. They mainly just give you a large portion of rice noodles. I would recommend you pass on the pho. 

If you happen to want to get some decent food that is not too overly priced when you are planning on going to watch a movie at the Metreon or Century theater, swing by Tin to get a quick meal. It's definitely worth a try.
author: Lynn T.

description:
There are 5-star reviews, and then there are 5-star reviews that I write with the utmost enthusiasm. Tin falls into that latter category. This was seriously the best pho experience I've had in SF, and that's saying a lot considering the strong competition. Props up front to my buddy Ben for introducing me some incredibly satisfying Vietnamese-style cuisine. 

I say "Vietnamese-style" because I actually went with their wonton soup and I'm not sure if that is a truly authentic Vietnamese dish. It sounded so scrumptious (shrimp & pork wontons, xa-xiu pork, egg noodles) though that there was no way I could pass it up. After chowing down on some of the freshest, tastiest spring rolls I've eaten as our appetizer, my hot and steamy bowl of goodness arrived very quickly considering lines out the door and a very crowded and busy interior. The combination of flavors, made even better by a healthy addition of srirracha, was soup heaven and the perfect dish for a wet and dreary city day.  

I also tasted the papaya salad, and again, mind blowing. There is nothing they could improve upon here. This menu has obviously been tested many a time and the result is some fantastic reviews. Keep up the good work, Tin!
author: Alex L.

description:
3.5 stars for a quick, cheap meal and nice ambiance. Fast service, lots of seating at 7:30 on a Saturday night. Really good prices for San Francisco ($10 for the pho bo) and surprisingly cute, modern decor and interior. 

There were a lot of menu options, including rice plates, clay pots, pho, and vermicelli non-broth bowls. I decided to get the pho bo (beef brisket and rare steak, but you can add meat balls or tripe for $1.50). The broth was tasty and the brisket was the perfect amount of fatty, but the soup was a bit too lukewarm. It didn't cook the rare steak so it was still a little rare. Also, the portion wasn't very large compared to most Vietnamese places.
author: Victoria L.

description: Yah... not a big fan of this place. Granted it's kind of hard to find many Vietnamese food around the area, but I was fairly disappointed in my food. We ordered egg rolls, beef stew, and pho. The egg roll was alright but my stew... the meat was so hard to chew! Not just that the carrot was still crunchy! If anyone had Vietnamese beef stew they would know both are suppose to be tender and soft. As for my fiancé he ordered some kind of pho which didn't look appetizing to me and he complained how there's little to no noodles which is one of the key ingredients in pho
author: Nina Y.

description:
Solid lunch option for me. I've never eaten in the restaurant because it's always filled to the brim during the lunch hours. I don't stray far from the standard chicken pho or chicken over vermicelli but those are still darn fine options. 

My only real quibble is that the spices the use on the chicken is real hit or miss, some pieces are heavily spiced while others have nothing. When it's all mixed together it doesn't matter so hats why I'm not really penalizing them. 

I recommend this joint and think you will enjoy it.
author: Chris R.

description:
Anytime it's raining, pho is ALWAYS the answer to make your day better! A group of us headed over to Tin for lunch and walked through the drizzling rain to get there only to be greeted by groups of friends with the exact same idea. Tin is not a huge restaurant but the nice thing about pho is that it's a pretty quick dish to turn out so tables flip fairly quickly. After about 15 minutes of waiting in the rain, we were seated and greeted by a super friendly and extra efficient server. We were on the clock to get back to work on time, so we all appreciated her hustle. 

Ordered up the chicken pho, papaya salad and spring rolls for the table. Pho was not the best I've had, mostly because I prefer a darker broth that tastes like it's been simmering for 24 hours. The pho broth at Tin is more like chicken noodle soup which my kids would have adored! But it's just not my personal preference. The papaya salad however, knocked my socks off with it's intense flavor and the spices that were added to it. I was surprised when the spring rolls came to the table and were actually summer rolls, which are not fried. Everyone still loved them but I would have preferred them deep friend. 

Still a great meal to break up the rainy day weather and the service was on point. I'll definitely be back again next time I'm in SF and it's storming in the city!
author: Emi H.

description: The restaurants around my place, this one is the best! but most of the time need wait for a table.
author: Faye L.

description: Had the papaya salad and chicken bun noodle bowl. Both were really good. The chicken would've been better with less sauce/marinade and same with the salad, but overall the food was great. Delivery was fast and I'd definitely order takeout from here again.
author: Debbie L.

description:
Pho that's actually good, in SOMA?! Hailllll yes!

At my previous company, my coworkers would get food from Tin all the time. But they'd get vegan/vegetarian pho, which made me think that was their thing -- no meat. No meat? Not for me. BUT one day in June-ish last year, I was craving pho for lunch during my weekend class (slash I was also really hungover). Tin was the closest, so I looked up their menu and they had pho! Regular pho! And more! Hallelujah! 

I ordered their regular pho, and it was good though the meat was a bit tough because it was sliced thicker than . The broth was nice, clear and flavorful without tasting like a spoonful of msg. Mmm. The noodles were also perfectly al dente just the way I like it. I was sold from that day on.

I have yet to try their Pho Ga (chicken pho), but people love it. My favorite is the Bun Bo Hue -- It may be the best BBH I've had in the city O= The broth isn't muddy and extremely oily, but clear and packed with spices and beefy goodness. The bowl comes with a ton of meats -- slices of beef and pork (the kind they use in banh mi, but I don't know the name of...Other than fancy pork..?). SO GOOD, even when you get it to-go. Winner winner chicken dinner! As with all Viet places, you'll get a dish (or bag) of veggies to go with the noodles.

Hungover or not, do yourself a favor and get yourself some Tin!
author: Doris K.

description:
I was really excited to try Tín since I'm a huge Vietnamese food fan and I saw that it's Michelin guide recommended.

I always get the Vermicelli noodle bowl with pork wherever I go, so I ordered that with an add-on of egg rolls. The meat was too oily for my taste, and the fish sauce flavor was too light to balance out the large amount of noodles. The egg roll was good, but I would have preferred for it to be less stuffed so the proportion of filling to skin would be more balanced.
