I do have to say that service was good, and there was no wait when I went (6 pm on a Saturday). I could see how those who enjoy heavier food could enjoy this place but I wasn't a huge fan.
author: Anna M.

description: Bad service!!! Very slowly you will wait long time outside until you get table, and very expensive!!!
author: Yaniv H.

description:
4.5 stars but I adore this little place so I rounded it up. 

This is definitely the place I bring people to when they come by the neighbourhood. It's also the place I go for lunch when it's foggy and sad outside. The reason? They serve up some delicious Vietnamese cuisine, has a good variety from different regions, while not being as grimey and gross like some others. 

Some of my favourites include the bun bo hue and the pho bo. The bun bo hue is so spicy it packs a punch, while still being somehow flavourful. The meat in the soups are usually sliced thinly and cooked decently - not too chewy or grisly, and rare round steak comes rare (isn't true for a lot of other places!!).

My only little gripe is that they can be a bit overwhelmed by the crowds and the service ends up being really slow. Just make sure you avoid the super busy times and go a bit earlier or later!
author: Alice C.

description:
SERVICE was efficient. Came here on a weekday at around 6:30 and was seated in about 5 minutes. I was surprised we didn't have to wait for seating and was v happy about this. It was windy outside, and I was definitely in the mood for oodles of warm soupy noodles.

FOOD definitely hit the spot. My friend and I both ordered the PHO BO, which is just beef pho. No complaints and I finished both of our noodles! Our food came out quickly considering how the entire restaurant was full. PRICE was only $10, which I found pretty reasonable considering the portion size. 

Decor is pretty basic and simple. The restaurant seemed clean and cozy. I definitely want to come back to try the spring rolls next time.
author: Julie L.

description: We went by during lunch time and the place was packed, so we decided to take it to go.  We ordered the pho bo which was tasty but average at most.  Perhaps the next time we can eat in and it may be another experience, however just based on the taste of the pho. It's a middle of the road average taste.
author: Suzy W.

description: Pho is really good here.Came with a friend to eat Pho.Order was placed at 11.35. It took them 1 hour to make our order, we've been one of the first one, every one around us got their food but not us. Will never come here again. For 1 hour lunch waiting 1 hour for 1 soup it's not worth it.
author: Denis G.

description: Ordered take out during lunch: Pho and spring rolls. One of the best Vietnamese food I had in SF. Prices are more then reasonable too!
author: Lisa B.

description:
To owners: Please hire more staff. Also the older white male waiter needs to seriously get an attitude check. He's been rude from my multiple experiences dining here.

5 stars for food but service is so bad and understaffed that I'm changing it to 1 star. I'd still come back, but beware if you're dining here during peak times expect to be ignored and wait long times to get anything done.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Definitely a more "upscale" Vietnamese food joint as opposed to your typical hole in the wall local joint. That is not to say, however, that the food here was not amazing. In all honesty, it was some of the best i've had (save for the stuff the Vietnamese part of my family normally serves up, you can't ever beat that). If you're looking for a great restaurant to impress some guests with, this is definitely the place to do it.

Came as a table of 4 on a Monday night and was sat pretty quickly. Service was alright. But the food was pretty damn amazing. I got the claypot catfish and it was pretty damn close to the stuff i'm used to. I will say that maybe it was a tad darker than I'd like and had a hint too much salt. However, balanced with the AMAZING broken white rice I think this was a pretty amazing dish. The price was also pretty damn great too for a "up scaled" Vietnamese joint.

Overall it was great, will definitely be back whenever im in SF again to try more of their dishes. Really looking forward to it!
author: Michael C.

description:
Unfortunately never got the chance to try the food here. We came, seated, waited, and left. 

I came here with two friends on a Thursday afternoon and was seated right away. There were even a few tables open. After perusing the menu for 10 minutes we were ready to order (we took longer to look at the menu to give the staff more time before taking our order). 

It seemed like no one was coming to take our orders so we flagged down the man who seated us. He told us to wait for the waiters to take our order (even though this man was also serving other tables and doing wait staff duties). 

So we waited, another 10 minutes go by. We try to flag down either of the two other wait staff. Hands up, flailing, eye contact, the works. We are at the table in the middle too so they all walked around us to get to other tables. 

The wait staff would just walk by with their eyes forward and ignore us. Would have been decent just to acknowledge that you saw us but tell us you'll be back in x amount of time. Nope, just eyes forward and pretend you don't see us. 

So we wait another 10 minutes while the staff pretended we weren't there. That's when we left. I'm honestly not sure if they even noticed. 

Wasted over 30 minutes sitting in here trying to place an order. I'm usually more forgiving if places are packed and service is slow or food comes out slow. But we couldn't even get our orders in. 

Hope your have better luck getting food here. I do not recommend coming here though based on this experience.

Let me know if any of you have had the same experience here, this is wild.
author: Ming Y.

description: Tin is my new favorite Vietnamese spot in the city. The place has a warm and elegant feel to it as you walk in. The service is quick and friendly. They dont rush you out the door even with people lining up outside. There were signature dishes from the three main regions of Vietnam: North, Middle and South. There was definitely a lot of research that went into the menu. Their prices were very reasonable as well . Tin is definitely a must try place!!!!!
author: Loc N.

description: Saw a previous review that said the pho broth was "soul warming" and that couldn't be more accurate. I was really impressed with this dining experience! I ordered the Pho Bo with tripe. Really hit the spot for a cold windy summer day in San Francisco lol. They are also generous with the tripe add-on and give you the good pieces. Although a bit pricier than a bowl of pho in other locations around the city or East Bay, the ambiance is perfect for a casual lunch. I took visitors from Ireland (their first time eating pho!) And they were absolutely floored. I'll be back!
author: Samantha Y.

description:
Had an amazing meal here! I came with a couple of friends that I'd just gone to Vietnam with a few months ago, so you know it's good if we think it's on par with the food in Vietnam =). 

Came around 7pm on a Wednesday and there were plenty of tables available. We started with an order of the Tin Rolls, which are Tin's take on summer rolls. So good!! These are somehow both light and refreshing and also really satisfying and filling. These had a nice crunch with each bite from the grilled lemongrass pork and fried shallots. 

Next we had the lotus shoot salad, a perfect blend of crunchy, sweet, and tangy with all the flavors blending seamlessly. 

Our two entrees were the lemongrass chicken with vermicelli and the claypot catfish, and we also got a side of the sauteed bok choy with garlic sauce. The chicken was so tender and moist! The only nitpick there was that the dish got a little soggy on the bottom so the noodles at the end were a little over-saturated with the sauce. The catfish was perfectly cooked and flaky, only complaint was that the dish was a little smaller than expected with probably only around 6 pieces of fish. Bok choy did it's job, tasty but wasn't particularly memorable.

Overall, prices seemed reasonable to me considering the quality of the ingredients and the mostly generous portions. I would definitely come back!
author: Vivian L.

description:
It's interesting that a lot of people (including myself until recently) don't know about this place, despite it's central location near the Westfield Mall. But the combination of price, ambiance, and good-ass noodles at this spot warrants more attention!

The upside is that the wait around dinner time isn't as look as it could be, but even if it was, I would still recommend it. The Pho Bo (beef brisket cooked rare with pho noodles) is full of flavor and great on a cold winter day. Will definitely be back to try other options.
author: Vasiliy M.

description: Coming from Boston, this is the best Vietnamese food I've had in a long time. Very delicious Pho Bo, with excellent noodles and broth (though the meat was a bit dry). I also really liked the Hue Rolls - got me super full from eating everything!
author: Darren H.

description:
If I had written this review 6-9 months ago, it would have been closer to a 4. Let me explain the 2 (more like 2.5 but I'm rounding it down).

Been here a handful of times and found their Pho Tai to be the most tastiest in the city. The broth was incredible. It was on the small side, but the flavour compensated for it.

Fast forward to my most recent visit. I couldn't believe the portion size shrank even more, when it was already small to begin with. Not to mention the price hiked up. It felt I was eating a kid-sized portion of pho. I was fine with the smaller-than-usual portion size before, but this was just ridiculous. You will not leave here feeling full, unless you order their $10 spring rolls to fill yourself up.

I sadly can't recommend this place anymore. Unless you want a snack-sized portion of pho, or you're generally not picky, this isn't the place for you. I'd recommend Mau (in the Mission, which is alright) or Ben Tre (much better, but all the way in Millbrae).
author: Heather N.

description: Came here for noodles on my birthday and can't say I was disappointed! We were sort of in a rush too so the waiter worked with us on getting our food quickly and recommending me things since it was my first time there. My friend got the dry bowl of noodles with soup on the side which prevents the noodles from getting soggy and it was super yummy! The Chicken Pho was great too. Some people complained about the portion size but honestly, I thought it was perfectly fine and greater than that other Saigon restaurant kind of around the same area. Quality over quantity guys, the quantity difference was honestly negligible. Someone also got a rice dish (non-noodles) and it was delicious so it's always nice to see that they're good at different dishes and not just noodles. Their broth is on point which is what makes 1/2 of the noodle soup experience for me tbh. Come to Tin for good pho and Vietnamese or South East Asian food - you'll leave satisfied. At least I did.
author: Leslie T.

description: Cute spot with the perfect variety of soup for everyone, ideal for the cold nights like yesterday, highly recommend the Pho Kho, and shrimp's apps.
author: Matt B.

description: Found aluminum in the Bun Bo Hue... multiple pieces of aluminum. Told the waiter and she said it's the sausage that's wrapped in aluminum before they cook it. The way she reacted made it seem like this has happened before and they've done nothing about it so it'll continue to happen. They made the meal again for me without the sausage but the dish lost its appeal to me. And they charged me for the dish after this incident. Wish I had made more of a fuss about it. Definitely not going back. Food isn't clean and the service is not good. Usually don't write reviews but this experience was bad enough to warrant one.
author: Anjali K.

description: Their lemon grass pork shoulder vermicelli bowl is out of this world. I found the sauce kind of light, but the pork shoulder is grilled slightly sweet, smoky, absolutely delicious. I'm used to it cut slightly thinner to mix in with the rest of the stuff better, but I absolutely don't mind the large pieces of delicious, savory meat. One of the best Vietnamese vermicelli bowls.
author: Ke C.

description:
Affordable and pretty delicious Vietnamese food. (Okay, so this food is probably not comparable to anything you'd get in Vietnam, but it's definitely one of the best in SF)

If you have the room for it, definitely share a starter. The Tin Rolls are great, as is the Banh Xeo. Really tasty way to start your meal, though portions wise, it's not AS good of a deal as the entrees.

With that said, most entrees are only about $10-11. My favorites are the Pho Ga, Hu Tieu, and the Bun Thit Nuong. The broths in the noodle soups are flavorful without being heavy, and anything with the grilled lemongrass pork is great. Seriously, I'm salivating just thinking about it.

Service isn't notably friendly, but it's efficient so I have no complaints. 

Definitely my go-to place for Vietnamese food (especially for dinner when I don't want to trek through the Tenderloin)
author: Sara L.

description: Excellent Bun Bo Hue.  Cozy spot that I would return to.  It deserves all the high ratings.
author: Raymond W.

description:
Good food at a good price. The price is especially good considering its location in the city.

I've tried the vegetarian pho ($10), which is tofu, mushrooms, and vegetables in vegetable broth. You can substitute a different broth, so it's easy to customize your bowl.

The portion size is generous. You get a ton of toppings on the side: pickled onion, Thai basil, bean sprouts, and lime wedges. The soup is flavorful and not too salty.
author: Elaine L.

description: Their vegetarian pho is to die for .... it's one of my favorites in the city ! It's really the only vegan / veggie item on the menu except their house salad which is really delicious too but I crave their veggie pho the broth is amazing!
author: Kelly W.

description: Literally so delicious. I do not have words. My soup was bon bo hue: the spicy pork meat soup with the thicker noodles. The broth is so flavorful and the spicyness of the soup was perfection. My dad loved his original beef pho soup. He thought the size was perfect for him and the beef broth was delicious. The service was amazing, constantly checking if we had water and all in all making sure we had everything we needed to make this experience great. We will definitely be coming back.
author: Selena H.

description:
My friend and I were in search of a nearby lunch place. Alas, the stars aligned and we were able to frogger our way across Howard St and arrive at Tin without much of a wait for a 2 person seating. Sunny, a little tucked away and lively but still enough space and not so loud I couldn't converse with my friend. The service was great, refilled waters promptly, nice but not too pushy. Price was not bad for a sit down SOMA lunch with table service - $14 after tax and tip.

I had the five spice chicken which was crispy, very filling and satiating with the fat, and great portion size for lunch which wasn't overwhelming and kept me full for until a late dinner. Good aromatic spices without being overwhelming, the dipping sauce was your usual spicy and slightly sweet fish sauce. As a native Viet person, Tin isn't inauthentic but a little higher quality in terms of ingredients but still not watered down. The food was okay, I'd have it again if it were convenient or I were nearby.
author: Truc N.

description:
I've come here twice and the service is sub-par. We asked for a seat that wasn't in a super dark corner and the guy put in the super dark corner even though there was a 4 person table in the middle (it was later filled by 2 persons).

I've also had my order taken and the wrong item was delivered. The server was confrontational. Very confrontational. We basically tried to eat and leave asap.

The food is just ok. Not amazing and it's small. 

Probably won't be coming back as the ambiance will be forever tainted.
author: Joshua F.

description:
Alright ladies & gents, the Bo Kho is where the flavor par-tay is at! This is essentially Vietnamese beef noodle soup. Dark beef broth packed with flavor from the super tender meat with bits of cartilage and tendon for added texture. You'll appreciate the large chunks of meat in the dish - no skimping out on the protein. The noodles are wavy yellow egg noodles as opposed to the clear rice noodles. Depending on your preference you could sub out for another type of noodle, but I found the egg noodles to be delicious with just the right amount of springiness. 

If you are like me and find yourself wanting to stuff yourself to the brim for no good reason, you'll also want to start off with the cha gio, crispy spring rolls cut into 9 smaller pieces. Take a piece of lettuce, place a few fresh basil leaves, a few rice noodle strands and top off with a fresh-from-the-fryer spring roll, then dip in the sweet and tangy vinegar sauce. 
YUM. EAT ALL OF IT. PARTY FOR ONE.
author: Julia K.

description: This is an Americanized Vietnamese restaurant, where you are given pickled red onions and shredded cabbage with your pho order. The portions are smaller and you do not get a lot of noodles. The bun bo hue is $12.50 and has a flavorful, nice semi spicy lemongrass soup. The noodles resemble a white spaghetti shape. The $9 banana blossom salad is julienned/spiralized refreshing and crunchy with fresh shrimp and boiled/steamed chilled pork belly.
author: Beth K.

description:
Hole in the wall on a sketchy block.  It's our go to first meal after arriving in SF.  Casual, clientele from all walks of life.  Great selection of beer and wine.  Split a special roll whose name I  can't recall, but it had a great assortment of textures and flavors.  I always order some variant of pho.  I let the waitress guide me.  It was great with satisfying, fragrant spice.  Lots of meat and spicy. My wife had clay pot shrimp and was too busy eating it to talk. 

Yay!  Wish the menu was a bit more comprehensive, but excellent meal.
author: Joel S.

description:
Must order: Bun rieu (crab tomato noodle soup), shaken beef, chicken noodle soup, and cha gio (egg rolls).

Highlights
- Tin is definitely a hidden gem off the beaten path in SOMA serving up the best bun rieu noodle soup dish I've tasted thus far in SF. Believe me when I say it's the best as I've been on a quest to find the best bun rieu in SF, since nothing has compared to the ones in San Jose (a.k.a. best Vietnamese food central). Flavor and authenticity is there, not skimpy on the fix-ins and flavor is delicious (Tofu, crab meatball, fancy pork, and tomatoes).
- Currently this place is on my weekly rotation and I'm constantly craving either one of the dishes I mentioned above to order. 
- Cha gio (egg rolls): it's a mini dish in one with dry noodles, lettuce, herbs, and fish sauce. It's the meat and the crispy outter layer that makes or breaks this dish and this one has it all. 
- Shaken beef: Reminds of comfort food with the cubes of beef, bell peppers, and perfectly cooked onions. The salt, peper, and lemon dipping sauce is a perfect accompaniment with a bite of warm steamed white rice. Yum!
- Chicken noodle soup: they add minced ginger into the broth, so there is a little kick and it definitely hits the spot during a cold day. 

Improvements
- Not a good spot for big groups, but with a small party of max 4, it's a great option. 
- I'm all about ordering ahead or delivery when possible for efficiency, but picking up To Go orders was pretty much the opposite where I stood around not being acknowledged by the server handling orders and I realized after a while that there was a bag with my name on a shelf behind another patron waiting around for his order. 

Tips
- I've been several times to dine in during weekdays in the evening and on weekends, never a wait and immediately seated. 
- Order ahead for pick-up through the Yelp app OR delivery through Caviar! 
- Parking is street metered parking, but not too hard to find since it's further out beyond the shopping area in SOMA.
author: Tracy T.

description: My fiancé and I stopped by Tin after finding them on Yelp during our day trip to the city. When we arrived around noon there was a little bit of a wait which only took around 10 minutes or so. We enjoyed the spring rolls with shrimp as our appetizer which were good but I wasn't a huge fan only because it had mint inside and I am not a mint fan. My fiancé however devoured all of them. I had a vermicelli bowl full of noodles (which is my absolute favorite) with fish oil and garlic topped with grilled shrimp. The shrimp had AMAZING flavors that flooded my mouth. The noodles were cooked to perfection and balanced out really well with the sweet savory spices on the shrimp. Our server was really nice and attentive even with a full house and being extremely busy during the lunch rush. Highly recommended if you are in the city and in this area looking for a great bite.
author: Alison R.

description:
Their pork bun was amazing and the mango salad was very good.  Super nice waiter that had great recommendations.  Clean and delicious. 

I was from out of town and found on yelp.  Highly recommend
author: Carol P.

description:
Mmmmm...boy do I regret not paying more attention to Tin!  I first discovered them while walking by several years ago, but I didn't think much of them.  Not for any reason on their end, just that with so many great Vietnamese places near me, I never had any urgency to look into them.  Clearly I should have though because this unassuming spot that I had so easily forgotten about is pretty awesome!

After recently seeing a bunch of Yelp friends check into Tin, I finally decided I had to check them out.  The place looked a lot like what I remember, but far busier; during our entire meal, there was a steady line of people waiting for a table.  Partly because the place isn't huge, but mostly because they're just that popular!  It's not hard to see why though - the menu offers so many legit and enticing options, my friend and I were torn on what to get!  Papaya Salad?  Banh Xeo?  Maybe the Bun Rieu or Bun Bo Hue people have raved about??  Oh the choices!

-- CHA GIO (Imperial Rolls) - Crisp-fried Rolls with Pork, Shrimp, Jicama, Taro, Wood Ear Mushrooms, Glass Noodles, and Peanuts...$9
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/t%C3%ADn-vietnamese-cuisine-san-francisco-3?select=uFJAoNRK8HpOnJchGjtJuA)
I've long been searching for something as good as PPQ's old formula (my favorite) and Tin's is the closest thing I've tried so far.  Between all of the different ingredients, the filling has a nice mix of flavors and textures.  That, combined with the rice wrap they use (which is thinner and crisps up better than most) makes for one tasty fried treat!

-- PHO BO - Rare Eye-of-Round, Brisket, Rice Noodles, Beef Broth...$9.50
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/t%C3%ADn-vietnamese-cuisine-san-francisco-3?select=W458QtOLgsYj_QdDOLj3MA)
While I wish there were more combinations to choose from (though you can add tripe, beef balls, or tendon for $1.50 each), this was pretty damn good.  The broth was well balanced and had just the right amount of richness to it.  What's more, the noodles were cooked perfectly and both cuts of beef were great (I especially liked that the eye-of-round was rare).  The one knock was that the portion felt a bit light compared to divey pho joints.

Beyond how the pho felt a little pricey, everything else about Tin was great.  The service was friendly and prompt despite how busy they were and I loved how much the menu had to offer.  Considering how close they are to my friend's place, I'm sure I'll be back sooner rather than late even if they aren't going to replace any of my usual favorites.  At the very least, coming here for some legit Vietnamese food is much easier (and preferable) than having to head into the TL.  Can't wait to explore more of the menu!
author: Mike L.

description:
I went here last week with a friend for dinner. Although the wait was long (we waited around 20-30 minutes) the host and servers were all very friendly and nice. The restaurant is small but considerably packed and the aromas from the kitchen smelled fantastic. I am pretty picky about my Pho so I was intrigued to see how my experience here would turn out. 

We ordered their Mango Salad to split as an appetizer, my friend got the Pho Ga (chicken) and I got the Pho Bo (steak). The food came out quickly but you could tell it had been prepared fresh. The salad was incredible, and I loved how they mixed different vegetables with the mango and there was even pork belly and shrimps in it. I definitely would order again! Our Pho soups came out shortly thereafter and again, I really enjoyed it. The broth was rich and the meat perfectly cooked and there was enough soup so you leave feeling full but not stuffed. The flavors of the soup were delicious and I think i've found a new go-to Pho spot! I'd highly recommend this place.
author: Carina P.

description: The best pho! Found this place after attending a conference at Moscone center from a well-placed sign. So glad I went. The seafood pho is to die for and they uniquely add crispy garlic on the top for an extra zing. The vegetables are perfectly cooked and the rice noodles last to the very end. Very good!
author: Lou S.

description: I've often enjoyed tin but in my latest take out I got a hair in my noodles and my bagged veggies were so old it was mulchy :c
author: Grace P.

description:
Came here on a Saturday for lunch at 12pm and was seated immediately. I ordered the pho bo and was quite satisfied with it. Meat quality is good, broth wasn't too salty, and the amount of noodles was quite sizeable. 

Sat at the table near the entrance so it was slightly chilly, but the pho helped warm me up. 

Service was efficient and they brought out the orders and refilled water very quickly.
author: Edward W.

description:
Gloomy day in SF? This is a lunch must-go for Pho.

It opens at 11:30, and there is usually already a line forming right away. They do a good job of turning tables quickly, but the wait can be a bit longer for lunch during the week. Not the best spot to go if you are in a hurry. 

The food is excellent though. My go-to is the Vegetable Pho, but subbed with the Chicken Ginger broth. So good and comes packed with fresh veggies. The portion sizes are always large, I always have some leftover.
author: Morgan W.

description: I got the summer rolls, Bánh Xèo, and Bun Bo Hue. The Bun Bo Hue was  watery, and lacked lemongrass and heat. But the Bánh Xèo was perfection - they get the crêpe very, very crispy and the flavor is just sublime. Would definitely come back and get the Bánh Xèo appetizer again. Maybe even completely forgo any entrées and get two!
author: Josh L.

description:
I've been going here since they opened years ago. I love this place. It's has a nice decor, good music and solid food. Family owned joint. The servers/staff are always super nice and friendly. They are kid friendly, although on a busy night it can be a bit noisy.
I've never ordered anything I didn't like. The Cha Ca is to die for. Super tasty and not greasy at all. The five spice chicken is also deep fried,  but not greasy. The vegetable are always cooked perfectly. If you like a good hearty soup the Bo Kho is delicious! I also really like their Bun Bo Hue. 
The vegetarian spring rolls are so good you don't even miss the meat. 

This place has become very busy, and I can see why. I sometimes wish that people didn't find this hidden gem so that I could have it all to myself!
author: Krystal R.

description:
EVENT: No special occasion - we're new to this city and trying to find some good Vietnamese food around the area... and here we are... at Tin's! It's a pretty hipster-ish... I mean... SF people in this place.. I was kinda expecting mah azn peeps.. but... you know what... totally cool... new place to try!

PARKING: saw some street metered parking - not so bad... but, we took uber instead!

SERVICE: there's a long line... so put your name down (especially during lunch time). Service is kinda slow here... had to wave down the waiter a couple of times to get what I want. The bus boy was always cleaning tables - that's how busy they are.

FOOD:
(1) Spring Rolls: Shrimp AND Pork with lettuce and mint wrapped in clear rice noodles! Dip it in some really thick peanut sauce (no wonder they didn't give us a lot) and mmMMmm! 5 stars!

(2) Bun Bo Hue - Broth flavor is super savory! They didn't have the usual "Vietnamese meats"... like pork blood.. I'm pretty sure that will scare some people away from this place... BUT...there's some beef and briskets! 4 stars!

(3) BBQ Pork Vermicelli Noodles - BBQ pork flavored really well and cooked almost until like a beef jerky... but it's so different but wayyyy cool! LOVE IT. Drizzle some fish sauce into the bowl... and I'm ready to dig in!

**OVERALL: Def try the Spring Rolls - my favorite with the peanut sauce... Oh don't forget to add some hot sauce!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
I was so excited about going to this place. We walked 25 minutes to get to this place from our hotel. It look like hip restaurant. It was crowded and full on a Wednesday night. Our appetizer looked good. The waiter/possibly owner was not so friendly. 

Our food came. Just as I was about to eat, a small cockroach came out of the salad and started creeping on our table. We caught it under the sauce bottle. Called the waitress and showed it to her. That was the end of our dinner. We walked out.
author: Kelly N.

description: Another hidden gem of San Francisco, great food and good price for the area it's in. I was giving great customer service and speedy service. It's because they are awesome and they need to get you in and out especially at lunch. Small spot and nice decor. Definitely a spot you will want to stop off to if you craving pho.
author: Miguel P.

description:
Today I came here with my friend, we got there on 5:30 so we were able to seat fast. Food was good but I agreed others said SERVICE WAS TERRIBLE. 

I said the service was good because when me and my friend just put down our chopsticks, the female server came up and said " are you guys done?" then she brought the check to us. I understand it's busy dinner time, but how could she being rude to push us out? I didn't think this is a good restaurant should be!

More to say about service!!! We ordered Tin rolls and two phos, when we received the check, we were kinda surprised. As you can see on the receipt, it charged something called "SF employer mandates", it was my first to see that on a receipt so I asked the female server what that was. She brought the Manuel to me and pointed to these tiny statements below. It said if you ordered food over $10, you need to pay "SF employer mandates"! Gee, almost anything on the Manuel is over $10 which means you have to pay "SF employer mandate" anyway. For my own understanding, that's like tips, but mandatory tips!! And yes, we did paid tips (actual tips) too. 

So be aware when you pay......
author: Jenny M.

description: I was in town on a business trip and wanted Pho. I used my trusted yelp app and found this gem. Small place with a little wait but worth it.
author: Karen G.

description:
Yummy food. The prices are similar to vietnamese diners (~$11 pho) but with much nicer ambiance. Started with a delicious papaya salad. Could've been more spicy, but I'm sure you can ask for that to be adjusted accordingly. It was a decent portion size with generous shrimp.

My pho was good, but definitely not my favorite because it was too sweet. If you are into sweeter broth, I think this is great. I personally thought it was too much and if/when I come back, I plan on ordering something else.
author: Ke D.

description: The food was delicious and reasonably priced. The banh xeo in particular is enough of a reason to come back; it's incredibly crisp and filled with flavorful ingredients. The decor of the restaurant is pleasing, but has a bit too dark of lighting for my liking. Staff is friendly, but wait time was surprisingly long, taking around 20-30 minutes just to get our starters.
author: Brian N.

description:
Easily one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in SF. Only been here once but I can see myself going back every time I'm in town!

Wrote a more detailed review on my blog:
nicajanae.tumblr.com
author: Danica C.

description:
Think upscale Vietnamese restaurant, minus the crazy prices! This restaurant offers a whole variety of diff foods so if you're craving pho, banh mi, spring rolls, or a vermicelli bowl... they have it all here! The problem, of course, is that you'll be indecisive since everything sounds delicious. 

Tin gets pretty packed and do not take reservations, FYI. I recommend coming with only 1 other person to snag a table. We loved everything we ordered, minus the Tin spring rolls. Those tasted really weird to me.
author: Janet H.

description: My favorite comfort food in SoMa. I go here once a week at least. Their selections of food is so good. Many many varieties of authentic (feels like?) Vietnamese food. My favorite discovery is their Bun Mac (not sure if I spelt right). It's like a Pho with fried meatballs; super comforting and yummy! You won't go wrong with any of the stuff on the menu really. I've ordered and tried many types of pho and noodles everything just tastes really good :)
author: Li L.

description: My coworkers decided to come herel so I tagged along. In general, when I go to a Vietnamese restaurant with a mostly English menu, I'm not expecting to love the place. It's probably prejudiced of me, but this place met my expectations. I ordered the claypot catfish, which is one of my favorite dishes usually. It was okay, but the flavor wasn't as strong as what I prefer, and the meat itself was a bit tough. Although I didn't particulary enjoy my dish, all my coworkers seemed to like this place, so it may be I ordered the wrong dish, or maybe this place is too Americanized for me.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
Nicer Vietnamese restaurant but still casual environment

Started with great service answering questions about some of the unique items. And provided extra interesting info about different types of skin used for imperial rolls. 

Ordered the pork shoulder vermicelli - yum! Nicely grilled pork sliced thin resulting in crispy edges and easy to chew meat (not tough). Generous portion of meat. Good proportion of noodles & veggies. I would order this again

Tin rolls are great! It's like a combo of spring roll and imperial roll because you get both crunch and soft skin. This can be someone's meal because they give 2 large rolls, or split comfortable between 3 people as an appetizer (2 of us split it and were no longer hungry) 

They serve loose leaf tea and are mindful how they brew it!! Proper tea to water ratio instead of most places giving those huge 2 cup pots with one tea bag.  Just ask for water refill when needed. The server told us how much longer to wait for tea to finish steeping. 

Service is good, knowledgeable, attentive and not overbearing. Good place for parties if 4 or less. Walkable distance to Golden Gate Theater. Will come again!
author: Jackie L.

description:
Amazing, amazing food.

Full of flavor, full of quality. I got in early and hence turnaround time between placing order and receiving order, better than McD's drive-thru.

I was bowled over by my simple meal. Splendid. Great prices for SF, and awesome that Nique Reco this unbeknownst to me yum Viet place.

Decor simple, modern, warm, not garish. Clean lines. Service was excellent.
author: Jana C.

description:
Came by on a Saturday evening around 8:30 and was seated immediately. I'd been here several times before since it's only a block or so from me, but ordered the Hue rolls for the first time - YUM - and also got a bowl of pho bo. I loved the crunchy texture of the fried shallots and vegetables in the roll and how the steamed rice paper seemed to blanket it all together. The pho is definitely above average but nothing I'd go crazy over since it is a bit pricier than what I'd typically pay for on Larkin St or San Jose. 

We also asked for a plate of raw onions so we could eat it as a side dish slathered in sriracha and hoisin sauce (if you know, you know), but I think we confused the poor server and she came back with a small bowl of both red and white onions - sorry to have confused you!
author: Lynn K.

description:
I ordered the Tin Rolls to start. Absolutely love spring rolls -- but these take normal spring rolls and bring them up a notch. The boiled egg is a scrumptious, umami addition, and the crispy lumpia paper add some great texture. 

Also ordered the Vietnamese Iced Coffee, which really helped perk me up for the night I had planned. Super rich, well-made coffee, and of course the irresistible sweetened, condensed milk helped tone down the bitter qualities.

Next up: vermicelli noodle bowl with grilled shrimp and the caramelized claypot catfish. Both well-seasoned and perfectly balanced.

The food is 5 stars. If I were being nit-picky, I may give them 4. Literally the only reason why that would be is the slower than standard service. I'm not one to gripe about service, particularly because there were only two employees running tables, but I also think that the owners may want to consider hiring a part-time bus boy for busy Friday and Saturday nights.
author: Emily M.

description:
Sadly, I don't really remember much about coming to this place. All I remembered was that it was rainy, cold and pho should definitely be on the menu, which is what I got. I think it was pretty decent, but I was most likely complaining about the price which is higher than the hole in the wall pho places that I like.

Overall, I'll need to come back and give this place a second chance.
author: Sophia Y.

description: I was genuinely surprised at how good the food was. Went in for lunch with a group of 7 and they were able to seat us pretty quickly. Only 2 vegetarian items on the menu. Vegetarian Pho and Vegetarian Bun (pronounced boon). I ordered the vegetarian bun thinking it was a sandwich but it was a bowl of crispy tofu, sauteed veggies, bean sprouts and vermicelli noodles. They didn't skimp on the tofu either! Best lunch I've had in while, filling but not too heavy. The wait staff seemed to be in a rush and weren't super friendly but I didn't mind because they got all the orders out really quickly. Bottom line: totally worth going at least once, even if you don't like Viet food.
author: Shubh J.

description: This was truly a great experience. The food was extremely delicious, the staff were friendly and extremely helpful, and the place had a nice ambience about it. I'll definitely return here when I come back to SF!
author: Dan B.

description: Seriously some of the best Pho i've had in my life! I came here with a group of colleagues around 12:30p on a weekday and there was a line but it was SO WORTH THE WAIT {even in the rain!}. I highly recommend the papaya salad, spring rolls, and chicken pho with vegetables! I ate so much, but it was all incredible, I just couldn't stop! The service was quick and friendly, you can definitely expect to get in and out in an hour {including a 15 minute wait!}. I also loved the decor...super cool spot near SF financial district! I'll absolutely be back the next time i'm in the city.
author: Hailey P.

description:
Totally worth the long, lunch time wait if you love REALLY good pho! 

A group of 5 colleagues (including me) headed here for a lunch when we had limited time. So, when we saw the line going outside the restaurant, we had to make a quick call on whether to stay or not. We decided we all NEEDED some delicious pho, so we opted to stick around for the 15 min wait. 

Well, the wait was longer than 15 mins, but it was worth it. We had to eat our food SO FAST... still worth it. My colleagues shared some spring rolls and papaya salad. They all raved that both dishes were the best they've ever had. I decided to hold off on both dishes because I wanted all my stomach room for pho. And glad I did. Holy cow, that's good pho. The broth is the star, in my opinion. I also got to try the broth from the wonton soup--OHMYGOD. It knocked my socks off. Well, I wasn't wearing socks, but you know what I mean. 

The service was great for how fast we had to get in and get out. The only star I'm knocking is for the unbearable heat inside the restaurant. Yes, it's packed during lunch. And yes, the restaurant is small. So some of the temperature control is out of their hands. But when you're sweating before you eat hot soup... yikes. Some temp control, even if it's just a little bit, would be amazing. 

Food = 5 stars FOR SURE.
author: Cara L.

description:
This place is now my favorite Vietnamese spot.
I can't believe it's only a block from my house.
We had Pho Bo and Shrimp Claypot. 
Usually it's really hard to mess up Pho but at the same time it's really hard to make impressions out of Pho. But Tin's Pho definitely impressed me. I can see that the ingredients they put in the Pho are top notch ingredients. Thinly sliced meat they melt in your mouth. The beef ball seems homemade. 
The shrimp claypot reminds me of similar dish I had in my hometown. Pricing is good for location.
author: Richard W.

description:
I've been to Tin at least five times and here are a couple of things you need to know:

-The food is not completely authentic Vietnamese. I should have known better since most of the customers and staff are not Vietnamese. Nothing wrong with that, of course, but if I consistently don't see a lot of Vietnamese people (or Asians, in general), it's sort of a red flag for me. I like their bun bo hue, but I'm not a huge fan of their pho bo. I know some of my non-Vietnamese friends like their pho though, so maybe you'll like it. Finally, avoid their Vietnamese iced coffee. On all the occasions I've tried it, I've been disappointed.

-You pay quite a bit of money for small portions.

-Service is ..not good. I cannot emphasize this enough! Literally every time I go there, service is slow or I get sassy waiters or some other mistake. Here are some of my experiences:

-Once, I went with a group of friends. All of us wanted pho except for me (I wanted bun bo hue), but one friend wanted substitution for a different noodle for his pho. So I told the waitress (she has short hair, tattoos, not Viet, for reference), four regular pho bo, another pho with larger vermicelli noodle, and one bun bo hue for me. The waitress audibly sighed, shook her head, and told me, "No. Everyone tells me their order one by one." I've never had a problem ordering food like that in a Vietnamese restaurant, but she explained that she needed everyone to order individually so she knew which food went where. Okay, fine. No problem. However, did she really have to be so rude when she told me that? Nope. Anyways, food came out, and guess what? She put the bowls in the wrong order. Bravo 

-I took two friends to try bun bo hue because they had never had it before. Both of them don't handle spicy foods well, so we asked the waitress (same person who sassed me in the first story) to make 2 of the bun bo hues less spicy. She insisted that it tastes better spicy (which I agree with), but my friends requested again to make it not spicy. When the bun bo hue finally came out, all three bowls were the same level of spiciness (I tasted all of them). So basically, waitress or the chef disregarded the request. That wasn't a huge issue because they just drank a bunch of water. However, my friend was missing all of the beef shank from her bowl and so we had to ask the waitress to get some from the kitchen (I'm grateful that the waitress was efficient about this and apologized). Finally, I found hair in my bun bo hue....lovely.

-More recently, (and this incident was probably the worst) I was craving hu tieu kho, but I noticed that in the menu, it's listed under the section called "Other Noodles without Broth." Here's the description: "Hu Tieu Kho / xa-xiu and ground pork, chicken, shrimp, rice noodles, soy-tomato sauce." Usually, hu tieu kho comes with broth on the side, but there was no mention of it on the menu. I was pretty confused, so I decided to just order their normal hu tieu with a request to put the broth on the side. When it was finally time to order, the waiter (not Viet) said, "So you mean hu tieu kho." I told him that, yes, I saw that, but there was no description for broth on the side. He kept insisting that I get hu tieu kho because there is broth. So I asked, "Are you sure?" I was going to continue on about why I was confused because of the section it was under when he interrupted me by PLACING HIS HAND ON MY ARM and said, "Honey, I've been working here for 8 years" and something along the lines of how he knew the menu, etc. etc. 

First of all, NEVER touch a customer without their permission. I am NOT your friend or your "honey." Second of all, all he had to say was, "Yes, it's under that section of the menu and the description doesn't say it has broth on the side, but it does." He talked to me in such a condescending tone for almost the entirety of that ordering process, and honestly, I was at a loss for words that I just went ahead and ordered the hu tieu kho. Yes, it did come with the broth on the side, so he was right. I just wish he told me that in a nicer way. Yes, I respect that you worked at the restaurant for 8 years, you probably do know your Vietnamese food well. However, I've been Vietnamese-American for all my life and to see a menu description like that definitely threw me off. All I needed was a polite clarification and it would have been fine. In the end, the hu tieu kho was decent, but definitely not the best I've ever had. Side note, he totally forgot about my friend's iced coffee until we reminded him - my friend is also Vietnamese and he wasn't impressed by the quality.

I used to come to Tin despite bad service because I missed food from home. However, coming to Tin just makes me feel like my own culture is rejecting me. The latest experience was definitely the last straw, so I will not be going back again. It's not worth paying that much money for mediocre Vietnamese food, a nice interior, and continuously bad service.
author: Trisha V.

description:
This is my favorite spot to get Pho in the city. Fair warning it can get pretty packed at lunch time and the spot isn't super big. The good news is the food is quite delicious and the portion sizes are hefty. I've been going here for years. I usually get Bon Rieu(seafood Pho). Definitely pile on some Sriracha once you get it. 

High on the recommend list.
author: Cynthia G.

description: Came here after work with a friend and was super pleased with my experience. This is definitely very upscale compared to most Vietnamese joints I've been to. The food was good (although not the best I've ever had) and the price is reasonable for the area. I would recommend checking this place out if you're in the area.
author: Helen F.

description:
Tin's is one of my favorite restaurants in SF! I remember finding Tin's on a late Thursday night after being at the mall for too many hours and needing pho real badly. We were hungry, looking for a good place to eat that was close by, for a good price. And we found Tin's :') 

Tin's is a smaller venue, and gets pretty busy around dinner time. The first time I came here, we had to wait in line to put our name down (yes!) but that's to be expected. If it's super busy, expect to wait 40+ minutes for a table. 

I've gotten their Bun Bo Hue, Pho Bo, Tin Rolls, and the Cha Gio. 

Bun Bo Hue
Good but pretty spicy, especially for someone who has a decent spice tolerance. Technically not as authentic as it could me (no blood in it) but for people who aren't used to or familiar with that, this is the safer route. If you have average spice tolerance, I'd recommend asking them to make it a bit more mild!

Pho Bo
The Pho Bo is pretty good. Just your Pho with beef in it, and you can add extra meat to it (meatballs, tendon, etc.) for an extra $1.50. It was pretty good -- I've had better pho elsewhere, but this place is still one of my go-to's for good pho.

Tin Rolls
Wasn't quite sure what this was to begin with, but we got it because it sounded delicious and was first on the menu. The meat was seasoned wonderfully and the dipping sauce that goes with it is SO good. So good. There was something crispy in the roll that gave it extra texture which was nice, but the hardboiled egg didn't seem to go well with the roll. If they took that out, this roll would be 100% spot on.

Cha Gio
I think about the Cha Gio often. Crispy, delicious goodness. Just go for it. Don't even ask what's in it. Maybe one of the favorite foods I've consumed in my life. Do this for me.

Tin's is great -- I recommend this place all the time to friends who visit from out of town, and they all love Tin's too :-)
author: Christine Y.

description:
I was extremely satisfied! It's not often that I am able to find affordable decent food in the city, but Tín was just that! We were seated immediately after we walked in through the door. The atmosphere was pretty lively but a little noisy. Really good service though. The waitress always made sure we had water at the table, which sadly is something a lot of other restaurants need to work on.

Most people in the restaurant seemed to order the pho, but I was really craving lemongrass pork, so I went with the Bun Thit Nuong (Lemongrass pork shoulder vermicelli noodle bowl no soup). Man did I make the right choice! The serving size was very generous (I got a huge bowl with a surprisingly large amount of meat). Had I not skipped lunch that day, the bowl would have definitely filled me up. The pork was prepared very well, crisp flavorful slices but not dried out. The sauce for you to pour over the noodles has a nice tangy flavor, and all the vegetables were very fresh. My only complaint is the excessive amount of bean sprouts that I found at the bottom of my bowl. I would have preferred there to be more noodles instead of so many bean sprouts.

Really solid restaurant! My order was $9.50 + tax/tip whatever. It's honestly not that much more than what you would pay for something similar at a nearby food court. Will definitely come back!
author: Eric Z.

description:
3.5 stars.

Cheap prices, but the food was a bit disappointing. Tin is located on Howard between 5th and 6th, which is a slightly better block, but I wouldn't recommend walking down towards 6th alone at night.

- Spring rolls: The rice paper was way too thick, ruining the balance between filling and rice paper and making each bite too chewy.
- Pho bo: Pretty tasty, but the broth wasn't as clean and much smaller portion size than what most Vietnamese restaurants offer.
- Lemongrass beef vermicelli noodles: The meat was good quality but not seasoned well and did not really have much of the lemongrass flavor. Including some pickled radishes and carrots was a nice touch though.
author: Tiffany P.

description: Ate beef pho and fried something as appetizer. It was okay, nothing really crazy. The portions are also reasonable
author: Why-Tie Z.

description:
The food is okay. There was only one waiter on a busy Tuesday night and there were a lot of issues with skipped people in line (even though there's a signup list).
More staff is most definitely necessary - there's way too much for one person to do and your service is suffering as a result.
author: Allen C.

description:
If you are a pho fan then this is a must try place! I have never dined in but I usually call in and order ahead! They are very fast with getting your order placed and ready to go! The most I've waited is 15 min. I usually order the chicken pho (pho ga) which is always a go to classic if you are new to pho or maybe even trying it for your first time.

What is unique about this particular restaurant is that their broth had fresh ginger in it as well. This gives the soup a revitalized flavor, it is one of my favorites I have ever had. I have gone back a few times and I am always very pleased.

The one thing on the menu that I was not as pleased with was the vegetarian spring rolls. These were not as good as I had hoped. The spring rolls contain tofu (which normally I love) but this one was extra chewy and a bit plastic like. I ended up not eating much nor it at all and the peanut sauce is very plane as well.

The restaurant is small and intimate but the servers are all very polite and inviting! I would recommend a stop if you are looking for some good pho!
author: Maddy H.

description:
My first experience at Tin was wonderful. I arrived at six in the evening on a busy Friday, but did not have to wait long for a seat. The staff was friendly, attentive and more than happy to offer suggestions on the food. 

My date and I shared the Cha gio to start, it came with the traditional dipping sauce and was dressed with extra veggies to eat along with glass noodles. I happily enjoyed each crunchy bite and excitedly waited for my meal when they were all gone. (If the rolls are this good I imagine everything here must be delicious. )

Next the mains, I ordered  the claypot shrimp and my date the Pho Ga. The food came sizzling and steaming straight from the kitchen, my shrimp was perfectly cooked and drenched in delicious caramelized goodness.   Even the veggies were dripping in sauce and before long they were all gone as well.  Despite the huge food coma I had following my meal, I will definitely be back soon.
author: Renee S.

description:
Yikes. Food was good but service was BAD!!!!

We had a party of 4. We came early on a weekday for lunch. The place is very small so we had to wait like 30 minutes for a table- not convenient of you are coming form work on a lunch break!!!!

We each ordered a dish- no app. The food seriously was taking over an hour to come out. We found out that the server forgot to put our order in!!!!! WTF! 

Then he didn't comp our dishes!!!! We literally had to ask- and then he only comped half. UHM- that's really bad customer service if you ask me. The only reason I am giving 2 stars instead of 1 is because once the food came it was pretty good. Half us us ordered the "beef stew" pho and it was warm and hearty. I just hate that the beef was so chewy and fatty. 

I wont be back. Rude servers. Clearly inattentive.
author: Erica D.

description:
I didn't actually get to eat the food, so this review is solely for service:

3 of us arrived at 7pm on a Friday and was seated immediately. Sat for 25 mins trying to flag down a waiter, while being repeatedly told that 'our waiter' would take our order. Needless to say, we left without ordering food. I wish we hadn't wasted our time here.

Overall, the entire staff seemed extremely stressed and over worked. They do their best to keep their heads down to avoid any additional load. Go elsewhere, there's several Viet places nearby.
author: David Z.

description:
I previous only ordered to go from order ahead and never had to experience eating in the restaurant, and I think I that if I eat from here again that I will only order TOGO.

My dine in lunch experience was SO HORRIBLE that I would never want to dine in again. The food itself is good, but I have had better service in Vietnamese places in Oakland, where the staff speaks mostly Vietnamese.

My co-workers and I (group of 4) got at Tin's at 12:45 and with only 2 groups in front of us was expecting to be seated within 20 mins. When we were the next table, I saw a table of 2 free and next to it another table of two, so I was think happy thoughts at being sat soon however that did not happen. With 3 two-tops opened next to each other and another 2 top on the other side, the server sat two one-tops right in the middle of the 2 tops and then another one top 15 mins later. 

Realize that we got there at 12:45 and 3 one tops (that came after us) got sat before my group. By 1:20, we decided to just get our food to go, only to have a table open up.

I understand that there are only two servers, but I have not had such horrible service. I have work as a bartender, server and host only to witness this three tables get sat in front of my party, made me never to come here again and only to go.
author: Mei L.

description:
My wife and I went here for lunch today. The restaurant itself is quite cozy, with tight seating.
I would not recommend for larger groups. The service was fast, and expedient, though when crowds grew - it took us a long time to get the check.

We had the Mango Salad, Chicken Wings, and Banh Mi (Chicken & Pork).

The Mango Salad was probably our favorite dish. It was crisp, fresh, just the right amount of sweet to spicy. It was not overdressed (as it often is at other places), We ate it up quick! The shrimp in the salad was good. It came with pork belly as well, though the flavor and pieces got lost among the green mango. My only criticism would be to do pork belly OR shrimp, so that you can taste your choice integrated with the salad (rather than lost in it). Overall though, we would order this again. It was a great appetizer!

The Chicken Wings were cooked well and were very tender. However, the flavor fell flat and the wings were not impressive. They had this generic, ubiquitous flavor, as though these wings could have been ordered at any restaurant. They weren't special, nor were they worth the stomach space! Would not order again. We'd encourage the restaurant to add a flavorful side-sauce, or to spice things up a bit.

The Banh Mi (we ordered 2, one with chicken and one with pork). Overall, we would rate the pork over the chicken. Banh Mi can usually be broken down by the quality of the bread, meat, and condiments. The bread here was fantastic. It was crusty, crispy, and added a nice crunch to the sandwich. Yet, at the same time, the inside was soft and provided good support for the fillings. Check plus! The meat was good, though it was tough to taste the flavor of the marinade, and further the meat was a bit chewy. Check minus! Lastly, the condiments were perfect. They combination of cilantro, mayo,  and other pickled veggies added additional crunch and an earthy / herby flavor to help break down the meat. Overall, would likely not order again.

We'd honestly give this place a 3.5 stars. The service was good and the food was also pretty good. We felt that we didn't order the right stuff. We do plan to go again, but will probably stick to the noodle / noodles & broth dishes, instead. We'd recommend folks do the same. You can get better Banh Mi elsewhere in the city.
author: Aditya Y.

description: We had a variety of dishes. Pho Ga, Bun lemongrass beef and Shaken Beef. Everything was on point and exceeded our expectations. Will come back for sure.
author: Michael H.

description:
Oh yum yum yum - this place is so good

Came here with some friends for dinner one evening and literally have nothing bad to say. Delicious food, cozy atmosphere, good service, and great prices. What's there to complain about?

Would definitely be back. We ordered a whole bunch of plates to share and every single one was good so I'd wholeheartedly recommend that you come.
author: Noha G.

description: Tin was a great lunch spot when i worked close by.  I lie the menu and it's a comfortable space.
author: Michael E.

description:
While the good may not be super authentic Vietnamese food as other people say (I personally can't tell), it's still good food!
We ordered spring rolls, bo bun hue, and pork vermicelli, which was all yummy!
But especially the understanding service. It wasn't the fastest but it was okay because I accidentally ordered tin rolls at first thinking they were spring rolls, then realized my mistake. We explained and they said no problem, and they switched them out for spring rolls which was so nice of them! 
All in all I'd come back for the good food and service!
author: Victoria C.

description:
I usually judge pho places on their most "basic" and "standard" pho and here it's the Pho Bo. Is it delicious? Yes! Is it high quality? Yes! Is it the best pho in the city? No. It is also a bit smaller in serving size than other pho places.
I'd say for the area and being a bit of a fancier Vietnamese restaurant the pho is indeed quite stellar. But.. you know the best pho places have to have a number in their restaurant name, or have a quirky name (shout out to Yummy Yummy), or have servers serve pho with their thumb in the soup for that extra flavor.
I've also had their Pho Ga, a chicken ginger broth, which didn't excite my taste buds but it would be a great "chicken noodle soup" substitute for those kind of days. Their 5 spice chicken over rice is also done really well with flavorful and juicy chicken.
Spring rolls, can't go wrong, and their Hue Rolls... such an amazing flavor mix and texture mix of the summer roll wrap with the spring roll crunch.
The Tin rolls were delicious but a bit off for me since it was quite "heavy" not too much of an appetizer feel.
Overall you won't be disappointed dining here.
author: Eden W.

description: The pho is good and the prices are very good for the area. I wish they had pho tai, pho bo isn't as good imo
author: Logan H.

description: Food and service were awesome. The place is small though, so they could use an expansion. The quail was cooked just right, and the pho broth was tasty. Expect to wait 10-15 minutes to get seated.
author: Billy H.

description: One of the best, if not the best, Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco. Portion sizes are large, they have more then just the standard pho and bun, and service is quick. When I have guest in town I often take them here for dinner.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Good authentic food. Go early to avoid the lines which can lead to lengthy wait. The ideal group to be quickly seated is 2 to 4. It's a smallish restaurant with big good food. The host and service was very good.

I would give it 5 stars if they took reservations. =)
author: Gino E.

description: A gem of a spot! Super fresh and flavorful combinations with excellent service as well. Well rounded drink list. Best Vietnamese in SOMA by a landslide.
author: Derek C.

description: Great vibrant and intimate ambiance with a fun soundtrack (thing regaeton Pink's just like fire). Seated promptly and handed a very easy to read menu. Only issue is that most items have pork in them, so if you're not a pork fan, there's slim picks, like their lemongrass chicken. However the teriyaki and Sriracha sauces definitely make up for it. Fragrant broth, fresh veggies and very attractive staff.
author: Carlos P.

description:
Tin is always full!

Came by to get our pickup (ordered via phone), and temporary street parking was pretty easy to find. The menu online is really easy to use, and the guy taking our order on the phone was quick and efficient, even when we told him we would be picking it up in an hour. When I picked up the food, it was still warm! THANKS TIN.

I paid $11 for a full box of rice noodles with my grilled and deliciously flavored shrimp. I can see why it's so popular for dinner, but I'd like to actually sit in and dine in the restaurant next time.

I loved the Bun Tom (without broth) that had grilled shrimp as protein! There was plenty of green onions and lettuce as well as bean sprouts and loads of vermicelli noodles to fill up my noodle-loving-belly. I would happily try Tin again, ordering maybe their soup noodles next time.
author: Jodi H.

description: Amazing Vietnamese food! I had the lemongrass beef vermicelli noodles and could eat them every day. Good vibe inside the restaurant.
author: Whitney D.

description:
Short Story:  A cool place for pho in SF near Muscone Center!

Long Story:  I've been here twice now and each time it has been great!  The place seats about 40 to 50 people.  The beef pho is pretty good and so is the crepe salad.  The prices are service are pretty good.  We ordered two beef pho, one chicken, and a crepe salad.  The ambiance and decor are a bit standard.  I like their their old school lighting.

Verdict:  I'd definitely go back!
author: Michael W.

description: My new favorite Vietnamese place. I've gone about 20 times in the last few months. The tin rolls are the best, and also love the grilled shrimp vermicelli and chicken pho. Service is perfect, quick. Ambiance is actually pretty nice, a great date spot.
author: Lulu S.

description: By far, the best pho I've ever had. I ordered the beef broth based pho with brisket chunks and eggs noodles with vegetable crispy rolls to start. My fiance had beef broth pho with thick noodles which she enjoyed. Service is somewhat slow but they get the job done. I'm a huge pho eater from the east coast and this place destroys the competition across the nation. PHOCKING PHOTASTIC!
author: Nima B.

description:
I'm hard to please when it comes to pho and I've all but given up on finding decent pho in SF. A friend of mine recommended Tin and of course, I was skeptical. But I happened to be feeling a little hungry after attending an event across the street from Tin. 

I thought, why not give the Pho Bo a try today? The portion size is on the small side and I should've asked for wide noodles instead of the skinny ones that I don't love. The broth is tastier than most places I've tried in the City. It doesn't have that watered down with tap water feel, which is a huge plus. What I was most impressed by was the quality of the meat. The raw meat was excellent and the cooked meat had just enough fat to be juicy. That was the best part. This is the best pho I've had in SF to date.

With tax and tip, the total was $12.50. Not bad for SOMA.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Like any popular SF lunch spot, timing is everything.  Tin Vietnamese opens at 11:30 am and by 11:25 there were at least half a dozen people milling outside (im)patiently waiting for those ugly gates to open.  By noon it was packed with a line out the door. 

Luckily, we came early enough, so we got seated.  As an appetizer we got the spring rolls, which were fine but way too large and somewhat bland.  I had to douse them in peanut sauce and even then it was touch and go. 

As a main course I got the Bun Thit Bo Xao (brothless noodles with sautéed lemongrass beef).  The beef was delicious.  The noodles were too many.  The vegetables were fresh but completely buried by noodles.  

Overall, a solid spot, but unclear why it's so popular.
author: Denis S.

description: Legit and traditional Vietnamese food with a modern and hip interior design. The pho bo is very good, soup base full of flavor and a good amount of protein. My only complaint is that the soup wasn't very hot when it came out. Other than that, the pho here is excellent and I love the decor inside. Definitely recommend!
author: Anita T.

description:
This place is pretty great! I got a Bun Bo Hue, and a Hue roll. Super nice server, but quite loud as the venue is pretty small. Great flavor on the Bun Bo Hue, just enough spice to make it interesting, and very flavorful broth. The roll was great as well, with delicious pieces of grilled pork rolled up in a spring-roll style. Don't let the slightly sketchy looking block scare you away from visiting, the restaurant is quite good!
The wait was about 20 minutes on a Friday evening around 7:30pm. They had a small pad on which people were putting their names down to queue. This restaurant probably doesn't accommodate large groups well.
author: Alexander L.

description: Great vegetarian/vegan pho, but the noise level was insane. We couldn't talk to our friends because of it, so likely won't come back here. Some noise canceling panels on the wall might help!
author: Daniel G.

description:
Really good pho at a really good price.
I was looking for a quick tasty meal and  this restaurant rocked!  The wait staff is polite, attentive and fast.  Broth is everything in Pho and their broth has a lot of flavor!  A very casual restaurant with quality food.  I would guess they are insanely busy at lunch; but I would also guess they turn the tables quickly.  Overall a great meal.  Happy I walked over here and I will definitely be back to try some other meals!
author: K W.

description:
Not as good as Mama M.'s cooking, but 80% of the way there.

Hue Rolls: 3.5/5.0. Good flavor, but veggie-to-meat ratio was subpar.
Bo Kho: 4.0/5.0. Got it with noodz. Tasty and hearty, but wish the broth was a lil thicker.
Bun Bo Hue: 5.0/5.0. My friend insists this was the truth.
author: Trevor M.

description:
Real Talk: I live 3 blocks away & frequent this gem on an average of 1/week. My go-to dish is the Veggie Pho & a side order of Sautéed Bok Choy. Both are amazing, and great for take out. I've taken scores of people here & been told all the pho's are equally amazing. 

When I eat in the restaurant I often mix it up by getting the carmalized cat fish claypot. AH-MAZING. The sauce is perfect, slightly crunchy on outside & fish melts in your mouth. 

The place is usually packed during peak lunch and dinner hours but they move swift through the line. If you are grabbing pick up just walk to the back server area & give your name. 

The decor is sleek, minimal and prioritizes capacity over ambiance but great for a 2-4 size party. Also, the servers are swift and friendly & pick up orders are always perfect!
author: Silver S.

description: The papaya salad was fresh and refreshing. The vegetarian vermicelli noodles with crispy rolls were seriously amazing, and those crunchy crispy rolls were to die for. Seemed like a great lunch/dinner spot for a party of 2 to 4 ... casual and friendly, pretty small
author: Terry B.

description:
First off, I'm used to going to Vietnamese restaurants where I get bad service or sometimes even no service. I'm lucky enough to live 15 minutes from Little Saigon (Orange County). 

But you're gonna give me bad service AND bad food? Not only did the server ask us to move seats to make room for another party, he sat us where the floor was clearly lopsided. 

The first dish we had were the wings, which were incredibly greasy. I don't mind grease, but if it's slipping through my fingers...dude. 

I had the claypot catfish which was okay at first, but the more I ate it, the saltier it tasted. The rice they gave me on the side was extremely mushy (dude, you can't even make rice?!) and unappetizing after a few bites. 

But what ticked me off the most...my boyfriend got the bo kho with the baguette. When the order came out, they had given it to us with the egg noodles instead. After I told the waiter, he said, "Oh we ran out of bread. The kitchen automatically substitutes it with the noodles."

I'm sorry, what?? You knew you didn't have anymore bread and didn't tell us beforehand? Or maybe you could have told us after? Gee, I wanted to tip you guys $5 for my $40 bill, but my wallet automatically substitutes it with $0. 

After my boyfriend and I could only get through half of our meal, we waited for the server to come around for our check. Fifteen minutes had passed before he came to ask us how we were doing. After asking for the check, we waited ANOTHER 15 minutes. 

Honestly, I would rather be served by an old cranky Asian man who only spoke to take my order than go back to Tin. 

I should have known better. If you wanna get a good authentic meal, you go to a 3.0 star mom and pop where you aren't the only Vietnamese person.
author: Michelle N.

description: 5 Star goes to Mike our server.  We asked what the recommendations were for this and he definitely pointed us the right direction.  I ordered the spicy beef noodle soup and their signature egg roll appetizer and it was delicious.  My only gripe about this place is the price is a bit steep for the portions they serve, but customer service aka Mike made me left happy and satisfied.  Ask for Mike for their recommendations!
author: Ben G.

description:
This is arguably the best hanoi-style pho in the city. I only wish they were open on Sundays (as that seems to be my go-to option on Eat24 for a cold and foggy SF Sunday)

No matter, the pho bo is delicious six days of the week, the broth for take out orders is always piping hot (a problem at some other places) and the meat looks really legit and tastes delicious. 

Hands down, my favorite spot pho show. (had to... sorry). 

Plus, for take out, I always seem to find a spot right in front.
author: Mike V.

description:
Delicious vermicelli bowls and phos!

I always get the vermicelli bowl with grilled shrimp -- best grilled shrimp I've eaten in the city. The vegetarian bowl with marinated tofu is also amazing! It's served with shiitake mushrooms and other pickled veggies. Yum, it's just very flavorful.

The restaurant can get super packed during the week at lunch time but once you're seated the service is pretty fast. Some of the servers are not the nicest or smiliest but honestly the food & price are excellent! 

Great vietnamese joint in SOMA.
author: Leslie S.

description:
As good as any good pho. I found this place convenient as it was only a few blocks down from Moscone West where I was attending a conference. Fortunately, my colleagues were adventurous and they decided to join me for lunch. 

Two of us split an order of spring rolls, which were great with the accompanying peanut sauce. We devoured them quickly. 

I ordered a combination pho with the beef balls. I didn't particularly care for the fact they charge extra for the beef balls, since just about any place I've been includes them (and tripe) in  a combination pho bowl. 

The pho was great. I don't think it's the best in the world. I've had better, but I've hard worse pho far more times. That's why I'm giving this place a solid 4 out of 5 stars. 

Lastly, be prepared to wait if you get there more than 5 minutes after opening! We were the first ones in the door when they opened at 11:30, but by the time we finished eating, every table was full and there was a line out the door.
author: Andrew L.

description:
An upscale Vietnamese restaurant in the middle of SoMa district, not far from Moscone center.  The food is solid but feels a little Americanized. Very busy when it opens for lunch, but thins out around 12:45.  Service helps you order fast, but then fades to not much..
 Picks:
Spring Rolls ($8) had large shrimp and a really nice peanut sauce.

Pho Bo ($10) had an average broth, not a lot of noodles or meat. Passable but not exciting.

Bun Bo Hue ($12.50) was a little lacking in heat, lacks the 'parts' real places have, but also was passable.

Just OK:
None

Would not reorder:
None

Overall - Good
Food - Good
Decor - Very Good
Service - Fair
Value - Good

Would we come back - Maybe
author: Ellen H.

description: I absolutely LOVE this spot! This is mine and my husband's new go-to spot in SOMA. Portions are good, quality and freshness are great and overall vibes and ambiance in this place are perfect for a date night or catching up with friends. We love the flavor of the Pho Ga so highly recommend it! I've also had the Bon Hue Everyone recommends but I got it veggie style. Also very good if you want a spicier flavor with a kick!
author: Anastacia W.

description: I'm not sure whether it was a really off-day for the chef or if all the pho have the same taste but the Pho Bo I ordered was the worst pho I've ever had. It was extremely bland, absent of any flavor or seasoning for sure. My friends around me ordered other noodle dishes and all of their soups tasted well-seasoned but they all agreed however that the soup of the Pho Bo was tasteless. We had appetizers and my friends ordered many different kinds of dishes that everyone seemed to be enjoying but if I did go back I'd probably not get the Pho Bo again.
author: Phillip C.

description:
Been to Tin twice now because my friend lives nearby. Every time I come to this place, it smells amazing and it's reflected in the food that they serve.

A lot of Pho places have weird serving portions but I really like how Tin does theirs! It's a perfect blend between the broth, noodles and meat where you don't feel like you're being overwhelmed by one thing. They're also quite generous with portion sizes, at least for the pho.

The line can be a bit long during busy hours but I would say that it's worth the wait. Tin is a relatively small restaurant, so it's best to come in groups of 4 or smaller.
author: Cassie Z.

description:
While I was visiting San Fran, someone suggested that we do our last dinner here. Now I will be honest, I was really hoping to grab Chipotle before I left the big city... A friend of my co-worker lives in SF and suggested this place. I can't remember if I've ever even had Vietnamese food before. I figured it would be best to try something new.

This place is small, but it has so much character! We drooled over the menu while we waited for a table for maybe 10 minutes. I didn't have a clue what to order so we all decided to order different things and share it all.

I started off with the egg rolls. Oh my goodness. It's been a long time since I've had egg rolls. Not sure what I've been waiting for, but I am really glad I got these. Crispy and amazing! Next up:  Pho Ga which consisted of: Poached chicken with rice noodles in ginger-chicken broth. For those who might be new to this dish, here's how I explain it: Chicken noodle soup on steriods. The flavor was out of this world. PHO real. Ha! I ate until I couldn't eat... and then I ate a little more. Fan for life. It inspired me to come home and learn how to make it myself. Light, healthy and full of flavor. I'm on it. 

San Fran had some amazing food. This was one of my faves. Thanks Tin! I'll be back!
author: Bridgett P.

description:
Was in the area and liked that it had a solid 4 star ranking. Cute and trendy. I got there around 11:45 and was seted immediately.  By the time I left, it was packed and really loud. Servers were quick and friendly. 

Food was decent but nothing to write home about. I ordered summer rolls and a Vietnamese coffee. I found the wrapper was too thick and kind of messed with the whole consistency of the roll but decent. Teeny iced coffee, prepped in the kitchen and brought out mixed. I'm used to getting the strainer and the glass so I was disappointed. Overall, probably a good place to go for lunch if you work in the area, but since I don't, it wasn't worth noting for me.
author: Mona M.

description: Don't know how the food taste yet and I m wondering if I ever will. Was waiting for a table and literally everyone who came after me got seated before us...
author: Catrina W.

description:
I love Vietnamese cuisine, but my largest problem with eating Vietnamese is that I end up feeling super thirsty afterwards and always fall into a deep coma. This is because 99% of Vietnamese restaurants drench their food in MSG. While tasty, I certainly do not enjoy the aftermath. 

If you have the same dilemma as me, you will be extremely happy to hear that Tin Vietnamese Cuisine is the 1%. Not only do they serve delicious Vietnamese food, but they don't use much (or even any) MSG! How do I know this? I never get thirsty nor do I food coma afterwards!

Menu items I've ordered and recommend: Pho Ga (Chicken Pho), Vegetarian Pho (extremely clean and fresh), and the 5-Spice Chicken Rice Plate.
