I know they are a bit pricier than the average Vietnamese restaurant, but I'd choose Tin any day for delicious Vietnamese food with zero consequences. Plus... how often do you come across a Vietnamese restaurant that serves good food AND has good hygiene?
author: Cindy L.

description: Been coming here to Tin Vietnamese over the last few years whenever we go shopping in downtown SF.  Definitely among the top three Vietnamese restaurants in my book.  The Carmelize Claypot Catfish has always been my go-to dish as it is savory with lemon grass and served piping hot. Service is always efficient.  Will be back at Tin soon.
author: Hugh Y.

description:
I usually love an excuse to add Sriracha to any dish. With Vietnamese cuisine, it's almost a given that I'll be enhancing it with a generous dose of Huy Fong's trademark sauce.

At Tin, however, I'd recommend relegating the Sriracha bottle to a table decoration. One spoonful of their Bun Bo Hue broth, and you'll quickly acknowledge that they've got the spice-flavor combo perfectly in check. I can't recall the last time I had Bun Bo Hue where I didn't end up adding additional spice.

The Pho also has a rich beef broth, perfectly cooked noodles and fresh sides. For me, however, this is a spot for the Bun Bo Hue, with the heat turned up to 11.
author: Darrin K.

description:
Interesting take on asian fusion.  It's a nice change of pace for the neighborhood and they have some interesting dishes worth a try. 

Lumpia Wrapped Firecracker Shrimp:
Nice crunchy texture due to the lumpia wrapping. Shrimp were well seasoned. Solid starter for two. I would always opt for extra shanghai sauce. 

Pho Bo: Broth is dark but doesn't have the body that usually comes with it  (lighter, less oily, less umami, more refreshing)

non-food notes: dark modern decor. almost like a lounge if not for the dining tables.
author: Norris T.

description:
Came here for the first time since my best friend swore this place has the best broth. We seated ourselves since it was still early & there were a lot of open seats. Right as I sat down, I noticed that their floor is super dirty. As if they haven't swept or mopped in a week. 

We ordered the egg roll to share, it was mediocre. I've had way better egg rolls from other Vietnamese places. Plus when it came out, it wasn't even hot or tasted fresh.

I had the hu tieu & that sucked. I told my best friend I'd rather eat top ramen rather than what I had ordered. Hers came with 4 shrimps, where I only had 2. The broth was bland & whatever.

My Vietnamese coffee was mostly ice.

Service was horrible, so I told my friend not to leave a tip & trust me, that's VERY rare for me to not leave or tip or tell my friend not to leave one. But hey, tips aren't mandatory & they're usually given based on service. 

They seemed to not want to serve us & when we were finished my friend had raised her hand a few time to get their attention, but nope. Nothing.

Overall I would not be coming back here. It's San Francisco, I'm sure there are WAY better pho/Vietnamese cuisine spots.
author: Phoebe T.

description: I went to dinner here one time with my boyfriend and everything was very fresh! would definitely recommend to anyone that likes Vietnamese dishes.
author: Truuu R.

description:
Lordy lordy lordy this place is so insanely good. I'm going to update this review after I try this place about a dozen times. What I had on my first at-bat exemplified why vietnamese food is so good. There was perfect balance between flavors, textures and the finish was light and satisfying. 

Tips: this place is small and fills up quickly. Get here before noon to guarantee a table during the lunch rush.
author: Darin E.

description: Tin is a true find for a Vietnamese restaurant - the Pho is authentic and mouth-watering. The Pho Kho here, with a more savory broth, is unique. Hip and modern interior makes this a very fun place to go with friends or bring family and out of town guests. Only downside is the front door is usually left open, and on windy days makes the tables close to the door, freezing.
author: Ben G.

description:
A friend and I went her for lunch while we were in town for a conference, and I was blown away. Seating is a little confusing as it gets busy - people stand in line, but you need to also put your name on their list for a table (it's not obvious until you see someone pass you in line to put their name in before you, which is annoying).

Once seated, the service is quick, prices are super reasonable (around $35 for two people), and the food is fantastic. Everything tastes fresh, light, and is perfect as a recharge for the rest of the day.
author: Nick D.

description: I came back, as I said I would, to try out their other vegan options. This time, I got the vegetarian bun--grilled lemongrass tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and soy vinaigrette which I think was even better than the bahn xeo. The shiitake mushrooms were caramelized to perfection. The bun had incredible texture throughout from the soft noodles to the julienned cucumber, lettuce, bean sprouts, pickled daikon and carrots, and peanuts. I also highly recommend to top it with the crisp-fried cha gia roll. The price point was a little high but the bowl is huge. Met a friend here who I hadn't seen in while and the location was midway between our offices. The place is small and does get a little noisy. It gets busy quickly between 6-7:30pm so best to come when they open at 5:30pm to avoid any wait. I still have to try the pho, so I'll definitely be back again.
author: Jay C.

description: What great food for so cheap!  Wow this is my new favorite in the city I believe and it was like 12 bucks with a coke.  I was shocked when my bill showed up. The food was bomb and the staff is nice.  Parking on the street was no problem for me.  I already recommended this place to a bunch of my friends
author: Sebastien L.

description: Such a treat this coconut pudding was awesome,  nice experience overall staff was friendly and the restaurant was clean
author: Liliana V.

description: I LOVE TIN!! One of the best pho I've tasted - also good cure for hangovers. The service is great and especially the food taste delicious. It's even better that its one block away from my office. It gets a bit busy during lunch but you should be fine if you come around 12PM or so. Definitely would recommend this place if you're looking for great priced vietnamese food.
author: Jenn L.

description:
I have eaten at my fair share of Vietnamese restaurants, but this one was great! The only thing was the wait was long because it's not a small space. At 11:45am on a Tuesday, the wait was probably 15-30 minutes for a table of 3. It was also a rainy day so that probably played into it.

I ordered the Hu Tieu and it was SO good, especially the broth! My friends got a vermicelli bowl and beef pho and both said it was delicious.

Will come back for a lunch pho fix!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Tin is one of my favorite Vietnamese places in the city. Sister restaurant to Mau in the Mission, both have the most flavorful ginger-chicken-garlic broth for their Hu Tieu pho. I find myself craving the Hu Tieu on a regular basis as I haven't found a lot of places in the city that have broths like this one. 

I also love their cha gio (imperial rolls), hue rolls, and salad with crispy pig ears. Honestly, you can't go wrong with this little hole-in-the-wall (but cleaner than most) if you're craving Vietnamese food. 

The place can get packed for dinner as the location is pretty small, and it's not quite as hipster as Mau, but if you work in SOMA, it's a great pit stop on a cold foggy day.
author: Kate M.

description:
The pho was incredible!!! Service was marginal. We got there first and 4 others were served before us.... our order was wrong... but the food was amazing!

Really, one of the best Vietnamese restaurants I have been to... very packed and just plain yummy!
author: Stephynie M.

description: Went here for lunch with co-workers. It was really great. The bowls had lot of beef in them and it was a hearty meal. Very reasonable in price and the service was quick and friendly. I will certainly be returning to this place, if you are in the mood for Pho then this is a good choice.
author: Ken A.

description:
Solid Vietnamese food in SOMA. The sugarcane shrimp is a must try. Pho is all right. 

Decent ambiance, good for friends gathering or treating out of town guests (esp. the type who is not familiar with Vietnamese food). It's more a "sit-down" restaurant, not your typical come-and-go pho house. 

Prices are high for Vietnamese food, but it's SOMA after all. 

Will return, but probably won't be too frequent.
author: El F.

description: The FOOD is amazing!!! I had the Bun Bo Hue and it was amazing!! Super tasty and of course huge bowl and warm in a cold day! We also had the papaya salad and it was great too!  Will def come back to this place when visit back San Fran!! Awesome spot !
author: Alexa Maria P.

description: The vermicelli bowl with shrimp is the best thing on the menu and oh boy do they knock it out. I would eat it every day if I could.
author: Natasha O.

description:
I love Tin! The Pho is always amazing and on point. They give you a good amount of meat, the broth is perfect, and they give you a ton of extra (beansprouts/basil/pickled onions) as well on the side.

However, I will say that I think the spring rolls are overrated. They have a piece of beef inside of them instead of shrimp that caught me off guard. I've found at times that the spring rolls are a little dry; I'm not a particularly huge fan of them.
author: Jessie Y.

description:
We walked in with no reservations and were both seated right away. It was a weekday night and we luckily got seated right before the dinner rush lined at the door right after us!

We ordered a number of the classics: Banh Xeo, Bun Bo Hue, and Bun Rieu. If a vietnamese restaurant was stellar, then these three dishes (including ca ko toh) should be done justice. Unfortunately, the banh xeo that we got that day was too burnt and oily. The BBH had alright flavors and was decent for SF Vietnamese food but we really missed that traditional pork blood that's usually in it. The bun rieu was pretty good as well. 

Service was efficient and was attentive which is typical at a pho joint. If you're looking for a server to present to you all steps of service along with small chatter...well, we hate to break it to you but this ain't the place where that goes down. Decent SF vietnamese food and quick service. Would be good for a quick, casual lunch or dinner if you're really in need of some standard pho. Also, this place is ideal for smaller parties due to limited seating.
author: Meli.Lars M.

description: More SoMa Gen X buzz than what its worth.  There are better and cheaper places around.  But if you happen to be on that side of town then it is a good place to experience Vietnam's flavors.  I found the Crispy Quail to be a different enough dish to make it worth my time.  Otherwise food seemed bit too salty.  Chairs not comfortable.  Ambience is mediocre.
author: Diamond H.

description: The food is delicious; however, the portion is sooooooo small. To give you an example, I paid $7 (pre-tax/tip) for stir-fried vegetables and the amount I got is less than the size of my fist... I am only 5'2" with small hands so yeah... that's how little food I got.
author: Ellen J.

description: Tasty food.  Very active busy restaurant.  Had two kinds of rolls, both great; clay pot shrimp (ok) and a collection of seafood on a fried noodles (very good).  Delish root beer and Vietnamese coffee.
author: Carol F.

description:
Was running some errands in the city, and realized how starving I was on a Sunday. SOMA doesn't have the greatest lunch options during the weekend since apparently most places are closed, and saw Tin on Yelp. I felt bad because they were closing in 15 minutes, and I try not to do this to restaurants, but I was so hungry, I had to. Then I saw the restaurant was full and a few parties came in after us, so I no longer felt bad...

I was totally expecting Tin to be a more casual take-out place vs. an actual sit down restaurant, but the food was good! I had the 5-spice chicken noodle bowl, and J had the meatball sandwich. The meatball sandwich came with a spicy broth for dipping, which was really good with the sandwich. I really liked the 5-spice chicken. It was crispy on the outside, but didn't feel like fried chicken. I'd definitely get it again.

Overall, good casual spot for lunch or dinner in SOMA.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I had vegan Pho with Tofu, mushrooms, and vegetables in vegetable broth and I really liked it. It tasted very healthy and refreshing. Extras like onions, sprouts, lemon etc go on a separate plate, so you can decide if you want them in your dish or not. 

The place is quite big, so it was comparatively easy for 4 of us to be sitting in minutes. I would recommend it for groups. Not sure about lunch time though, as the spot is popular and portions are huge. 

Highly recommend this place to all the vegan fellows!
author: Liza B.

description:
OK, I get it.  You're closed between 3:00 and 5:30 PM.  How about a sign in the window, then.  How about NOT leaving me at the podium for a couple of minutes, then coming out with a scowl on your face and a snarl on your lips to tell me that you're closed?

Thanks for sparing me the experience of actually buying a meal from you, which I will never do, now.
author: Lawrence S.

description: Love Tin and Mau. They use high quality proteins which is hard to find at Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Julie N.

description:
Tín offers a good variety of Vietnamese food- pho, noodle soups, vermicelli bowls, rice plates, bahn xeo, salads, etc. I've tried the pho, warm beef salad, and rice plate, and I've always left satisfied. Though, the beef on the warm beef salad had a bit too much sauce on it. 

Other reviews talk about the slow service, but I've never had a problem with it. Restaurant is located in the area of SOMA that begins to get sketchy. Tín plays music, creating a noisy atmosphere where it's at times difficult to hear people talk. The place is busy during weekday lunch hours, but you're able to get a table (or at least we were when we came around 1pm). 

My friend (who's a chef and fan of Turtle Tower's pho) described this place as hipster Vietnamese. He said the pho was a bit salty. Take that for what you will- everyone has different taste buds.
author: Joanna L.

description:
Tasty food. Tried the 5 spice chicken and it was 1) tasty 2) filling 
Restaurant was also cheap and good value for money.
author: Arjan N.

description:
Solid pho place in the city. Actually, probably my favorite pho place in the city. 

I came on a rainy and cloudy day while I was extremely hungover, and the bowl of pho was the best thing that happened to me the whole day. I literally went back to sleep after the meal and woke up at 4pm, and I'd do it all over again if I could.

The restaurant is clean, hip, and a nice change from your typical pho restaurant. The broth is flavorful, and the Cha Gio was to die for. The crispy fried rolls (egg rolls?) reminded me of the ones I had at The Slanted Door, and I just couldn't get enough of these. I would recommend trying these as a starter if you've never had them before!

The downside of my visits here was the slow service we experienced the first time we came. When we went after rush hour the second time, the service wasn't too bad and got seated almost immediately. If you're willing to wait for a bowl of ramen, then you should also try checking this pho place out!
author: Christina L.

description:
A nice, modern, and Americanized take on Vietnamese food. Not as authentic or cheap as what I'm used to (being from SJ) but still pretty damn good.

Small place, really clean, service is pretty good even through the crazy lunch rushes. It can get very packed for lunch and dinner, so be prepared for a little wait.

Thirsty?
The fresh limeade is amazing, house made and perfectly refreshing. Also can't go wrong with their fresh coconut juice, a nice cold whole coconut busted open for you to sip away, while you imagine yourself on a beach.

Hungry?
The papaya salad appetizer is absolutely delicious! And I don't even really like papaya salad. Although there's not an ounce of spice to it, which is kind of given with papaya salad. It's pretty much a delicious tangy sauce. For lunch/dinner entrees I highly recommend the 5 spice chicken (amazing flavors and very juicy/tender) and the claypot shrimp or fish (hot and fully packed with flavor, sometimes can be a tad bit too salty - but overall tasty).
author: Saleen L.

description: Ok, my 1 star is or the awful service, not the food...When you arrive, you will be seated by a very sleepy man who appeared to be high on something. He does not say hello or anything but what can I expect from a Vietnamese restaurant? Carrying on. The day I came was a Sat, which is quite a busy day but they had 1 waitress working. She took my order wrong and gave me Pho BO instead of Bun Rieu. Instead of apologizing, the manager just stood there and looked at me as if I should be happy to have a Pho Bo. He was also very sleepy looking. My only conclusion to this experience, is that they were partying all night and are all hungover. Hopefully my next experience will be with a more alert team.
author: Venus T.

description:
Beautiful decor, nice service, and delicious Vietnamese food. Definitely a great choice if you're craving pho. The restaurant is really popular. There was a wait even at an off time for lunch. 

I got the pho bo ($9). The broth was very flavorful and didn't need anything added to it. The meat was tender and noodles had a good texture. The bowl is on the small side compared to pho at other places. We shared the spring rolls ($7) which were tasty with the peanut sauce. The vermicelli noodle bowl with pork ($9) was amazing as well.
author: Linda X.

description: Tin is excellent! Really enjoyed an early weeknight meal there during Dreamforce. Arrived around six pm. No wait. Loved the fresh spring rolls but the lemongrass pork noodle bowl was other-worldly!! Really excellent! Fresh, flavorful, absolutely the best pork noodle bowl I ever had! Good service. Dining room filled by the time we left.
author: Elliott Y.

description: This is the best pho place in the entire Bay Area. Not only do they have a lemon grass soup, but everything on the menu is amazing. They don't accept reservations so anytime I go I have to go right when it opens or right before it closes. There is alway a wait at high times so be prepared. The Tin rolls are amazing and I have never had anything like them before. I've literally driven all the way to San Francisco from the Peninsula just to eat here.
author: Sanam A.

description:
Food was decent (4 Stars). Service was meh (2.5 Stars). 

Come early or wait forever. Unclear to me why this place is so popular since they serve the same food as most Vietnamese restaurants in SF. 

Overall, spice and sodium levels are on par with my taste buds. Sometimes SE Asian restaurants can overdo the seasoning, but Tin did a good job. 

We shared the HUE ROLLS. It was all right, couldn't really tell if it was made-to-order though. 

My fiance had the PHO GA (Chicken Pho), nothing remarkable. Midway, she was eating half my entree, which was BUNH THIT NUONG (Vermicelli Noodles). This is definitely what I'd like to get again. For me it had a good ratio of noodles, vegetables, and meat. Also, the fish sauce came on the side. 

They have an abnormally diverse list of alcoholic drinks, and of course Vietnamese coffee. 

Would love to be a regular and try their other items, but the wait...ugh.
author: Patrick M.

description:
We ordered two different rolls (Tin and Spring) as our appetizer iser They both tastes very delicious.  The skin of the roll was so soft. 
My wife ordered the Bun Thit Nuong and I ordered the Bun Tang. I went to many different Pho restatements. I like the noodle soup the way they make it. No MSG in their. Two thumbs up and will recommend to come to this place.
author: Hui C.

description:
I don't think I get the hype. I'm going to keep it completely real - there are too many other Vietnamese options in SF for you to be settling for Tin. However, if you are walking around, hungry, downtown SF at around 9 on a Thursday night, it is one of the few places open.

Service is really terrible. Not sure why, but every time we would wave down our waiter to order/pay the bill/get more water, he wouldn't come. Sometimes he would acknowledge that we waved him down, nod at us, and then proceed to help other tables and then hide out in the kitchen. Other times, he would purposefully look the other way. The restaurant was fairly packed that night, but I don't think that should have compelled the waiter to act this way. Definitely bizarre and I'm left unimpressed.

Food is okay but as some other people have mentioned, it is not authentic. Prices are a bit steeper than your average vietnamese place - but it is downtown SF, so I'll give it that. Portions are also decent to help make up for that higher price point. Also, the vegetable plate that accompanies your pho comes with pickled onions which I thought was a nice touch.

Food alone would have earned Tin 3 stars, but because of the dismal service, I had to go down to two stars. Its redemption point is for being open late night on a week day.
author: Josephine T.

description: I have loved this place since it opened. It's got the best Vietnamese in the city at unbelievably good prices. I love everything on the menu, but the braised pork belly and egg is by far the best thing. You really can't go wrong here.
author: Alexander C.

description: Excellent vegan options, especially the vegan spring rolls and the vegan pho. The tofu in the spring rolls has a unique flavor compared to other Vietnamese places, but I love it. And the broth, tofu, and veggies in the pho are all flavorful as well, though I do not care for the noodles at all. The pho I'm used to is made with thicker rice noodles, and Tin uses super thin ones...I just can't do it. However, the pho is still good so I now order the dish with little to no noodles.
author: Christina M.

description: I knew this could be good when we saw that there was a line out the door on a week night. We were not disappointed. I had the Vietnamese sandwich with Lemongrass marinaded beef and oh my it was absolutely the best! The side salad was generous and fresh. I think this may be a new favorite haunt.
author: Joan S.

description: This place was great! I went because of all the positive reviews on Yelp and I was not disappointed.  Great flavor, huge portion size, would definitely eat again.
author: Kat C.

description:
Looking for flavorful pho broth? This is THE place. 

Came here for dinner with a friend. Neither of us had been here before but were in the mood for Vietnamese food. The ambience is very trendy-- black walls, hipster lighting, mainstream electronic/pop music, snapshots of Vietnam hung up everywhere. Service was quick and to the point. 

Since I've become vegan, I've had a difficult time finding vegan pho since most pho broths are beef based. Fortunately, Tín had a vegan pho option named vegetarian pho. The broth of this soup was probably the most flavorful thing I've had in my mouth for a long time. The tofu was seasoned exceptionally well, and they were not skimpy on the vegetables. For $9, I got more than I expected and left as very satisfied customer.
author: Nicole A.

description: Being Vietnamese, this place was a little underwhelming. The bun bo hue and the pho were decent, but not the best I've had in the city. The broth didn't have the richness that one expects to taste. If it were a richer taste, this place would be great!
author: Henry T.

description:
Tucked away in SOMA, Tin can be hard to find.
Approx 2-3 blocks away from westfield mall, Tin is an Asian Fusion restaurant that caters toward the younger, less traditional palette. Though a majority of the items are classically vietnamese, the execution definitely permits individuals not too accustomed to the bold south east asian flavors to enjoy their meal.

They have a good selection of pho, bun, and rice plates. Prices range from 6-9 for appetizers and approx 9-15 for their rice plates.

I was pleasantly surprised at the portion size. Being near DTSF, i really wasn't expecting the portions to normal size. I ordered the five spice chicken rice plate (was able to sub rice for all greens) and was VERY happy with my dish. They had a great char on the chicken and flavors on the chicken itself was bold and tasty. inside the chicken was still moist-definitely a win win situation.

My friend ordered the pork shoulder vermicelli dish and gold that pork was fabulous. I loved the caramelization on the think sliced pork, each piece was sweet and savory at the same time. I personally was quite impressed. Oh and they didn't skip or dilute on the flavor of the fish sauce.

Overall, a nice experience. The spring rolls could've been better, hence the 3.5 stars instead of 4. They were bland and the peanut sauce was a bit too sweet for my tasting. 

I would come back if i'm in the area.
author: Diane T.

description:
Friends were in the mood for some noodles and we wanted to try something new. Don't get me wrong, San Francisco is the best city ever, but in this part of SOMA I did not feel safe parking my car here...

Anyway on to the food, Tín is a nice small restaurant with the Vietnamese feel to it but also very San Francisco at the same time. 

As for appetizers, we ordered the spring rolls with peanut sauce and it was very fresh, something light to start us off with and it was a solid pick.
The chicken wings were paired with a pepper sauce and the wings were okay for what they were. 

I got to try the Bun Ga Xa (vermicelli noodles with lemongrass chili chicken thighs) and I was pleasantly surprised. The portions were very generous and the chicken thighs were packed with flavor. My bowl consisted of a lot more chicken than noodles and I can't complain about that. 

After reading a few more reviews - I've got to come back and try their bun bo hue. The food was delicious, service was excellent and I'd definitely come back for more.
author: Sam K.

description: Great Vietnamese! The pho was awesome and the vermicelli bowl we got was jam packed with flavor. I agree with past reviewers on the garlic book chit- it was great. In definitely coming back for some beef pho and Bol Choy. Also a huge fan of the atmosphere which was that of a more modern, posh Asian food place than that of a traditional, hole-in-the-wall.
author: Quinn Li O.

description: I want to give this place more stars because the staff is very nice.  But they food is not quite Vietnamese food and not quite up to par.  The Bun moc is all wrong.  Broth should be clear and not salty.  The Bun bo hue should not be dark brown and drowned with other flavors.  The Tin Roll is good and a good variation from the mundane Spring Roll though. Good in a quick crave for Viet food, but not much more than that.
author: Hien D.

description: The best Vietnamese I've ever had and I go at least once a week when I can find time off-peak hours since it gets crowded. Go for the vermicelli bowl (no broth) it might be my favorite meal ever.
author: Chris H.

description: Place is small so you have to wait a bit for a table but the food is pretty good. The spring rolls tasted real fresh and the beef pho was pretty yummy. I'd come back.
author: Carol S.

description:
We ordered 2 pho and spring rolls to go. The broth is super tasty and the spring rolls are yummy.  

Will definitely order from Tin again!
author: Brenda W.

description: Bland food and served barely warm. Servers are stressed out. Overall they can do so much better if they tried.
author: Joe S.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite Vietnamese spots in SF. Everything you get will be delicious. It's always packed during lunch time but the wait is completely reasonable and worth it. 

Tin is extremely clean and has a cool, modern vibe. They have a large menu, great spring rolls and hue rolls. My personal favorites are the Bun Bo Hue (spicy beef soup) and Hu Tien Kho (dry noddles). 

Highly recommend checking this place out if you are in SOMA or DTSF! I'm a FAN!
author: Sandy L.

description: Came here with colleagues for lunch on Monday. I ordered Beef Pho, which is amazing! Finally a legit pho place near work. This will be my go to place for pho!
author: Angela W.

description: The waiter is super rude. No one comes to take orders. When we try to get their attention, the short white waiter with earrings on is super rude. "What are you doing??" is literally what came out of his mouth.....
author: Victoria Y.

description:
When you're deep in SOMA, wanting a quick, delish and affordable bite... you're in trouble. It's somewhat of a culinary desert past Mission, and Tin Vietnamese appears like a paradisiacal mirage.

It's nothing fancy, but it's got all the Vietnamese goodness you crave. Prices seem reasonable ($8-12), and service was lightning fast. No wonder they were packed on a Wednesday night!  

Our tofu vermicelli salads were perfect, filling, and fresh. For a no-fuss SOMA dining experience, Tin it is!
author: Nique F.

description: This place was really good. I don't usually order pho because vegetarian/vegan pho can be pretty tasteless. I followed the reviews, however, and ordered it. I was very pleased with it. I like that they serve it with pickled onion. They gave the soup a sweeter flavor. I would definitely come here again. My omni friends enjoyed their food too, although one said her noodle bowl had far too many noodles.
author: Gabi H.

description:
TL;DR - Not usually a fan of vietnamese food, but this place is solid! 

Ambience: 
Clean and modern. The service was definitely typical of that of any other asian dining establishment; lackluster.

Food:
Delicious. 
Spring roll (good amount of veggies and mint). 
Vermicelli bowl- solid balanced bowl. 
Pho - least favorite of the bunch but way better than any other pho place

I'd definitely come back for the rolls and bowl, but I think pho is better eaten at dirty little hole in the wall joints haha.
author: Crystal Z.

description:
I don't typically eat Vietnamese food often. I was raised by a very good Vietnamese cook, and she made really good Pho and what have you. However, her Bun Bo Hue was only 'above average' and I've been looking for a really good one for years.

I found it here! Best Bun Bo Hue I have found in years, even better than the many Vietnamese places in San Jose. 

It's not as traditional (no blood, tendons, etc.) and more Americanized, but it has a lot more flavor and is much 'cleaner'. Service is fast and fresh.

Only down sides are it's pretty pricey compared to its counterparts in San Jose (but it's SF so who can complain). The other dishes aren't bad, though many of the servers aren't well versed to Vietnamese dishes so they often don't understand my inquiries of the ingredients that go into the dish.

Still a solid place for lunch though! Get there early, cause a line always starts to form at around noon it seems. And try the Bun Bo Hue!
author: Alton D.

description: First timer!!!! Found this cozy spot on yelp. Based on all the 5 star reviews I thought I better check it out. Especially on this cool brisk day, why not have a huge bowl of pho ga! So delicious extremely tasty! Prices are very reasonable, customer service pretty good. The waitress was the only one taking orders and we had arrived right before the lunch rush! Which is a good thing because the restaurant fills up fast. Will definitely return
author: Simone D.

description:
Super good Vietnamese food, but not very authentic. Hits the spots and that's all that matters!

Ordered:
- Papaya Salad (green papaya, poached shrimp and calamari, Thai basil) - refreshing and fresh! The papaya is sliced a little thicker than the average papaya salads, but found myself liking it way more texture wise. Wish it was a bit spicier, but still so very flavorful! Would get again!
- Grilled Shrimp Vermicelli bowl - Shrimp was grilled perfectly and didn't taste like the frozen kinds! The fish sauce was sweet and tangy and not overpowering. Probably one of the better vermicelli bowls I've had.

Service is extremely slow due to 1 server and 1 bus boy working at a time. Food doesn't take too long to come out so there's a plus. Don't come here looking for A+ service, afterall it's a pho joint.
author: Anna M.

description: I keep on coming back to Tin Vietnamese Restaurant for its really delicious noodle soups and salads, such as lotus shoot, mango and papaya salads that I highly recommend. Worth visiting this restaurant for its wonderful food.
author: Andy A.

description:
Service is fairly quick here and you can usually be seated pretty soon after arriving, if not immediately even on a weekday lunch when the restaurant seems busy. They have a slight modern/industrial vibe going on with the interior decoration.

They serve one of my favorite vietnamese dishes here -- caramelized claypot catfish -- and they do it pretty well! Lot's of flavor. I've also tried the bok choy (side dish) a few times and unfortunately it is often undercooked.
author: Rica Z.

description:
Solid solid solid.

The place has a very mellow vibe, perfect for just grabbing lunch or catching up with friends.

The price is hard to beat in this area of SF.

$10 + tax and tip can get you a pretty filling meal.

The Hu Tieu isn't bad, it's very light with small strips of chicken, add some siracha and hosin sauce and you have a winner!

Definitely one of the better bang for your buck places in the area.
author: Mike L.

description: Food is decent. A bit on the pricey side. Wait time is long. The biggest issue is the service. Everything takes forever. Either hire more servers or use the existing staff to assist with the server. Unfortunately from the last experience of waiting for 20 minutes and continually being bypassed, we have decided to no longer bring our business here.
author: Lo L.

description: Been here a few times and never been disappointed by the quality. This one is one of the best Vietnamese restaurants in the city. I would highly recommend for friends and others if they are looking to try some Vietnamese dishes. Cuz this place offers an almost original Vietnamese taste. Can't wait to come back again!
author: Vu P.

description: Really tasty bahn mi. Got the BBQ pork one to go and thought it was awesome. Pricier than what I'm used to, but SF is expensive so I wasn't totally shocked. Good and past service too.
author: Katherine S.

description: This place is great. Almost every city I travel to I try to find a good pho place. This is probably my favorite so far. The Pho Ga was delicious.
author: P. K.

description: Tin serves up solid dishes for a fair price! It's a very low key, casual place too. We showed up at 6:45 on a Monday and were seated immediately. Highlight: The broth in Hu Tieu tasted fantastic. Lowlight: The restaurant is small, and tables are situated closely so I had a difficult time carrying a conversation with the noise. On the other hand, you can be pretty loud here if that's you!
author: Lee H.

description:
Nothing is good about this place. The pho is expensive, tastes plain and the portions are tiny, like oh my god I've never seen a smaller pho bowl. And they have the audacity to charge you 10$ for it when you can go to Chinatown and get a better, bigger, cheaper bowl of pho. I don't think so. How did this place even manage 4 stars and 800 reviews?

Service and atmosphere is good. If you're fine with crap pho
author: Davis W.

description:
Tin and Mau (of the same owners) are two of my favorite Viet restaurants in SF.

That being said, I prefer Mau over Tin, not just because it's in my hood, but because it's more open, less stuffy, less of a wait, and there's a bar you can sit at while the rest of your party arrives. Besides that, Tin has the same friendly service, reasonable prices, and great food. 

My favorites:
* Five Spice Chicken - my go-to dish if I'm not in a noodle/soup mood. The chicken has a crispy skin and is super tender and juicy! I usually never order chicken dishes at restaurants, but this is one of my faves. 
* Lotus root salad - always fresh and delicious. Love the pork.
* Bun Bo Hue - I'm usually pretty picky about bun bo hue, but I really liked Tin's version. It's not as authentic, but definitely very flavorful and spicy. The broth is delicious and portions are large with a good meat-to-noodle ratio. Sometimes, the meat is a bit too chewy and overcooked, but overall really good.
* Pho - good, but not extraordinary

Great spot in SOMA, but I'll stick with Mau from now on.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Was not impressed with Tin. The service was lacking, and they rushed us as they anticipated more customers coming in from Dreamforce. 

We got the Pho with beef and Caramelized Catfish with rice. The pho was barely lukewarm and they really skimped on the beef as well as the noodles. It didn't taste bad, but it didn't taste great either. I much prefer Miss Saigon Pho. The Caramelized Catfish was much better than the Pho but was laden with MSG and oil. Again, portions were smaller than I'd liked. 

Would recommend going down the street to Miss Saigon, as I will not be returning.
author: Claudia C.

description: One of the top 3 pho places i've had in the city. Didn't even know SOMA had good pho places until we found this gem. I would recommend the vegetarian pho for non vegs or vegetarians it was so goood. Literally had all the colors of the rainbow (all veggies) in their yummy vegetable broth and it hits the spot on a rainy, hungover, or sick day.
author: Kunal T.

description: They ran out of the first two choices of pho that I wanted . At first I was bummed but then this led me to an amazing food experience, vegetarian pho!?! This was my first time and it was beyond flavorful and satisfying. Now I get why they ran out of stock , I was very happy with what was available.
author: Carmen M.

description: Great food and service.  Expect long waits for table, especially with odd numbers in your party.
author: EyeYelp N.

description: As always this place does not disappoint. They happily accommodate vegan, gluten free, and sugar free diets. This is our go to spot when we are downtown.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Great Vietnamese food in SoMa, with a clean and modern atmosphere. It's not too crowded around dinnertime, so it's a great place to meet someone after work for a reasonably-priced dinner near downtown.

The menu is pretty standard as far as Vietnamese goes, with pho options, rice plate options, and dry noodle options, though the menu design is notably more minimalist than typical Vietnamese restaurants. In particular, I really like the five-spice chicken rice plate (Add a fried egg!). The chicken skin is crispy while the meat is tender and juicy, and the flavors are awesome and well-balanced. They're also pretty generous with the portions so you should be pretty satisfied with your meal.

The staff is friendly and fun, though no one seems to be actually Vietnamese. Interestingly, this makes the place seem a little "less authentic" (though it could just be perception).

In general, this place is a little higher-end than your regular Vietnamese place, without being fancy or expensive, and manages to be just as delicious!
author: Brittany C.

description:
Came here for dinner with a pho craving. There were only a few seats left on a Fri night and after we were seated, a line started forming outside the restaurant. The location is a few blocks south of Market St. Given the popularity, I had really high hopes.

We ordered spring rolls, pho bo, catfish claypot and a tea. 

First up were the spring rolls. They were good but not as flavorful as our usual pho spot, Mau. Seemed like a lot of noodles and not much else. 

My pho bo was good, but later that evening, I was extremely thirsty, usually a sign of excess salt or MSG :( My bf's catfish claypot was also good but shortly afterwards, we noticed that the claypot wasn't hot which made us wonder was the catfish actually cooked in the claypot??  Usually claypot dishes are piping hot and the server's always warning you to be extremely careful. 

It was beginning to be a pretty busy evening and we still hadn't received our tea by the time we were done. Our server realized this and brought us the tea for free of charge, which was a nice gesture. 

The restaurant is very reasonably priced (~$30 for dinner for 2) and in a convenient location. However, the food was on the salty side and I'm still not quite sure how the catfish was cooked.
author: Yin H.

description: Love this place!  Used to come almost weekly when I was living a mile away. I am here again all the way from the South Bay! Why? Because the broth is just SO YUM!
author: Victor K.

description: I just went to Vietnam (Hanoi, to be exact) a couple of months ago. The dishes we tried here were not only authentic, but some of the things we had were even better than what we had over in Hanoi. Definitely enjoyed the Bun Rieu and the Bun Bo Hue.
author: Kazu O.

description: Soooo good. We got the tin rolls and Pho Bo. You can't go wrong. My husband's not a fan of Vietnamese food and he raved to his friends about this place.
author: Nickie G.

description:
The best VN food I've ever had outside of VN. I had Pho and crispy rolls. Both were great. They even provide pickled onions with the pho - unique and good. 

Update 3/16: Still great! New grilled lemongrass rice roll was fantastic. Fast and caring service. Server took time to listen, make a suggestion, and check in on how it was. That never happens anymore.
author: Eater S.

description: Some of the best Vietnamese food I've had in a long time! Pho Ga, Chicken Vermicelli, and the Camelized Fish over rice were all great!
author: Varun C.

description: I ordered beef over vermicelli and it was alright. A bit overpriced and the flavors not quite authentic. A little too sweet for my taste. Probably would not visit again but they do open until 10pm which is why I was there.
author: Andy W.

description: Can't rave about these guys enough. Special thanks to Hung. I placed a huge to go order here a week or so ago for a friends birthday- serving about 15 people.  They helped me figure out how much food to get and a great variety.  When I showed up they not only had everything packaged and ready to go, they offered to help and happily ran across several lanes on Howard St to help me load my car with the trays.  Such delicious food, but really their service was what was amazing. Will definitely be ordering from them again!
author: Sarah D.

description: I would go back for the Tin rolls which are delicious marinated beef wrapped in rice paper (soft not fried on the outside). Inside the rolls there are crispy pieces of egg roll skin which gives the whole thing a dynamic texture. The pho was pretty satisfying on a gray SF day, but particularly because I got it with beef balls, tendon and tripe, which were each an additional $1.50. Overall I found this place to be an affordable delicious option for dining out in SOMA! Lucky to have this in the neighborhood.
author: Alias A.

description: One of my favorite lunch spots near my work. I get the pork vermicelli bowl without the noodles and it makes the most satisfying salad! So good! I also get the chicken pho without noodles and sub in extra veggies! I eat mostly paleo and this place has several dishes that I can eat with a few small tweaks.
author: Ms. G.

description: Tin where have you bin all my life!!! Ordered the veggie pho and the tofu bahnmi. I was in bahnmi heaven! Its was so good and well balanced. My mouth is watering thinking about it. The soup was delicious as well with the right vegetable to noodles ratio (very important). We also had the mango salad which was so so good! Vegetarians MUST TRY!
author: Ashmita V.

description:
Upscale decor deceives.  Maybe that should have been the tip off

Worst pho ever.  Toughest meat (brisket?)  
I like to chew but it has to lead to some decomposition of the meat.  No such luck here
Broth was more like an oxo cube.   None of subtle flavor I expect
author: Eric B.

description: Deliciousness all around. Spring roll and chicken vermicelli. Down side is the sketchy neighborhood, be mindful where you park and leave no belongings in the car
author: Long C.

description:
A surprise hit! I actually wasn't expecting much since I find that Vietnamese food is just not that great in the area but I actually liked this place.

The inside is totally not what you'd expect for Vietnamese food. The servers are not Vietnamese and the decor is just overall nice.

I got the pho bo soup. The broth was exactly what I was looking for - that complex beef flavor that's slightly sweet. I thought the noodles were a bit skimpy though but the noodle consistency was good. The size of the bowl was not super large considering most Vietnamese places give you gigantic bowls but it was a good size for me. I would definitely get this again. It was like $10 for a bowl.
author: Danielle C.

description: Great service good food! Can't go wrong with anything on the menu even the salads which I almost never say as a carnivore. I got the bun rieu which was good flavoring but wished there were more meat. The pork with lemongrass is amaze!!
author: Y W.

description:
Really great place. Was suddenly craving Vietnamese food, specifically pho and didnt feel like sluming at a dingy place, especially with the company of my friend who is from out of town. Thanks to Yelp, we found this jewel on Howard street. Now the location leaves something to be desired but thats besides the point.

We were seated quickly, despite a few waiting to be seated. Thank you for this btw.  The service was impeccable! I felt like a princess  and give the servers high marks for flawless service. There was both a lady and a gentleman waiting on us tonight.

The crowd is literally melting pot.  Basically everyone.  I saw the techies with their goofy tshirts advertising whatever startup, old people, asians, all the colors in the rainbow. No set age group. Btwn legal and retirement. 

We had the chicken wings and deep fried spring rolls  for appetizers.  And for the main course, my friend had the pho with shrimp and I had the one with mushrooms, eggs, tofu (and perhaps sausage ?) It really doesnt matter.  Everything was absolutely mouthwateringly delicious. I tailored the magical broth with as much chili as my heart desired and ended up sweating like happy stuck pig. We were soon both so stuffed with leftovers to boot. The later consisted of few bits of pho and the magical broth plus 2 errant wings. Lol the food smelled so good that I literally finished my leftovers the minute I got home! This never has happened to me before! 

Thanks so much for making Mondays a little less painful and a great start to the work week. Last but not least, the pricepoint is amazing. $40 for all of this? In the City? Phenom! Thank you! We'll be back soon!
author: Ann S.

description: Outstanding flavor.  Didn't think Vietnamese food could taste so different from other high end restaurants.  Price was very reasonable for san francisco and way cheap for a michelilin star rates restaurant.  Spring rolls were amazing as well as beef cubes.  Place had constant stream of customers.  Will definitely be back.
author: Terry T.

description: Absolutely delicious and fresh dishes, loved it and would recommend. Must try papaya salad, tin rolls and chicken with lemon grass
author: Tom Lee J.

description: I'M NOT A VIETNAMESE FOOD CONNOISSEUR. But if I needed a bowl of pho in SoMa, I'd say this is my go to spot. Being Michelin recommended, you can't really go wrong with a hot bowl of Pho or bun bo hue on a cold, rainy day outside. The broth for the beef pho was very hearty and made my stomach / taste buds happy. I haven't ordered anything else besides the noodles, but everyone had appetizers and stuff so I guess they aight. Also the bun bo hue is spicy so if you're so congested that you can't breathe through your nose, this one is the ultimate decongestant.
author: Alex L.

description: a bit pricey for viet food, but everything we had was delicious.  will return.
author: Henry H.

description:
A very quaint establishment, seating capacity probably 30 people max.  Had a conference just about 1.5 blocks away at the Moscone Center West.

Was a party of 1. Just got there right before the lunch hour rush!! Good thing!!! In a matter of 10 minutes, there was a line waiting outside the door!

I ordered the Phone Ba with tripe as a side. Service was super quick, got my meal in about 5 minutes. They serving portion was just right, perfect for lunch. Pho was served in a 8 inch bowl...

By the time I got my meal, the place was full and a bit noisy. But the food was a great distraction, or should I say diversion...

I would recommend it to all!
author: Dalmacio C.

description: This place has gained a ton of popularity and rightfully so. There's a great variety of Vietnamese food for vegetarians, vegans, and carnivores and everything tastes good. They have a simple menu of appetizers, noodles, rice, pho, and banh mi and many options within each of those categories. The portions are generous and the seasoning is spot-on. It's a casual spot but still cute enough to be a date night spot. It's also good for groups (maybe up to 8 people) because they can push the tables together. Walk-in only, so there can be wait.
author: Naomi P.

description: Though this may be pricey compared to other Vietnamese restaurants, the taste and quality is there to make up for it.  We ordered the Tin Roll based on everyone's review/suggestion.  It was different from what I've been use to.  The Roll had marinated meat stuffed with fresh veggies.  We also ordered the Pho Ga and Shaken Beef.  All of our dishes was delicious.  The broth of the Pho Ga was clean (clear) and very flavorful; one of the best Pho Ga we've had (Sorry Turtle Tower).   The Shaken Beef was tender and seasoned nicely.  The salad that came with the plate was great as well.   We went on a weekday right when it opened so we didn't wait at all to be seated.  Servers were kind and attentive.
author: Jasper B.

description:
This review was a bit hard to write, given that the food is so exceptional, and the staff is so ridiculously unfriendly. There is always a long line to eat here, so get there early. My office is right around the corner so we frequent Tin often, and usually get there around 11:30 (the rush hits around noon). 

The food here is super delicious. My favorite dishes are the five spiced chicken plate (with a fried egg, of course), and the Pho Bo. Their spring rolls are also super good. All of their sauces and broths are super tasty, and the portions are very generous. All in all, the food is a solid 5. 

The service, however, is a around a 3, if not lower (hence the 4 star rating). There are not that many staff members working there at lunch,  and they are consistently unfriendly, and sometimes very rude. We're talking about the server snapping when we ask questions, slamming plates down on the table, and cutting people off when taking orders. It's certainly off-putting that the staff has a miserable demeanor every time we're there. 

Go for the food, but don't expect much from the staff.
author: Regina L.

description:
What I ate: Vegetable pho, shrimp spring rolls
Visit date: March 20, 2014
First time? Yes.

This place has been on my bookmarks list for a while now. I finally got to try it, but since my visit was during my no-meat for Lent diet, I was a little bummed that I couldn't try my fave - Pho Bo. I tried the vegetable pho instead. To my delight, their veggie pho was amazing! If their vegetable broth is any indication of the richness of the beef broth, then I must come again! The vegetable pho had an intense vegetable flavor, and it was filled with a variety of ingredients -- carrots, mushrooms, broccoli (this was the best in the bowl!). Oh, and may I add that in addition to the fresh basil, jalapenos, bean sprouts, and lime served with the pho, they also give you pickled red onion! What a nice addition!

Nothing too special about the shrimp spring rolls (normally made with pork & shrimp), but their sauce is slightly different than traditional peanut sauces. I couldn't quite get my taste buds around the unique flavor so you're going to have to try it for yourself instead. 

The only negatives -- 
My friend and I were seated at a 4-top table, and then asked to move when more guests came in - understandable, but annoying. 
They only had two wait staff for the dinner rush; they needed a third.

I shall return!
author: Erin G.

description: Great value! Dishes can be a little salty, but very tasty overall. Especially like the pork chop over rice. Five spice chicken also very good as is the ciao gao rolls and warm beef salad. I like the pho at places like Turtle Tower better though, although the pho here is definitely better than at Fresh Roll which is down the street.
author: Anthony W.

description:
Located between 5th and 6th street on quiet part of Howard.
It is amazing how much difference half a block makes.
Walk over to 6th street and you know you are in the Tenderloin.

The restaurant decor is modern and the staff were friendly.

This was my first visit and I tried the following:
Cha Goi -  fried spring rolls - Awesome
Grilled lemon grass pork shoulder - Awesome
Caramelized catfish - Pretty good
Bun Bo Hue - Needed to add some chilli sauce and fish sauce to make it sing

I think I have a new favorite Vietnamese restaurant.
author: David T.

description: Bbh super not real.  It's pho broth with some actual ground pepper in it.......what the... It's sweet and tastes nothing like bbh. Noodles way over cooked.
author: Kristine N.

description:
So incredibly satisfied with my hearty, delicious meal from Tin! Yelp brought me here when I was craving something warm and soupy in this weather. 

I'm a huge fan of pho and the broth is always supremely important to me! I ordered the pho bo with rare beef & added beef balls. The soup was unfortunately no longer steaming hot when it came so I couldn't eat the rare beef but really not their fault. The beef balls were juicy and yummy. You can also tell it's a legit Vietnamese place when it comes with a large bundle of raw bean sprouts and mint leaves! 

I was also pleasantly surprised at the spinach & ground pork add-on for like $4-- which I ordered on a whim after assessing the pathetic amount of veggies I've been eating. It was legit!! The spinach was fresh and sweet and generous, and the soup was sweet and tasty without being overly salty or tasting of MSG.
author: Jia L.

description:
Honestly, its hard to find good ole fashioned Vietnamese food here in San Francisco. So I was pleasantly surprised to stumble across Tin while I was walking to Sightglass. It wasn't crowded at all (mostly I suppose b/c it was 2:20 pm) and the server couldn't have been more friendly and helpful.

I got the standard Vermicelli Bowl with Lemongrass Grilled Beef (Bun Thit Bo Nuong). Everything was spot on perfect - the beef was very thin and tender, bursting with flavor. The noodles were fresh and bouncy along with the standard carrot/daikon compliment.
author: Henry W.

description:
WTF ... Why the high yelp ratings?
              I had the Imperial Rolls.
              It was so oily, I thought l was biting into an 
              Oil well. The filling was good, but it was 
              double fried cuz the meat was like warm
              and the roll skin was burnt.

              Seriously messed up
author: Food Sage W.

description:
Upscale and authentic? I truly am impressed that Tins pho is so good. They nailed the broth and the noodles, and you can tell from the freshness of their bean sprouts that they don't take shortcuts. This is probably one of the best beef phos I've had in San Francisco!

I can never get myself to order anything but Pho but last time my friend came and ordered the bun bo hue, and the broth was equally delicious but in a different way. I'm definitely getting that next time.

* BUN BO HUE - 4.5 STARS:
The best bun bo hue in the city. I like to ask for pho noodles because I'm personally not a huge fan of the traditional, larger rice noodles.

* PHO - 4.5 STARS:
Fresh. Satisfying. Delicious. Also one of my favorites in the city.

* LOTUS ROOT SALAD - 5 STARS:
Just the best thing ever. Crunchy, savory, refreshing and light all at once. 

* LEMONGRASS CHICKEN THIGH BUN - 3.5 STARS:
A surprisingly generous portion of chicken thigh but I didn't like the grainy, gingery marinade on the outside of the chicken. Unlike their sister restaurant, Mau, they don't have 5-spice chicken. Boo....+$2 for 3 pieces of grilled prawns, super fresh flavorful and delicious.

* VIETNAMESE ICED COFFEE - 4 STARS:
Super strong and yummy but even when I ask for "light milk" they always use way too much condensed milk. I prefer to ask them to serve the condensed milk separately so I can add it myself.

Prices are surprisingly modest - only $7.50 for a bowl. 

AMEX now accepted!
author: Jess C.

description:
Are you looking for great tasting pho, served within just a few minutes of ordering?  Would you like your order to be taken after you have had ten minutes staring at the menu?  I know I sure do.  However, this place fails in all aspects, and should be disregarded if you have any standards.  Tin is quite possibly the most horrible Vietnamese restaurant I have ever been to.  From the bad service to the equally bad food, I cannot tell you which is worse.  

The GF and I came at 9:15 pm on a Saturday.  There was no worker at the small check-in counter.  We waited for about a minute for someone to approach us, and we were seated at the most dim-lit table, closest to the kitchen.  Normally, figuring out what to order takes such a long time with the GF because she has to check yelp for reviews and photos.  Yet, she did all of this, and still no one would take our order.  If we did not finally manage to flag down someone, we would have never placed our order, and never had food (which, looking back, would not have been a bad thing).  

We decided to order the pho ga and the five spice chicken rice plate.  The food took quite a bit of time to make its way to our table.  However, this was understandable because it had gotten busy since we arrived. 

The pho looked good.  Surprisingly, the ginger broth tasted even better than I thought it would.  The chicken was the only thing wrong with this dish.  The broth could not mask the failure of what could have been a winning dish.  The chicken was extremely dry, to say the least.  .  To paint a picture, imagine taking a few squares of toilet paper from a roll.  Wet the paper with luke-warm water.  Then, squeeze the excess water out.  Now place the paper in your mouth and chew. 

The five spice chicken was equally disappointing.  We added an egg to the dish, which allowed the yolk to make the chicken less dry.  It helped, but could not save the dish.  Hot sauce was needed to downplay the dryness as well.  Some of the chicken was overcooked leading to burnt skin.  

Everything in a dining experience that could go wrong, did. 

On a side note, as we were halfway done eating, a customer walks past our table to make his way to the restroom.  However, he loses balance over the clearly wet, slippery floor.  He just barely escapes from falling and/or breaking his ankle.  I am almost certain no one working seemed to care about the well-being of the man.  Quickly, they ran to get a wet floor sign.  Something tells me, this was just to limit liabilities on their end, should an accident happen.  Otherwise, they would have already had the sign up, knowing that the floor was wet.  

I will pass on Tin. You should too.  There are way better options.
author: Victor L.

description:
"Hi, so, is the shrimp paste a strong taste or some sort of an acquired flavor? Oh, ok, I'll just have pho ga." Oops, please excuse my bad manner for eavesdropping on a question my neighboring table patron was asking the waiter. I should have known, Tin definitely caters Vietnamese flavor to a certain genre here. 

The ambiance would have also been a wonderful clue to the kind of Vietnamese food being served here, everyone seems to be yelling over each other for a conversation, all the while, loud top 40's play in the background, hmm this definitely reminded me of being in a dive bar or some sad nightclub. Nope, we're just at Tin Vietnamese Cuisine.

The pho ga is definitely quite bland and the Bun Rue, totally thin and without much of a soul to that supposedly rich "chicken tomato" broth. All the great flavor of garlic, onion, cilantro, are all absent from the food I've tasted here at Tin's. It felt like all the "acquired flavors" are erased and toned down to appease a certain crowd here, and when I look around, this totally makes sense. Tin Vietnamese Cuisine is basically the Osha Thai of Vietnamese restaurants.  

I do however like the fresh spring roll, they definitely did quite well on this one. I will definitely come back just for the fresh spring roll but not the pho, nor the confusing night-club like ambiance.
author: Taffany H.

description: One of the waiters is nice. There banana cake is not that good. And it is a super small slice. The price of the  broth was fair.
author: Camrie F.

description: My co-workers and I were in town for a conference and we were pleasantly surprised to find this place. Three of us ordered the Bo Kho and one of us ordered the Bun Bo Hue. We split the egg rolls and ordered a baguette. The baguette is fresh out of the oven (so it seems). It was crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside. The flavor a at this place were great and I think this might be my favorite Vietnamese place in the Bay Area. I'm going to try some places in San Jose tomorrow.
author: Yale K.

description:
Tsk, tsk, tsk Tin.  Now mind you I would expect this from any other pho place, but your set-up led me to believe that you may be bougier than most so...I was hopeful.  Why?  Because I can actually rest my elbows on the table without sticking to it!  But damn, I'd rather stick to what I know than come back here again.

What I know with Asian joints is you come for the food, not the service.  They're quick, efficient, direct and do the job:  they feed you.  But your place was NOT at all quick (though they ran around a lot for no apparent reason) or efficient and the only direction I got was where the bathroom was.   We get that you're a small place so if it's busy and we have a party of 6, obviously there'd be a wait.  But...don't say 15-minutes when you really mean 50!  And...don't make it seem like you're doing us any extra favors since we gave you a shot and actually waited.  

We couldn't make any changes (no matter how slight) to our order, we barely got any water and our server acted like we should be serving them.  By the time we got our food, we were so famished we forgot to chew!  And by that point, we couldn't remember whether we even liked our dish!  However, the service was so bad, it left a rather bad taste in my mouth that weeks later...I still remembered enough to write this review.
author: Myrnelle G.

description: I've been here 4-5 times and it's always been consistent! I normally get the Bun Thang which has chicken, egg, pork sausage, shitake mushrooms, fermented shrimp, cilantro, chicken broth for $11. The only downside is that I think it's a bit salty for me. I do crave it from time to time though.
author: Natalie C.

description:
Disappointed, that's the least I can say... The pho was not good at all. I'm half-Vietnamese and I've been eating pho forever! The pho had no taste, and for a real pho Dac Biet, you had to pay for the extra pieces of meat.. The waiter aren't even smiling. I had to wait long before my order came. The place was also noisy and didn't have the Vietnamese feel you can have in other places. The only good thing here was the 'com xuong nung' (the pork and rice) but even then you had to pay for the eggs...
For a real Vietnamese place, with a real Vietnamese feel and a good pho, go two blocks away at Miss Saigon!
author: Nicolas G.

description:
Probably the closest taste to home. I was born in Vietnam and I've never taste anything closer to home than the food that was made here! 

Recommend getting the grill pork rice plate!
author: Duc H.

description:
Chicken wings were nuts! I love wings and these were nice and crispy. Meat was nice and tender. Loved it.

Pho was good too!
author: Keri V.

description:
Tin is the opposite of every single Vietnamese restaurant in existence: it's clean, trendy, and my waitress was wearing Taylor Swift Keds. 

We started with the springs rolls and mango salad, which were good, but not anything spectacular. 

I had had pho just a few days earlier, so I got a 5-Spice Chicken sandwich, which comes with pickled daikon and carrots, cucumber, cilantro, and mayonnaise. It costs more than one of the Vietnamese sandwiches you can grab from a more traditional Vietnamese restaurant and not nearly as good, but it'll do if you're in a bind.

Nothing that I ate blew my mind, but it was satisfactory, and everyone around me seemed to be enjoying themselves. Maybe I'm just too picky.
author: Christina S.

description:
Way overdue review. 

Their food is solid. The restaurant itself is pretty small, but very clean and posh-feeling. Reasonable prices, though. 

Excellent vietnamese coffee. 

Good papaya salad and rolls -- start with those. Their pho and noodle dishes are great, but what stands out is their claypot dishes. Love their fish claypot -- caramelized fish filet over rice. Yum. 

The wait can be long since the restaurant is tiny.
author: Michelle K.

description: Delicious Vegetarian pho & bok choy! The lemon ginger tofu looked awesome as well. The flavor of the broth was super savory and fresh. This is a quaint, casual but refined restaurant. If I was local this would be my pho spot!
author: Jessie V.

description: One of our favorite Vietnamese restaurants. We love the atmosphere and the service is great! The food is a little pricier than other, more traditional Vietnamese restaurants and the portions are smaller but the quality and flavor is really good. The pho and grilled pork chop plates are out go-to dishes here. Definitely recommend! :)
author: Jamie K.

description: Delicious. I can't say enough good things about this place. Everything on the menu tastes good!
author: Kristen S.

description: This place is such a gem! Very close to our hotel in Union Square. We had the vermicelli noodle bowl, pho and the pork sandwich and the house spring rolls. Every bite we had was fantastic. The only complaint was the service it was not very welcoming. The food and price def made up for the lack of service.
author: Katherine G.

description: I don't understand the long lines for lunch. Prices high in comparison to other traditional VN restaurants. Entrees not classic but blended fusion of Asian and American tastes so trendy today on both coasts. This one is good, tasty but nothing special. Fresh rolls were fresh, that was it. Pho ga was average for an America chain noodle shop, noodles were pho but undercooked and al-adente, way to firm for good pho, chicken was overdone white meat. Caramelized catfish you won't find in VN, and was very good. It seems I am in minority in saying Tin is average at best, but too many better choices in area for real spicy, real Vietnamese.
author: John S.

description:
tin is one of my favorite lunch spots in soma! it's located a very short walk from my office, on howard between 5th and 6th. the space is pretty large and can accommodate larger parties pretty easily as long as you get there early!

my go-tos are the Pho Ga (chicken pho in a ginger chicken broth, $9) and the Hu Tieu (pork, chicken and shrimp in a garlic-chicken broth, $10). i also add vegetables (carrots and broccoli) for an extra $1.50. for appetizers, i would recommend the spring rolls and the cha gio!

definitely go BEFORE noon, because once noon rolls around, prepare to wait. we usually head over around 11:30 and get seated immediately, but by the time we leave there's always a line out the door!
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Amazing papaya salad. ...can't go wrong on this place need one in Miami .
Went 3 out of 6 days visited
author: Geno B.

description:
This is a Pho place, and as such it excels. Food is very tasty, service is friendly, interior design is simple and clean.

If you like Vietnamese cuisine and are attending a major conference in the Moscone Center, note that at dinnertime this is one of the closest restaurants that are far enough not to be too crowded at 5-6PM. Will definitely return on a similar occasion. This is not a romantic place or a high-end French-Vietnamese outfit, but it feels quite upscale for its league (no tablecloths and other fancy stuff, naturally). 

The prices are quite reasonable, $9-$13 for good appetizers and main dishes at dinnertime. Appetizer (roll) portion felt quite large, sharing might be a good idea, black tea was excellent.
author: Dmitri V.

description: VERY crowded at lunch. Best is to order via OrderAhead and then it's a snap. They do a nice job of packaging pho to go, which isn't the easiest thing to do well.
author: Jane M.

description: Honestly one of the better spots in the empty soma area! Was surprised by how packed it was and how flavorful the broth was! Ordered the brisket soup (very heavy!) the first time and the vegetarian pho (meh wouldn't recommend) the second. Affordable, quick and pretty good - rare to find around this area in soma :)
author: Taryn Q.

description:
This quaint pho restaurant is a really great eatery in the SOMA district where you wouldn't expect to find quality food.  Surrounded by odds and ends stores and automobile detailing/maintenance garages, and you would not think t look for an upscale pho shop tucked between these businesses even though Mission St. is so prominent and has heavy foot traffic. 

I like to come here for a late lunch during the workday to avoid the busy lunch crowd, but they do stop serving at 3pm to prepare for their dinner service which is a bit unconventional for a pho place, so keep in mind that there are designated lunch and dinner hours and it doesn't operate through the day. 

Tin Vietnamese is living proof that authentic pho can be served at a place that isn't a run down hole in the wall with cheap vinyl covered chairs, wobbly tables, and unclean utensils.
author: Kathy T.

description: This place was great.  Pho broth was subtly flavored and noodle was not soggy.  Their specialty roll had tasty pork and fresh veggies but a little oily for my taste.  But everything was delicious!
author: Haeran K.

description: Nice surprise in a somewhat hairy part of town. As others said, I wouldn't park here but I'd definitely eat here again. Just a few minutes walk from both Market St. And Caltrain. I had the "veggie bun" noodle bowl, which was like a deconstructed bun with crispy tofu, veggies, lots of noodles, and a flavorful sauce.
author: Andrew S.

description: There was a crazy line outside shortly after we were seated. I don't see too many Vietnamese restaurants that would require that kind of a wait. I ordered the chicken pho, which had a great broth. The shredded white meat was a tad dry. I would order it again though.
author: Huey N.

description:
Love:
- Vermicelli noodle bowl with lemongrass-chili chicken thigh
- 5-spice chicken rice plate
- Chicken broth

Dislike:
- Car got broken into :(
author: Michelle W.

description:
This is one of the best Vietnamese places I've found in the area. It's a great place to go if you're looking for a quick and cheap meal. It's a small shop so it can get pretty crowded around dinnertime.

The Pho Bo was fantastic. The meet is still pink when they serve it and it cooks in the broth within seconds. The noodles have a great consistency and the broth is very flavorful, salty with a hint of sweetness.

The spring rolls were surprisingly big, filled with fresh ingredients. The peanut sauce was different from the kind that I'm used to and the rolls are large enough that you'll a lot of sauce.

The waiter recommended the lemongrass pork shoulder to us and I was definitely pleased. The meat had a great slightly charred flavor to it and the picked carrots went very well with the pork and rice.

The next time I'm craving Vietnamese I'm definitely coming back!
author: Richie Z.

description: Not bad! We tried the Shaken Beef, which comes with rice. It's a bit of a "hole in the wall" restaurant, on a street that is slightly deserted. But that is obviously not a deterrent for most since this place is always packed whenever we come. It seems like you can't go wrong with any menu choice though, be it Pho or Vermicelli. The food quality is fresh and flavorful, and the prices reasonable. I am always full when I leave (unlike at Freshroll @Metreon). The only problem is that this restaurant has odd hours sometimes. It's similar to SO and Golden Gate Bakery in that there are days they're closed, when they would normally be open.
author: Connie L.

description: We walked in this place 30 min before closing on a Thursday night, and it was was wall to wall packed. That was a good sign. Kind of a hipster vibe, good ambiance. I ordered the pork shoulder with rice and my wife ordered the lemon grass chicken thigh vermicelli. Both were cooked to perfection. Amazing quality food for such a low price (approx $10 each). Service was meh, but I give them a pass because it was so busy.
author: Tomo T.

description: We had a very good lunch! They told us they don't use MSG. Ate the Bun Cha Ha Noi and also got the baby back choy with garlic. We were surprised that they actually used the REAL baby bak choy which is the most tender part of the vegetable. Cooked perfectly, still crunchy but not raw. Delicious!
author: P N.

description: Stopped in for lunch today and was extremely impressed.  Menu was extensive and the food didn't disappoint.  It was absolutely delicious, and the staff was very friendly.  I got there right when it opened and the place filled up fairly quickly, so get there early if you don't want to wait.  Highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Jarrod H.

description:
Came here for lunch at work one day and there was a line of about 6 people ahead of us. We were still seated in about 15 minutes, which is pretty impressive for a small place at lunch rush. Our service was very quick and no frills, and it was clear that they were trying to get people in and out as quickly as possible with the way they were interacting with us. 

I got the pho bo, which comes with the standard pho toppings as well as pickled red onions, which I enjoyed a lot. I think that the broth here is very flavorful and rich, without being overwhelming. However, the portion is VERY small and seems overpriced at $10. Next time I'll try one of their other rice or noodle dishes as they seem to be very popular.
author: Amy Y.

description: There is nothing more that bothers me than when classic Viet food takes a trendy spin just because it's in a cool part of the city. I came here a little skeptical, but was pleasantly surprised. I got the lotus salad, and although I do think it was overpriced for what I was served, it was good. The prices are standard relative to all the other places in San Francisco, but still, it's high for Viet food.
author: Steph V.

description:
Review isn't for in-house dining but, for a delivery me and the roomie had via Postmates. I ordered Pho Bo, he ordered their Vegetarian Pho. We also ordered two Vietnamese coffees, iced. 

I've been spoiled in Seattle with good Pho broths, fresh vegetables and great noodles. In SF its been harder going. One place bland broth, another old veg, another old tasting broth/stock, another overcooked noodle, etc, etc, and so forth. Always something off. HOWEVER, I am pleased to report absolutely nothing was "off" here. Everything was most definitely ON.  

We were pleased with the food itself, portion size, price and the fact it was packaged to go neatly including vegetables/garnishes, chopsticks and condiments (little cups with hoisin and chili). Hey, it's the details that count! I can't tell you how many places leave out the sprouts/lime entirely with nary a chopstick to be found! But not here. 

 Everything was super fresh and the attention to detail both in the food and in the packaging to go was first rate and very appreciated.  

We will definitely be back to eat on location!
author: Liss T.

description: Looking forward to coming back. This is where I had Pho for the first time and now I'm in love. My waiter was helpful in helping me decide how to jump in. The Papaya salad was wonderful and I can't wait to try more items at my next visit.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Bun bo hue 
Pho bo
Both were Great. Western style Vietnamese and done surprisingly well
Ok service 
Don't park in the area
author: Jones T.

description: One of my favorite places in sf!!! Food is so delicious and in large size. I've been there twice and will definitely treat it as a cafeteria whenever I visit that area. Most likely a fixed meal place whenever I go shopping in Westfield lol.
author: Xiaochen Z.

description: I feel a little guilty giving only 3 stars to Tin. But in the end, I only kind of liked my lunch. Bun vermicelli w/chicken. It was VERY oniony and very lemony. Guess what? Not to my taste.  Seems like a nice place but I love Vietnamese food and on,y tolerated this.
author: gary g.

description:
Kind of a crazy spot during lunch - it was totally mobbed when we first arrived. Servers were curt and not really friendly, even after the place emptied out. 

We got Bun Bo Hue (spicy beef) and Bun Rieu (seafood and tomato soup). My soup came out hot and was pretty tasty - a bit like spaghetti soup, especially with the super yummy meatballs. My buddy's soup wasn't as hot, but was just the right amount of spicy to make up for it. My soup lost its edge a ways through, so I added sriracha, but it was good all around. 

Bummed that the experience was so poor, considering the food was pretty good.
author: Jacob S.

description:
This is one of the most authentic Vietnamese place I've eaten at in San Francisco-except the pho bowl. Besides that, the spicy beef, "Bun Bo Hue" and "Bun Rieu" are two great choices if you're craving a soup bowl. For a more hardly dish get their five spice chicken or Bun Bo Nuong.

This place earned a Michelin recommendation which may be why it's packed during dinner time. Not too much of a wait as the service is good and your order comes to the table quickly.
author: Brad N.

description:
My bf lives 3 minutes away from here. He's been wanting to try since they've open. We were lazy to cook so we decided to stop in. It was super busy!!! 20 min wait @ 6. Reasonable. We waited and were seated. I suggest while you wait you take a look at the menu and decide what you like. 

For apps we had the shrimp and plumb dip. The dip wasn't what i thought it would be. It was good though. I was expecting sweeter? I think they should change the name to sweet and sour dipping sauce though because it pretty much tasted that way.
