I ordered the shaken beef. Its 12$ but it is worth it! You get salad, chunks of beef, onion and red and green bell pepper, brown rice(or white) and lemon pepper dipping sauce. IT WAS THE SHIT. I highly recommend.

My bf ordered the hu trieu pho. Or something...it was okay. I'm not really a soup fan because I feel like its so easy to do at home. It has garlic broth and it tasted nice.

I was really surprised at how modern looking it was. Its a real hip place. Too hipster for me. I like foreign gems. Kinda turned me off. But it was clean. I like the cool lights up top. Only thing is They need to make the chalk board more appealing to the eye. Maybe get someone who has an artistic touch.

Wouldn't come again but nice to try.
author: Lynn C.

description: Bon Bo Hue... Very tasty if you enjoy spicy. Only thing is that it doesn't come out HOT, its mostly warm. Good place though! Vermicelli bowls are off the hook too. You'll enjoy it.
author: Josue O.

description:
Pretty good Vietnamese food--definitely catered toward the young, hip, and non-Vietnamese audience. The atmosphere is nice, which probably makes it a higher-end place. I thought the pho was nothing special for the price. It came with picked sides, which was super unusual... The service was just OK; we had to go find a server after a while because they weren't filling up our water and didn't drop off the bill after a while.

Solid three stars. Will come back and try other dishes!
author: Melissa K.

description:
5 Stars for the food, 1 Star for the service. A total of 2 Stars, however, because a 2-Star review would mean "Meh. I've experienced better." in Yelp lingo, while a 3-Star review would mean "A-OK.", and while I think 2-Stars is a bit harsh, I can't rate my review 3 Stars because no, my experience was not "A-OK." 

I've been here at least a dozen times, and while I get that the service is pretty terrible, I keep coming back because the food is so good.

So earlier tonight, while at work, I decided to use EAT24 to order food for myself and a few coworkers, and I walked the 15 minutes or so [one-way] to pick up the order. Yes, it is far considering the abundance of food options in the area I work in, but I was more than willing to walk since the food is so good, and my coworkers were enthusiastic in trying it out.

I was quoted about 30 minutes, and it was ready right as I got there and I was out the door in about a minute. Nice. I walk the 15-minute walk back to work, only to discover that one order was missing. I call Tin and right away the man over the phone said yes, they do have it. Okay, great. It's a 30-minute round-trip, and now I need to repeat that trip, so about an hour of walking total.

I finally get there, the man recognizes me, and hands me the food. He says: "sorry about that", and walks away to attend to more orders, because it was really busy (Saturday night, 7:30pm). I stood there, waiting for him to come back, because I was hoping they'd make it up to me somehow. Yes, the man didn't know that I had to walk as far as I had to in order to come here. Yes, I could've waited longer and remain in the way for servers coming and going from the kitchen, for him to notice me and ask me if something was wrong. I left because I had to get back to work ASAP (since I was no longer on my break), and because I felt like he wouldn't do anything anyway. So I left, feeling defeated.

While I will return in the future, I won't go out of my way like I did tonight to come here. I never had any expectations for the service here, or lack thereof, and thought that my low expectations would shield me from disappointment, but I was mistaken.

Tin, if something like this happens to another customer of yours, please try to make it right. There are times when merely correcting your mistake is not enough; sometimes, more is needed. You should not have to wait for customers to complain to you for you to make something right. In my case, you were clearly in the wrong (could you have called me instead of waiting for me to call you, perhaps saving me time and frustration? Because as soon as I called, the man immediately acknowledged that they do have it--he didn't even have to look for it), so there's no reason for you to not try to make it up to me, like maybe throw in a Vietnamese-style iced-coffee? Something. Anything. I'm easy to please.

Or maybe you guys know people like me will always come back because your food is so damn good? Ugh. Clever Tin...
author: Bobby M.

description: good place for some vegetarian pho. service was great
author: A P.

description: The pho bo was in an unusually small bowl. The slices of beef are very round, regular, and were relatively tough. At first I did not notice the noodles. It turns out that they were all clumped into a ball at the bottom of the bowl. I did not like the presentation of the pho. I enjoyed the sourness of the broth, I was not sure if that was the extra lime I put in or that it was a bit sour to start with.
author: James S.

description:
yelp asked me - "you've checked in here twice! what keeps you coming back?"

well yelp, the answer to that question is legit bun bo hue! i wouldn't call it very traditional, but it's spicy and the noodles are enjoyably chewy and slurp-worthy. 

also, the shrimp spring rolls are soooo good! i'm not usually a fan of spring rolls or egg rolls because i feel like it just fills you up and detracts from enjoying the main course of the meal. however, the ones here are different - you MUST get the 6 bite-sized morsels and you MUST dip in the accompanying peanut sauce (add spice!) that will blow you away.

it's not a particularly large place, and service tends to be a bit slow. so if coming here for dinner, expect some sort of short wait (less than 20 minutes) on most nights.

prices can be a tad higher than vietnamese food anywhere else in the city, but is expected in soma. at least it's not cash only.
author: Yiwen S.

description:
Some of the best pho that I've found in the city! "Pho bo" is my go-to on the menu. (I know I'm not alone in this.) They won't seat you until your whole party is there, so don't invite your slow friends. I love the lighting in this place.

Apparently it's pronounced "fuh" but nobody will fault you for saying "fo"
author: Andrew R.

description:
Easily the best Vietnamese restaurant I have been to. 

Vegetarian roll was a bomb . 
Vegetarian pho was flavorful and tasty .

Will go again .
author: Krishnan S.

description:
We were giving a friend a tour of SF when I noticed on Yelp that a few people mentioned this place had "a lot" of vegetarian options, so we decided to stop here. It was a Tuesday and there was plenty of parking within the block on Howard street. ***side note: after our meal we returned to our car to find the back window was smashed in. Just something to be aware of when parking in this area!!**** (Update: after looking at other reviews, it looks like other people have had the same problem with their cars being broken into on this street. I'd highly recommend taking public transportation when coming here!! Not worth the hassle of replacing a window)

The inside of the restaurant is cute and is lit with a nice ambiance. They had a good mix of music playing, somewhat loudly. Once I looked at the menu, I could pick out about 4 vegetarian items easily (which is a pretty big deal to me, considering I usually struggle finding a Vietnamese joint with veggie options in the heart of SF). My only complaint on this matter is that it would have been helpful if they had a vegetarian section so that I didn't have to dig through all of the menu to figure out my options... 

The items I tried were: the Papaya Salad (veggie version), Firecracker shrimp, Vegetarian Pho and Vegetarian Bun. 

-The Papaya Salad was so good, even the meat eaters at the table were loving it. The sauce could have been a little spicier, but it had a good amount of tamarind flavor to it as well, which I loved! Lots of chiffonade-d basil and peanutty goodness too. I found myself drinking spoonfuls of the sauce leftover after we finished the salad. I would definitely order this again and have it as a meal to myself :) It was my favorite item and I give it 5 stars *****

-The Firecracker Shrimp were alright. I don't really care for shrimp much these days, but the dipping sauce flavor and crispiness of the wrappers were yummy. They were cooked well and tasted good, but I probably wouldn't order again. 4 stars ****

-The Vegetarian Pho was light and delicious. We took half to-go and finished it the next day and it still tasted great. I feel that it could have had more veggies going on though, to give it more substance. The broth could have been more flavorful, but we usually add a ton of lime, Hoisin and Sriracha anyway. Tasted like maybe it was broth from a box... I would order this again though because it was good! 4 stars ****

-The Vegetarian Bun was pretty good as well. It was my first time trying vermicelli, or any noodles without broth. There was delicious tofu (so so good and flavorful), mushrooms, lettuce, basil, and a few other pieces of veggies, as well as a small dish of sauce to pour over. I found myself wishing there was more of the sauce, as the flavors didn't seem to coat all of the contents of the bowl. I took my leftovers home and it was actually better the following day, in my opinion, after it marinated in the fridge overnight. All the flavors really meshed together. I'd probably order it again sometime, and I give this dish 4 stars ****
author: Jeni S.

description: Zero star is not possible so I will give "one" star. As a Vietnamese cuisine, this place is an embarrassment to Vietnamese all around. This place seems to cater for Americans taste--which is tasteless and not authentic. I had "bun bo hue" and it tasted like blended pho. It had no flavor of Bun Bo Hue. A bowl costed $11.50 which is way too expensive and tasteless. I got fooled by the rating. This place has good rating, which I'm sure it was rated by Americans who doesn't know anything about the authenticity of Vietnamese food.
author: David L.

description:
I would come back just for their bun bo hue. I came with my AWESOME DATE at around 6pm and there was no wait. We left a little past 7pm on a Tuesday night and almost all the tables were filled with like 6+ people waiting outside, so be prepared to wait!

Canh Ga Chien $8.50 - I would probably skip this, I liked Miss Saigon's version of this fried chicken dish better... It was a bit too salty and didn't have enough flavor IMO. There were like 8 small-middle sized wings, fyi.

Bun Bo Hue $9.00 - Probably one of the best bun bo hue I've had from a restaurant. I asked them to make it extra spicy and it turned out to be a perfect amount of spice for me!

Bo Kho $9.00 - My friend got this and the broth was sooo good! It almost tasted like home.

Service was fine and overall value was great! Usually Vietnamese food in SF is more expensive so I was pretty satisfied minus the fried chicken wings.
author: Andy T.

description: The pho here was very very good! I was very surprised at the caliber of their pho since I haven't had any that good since leaving Houston. The prices were also not that expensive and the wait staff was pleasant too. The only thing I have to say against it is that it gets so crowded sometimes that sometimes they have to seat you at the same table as two other strangers. I can't say my friend or I have ever done this before and it is a little strange to be sitting right next to somebody you don't know for the entire meal instead of having the standard 2 feet of space between tables. But I shouldn't spend too much time on this anyways because the pho was very good. Seriously you have to try it cause it did not disappoint me!
author: Itzak H.

description: I can't break out of the habit of ordering the same Pho every time. It's so fucking reliable and delicious. I just want to bathe in it sometimes.
author: Dora C.

description:
Since I was out of bread at home and couldn't make a sandwich, I decided not to bring a lunch to work for a change and venture out somewhere in the neighborhood. So, I took to Yelp for some assistance. 

In comes Tín. I'm not a pho connoisseur, but I've taken a liking to it as a fresh option for eating out. Tín definitely didn't disappoint. Though the price is a bit higher than what I'm used to paying at my usual pho spot, the visit was still worth it. I stuck to the basics (spring roll appetizer, Pho Ga with added beef balls). The ginger-chicken broth was...how shall I put it...HELLLLAAAA bomb! About half way through, I found my nose practically running laps around the corner with the crackhead that was yelling at me down the street. 

The provided veggies were crisp and the added beef balls were cooked just right and peppered with some extra flavoring. The spring rolls were as fresh as I've ever had. The staff, unlike many other pho spots I've been to, did not try to rush me with my order/check. Despite being pretty busy (I went on a Friday around 1:00 pm), they were attentive to my table and still pleasant.

Would I go back? Sure!
author: Kevin G.

description: Might have caught them on a bad day. Service was terrible and, with plenty of good food with good service in this city, I don't see them lasting much longer if they keep this up.
author: Shreya C.

description: Fair prices, delicious vegetarian pho. Service has always been good. Food consistently delicious.
author: Kayla B.

description:
Best. Pho Bo. Ever.  

And almost everything on the menu is great including the ice coffee.  Gets very busy/loud when they first open, so if you want a quiet lunch go after 1p.m.
author: P R.

description:
My SF friend and I had lunch here. There were no available restaurants close to Moscone so we ended up in this restaurant. 

Toilet was disgusting. Filthy toilet = clean food? The SF health department must inspect this place. The whole place did not look clean too. 

Bad service. The front person was a bitchy guy. 

Slow service. The server explained that they were short staffed today. Okay, fine but we waited for almost 45 minutes! I've waited shorter than 30 minutes in fine dining restaurants. But here? WTH! 

Food is not bad but there are equal or better restaurants around according to my friend. 

One star is being too generous for this restaurant. 

If you do not mind the bad and slow service, disgusting toilets, okay food then come here. 

As for me and my friends, we will NEVER be back here.
author: Alex P.

description:
Just ok.  The papaya salad was sharp and tasty, but quite small. That's fine, as it was an appetizer, but for $9?

I got the medley pho (forget the name, but it had all the meat), and it did not have much of all the meat.  The broth was real flavorful, tho.
author: Lucy G.

description:
Tin goes beyond expectations and stays under budget!

We shared among 3 people:
1. Bun Bo Hue ($9 beef and pork noodle with broth, exceedingly generous portions)

2. Bun Bo Nuong ($9 noodle with stuffed beef rolls), also generous portions)

3. Spring Rolls Appetizer ($6.50 for 6pc and having hand-made these at home before, I have to give props for the wrapping technique. It was so well-made that I couldn't even pull the shrimp out as I was allergic to shrimp)

I would recommend getting all three dishes above because of the care and quality that were put into the making and presentation of the food. Definitely a place you want to show your friends who are in town. The atmosphere was also very relaxing and the server came by three times to check on us even though it was very busy (at 7pm).
author: Shelley C.

description:
Yay to this restaurant!

Delicious food. Their "Hu Tiu Kho" is slightly better than the ones I always have in San Jose. Fresh ingredients. Cute store. Adorable waiter!

Parking SUCKKKKKKS. I blame...

actually I don't know who to blame for that. So. 5 STARS!
author: Don N.

description:
***Definitely a 4.5 star restaurant in my book!***

When I am away from home, I really seriously crave comfort food.  Growing up eating pho 12 months out of the year, I had the urge to seek out some delicious Vietnamese cuisine.  Tin had some reviews and pictures so I ended up making my way to Howard Street for pho.  Tin is pretty close to the Metreon and Yerba Buena Gardens so if you're in this area and want Viet food, come to Tin!

At first, it looked like Tin was closed because they don't have the crazy, flashy, neon signs that a lot of Asian restaurants gravitate towards.  I noticed the clean and simple decor and thought "Wow, this is one fancy and non-sticky Viet place!"  The menu was simple and not clustered like many Viet places.  Downside was that they didn't have pictures.  I ordered the pho with beef balls ($8.50) and a plate of chicken wings ($8).  My partner-in-crime ordered the Hu Tieu ($.8.50), which came with a variety of meat and shrimp (loved the broth).  Our soy-garlic chicken wings were nice and crispy on the outside, but moist and juicy on the inside.  When you first look at them, they may seem overcooked, but they really aren't.  SO GOOD.

One thing that made me scratch my head a little was why the option of adding beef balls to my pho cost me an extra $1.  They really only give you two whole beef balls cut into halves (so that it looks like you got 4 beef balls). *EDIT*  People!  I am talking about meat balls here, not testicles hahah!  Just wanted to clarify!  Been getting messages about this part of my review. *EDIT*

Anyway, I'm definitely a fan of Tin and will be coming back the next time I'm in the area.  GOOD FOOD AND GOOD SERVICE!
author: May W.

description:
I'm going to start off saying this is a nice little place that has a decent number of patrons even on a Monday night so they do have a following.  

However, it took 30 minutes for my lemongrass chicken vermicilli noodle salad to arrive.  I was starving and seeing stars.  Most vietnamese places takes 5-10 minutes to bring this out. 

Secondly, the lemongrass chicken tasted nothing like traditional lemon grass chicken.  Instead it was covered in some soysaucey brown sauce that completely overpowered the rest of the ingredients and dressing.  

My boyfriend ordered their beef pho and they forget to include the beef balls.  They did bring it out later in a little bowl after we mentioned this to our waiter.  He said it was pretty good.  Of note, good luck waving down a waiter.  They tend to busily walk by you without much of a glance despite several attempts to wave at them.

Just ok in my opinion, if you got an hour to waste then come here.  Maybe another dish would be better than the vermicilli lemongrass chicken dish.  I just don't like it when they don't follow traditional recipes.  Or if you change it, at least tell us in the menu.
author: Yue L.

description: This is my favorite place to eat if i'm working late or want a break from whole-foods for lunch. Its delicious and cheap and good for groups and outings. I usually get the banh ga xa, which is the vermicelli chicken and lemongrass salad bowl. Yum! The rice paper-rolls are really good (fried and fresh), papaya salad, beef salad, pho, and the chili lemon grass chicken with an egg. Also the ginger beer they have is yum to and really authentic. It can get busy at lunch time but the wait isn't long they also do take away. I come here once a week its that good.
author: Sian S.

description:
I'm a vigilante on restaurant cleanliness and one of the first things I look for is the hygiene score near the entrance. 

When I couldn't find it prominently displayed at Tin my suspicion arose. I decided to look it up online and it's no good. Horribly low I have to say. 

So my advice to the management is instead of trying to hide it, make an effort to improve on it. It really shouldn't be that hard? 

As for the food, I do enjoy it. Maybe a little less MSG?
author: Ernest Y.

description: Picked up to go order Saturday night and 1 of the 2 items was wrong.  Called that night and was told to go in to get it taken care of.  Went there today and the manager went above and beyond just refunding me the 1 item.  Love great customer service, and will definitely be back for more of their great food.
author: David H.

description: Came here around 7pm on a Thursday with four other coworkers. We got seated immediately! We ordered cha gio (egg rolls) which were delicious but be careful, they are served really hot. We also ordered tofu spring rolls for my vegetarian coworker and she enjoyed it! The papaya salad was a bit on the spicier end but it wasn't bad. My beef pho was good, but the broth could've been better. My coworkers vegetarian pho had good broth too! Not bad, but probably won't return until the next Dreamforce :p
author: Amanda C.

description:
Comparable to Mau in the mission -- modern and upscale vietnamese food! 

My favorite item is the Bun Thit Bo Nuong and I haven't been able to find the dish anywhere else in the city. It's grilled lemongrass beef rolls stuffed with carrots and onions over a vermicelli noodles and raw veggies! So yummy!
author: Xinxin W.

description: Best broth I've ever had in a Vietnamese restaurant, and really killer service to boot.
author: Mykala C.

description:
Came here after work for dinner with a friend.  There was a slight line when I got there at 6, but we ended getting seated promptly only being 2.  Nothing fancy about the interior, but it was clean and above average for Vietnamese restaurants.  We ended up getting two starters and an entree and sharing them.  

The first starter was the Lotus Root Salad.  This was a good dish, and pretty hardy for a salad.  The poached pork and shrimp give it a good protein boost, and the finish sauce vinaigrette was well executed, not over powering the other flavors.  

The 5-spice quail was delicious and fried well.  However, the lack of meat on it was noticeable.  

The final dish was the braised pork with twice cooked egg and a fried egg on top.  This dish was so flavorful and rich.  Right up my alley.  A bit on the salty side, but you should expect it from this type of dish.  The sweet/salty  broth went well with the egg and the pork was braised to tenderness that require a couple of hours in a slowcooker.  Just dump your rice in the claypot and start eating! haha.

Price was reasonable, and service was okay.  I feel that the food here is pretty authentic in the sense that they stay true to flavors, although execution my be more modern (twice cooked egg).  I would come back to try some of their noodle soups.

YUM!
author: Veasna H.

description:
So the past few times I have been here it was a good experience. And then we have today. Our server was kind of an ASS and seriously if you do not like dealing with people the get out of a Customer Service facing job. We were a party of 4 and two people with us has never been to the restaurant before, so of course questions were asked about certain dishes. The server, a short White Male with a buzz haircut and dirty blond hair, was pretty snippy and visibly irritated with our party guests questions about the dishes. Fast forward 30 minutes later when the table next to us who had been seated well after we were received their lunch and we were still waiting. The server then came up to tell us there was a "computer glitch" and the cooks were working on our food. We tried to wait patiently as all other tables around us got their food and people waiting got seated. Finally I had to ask for someone to check on our food. Eventually the good came out and as we proceed to voice our concern, the server cut us off in mid sentence to tell us 2 of the soups would be deducted. That's great and much appreciated, but I think that's not what really bothered us. It was the servers attitude. There was no apology for the delay or empathy for us literally being at our table for an hour before food was delivered. 

Great food. Horrible horrible service.
author: Mark V.

description: First off, so over priced. The vermicelli is pretty good, but the spring rolls are horrible. I wouldn't go back because I can get Bette  vermicelli somewhere else. The spring rolls ($7.50) are super dry and they literally taste like rice cake with random fillings. The Bun Thit Nuong vermicelli ($10.35) isn't bad, but it gets a little too sweet.
author: Esther Y.

description:
Some friends and I got a late start but, needed to find food before getting straight to the bars.  We walked into this dive bar place that got great reviews nearby.  Once we walked in, we realized that the reviews must have only been for the drinks, because not one person had food in front of them.

We opted to keep moving.  Luckily we stumbled across Tin.  Tin was exactly what we needed.  Still open, quick, cheap, and very filling.  I know everyone says the service can be lax.  Not for us.  It was later in the evening before closing time so we had Tin's full attention.

My Order:
Pinot Noir / Seaglass '10, Sonoma, CA
Spring Rolls / poached pork & shrimp, vermicelli, mint, peanut dipping sauce
Hu Tieu / xa-xiu pork, chicken & shrimp, ground pork in garlic-chicken broth

The spring rolls were fine.  Very fresh and similar to spring rolls I have had elsewhere.  The peanut sauce was better than most though.  I was in love with the Hu Tieu.  I'm not sure what the official difference between the Hu Tieu and Pho Bo that my friends got is but, they are very similar soup dishes and served with the same accompaniments.  Personally I enjoyed the garlic chicken broth and shrimp in my tasty delight compared to the Pho Bo.  Both were delicious though.

My only regret is not having enough room in my stomach to fit more.
author: Scotty C.

description: Pork sandwich was delicious. The meat was very flavorful and exactly what I was looking for. Spring rolls also refreshing and tasty with a peanut sauce that doesn't overpower the fresh favors of the roll.  The Chicken Pho is pretty gingery, but not too much so it's tasty and perfect for a rainy day (or a hangover for that matter).
author: D C.

description:
This was the first Vietnamese restaurant I've eaten at in SF. Being Viet, I had high expectations. I had the bun bo hue, pho bo, spring rolls and papaya salad.
I was thoroughly impressed with the papaya salad, lots of sriracha and awesome spiciness. The spring rolls were good but the sauce for it could have been better. 
Bun Bo Hue was a super highlight (although there could be more greens that came with it). The Pho broth was on the sweeter side but still delicious! Definitely coming back.
Nice ambience compared to many other Vietnamese restaurants!
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
There's no shortage of Vietnamese food in this neighborhood, but Tin is a great option. The last couple of times I've been, I've only had chicken pho along with appetizers/sids like fried spring rolls and greens of the day. The steaming bowl of pho is to be expected - big bowl of noodles with delicious broth and assorted accoutrement. The greens are a great way to round out the meal - I've only had the bok choy, but I hear from Miriam W that the bok choy tends to be the seasonal green through most seasons. 

It's one of the nicer Vietnamese restaurants in the area - nice enough that you would linger a bit at the table after your meal. But the bowl of noodle soup will only set you back $8-9. 

It's a great lunch option, but it can get busy during the lunch hour.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Omg the food is AMAZING and inexpensive.

We had a long fun day of walking the city and didn't feel like going out for dinner so we decided to have food delivered in. We walked by this place earlier and it was completely packed, so for Tuesday we thought that was a good indicator. We ordered the shaking beef,  lemongrass pork shoulder, bok choy and fresh spring rolls. Everything was super good and delicious. They delivered it right to our room within a very reasonable amount of time. Great food, great price, great delivery service. We highly recommend this place.
author: Tamara K.

description:
Went here with my wife as an alternative to Miss Siagon (a competing Vietnamese restaurant a block away from Tin), and we both agreed that Tin will be our go-to choice for Vietnamese food in SoMa in the future.

As others have pointed out, the flavor of the food here is the big draw, and what will bring us back to Tin.  The highlights for us were the rich, deep flavors of the broth in the Pho Bo, the flavor balance of the pork in the Bun Thik Nuong, and the fresh limeade to drink.  Fairly inexpensive as well, two entrees plus two drinks for $25 +tax/tip.

A downside is that the restaurant is on the noisier side -- because it was completely full with a waiting list at 8pm -- so it was a bit chaotic to have a conversation at times.
author: Jason S.

description:
It is with all due respect when I say,
this is not the kind of place I envisioned when
someone suggested getting Vietnamese for lunch.

I did not expect to see a stylishly dark interior
with over sized light bulbs hanging from the ceiling
nor did I expect the cascading sounds of either world music
or some kind of ambient beats. 

I also did not anticipate
being so enamored with their veggie bun.

Their addition of shittake mushrooms
to the dish gives it
a nice meaty bite.

The soy vinaigrette
plus a little red chili sauce 
added a sweet acidity
with just a bit of heat.

I got to say
I really like this version
of a standard veggie dish.

It is quite reflective of the nouveau-ness
of the restaurant and,

most importantly,
it works.

Nice job Tin.
author: Dan B.

description: Delicious food, with many options including bun rieu and bun bo hue. Of course there's the usual dishes as well, with a little bit of fusion. This place gets freakin' packed so get here early! Prices are a tad bit higher than your average Vietnamese place, but for the portions it was more than reasonable. The decor is a lot more modern and much nicer than your typical Vietnamese spot, and the service was good. Flavors were on point, so will definitely be back to try the other dishes!
author: Elaine H.

description: I enjoyed the two dishes I had here. The pho with fishballs and some other seafood and the chilli lemongrass chicken. I intend to try some other dishes next time .. yes, I will definitely be back. I also found the location to be very safe even though I walked in the area in the dark. Do try this place - you won't be disappointed. It is very cheap too!
author: Charmaine L.

description: This was my first Pho experience, and I was not disappointed, Pho-real. I ordered the spring rolls and Pho Bo. Which was so much food I was only able to finish half of it.  The place was packed and even with 5 people in our food party we were seated rather quickly.  The food came out just as quick.  The app to main course timing couldn't have been better.  I hate when I go somewhere, order a starter and it basically comes at the same time as the meal. News flash, not a starter. That is not the case here. The beef in my Pho was so nice and thin, and I don't know if this is the case with all Pho places but the onions, bean sprouts etc came as a side to add at your own discretion.  Loved that. I will for sure be on the look out for fabulous pho places in my local area, fingers crossed they live up to the gold standard of this place.
author: Lesley M.

description:
Overall this was a forgettable and slightly disappointing meal with bland food, I was hoping for so much more at a Vietnamese place.

We has the crispy rolls to start, which were probably the best part, but even they did not have a whole lot of flavor.

We had beef vermicelli noodles and the same with pork. The beef was not very pleasant and salty, not sure what it was we ate but the pork was very good and I would recommend at least the meat portion of it. The rest of the dish was not authentic and just kind of plain. The noodles were your standard noodles kind of soggy, I just didn't feel like it tasted like anything, even with the sauce kind of bland.

As I am from NYC maybe I am just used to a different Vietnamese style, but if so then I prefer all the other places I have been to this one.
author: Trevor N.

description: I love this place! The food is fresh & delicious (without "mystery meats" you commonly find in other places). The staff is friendly, and the cost is very inexpensive! It's not uncommon to have a line out the door during peak lunch and dinner times. The Iced coffee and freshly squeezed limeade are amazing!!!
author: JonJon W.

description: Probably the best Vietnamese restaurant I have been to in SF so far. Wanted to order Bo Kho at first, but I had pho instead cuz they already ran out of Bo Kho. It was so tasty, especially the broth. The ambiance of the restaurant was great and the staff was nice as well. What I like most here is that they put veggies separately in a plate, so I can add the ones l like to my bowl (I'm a picky eater). Love their pickled onions. Most important at all, it's even cheaper than Fresh Roll! You can't beat the price.
author: 孟瑾

description:
So happy to find this place - the food is fantastic & the staff is super friendly. 

The food.
I ordered the Chili-Lemongrass Chicken with white rice and an order of spring rolls. Wow. The flavor of the chicken was excellent. So many different layers. The spring rolls were very fresh and tasty, but I wasn't in love with the peanut dipping sauce. It was a little on the thicker side for me. Not that big of a deal though.

The service.
My order was for take-out and RJ was super nice. He answered all of my questions about the food and helped me make the right choice. Everyone was friendly and greeted me, but RJ stood out.

The dining room is fairly small, but charming. You definitely get the sense this is a neighborhood joint...which I love.

Everything on the menu looked fantastic. I can't wait to go back and try something else.
author: Wendy P.

description: Very slow service during lunch time. Rude waiters that do not know anything about vietnamese food. The short white waiter and fat Latin  waiter needs attitude adjustments and they need to  provide better service to their customers. The short white dude got pissy because brought out something that we did not order. The eggrolls were so greasy....even using napkins to squeeze all the oil out.  Bun Bo Hue us not supposed to have rare beef in it...lacking lemon grass...and the broth was warm.
author: Billy V.

description:
I've always enjoyed Tín, but my "Bo Kho" beef in star anise broth soup was just amazing tonight.  The richness and depth of flavor, with just a bit of chili spice, was incredible.  The texture of the egg noodles was perfect: Firm, not overcooked, and nice and thin.

My wife also claims her vegetarian Pho was some of the best she's ever had :).
author: Jon E.

description: I would give this place five stars for the food but the location was in a sketchy area and parts of the restaurant needed some help. RESTAURANT: Cons- Bathroom was dirty, floors were slippery and slick, area you pass to the bathroom is used for storage and was disorganized and open. Pros- tables were nice, decor was pleasing and appropriate, lights were modern and fun. FOOD: Pros- TASTY. TASTY. TASTY. We ordered the Pho Bo w/ tripe, Bo Kho, baby bok choy w/ garlic, house made Limeade and Tung Tin Tea. The bowls were sized just right (except for my friend - he probably could've eaten a bigger bowl) - the meats were perfectly cooked (not chewy), the bok choy was soooo good (probably could've eaten two plates as a meal) and the drinks were good as well (though the Limeade had more ice than I wanted). We're DEFINITELY coming back (if not this visit, on our next visit).
author: Rovi D.

description: The food was just ok and took a while to come out. Unfortunately, I had an upset stomach after the meal so I won't be back.
author: T L.

description:
So authentic!!! My friends and I came here for lunch and this place surprised me. We ordered Goi cuon (spring rolls), Goi ga (chicken salad), Bun Rieu, Bun cha Ha Noi and Hu Tiu. All of them taste so Vietnamese I think. Price range is reasonable.
Service was a bit slow but so helpful.
Even the lemon iced tea and Vietnamese coffee are so alike. So good!!!
author: Phuong P.

description: Stopped in to escape the Dreamforce mob and fell in love with the Pho Bo. The meat was so tender, the broth flavorful and well balanced (no one strong flavor as I have had with other broths). Only thing I would say is service is spotty during lunch. We waited around for a while to be seated and it's a small place so they definitely saw us. Things picked up once I said we were in a rush. All around great meal.
author: Natasha D.

description:
Who would have guessed that hipsters serve good Viet food? I'm used to the nicer/trendier the ethnic restaurant, the worse the food tastes. Tin is definitely an exception. Although Tin does have that too-cool-for-you vibe... I feel like it's one of those places where the plaid shirt and horn-rimmed glasses-wearing server would call you out if you pronounced pho wrong. But enough of that... 

- Good: warm beef salad appetizer, Bo Kho (awesome, brisket, beef, and carrot in star-anise beef broth, reminds me of Taiwanese beef noodle soup so it brings back good memories)
- Fine: Pho Bo (beef and brisket, bf didn't like very much because both the noodles and soup were different from traditional pho), lemongrass pork shoulder bun

Don't go too close to closing, because they can run out of stuff. They ran out of chicken broth, so no Hu Tieu for me.

And don't expect this to be like your usual cheap and ghetto pho joint. The food takes a lot longer, and the prices are a bit steeper (around $9-10, so still not bad).
author: Alice T.

description: Omg you have to be a hipster or Asian to get served in this place. Took way to long to get our meal. Write down what your ordered to remember what you did order and if that's not bad enough. Park your car in front on the restaurant becAuse I walked back to my car with a broken window. Apparently that's the rage in San Fran amongst  the absorbent amount of homeless people walking around the neighborhood. Slow service + broken window = not worth the trip.
author: Steven R.

description:
My office is down the street and we order Tin for lunch once a week or so. 

Its always delicious! Definitely recommend
author: Brittany U.

description:
One of the best pho veg dishes I have had.  After much insist I got my dish to be spicy and definitely worth the request. The variety of vegetables and the thinness of the noodles was exceptional.

Ambience was great though located in a place that is not very busy.  Lot of people for lunch that made this small place attractive for an afternoon lunch. Good for small groups of people! Can't wait to hit up Tin again when I'm back in SF.
author: Arvind M.

description:
The food and service were both OK.

Every time I check out a new Vietnamese joint, I always go for the Pho Dac Biet. It's the yardstick by which I compare everyone. Strangely, Tin did not serve the typical special, which comes with tripe and tendon.  They only had a regular which came with cooked beef and rare flank. I added the meatballs for $1.  So for a relatively expensive $9.50, I got a regular sized bowl with three different meats. 

The broth was flavorful, although a little saltier than I'm accustomed too. I usually add lots of hoisin sauce, but it wasn't even needed as it would've become too salty. The accompanying plate of toppings had some bean sports, lime, and....basil? There was no mint or culantro. A very odd decision, which changed the taste profile of the soup.

Overall it was just OK, but definitely missing some toppings.  Service was friendly, but a little slow.
author: Ho L.

description: Wonderful food and on top of that the servers are really nice as well. I highly recommend  the 5 spice chicken and the fried rolls!
author: Sandra N.

description:
Hands down one of the best Vietnamese Cuisine's I've had so far!

My coworker ordered the Bun Bo Hue (sorry if I am spelling these wrong) and I ordered the Bun Rieh. The Bun Bo Hue was suuupperrrr spicy! So for you spicy lovers out there, that's for you! And my noodle soup consisted of rice noodles with tofu, pork cutlets and turkey meatballs(?)  and it had a tomato based soup.
IT WAS SOO GOOOOODD!! YUM!!
We also ordered the spring rolls which consisted of two rolls cut into three sections and the peanut sauce that came with it was creamy and delicious as well!
I am looking forward to coming back here again!
author: Linda K.

description: Stopped in on a Monday night for a quick dinner later in the evening. While traffic was not bustling, there was a decent flow of people in and out for the location. A definite neighborhood go-to for locals in the area. The decor was a little reminiscent of Mau in the Mission, but without the hipster waiters. Service was no frills, but we were seated quickly, food came out in good time and our glasses never lacked for water. An A+ in my book. The food was tasty. We ordered the braised pork shoulder and warm beef salad. I enjoyed the warm beef salad, but was more delighted with the pork shoulder rice plate. Accompanying the main dish was a side of pickled mustard greens and a twice cooked egg...yum!
author: Alice H.

description:
Honestly this food is so fresh and they do not use msg. I know msg maybe isnt thaaaat bad for you but it does not make my body feel good so no thanks. Also holy crap the prices here are so reasonable. Super easy to order take out and they open late on weekdays!!! What's not to love?!

I tried the veggie vermicelli and like I said- fresh and tasty. Mate got the beef roll vermicelli. He loved it.

I have a feeling we will be frequent visitors.
author: Lisa K.

description: I was pleasantly surprised at how flavorful  everything tasted. The egg rolls were on point and I liked that it was served with a small amount of  vermicelli noodles and sliced pickled carrots and radishes so that you can roll it altogether. The Pho Bo was good, but I found it a bit on the saltier side compared to what I'm used to. I was disappointed that the noodle to beef ratio was off. After all, pho  is meant for slurping noodles and broth! :)
author: Tegan P.

description: Exceptional food! Everything we had was made with high quality ingredients and lots of passion. A bit pricey but you get what you pay for.
author: Eitan S.

description: I tried the pho noodle soup and the clay pot shrimp. The pho was okay, the noodles felt a bit too flour-y falling apart too quickly and not chewy enough. The soup wasn't hot enough. Clay hot shrimp was a tiny bowl of a few pieces of shrimp and a little bit of garnishes, so if you're someone who enjoys a variety in your food, don't get this. Overall, an okay experience. The best part was the cheap price.
author: Connie S.

description:
The service was a little slow but the food was good.
I had the pho ga (chicken pho) and the banh xeo (shrimp, calamari, pork and herb crepe). The pho ga was alright but I have to say the banh xeo was amazing. It tastes like banh xeo I had in Vietnam.
author: Jeffrey Q.

description: Waited about 10 minutes but no one came to greet me. I had to personally walk into the kitchen to tell the server that I need to be seated. Food was fast. The lychee infused ice tea tastes straight up like water with very subtle ice tea flavor, not to mention about lychee taste. There is none. Yet they charge it for four dollars.Pho bo is ok, the soup tastes a little sweet for some unknown reason. The soup is not hot enough because when i was about to finish my pho, the beef is still pinky and red and raw. However, the soup is not overseasoned. Environment is ok. So overall so-so.
author: 添

description: We ordered springroll and grilled pork on rice with additional fried egg, it was delicious and highly recommended
author: Rico K.

description:
Came here for lunch and man are they busy/packed during prime lunch hours (12-1)!

I ordered the shrimp spring rolls (I'm glad I could opt out of pork!). Pretty standard (nothing exciting but they did taste super fresh!).

I also had the vegetarian pho and I was quite pleased with the broth's flavor! Light but with an earthy hint of mushroom. The only thing I could do a little without was the excess broccoli. I love broccoli, just not sure I feel about it in my pho.

Anyway, pretty solid place for pho!
author: Christina C.

description: The restaurant was nice and clean, but the food is subpar. I got the Quail appetizer and Bun Bo Hue and neither had much flavor or spice. Maybe they're catering to Americans, who knows.
author: Molly L.

description:
Cute little place I randomly selected on yelp while running errands with my coworker. Hands down one of the yummiest modern looking Vietnamese restaurants Ive been to here in the city. Soooo happy I chose it!

I ordered their Bun Xiao, which is a crispy Vietnamese crepe with bean sprouts, Mung bean, shrimp, and pork; not to mention dousing it with lotsssss of fish sauce! Wrap that sucker with some lettuce and mint and it is a match made in heaven! The texture and flavors are amazing for something so simple. Tasted like something straight from the motherland. Talk about authentic!

Service was a bit slow, especially phoning in my order and picking it up half an hour later. I figured that would have been more than enough time to have my food ready :(

Anyways, on a brighter note! Their clay pot dishes looked bomb and seemed like they are quite a hit. I must come back to try it sometime!
author: Anh T.

description:
Great place for a good meal. Me and the boyf checked this place out on a friday night. 

Vermicelli bowl with imperial rolls and pork- 4.5/5 this is the one i got. really good meat, the sauce that came with it was good too. Deducted .5 because of the amount of vermicelli compared to the meat and rolls...the ratio was a bit off. Still delicious
My boyf got the one with chicken and it was also good. 

Spring rolls-3.5/5 there wasnt a lot inside the rolls. Just vermicelli, mint, and a piece of shrimp and i think they also put turkey (?!) in it. I wanted some more stuff inside.  The peanut sAuce that came with it was good. 

Fresh veggies and ingredients, nice dark-ish slightly fancy atmosphere fit for a romantic date...or just a casual pop in.
author: Rose M.

description: Wish this place was bigger so we could sit in the restaurant. Other than that the food was great! Totally recommend the Vegetarian Vermicelli bowl, the tofu pieces were huge and flavorful.
author: Ashley N.

description: I was looking for a good Vietnamese place near my office and I found it. I ordered their Bun Bo Nuong and added Cha Gio to it and it was delicious. Also be prepared for large portions, my bowl was huge. If you're in the neighborhood definitely stop by, you'll be glad you did.
author: Claudia C.

description:
Being from Toronto, it's hard to find a pho place that doesn't just load up the broth with msg. This is a place that takes their time and develops the flavour in their broth the proper way instead of just cheating and dumping in msg. 
Portion sizing isn't too big but enough unless you're super hungry. Noodles and meat are nicely cooked and flavourful. 

A little expensive for what you get but worth it for the quality!
author: Derwei C.

description: Rude customer service. Women with a short hair just throw us the menu and walk away even though it not that busy. When we first came here they never handed us any menu and we sat there for 10-20 min. I wanted to set at a 4 table people bcuz I'm a big guy and I'm coming with two. The guy with a green Tshirt dress like a homeless won't let me set at a 4 table. So he move us to the two small table. He came back again and talking to me rudely and saying that "YOU SEE FULL TABLE!" I was minding my business eating and now I have experience it I WONT COME BACK HERE EVER AGAIN. Horrible server and bad service. NEVER COME HERE AGAIN.
author: Bk K.

description: My boyfriend and I decided to try Tin Vietnamese cuisine since it was only few minutes walk from our hotel.  We visited from Boston so we are kind of skeptical when eating out at the new place.  It turned out the food was good.  My Bun Bo Hue was not at my liking but it was doable for being away from home.  My boyfriend shaken beef was really good and he really liked it.  It was probably the cheapest dinner we had in San Fran.  The portion was just enough.  The place was not that fancy so that maybe the reason why their prices was lower than others.  There was a wait but we didn't have to wait for too long.  They got you in quick and they also got you out quick.  That was how I like it.  I would definitely come back to Tin if I am ever in San Fran again.
author: Mongbinh D.

description: False advertisement they don't have the hue rolls , atleast tell people , go to Mau instead
author: Nancy N.

description:
The best Vietnamese food that I have ever tried!!! :)

Vermichelli noodles are very fresh and delicious; home made spicy sauce and the fish sauce tastes perfect! Crunch spring rolls are so delicious and fresh! Soup noodles are really good as well. I went to Tin with my six other colleagues from different countries, we all loved our food. All the food were so good, really the best Vietnamese food! :)
author: Stella K.

description:
I was surprised to see the only Vietnamese people I could see in Tin were in the pictures of the homeland on the wall; wait-staff was a male & female Caucasian (not that there's anything wrong with that!). I didn't peer into the kitchen to see who was doing the cooking.

Simple menu with a handful each of soups, bun dishes (vermicelli bowls), and rice plates. One chicken, one beef, and one veggie pho. I went for the Pho Bo (rare beef & brisket, $7.50. beef balls are +$1 add-on), Cha Gio (Imperial Rolls, $6), and Iced Coffee ($2.50)

Cha gio - Came on an nicely appointed plate with lettuce, herbs, vermicelli, pickled slices of daikon and carrots, and nuoc cham (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/p1oiqn-SkMrQG0lT3V6jIA?select=q2R3cqyrkYvIeE3LHc1a7w). Made with rice paper wrappers instead of the more commonly seen egg-roll wrappers. These were very good and the dipping sauce had a nice garlicky kick.

Pho bo - Smallish bowl. Only rare steak & brisket (or optional beef balls) are offered which I was disappointed to see, but probably makes sense with the clientele who didn't appear to be the tripe and tendon crowd.  I wasn't a fan of the flavor the thinly sliced celery added to the soup. Other than that, the broth was decent. Noodles well cooked. 5 large slices of rare steak and a pretty good amount of brisket.

Iced coffee - Drip brewed at the table, it came out surprisingly weak.

Cha gio - 4.5 stars
Pho bo - 3.5 stars
Iced coffee - 2 stars
author: Andrew C.

description:
I come here only for the shaken beef. Its really good.  Ive tried several other things on the menu and they were decent.  Im not that big of a fan of
Pho but their pho here is pretty good.  Prices are good too.
author: Nazanin R.

description: Came here with friends on a whim. Delicious food! Everything was so fresh and so tasty. We had the mango and lotus root salad, both really well spiced. I had the Bon Tam and the shrimp was super yummy.
author: Aida T.

description:
Great little Vietnamese place. I don't know about y'all but most pho places I go to don't care much about ambience. So Tin stands out a little for having that SF restaurant vibe to it. Good place for a casual, inexpensive pho date without sticky linoleum tables. 

My boyfriend and I were seated at a longer table that turned out to be a sort of communal table for small groups. (We didn't mind.) We ordered a shrimp roll, pho bo, and lemongrass pork shoulder. The shrimp roll was great--loved the peanut sauce and used it liberally. Pho was smaller than expected (you can get much more for the price at typical pho places) but it was pretty good quality. I didn't eat much of the pork but it was very flavorful. 

Water was always refilled and service attentive. Bathroom in the back was pretty clean. Good place overall.
author: Tina T.

description: 3.5 not quite as good as nearby tu lan. but still all with some fried smaller imperial rolls and bun thit nuong with decent fish sauce but less exciting sliced carrots.  pho ga chicken was a bit dry.
author: Rob C.

description: They charge S.F. Health Tax. If I have know in advance, I will not have step into the restaurant. The food is good and not cheap. I could have gone somewhere else with the same quality of food without the S.F. Health Tax. Especially when they mention it is mandatory. It whould be the employer's responsibility and not the consumer.
author: i r.

description:
This is a no-frills-shove-your-delicious-food-in-your-mouth-and-shut-up kind of place. And I like it.

I, however, would not recommend it for a one hour lunch because you're gonna have to wait to get a table. And then you're gonna have to wait a bit to get your food. So, maybe give yourself about an hour and a half at the minimum to eat here.

The wait staff is pleasant, but they pretty much leave you alone other than taking your order and bringing your food/drinks. That doesn't bother me in the least because they bring the food, refill the drinks, and let you pay your tab in a timely enough fashion. And the food. My goodness, the food....

I had the Bun Thit Nuong (grilled lemongrass pork shoulder) vermicelli noodle bowl ($8), WITH the crispy-fried cha gio roll for an extra $1.50, which was the best decision I made all week most likely. The flavor bomb in my mouth, the texture of the noodles, veggies, pork...was so delightful I find myself craving it again right now...

Damn you Tin for being in SF and not Denver!

If you are lucky enough to be in the area of Tin and are in the mood for Vietnamese food, you'd be doing yourself a disservice to not go there. If fact, you should probably go there if you aren't in the area, but are in the mood for Vietnamese food. Or if you are in the area, but aren't in the mood for Vietnamese. Or... just go.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
It's common that in heavily populated Asian communities the cultural food is really good and authentic and you'd be wrong if you thought SF had a concentration of Vietnamese that would showcase this. The predominant Asian community is Chinese. I was fully expecting a wonderful display and a broad authentic menu. It's about half the options I was expecting and a little more gourmet than most.

Spring rolls were large and rolled nice and tight plenty of pork flavor, but the shrimp was there, but I barely tasted it. The peanut dipping sauce was extra sweet, very little fish sauce.

The pho broth was excellent the noodles were a little less than proportionate to the size of the bowl, but the rare steak was really good and probably the best brisket I've ever had. Intramuscular fat, sliced to perfection. Not quite fall apart. No tripe, no flank, no tendon, no meatballs. A very watered down version for more public consumption. A nice size somewhere between a regular small and large. 

Lemongrass pork is tender, well marinated and crisp notes of the fresh herbs used were a winner winner. A little light on the rice and the usual cucumber and tomato garnishment. 

Do not add grilled shrimp to an order. It's $2 for 3 medium shrimp probably U-25 sized. Vermicelli is perfect . Fish dipping sauce was thick and not very pungent. I would have liked to see true broken rice dishes. 

They have quite a few drink options, but none of the super traditional kinds. 

On a busy Saturday night the wait wasn't very long, but the service wasn't up to par. Server was not friendly, probably stressed out, our waters and tea were not refilled and they took some of our dishes a little early despite asking if we were done. Definitely in a hurry to move along another party. I like the décor as it's more modern and not so traditional, no fish tank. TV's in the corners are not distracting.
author: Walter M.

description:
Some items on the menu warrant four star but others are flat out horrible compared to other Vietnamese restaurants. On top of that, I've been here twice and the service is consistently horrible. The whole time, I don't think my waiter (who I think is actually the owner?) did not say one word to us. The wait was long and we could not even call anyone over to pay our check.

If you do visit Tin, I would highly recommend the Bun Cha Ha Noi. All portions are pretty small but the Bun Cha is really tasty. I would also recommend the Bo Kho. My friends tried the Bun Thit Nuong and enjoyed it too.

As for meals to stay away from, the Pho is served in a very small bowl and does not taste good at all (though, I suspect a lot of MSG). I would also steer away from the Cha Gio which is extra crispy and the Bun Rieu which is no where near the taste and ingredients of the traditional dish. All in all, I would come back for the Bun Cha, Bo Kho, or Bun Thit Nuong but I would be very cautious about trying anything else.
author: Brandon P.

description: Came here for lunch. Got the Pho Bo and some spring rolls. If you're craving Vietnamese and just want some comfort food, not a bad place it hit up. Simple ingredients, the pho wasn't as flavorful as I'd like but still pretty good. Veggie spring rolls were tasty. Love the sauces.
author: Zara S.

description:
This restaurant provides great bang-for-your-buck. 

I met a friend here for lunch. We shared an appetizer of minty fresh Spring Rolls with pork and shrimp wrapped in a soft vermicelli wrap. For the main course, we shared a Lemongrass Pork Shoulder Rice Plate and a Lemongrass Tofu Rice Plate. While I'm a huge fan of anything with pork, the Lemongrass Tofu dish with perfectly seasoned and crispy tofu absolutely blew me away! We also got a side of Grilled Eggplant with Garlic-Chili Fish Sauce, which was a surprising highlight of our meal. 

With tea for each of us, the entire meal cost $40 with tip. The decor and atmosphere of the restaurant give it an upscale feel. You'll get great food and service, all for a great price!
author: Mark C.

description:
The word about Tin has gotten out, and the crowds have come.

I'm happy for the crew; they're very nice, make some killer food, and have brought lunchtime back to this trash and poo filled stretch of Howard. That's harder than bringing sexy back, for sure.

These are the reasons that I'm the Duchess of Tin. It's not a hard job, and anyone with a taste for fresh Vietnamese can do it. Carnivores and vegetarians, and those in between, are all qualified for the position. The five spice chicken is juicy and tender, the rice has the perfect fluff to it. The veggie bun is my favorite dish, and I'm a seasoned meat eater. It's the perfect mid-day lunch and just tastes so clean and fresh, as do all their dishes that I've tried.

The service can be a bit haphazard, especially during lunch, but it's always so hospitable and charming. I hope the influx allows another wait staff to be hired; sometimes there is only one person during lunch and it gets hectic. The dimly lit and chic interior helps you relax, as does their wine and beer offerings-check the chalkboard for the former and ask the server for the latter.

So the Duchess grants you permission to come in, and if you don't soon she'll grab you by the hair of your tinny tin tin.
author: Joanna M.

description:
I have been to Tin a few times and I always enjoy the food.  I've had most of the pho's (I think) and never had a complaint.  Sometimes the service isn't great; with a Vietnamese menu, I've often been with friends who wanted more explanation or suggestions about the food and the servers aren't great at that.  It also gets very crowded and tends to be a bit of a hectic environment which is not ideal.  But if I want Pho in SoMa, Tin is the go to place.
Tip- there's usually people waiting outside, so go early and put your name down, I don't think they take reservations, which is also a bit frustrating.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night, and boy, were they busy!  Now I can see why.  This place was very clean for a pho restaurant.  They have a far wider selection than pho.

I ordered the Pho Bo, which I highly recommend.  It was one of the tastiest pho broths I've ever had.  The spring rolls were also great.

Not to mention they have a wide selection of beer.  I'm definitely coming back here again!
author: Andrew H.

description:
I wouldn't recommend Tin if you're in a time crunch and trying to squeeze in a quick meal on your 1 hour lunch break between meetings - it took a while to get seated and service was slow, as there were only two servers handling the whole restaurant. 

That said, I would recommend Tin for everything else. Specifically the lemongrass grilled pork vermicelli (Bun Thit Nuong) with fried cha gio roll. Now THAT is a dish worth waiting for. Fragrant, tender pork, crisp veggies, to-die-for noodles. As we were in a hurry, I had to ask for a fork so I could shovel mouthfuls in quicker than chopsticks would allow! Doesn't make me sound great but oh well. 

I sacrifice etiquette for flavor and I'm totally fine with it.
author: Emily C.

description:
Good
- Food is fresh and delicious
- Open late

Interesting
- I would call it a "hipster Vietnamese place"
- staff can sometimes be brusque
author: Marc V.

description: Authentic and delicious Vietnamese food. I tried the pho bo and it was exactly like how I remembered it when I went to Vietnam. The broth was perfectly salty and the lime and basil added a great tang. Not only was the food delicious, the portions here are generous and the prices are more than fair. My pho bo was $8, which is a great deal in San Francisco. We also got the spring roll with pork and shrimp in it. There are so many different dishes here and all are worth trying! The service here was a bit slow, but attentive.
author: Hana K.

description:
Some of the worst service I have ever had. The waitress was hostile and unpleasant the entire meal.

The restaurant was OK, it was pretty hot though.

As for the food, it was decent, but not good enough to put up with the service.
author: Andrew R.

description:
This restaurant has the lowest health score I've seen in San Francisco so far!  Seriously, 56 (as of March, 2013)  out of 100?!  I could probably get a better health score serving food from a public restroom.

We ate here anyway, and the food is pretty good.  I had the vegetarian pho, and it was definitely the best vegetarian pho I've had.  The broth is actually flavorful, so that was a pleasant surprise.  I tried some of my friend's beef roll vermicelli, and it was pretty tasty so I know they can cook their meat dishes well too.  Overall a very nice experience.

This is definitely your typical fufu San Francisco Asian restaurant - there's a freaking chalk board displaying things at the entrance.  It feels like your standard yuppie fusion restaurant - there's no tripe or tendon pho on the menu, so only go here if you don't mind that.  But if you're in the mood for some standard pho or vermicelli, they do it well for a good price.
author: Allen C.

description: loved it! quick fast and yummy. we both had Pho Bo's and the broth was very tasty. wasn't too bland and wasn't too salty. didn't even have to add hoisin or sriracha into my soup! plenty of beef with the bowl of Pho! great experience. would come here again!
author: Felicia C.

description: Pho bun hue was dope! Very good, very authentic and msg free. I highly recommend you get this if you come here. Service was a tiny bit lacking though, left the desk wet and noone wiped it dry for me though..
author: Samson T.

description:
Well. It was dark in here, prices are up, which is all fine since this is in the SOMA and people put up with that kind of stuff. The food on everyone's tables looked delicious. 
My review is based on my sandwich. 
I ordered a 5 spice chicken. I consumed it. Bread was thick, there was nothing but mayonnaise, a few sliced carrots that almost seemed pickled but could easily have not been, and a thick chunk of chicken meat. My thoughts?
$6+ for a freaking dry banh mi with hardly any pickled vegetables , no jalepeno, I don't think so. It just seemed so roughly put together that I regret paying for it. I should have just went to Chinatown or something. But that is just for their sandwich. I am sure the other food is great and serivce seemed attentive.
author: Stacey T.

description: One of my favorite Vietnamese places in the city. I like it better than turtle tower. Pho, vegetarian bun and claypot catfish are all amazing! Signup sheet by the door. Will not seat you until your entire party is there.
author: Wen G.

description: Favorite Vietnamese in SF. Good portions, good prices, delicious food. I recommend the 5-spice chicken w/ rice, shaken beef, and any of the bun (cold rice noodle) or pho (clear broth soup) dishes.
author: Webb P.

description: I love love this place! Best pho I've had! So flavorful and fresh each time. I always get the hue tieu and fried rolls. Yumm!
author: Vicky A.

description:
pretty good food and fresh tasting stuff
got there 12:45pm which is still a rush hour, but was seated in 10 min. Food came out in about 5 min. 
I got porkless fresh spring rolls and pork with rice vermicelli in spicy lemongrass broth (and actual spicy jalapeños :) )
both were delicious 


AWESOME Place! will definitely be back
author: Alex S.

description: This place is super busy now. So hard to get a spot. You either have to be here 20 minutes before noon or wait til after 1pm to get a seat. Sigh. :(
author: Trisha M.

description: Probably the best Vietnamese restaurant in SOMA. Had the five spice chicken rice dish and it wasn't the best I've had but it was definitely good. Chicken was tender and came with the typical fair of sweet chili sauce and pickled vegetables. The service is good, although they won't seat you until everyone in your party arrives. If you feel like getting Vietnamese food and in the area, can't go wrong at Tin.
author: Sherwin M.

description:
Craving pho and TT in the TL was closed. Searched what was nearby and Tin popped up. After looking at the pics and reading the reviews we decided to check it out and give it try. To our surprise it was packed! I figured this must be a good spot, right?! Well....

We ordered the banh xeo, pho bo, bun bo hue and bun cha ha noi. 

The banh xeo was a bit too oily and bland in my opinion. The crepe wasn't very crispy and just didn't come out right. At least the lettuce and herbs were fresh. 

The bun bo hue (bbh) had the right spice level, but the broth lacked the complex flavor that it should have. No pig feet or pork blood? I get it that some don't like it, but when I'm ordering and the server doesn't ask me if it's ok, then I'm gonna assume it's included. Maybe the place is targeted to more 'americanized' tastebuds? I hope not....  the plus is that they did serve it with cabbage on the side. Most places don't and I'm glad they got that part right. 

The bun cha hanoi was a pretty large portion and the veggies were fresh along with the noodles. The pork patties were a good size and had ok flavor but it was pretty salty. 

I can't comment on the pho bo since I didn't get to try it, but that's probably a good thing...considering the other dishes. 

Total bill with tip came out to near $50....for Vietnamese food

Look, everyone has an opinion on viet food and will always compare it to their favorite spot but unfortunately this didn't make the grade for me. I wanted to like this place but sadly it failed.  The pluses were the décor was nicely updated and the server was cool. Lucky for them it's the only one in the immediate area because if you took this place and moved it to the TL it'd have a hard time surviving.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Walked past this, something about it grabbed us, and we walked back in. I love Vietnamese cuisine (minus pho), and this was really, really good. *Great* clay pot catfish.

A bit of a diamond in the rough, which to me only adds to the effect.
author: James A.

description:
Great food, the vermicelli bowl was excellent. Usually places put too many noodles, but not here. A good balance between noodles, fresh greens and meat. Spicy papaya Salad hit the spot as well.
My only complaint was noise level. It is such a small space that all the talk and music made it hard to hear my companion. Since we were so busy enjoying our food it didn't matter too much . Definitely worth many return visits.
author: Matt A.

description:
The Pho is reasonably tasty. The staff is friendly except for the man who set water for me. He looked fed up or tired or both.  

The place is quite lively, very noisy.
author: Ann S.

description:
Super fresh ingredients. Very patient and kind server, serving the entire restaurant by herself and managing it expertly. Quick service, at that. 

Minus one star for the absence of traditional Vietnamese condiments; namely the chili oil and pickled jalapenos. Also, the bun I ordered came all disassembled on a plate instead of in a bowl. Unwieldy. Had to take time to construct everything. 

I'll come back if I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Julia D.

description:
The Pho Bo is a bit non-traditional (I've never had onions in my soup before) and a bit small, but very rich and tasty with very high quality beef.

The housemade limemade was good and complemented the rest of the meal.

I would get it again.
author: Diane W.

description:
Came here with my Dad for dinner the other day.  Food was delicious. I've been missing Vietnamese food and this fit the craving bill. 

We started with fresh rolls which had super juicy, plump shrimp.  The peanut sauce was a bit thicker than I wanted and I added a ton of spice, but the flavor and texture of the roll was spot on.

For my main, I had the Bun with Lemongrass Pork.  Chia Gio added for a supplement. I finished the bowl.  Portions were good, but not too large.  

Atmosphere is nice.   As someone else stated, the waitress was very white hipster.   Clean and nicely decorated.  The place was packed. 

I'll be back if in the neighborhood.
author: Katharine A.

description: Giving this place a solid 3 stars mostly for the service. It's a great place to grab quick lunch in SoMa, though space may be an issue. It's a small hole in the wall place, so definitely not ideal for large groups. We came here on a Friday before noon and was able to grab a table right away. This place got more busy afterwards. There was already a line forming outside about 15 mins after our arrival. The staff here is very courteous and attentive. Service is super fast and stress-free. For the food, I ordered their Vegetarian Pho which was a decent mix of tofu, mushrooms with rice noodles in veggie broth. The broth was okay, but not as flavorful as I'd hoped. Ultimately, my main concern was that my order came out only slightly warm, almost room temperature. I came here expecting a comforting, steamy bowl of pho, but left disappointed. So because of this, I probably won't be coming back. I've had better pho elsewhere for a cheaper price.
author: Jasmin H.

description: We were worried about finding a pho place as good as Mau when we moved to SOMA, but we found it. Beef pho, Vietnamese iced coffee, and baby bak choi. I want to try something else here but I don't know if I can go without this epic lineup
author: Rebeka J.

description: Great Vietnamese restaurant in the city! Ambience, food and service were all excellent! Prices were very reasonable as well. I would highly recommend it to anyone that needs their Vietnamese cuisine fix.
author: T L.

description: When you come here get the bowls of noodles and not just the Pho Bo. The pho bo is good but definitely on the smaller size. The wonton in the soup actually looked a lot better than expected. Make sure you check the schedule so you know when they are open (they aren't always open). The place is clean, service is fast, and it's priced reasonably. For Pho i might prefer Miss Saigon for the cheaper prices and bigger portions. I have yet to try turtle tower though...
author: Lily P.

description: Second time we've been here.  Last time I ordered the papaya salad and crab soup.  Both were good, so I decided to come back.  This time I had the spicy noodle soup, bun bo hue.  My partner ordered the lemongrass beef noodle.   We waited a while before our meals came, which was a bit odd considering we had just got in before the lunch crowd.  My soup was missing the spiciest and the lemongrass taste.  And some of the rice noodle was undercooked.   A few pieces were still hard. My partner's noodle dish which included an extra ordered of the crispy fried eggroll was not good at all.  The beef had flavor but missing that grilled beef taste.  Pieces of the thinly sliced beef were stuck to each other and turned out steamed instead of grilled.  The noodle was warm so the veggies underneath were steamed as well.  The crispy eggroll ended up being soggy.  The waiter came by, saw the barely touched noodle dish but didn't bother to ask how things were. I like this place enough the first time to come back.  But after two disappointing dishes, we will not be back here again.
author: Bry B.

description:
I and three friends of mine went to Tin yesterday for lunch.  In a sentence,  it just wasn't a good experience for me overall.

Funny thing is that I actually suggested this restaurant to my friends.  Perhaps I always came either for dinner or during the weekend.  For lunch time during the week, this place would be A ZOO!

We knew it was going to be busy.  We planned to arrive even before the restaurant was open.  We were the 2nd group or 3rd group of people to arrive - or I should say 3 of us arrived first, and the 4th person was on the way.  And people (customers) weren't really lining up.  We were just standing outside the door chatting.  

I'm setting this up to describe the next thing that happened: when the door opend, we went in.  We informed that there were going to be the 4 of us, and our friend would be arriving in a few minutes.  (My firned texted me to say he had already parked and on his way.)  But the matradee/bus boy WAS RELUCTANT TO SEAT US!  And worse thing is that, he just sounded like he had an attitude, " you know we're going to be full."  This is when there were only THREE groups of customers sitting down!  90 percent of the restaurant were still EMPTY at that time. (The other two groups were just parties of two's.)  And there was still half an hour before the noon time.  Eventually he did let us sit down.  And fortunately our friend did arrive shortly after.  So we felt we were not "wasting" their bigger table.

And that attitude did not stop.  Later on, when I was eating, he asked me to scoot the chair further inside.  I understand he had a point.  They were busy, and the path behind me needed to be cleared.  But the tone WAS CLEARLY IMPOLITE.  I felt like I was being reprimanded.  And I felt that he did that to me on purpose.

I think at this point, it was pretty much very hard for me to enjoy my meal.  I just don't need to be in a restaurant to feel like I need to put up with attitudes.  

There WERE, two factors that were the saving grace for me to not to give my experience as a one-star.  One was that our waitress was wonderful!  She was polite and attentive.  The other was that the food I had was good -- which of course, was the main reason that I suggested this place to my friends, that they have good food.  My friends also said they liked their food.

If you think that 2-star is too harsh for the attitude, then l would elaborate why I said this place was a zoo during our visit.  Well, now that I've said it, "zoo" wasn't a good analogy.  Because zoo was more quiet.  The space was just too small, too packed.  Customers sit so close to each other.  So in order to hear they own conversation, they were essentially doing shouting matches!  It was SO LOUD, I couldn't concentrate on enjoying my food. 

I would not go back, left alone recommending this place to anybody.
author: Charlie Y.

description:
SO GOOD. UGH. NEED TO COME BACK.

I've had a lot of thai food in SF but this one really takes the cake. Came in around a Wednesday night at 7:30PM. Was not very crowded at all, had small tables so it's not very suited for big groups. Here's what we ordered:

-Papaya Salad: green papaya, poached shrimp and calamari, thai basil. 3/5 I guess I'm not a fan of papaya salad but do know that it comes in a huge portion. It was quite spicy!
-5-Spice Chicken Rice Plate $8.5: 5/5!! This is a MUST. It is service with jasmine rice or you can request for brown rice for one extra dollar. It was SO flavorful, not too salty and not too strong. I'm craving it right now as I write this...
-Caramelized Claypot Catfish $9.5: 5/5 as well!! Came in a tiny pot but was filled with flavors. The catfish was flaky and topped with shredded ginger (I think..) and paired perfectly with the rice. A good size portion, nothing you can't finish but I still saved some to take home.

Some cons about this restaurant is that it's just..so...hot! My friend and I were SWEATING just sitting down. Eventually got used to it but man, turn some air conditioning on!

All in all, there are some gem dishes at Tin, do come try it!
author: Ting Jung L.

description: The best vegetarian Pho in SF.  The veggie fresh spring rolls came with a marinated tofu and are also highly recommended.  Vegan options are available.
author: Carl C.

description: You know I'd hate to be one of those who gives a bad rating for the service but I almost have no choice. I walked in and after it took them about 5 minutes to seat me (bunch of open tables) even though I was eating alone, they still looked at me like I was some sort of criminal. I couldn't help but feel as if they kept watching me as I ate to see if I was going to run for the door and not pay. After I was done eating the guy told me he'd bring me my check and after 15 minutes he walked by again and said "oh, your check!". I get it, it was semi sort of busy but that's no excuse for horrible service. The lady who brought out my sides literally threw them on my table and didn't even look my way when she did it and just ran on by.
author: Jose R.

description:
Very good Vietnamese food in Bay Area, but...

On the day when the boss was not there, the food quality was not as good as usual, the service was cold.
author: Shan S.

description:
Two words: Vegetable bun. 

It doesn't matter what kind of species you are, I think it's very hard to dislike this dish. The tofu in this dish tastes like it was prepared carefully from Asia. Besides tofu, it has several other veggies, mushrooms, and peanuts (which I don't typically like in my food) on a bed of silky round rice noodles. I've had the same dish 3 times this week already. 

Previously when I'm craving some home-cooked veggies from my home home, I think and crave for their vegetable of the day, which has always been baby bok choy. The way they prepare it is also quite authentic. I usually eat this with rice. It comes with delicious sauce as a part of the dish. It's listed under sides but don't be fooled, it's quite large of a portion and only $5!

4 stars because I've tried other food items multiple times like pho, sandwiches, and sides of soup and aren't even as good as those two dishes above. Don't even touch the soup, it's too sweet and makes me think that they've tweaked the taste so it caters to more westerners. Sandwiches too dry.
author: May G.

description:
