I've been here a few times now. I've had the mango shrimp salad, grilled pork vermicelli and spring rolls. All were quite tasty and a great choice! I highly recommend this place, but the line can get quite long during peak hours so I'd come early, stop by to put your name on the list and come back, or order ahead using the OrderAhead app if you want takeout. 

This is a go-to for me for Vietnamese food- huge fan!
author: Lillian C.

description:
Came her on a Wednesday night and the place was full. We were seated fairly quickly but waited for some time before someone came by to take our order. 

I was disappointed they were out of Bun Rieu for the night and ordered the beef soup instead. 

The food is pretty delicious. My only complaint is that it was EXTREMELY stuffy in the place. Would be nice if they could crack the door or open the window to allow some circulation. Also, the service was a bit slow even with four servers circulating around.
author: Mimi T.

description: This review is long overdue!! I live extremely close to Tin and have been eating here for well over 3 years (in the restaurant or via takeout/delivery). Some of the best Vietnamese food I've ever had and, hands down, the best pho in SF (yes, even better than Miss Saigon, which I've previously reviewed). Clean, fresh ingredients and vibrant flavors on every dish. Pho Bo is my favorite (with extra broth...yum!); also, the Hu Tieu (delicious garlic-y chicken broth). You can't go wrong with the vermicelli noodle bowls either. A side of Sauteed Baby Bok Choy is always a must along with the Hue Rolls. Just try everything on the menu. It's all spectacular :)
author: Amy G.

description: I normally don't venture to order Bun Bo Hue, because it's hard to make it great, but I did it this time as I heard that they make it very good here. So to my amazement, it is truly great. The broth, the meat, spices tasted delicious. We also ordered Spring rolls and again they are excellent. They are crispy and very tasty. Next time I will try other dishes.
author: Duc T.

description:
Excellent service & great food. They seem to be a little understaffed but the staff they do have are diligent and hardworking. Just have some patience when waiting to be seated or pick up your to-go order. 

There was some miscommunication when we placed our order, so when they brought out a bowl of bun bo hue we didn't order, they returned the noodles to the kitchen, offered to box it up for us anyway, and brought out the correct menu item. They even removed the item from our tab to compensate for the mixup. Now THAT is great service! 

Give the lemongrass pork and pho bo a try! Good stuff.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
There is a high correlation between poor restaurant hygiene and quality Vietnamese food, but Tin proves that correlation does not indicate causation. Tin manages to combine chic, naturalistic decor with cheap, tasty cuisine. The menu is set in an unassuming sans serif typeface and the check comes in a polka dotted book. The lighting is dim and noise level is moderate, considering how many tables can be packed into the space. At 6PM on a Wednesday night, Tin was a bustling gem on an otherwise empty street. I came with a friend and we were seated immediately at a communal table.

We both ordered the Pho Bo ($8.50, +$1 to add beef balls), which is beef broth with rice noodles, rare beef, and brisket. The broth and noodles were good, but the meat slices really stood out to me. Pho joints sometimes compromise on the quality or texture of their meat, hoping that the mere presence of red meat will appease diners, but Tin serves up high quality beef. I also enjoyed the sweet pickled onions (different from the onions already in the bowl) on the plate of vegetable condiments.

If you're looking for solid Vietnamese food and trying to avoid the heart of the Tenderloin, Tin is a lovely alternative.
author: Jessica F.

description: This is yuppie-style Viet food, but in a good way.  Excellent spring rolls!  Pork shoulder is a must have
author: Dela P.

description: Good fragrant pho and great egg rolls at reasonable prices.  Left feeling Service was fast and friendly.
author: Bryant K.

description:
Awesome place for some quick and delicious pho!  It used to be a quick walk from my apartment, but I'll still come back here if I'm in the area.  

Only problem I have with the place is their hours... I always want pho after a night of drinking on Saturday, but I'd definitely come here more if it was open Sunday mornings.
author: Keith C.

description: Their Bo Kho - unreal. So, so good. This place has been a favorite for years,  I haven't been in a while and I'm glad to see them packed at lunch and the food still as good as ever!
author: Alex C.

description: Tin is by far my most favorite place to get Pho in the city! I always get the Pho Bo. The broth is SO GOOD and is perfect on a rainy and cold day. Their spring rolls (cha gio?) is great to share with friends as an appetizer. They have the perfect amount of crunch, and all around great flavor when you wrap them in the lettuce with noodles and carrot.
author: Gina P.

description:
Don't come during lunch unless you have some flexibility with your schedule. The place was packed at 1pm, and we had to wait 20 minutes for a four-top. The pace of the meal was also slow -- two servers were assigned the whole restaurant, and seemed spread thin... delivering pick-up orders to the front, busing and cleaning tables, and managing order taking and water refills. Our food arrived about 20 minutes after we put our order in. And it wasn't until that time that the drinks arrived as well.

But when I dove into my pork lemongrass vermicelli (add the spring roll), it was clear why people were flocking to it and putting up with the wait. Possibly the best Vietnamese food I've had yet. Great dimension and grilled flavor coming from the pork, textures from the crisp veggies, tang from some pickled daikon. It was awesome, and could have only been awesome-r if I'd had time to finish it. But with the clock ticking down til our next meeting, we had to shove some forkfuls in, grab the check, and hightail it out of there.
author: Christina G.

description:
Tin's mango salad is amazing! I absolutely loved it. I would come back just to have it again and again and again. The salad consisted of fresh green mangos, shredded carrots, mints, and a few other items I didn't recognise. It also had prawns and pork belly. All this was coated with a great dressing that was sweet, salty, sour and spicy. Amazing combination. 

I also had the pho ga (pho with poached chicken) with their ginger dipping sauce. The broth was flavourful and not salty. The poached chicken was full of flavour and sprinkled with lovely herbs. I would definitely had it again. 

I noticed that they had a few items that were veggie friendly on the menu so I'll definitely come back try those.
author: Trang H.

description:
This too-low-key Vietnamese eatery has been open for over nine months, and I had no idea it even existed until someone mentioned it to me in passing a week or so ago. Did YOU know it was there? I didn't think so. Imagine my embarrassment since I live just a couple of blocks away. But c'mon, how would I know it's there? It's on the most barren stretch of Howard between 5th and 6th Streets, and it has the most nondescript storefront with the most indecipherable sign. Yep, Tin pretty much violates every rule in the retail marketing handbook. 

Once you enter, it still feels like a blank slate, a vision in minimalist neutrality that belies any indication that it's a Vietnamese restaurant. Wait, there's a skinny, slightly disheveled Gen-Y guy coming our way. Probably going to ask me to take a picture. Happens to me all the time. Oh, that's the waiter. Jamie W. and I are the only ones in the place at about 7PM. Once we sit down, we both notice a noticeable slant to the floor and the table dipped discernibly. We were constantly worried our glasses of Diet Coke would turn into puddles of broken glass. 

Spring rolls are the true litmus test for a good Vietnamese restaurant. Filled with pork, shrimp and vermicelli noodles, the $6 rolls offered here were on the average-to-good side. Not bad, just not in the ballpark of a Pagolac with a generous shot glass full of peanut sauce (see photo). Jamie W. went conservative and ordered the $8 Bun Cha Gio Thit Nuong, which was made up of strips of grilled lemongrass pork and a cha gio (crispy spring roll) on top of a bowl of vermicelli noodles. Hearty stuff. 

Mine required labor. It was the $8 Bun Cha Ha Noi. What came was a plate piled with Romaine lettuce leaves, a mound of vermicelli noodles, grilled pork patties and some morsels of pork belly. I was informed that I needed to pour said ingredients in a bowl with the fish sauce. Gee, couldn't you do it for me? While it took me a while to master the mixing, it was pretty good if rather sloppy since all that pouring and grabbing challenge my lack of coordination skills. Forewarned that it takes twenty minutes to prepare, the $4.50 Grilled Eggplant with Garlic-Chili Fish Sauce looked like an unappetizing mess (see photo), but it was pretty tasty despite its wet state.

We saw no indication of a kitchen. The food would just magically appear through a half-open curtain. We did overhear the waiter talking about the "pha" of which they were apparently out. The way he pronounced it reminded me of Cameron on "Modern Family" when he was trying to ingratiate himself with his Vietnamese baby's Japanese-American pediatrician...."You'll be pleased to know that Mitchell & I will be raising Lily with influences from her Asian heritage...When she's ready for solid food, there's a fantastic 'pha' place right around the corner from our house. Am I pronouncing that right? Is it 'pha'? It's a soup.".... "I don't know. We don't have much 'pha' in Denver." 

FOOD - 3 stars...pretty good Vietnamese but c'mon, Little Saigon is really not that far away 
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...looks like a converted club...and could you fix that floor before all my food slides toward the drain hole 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...certainly attentive...and he recommends the "pha"...is he pronouncing that right? pha? 
TOTAL - 3 stars...how about a more prominent sign...and some color?...just feels hidden among the SoMa warehouses
author: Ed U.

description: I have probably been coming here atleast once a week for the last year and half.  Although the shaken beef here is one of my favorite meals in SF, the drop in quality of service at this place is starting to become really bad and I have decided to come here less often.  All the waiters here act like they're doing you a favor by serving you.  The last several times I've been seated, it takes atleast 10-15 minutes to have our order taken.  The last two times, my main course arrived before my starter. Like wtf?  Ask for the check? Another 10 min wait.  Management better do something or I'm out for good.
author: David S.

description: I have been to quite a few Vietnamese Pho places. Since I only eat halal meat, I usually get vegetarian pho and let me just say that this is my favorite spot for a piping hot bowl of pho. The food is always flavorful here and the portions are perfect. The service can be a little slow as it is a small location with a large crowd most of the time, but this is the type of place where you wait because its worth while when you get your meal.
author: Mariam R.

description:
I get the Pho Bo every time! It's definitely the most flavorful broth I've ever had and I've been to more than a couple Pho places. There's sliced lean beef and sliced beef with a little bit of fat. I only wish there could be a few slices of tendon or tripe but not everyone dig that :)

Service is fast. The lights dim and brighten every once in a while but it's great food and I'm so thankful it's close by!
author: Laura S.

description:
Tin looks like it should be more upscale than it really is. It's all stylish dark wood with nice tables but the food is just typical Vietnamese food like you would find in LIttle Saigon - in other words not fancified like Slanted Door or Hakkasan.  Only tried the pho bo (rare beef & brisket with rice noodles in beef broth - $7.50) when I came here for lunch the other day. The pho was decent, average. I think I prefer Miss Saigon down the street better.

This place is popular at lunch - seemed to be at least 2/3 full the entire time - the cops like it too!
author: Jean K.

description:
I like this place and don't like it at the same time. Granted, their bun bo hue is the best I've had in SF. However, like most low score reviews mentioned on here... I agree that their service needs improvement. 

For instance, I came here right after an evening yoga session and was dying for some bun rieu. There were a list of names waiting on tables; mine was about fourth. When it came to my turn, there was an open table seated for four, but I was just by myself and the party after me had only two people... The server refused to seat either parties if we didn't want to sit together. Uhhh...? Ten minutes later another table for four was opened so he finally seated both parties, separately. 

I only wanted to get my bun rieu fix, which took about an hour and forty-five minutes on a Thursday evening. So yeah, good-to-decent Vietnamese food but service, you are so horribly baddddd!
author: Jen N.

description:
I recently went to Tin and I had an absolutely horrible experience. I'll start this review by saying the one star review is for the service / staff / experience. The food was perfectly fine.

First, when I got there with my girlfriend, they asked if I wanted to wait for one of the few two person tables, or if I'd be willing to share with someone else. We opted to wait. About 5 minutes later, they said never mind, just sit at a four person table (several were available) and we did so.

Then a few minutes later, they sat someone at the table. When we mentioned this to the host, and he moved the gentleman to another table. Two more times a waitress tried to seat someone at the table (I'm not sure why it was a waitress and not the host, probably because he knew he had made a mistake seating us there) before telling us hostilely that if we wanted to sit alone, we should have waited for a two person table. 

When we told them that we did ask to, and after a while they changed their mind, they seemed to get more upset (and never once even spoke to the one particular host who had sat us at the larger table). Quite frankly it didn't make any sense why they would be openly hostile towards us when we asked to wait and only sat where the told us to!

Eventually it got so bad that we had them box the rest of our food and just left.

This was quite possibly the worst service experience I have ever had at a restaurant. I can only hope they don't treat all their customers like this.
author: Andrew E.

description:
Having been here twice now I can now endorse this as one of the better sit-down lunch options in the downtown SOMA area: affordable, nice, fast, takes credit card.

The review highlights don't lie - claypot catfish is quite good. The daily sauteed vegetables are very tasty and the fried imperial roll appetizer is delicious; pho is solid. The best value is probably the $5 banh mi, but I don't recommend the optional $2.50 salad add-on (not worth it).

Few considerations before you go here:
*It gets pretty crowded a little after noon so if you're heading over there about that time expect to wait (though not too long).
*If you are a group of fewer than 4 the odds are good you'll sit with strangers. (Or make new friends, depending on how you see it?)
author: Stephanie T.

description:
I work down the street from Tin and it's definitely one of the go-to lunch places in SoMa. Their pho bo is delicious and is the only thing that I order from Tin. What really stands out to me is the quality of their beef. A lot of pho places will wimp out and give you some "meh" looking pieces, but the amount of beef they give is consistent and not fatty (which is a big plus to in my opinion). Their beef broth is awesome - it's packed full of flavor and doesn't tasted watered down at all! 

Although I only order their pho, I've tasted some of their other dishes thank to my co-workers. Their five-spice chicken is on point and their spring rolls are also pretty bomb. If you're craving a bowl of pho or vietnamese food in general, hit this place up.
author: Nate W.

description:
It's been forever since I've been on Yelp.  But thanks to you, I've finally found a decent pho place in SF.  I was craving some pho today, perfect for a gloomy cold day in the city.  

There isn't much around in the area, about a block down from Bucca.  Luckily, I saw a picture of the storefront on yelp and was able to find the place.  It isn't flashy.  It has a simple modern sign in front to go with the clean modern decor inside.  There were tables for 2 or 4 and one long table, for either a large party or sharing with other customers.  When we arrived for lunch, we didn't have to wait.  But this might be because it was a public holiday.  While we were there, it did get busy and people had to wait for a table, but it seemed to move quickly.

The bf and I ordered spring roll, a 5 spice chicken bahn mi sandwich, and a pho bo.  We also got a pot of oolong tea. 

The order of spring roll came with 2 huge spring rolls cut up into 3 pieces each.  I was surprised at the size because I am used to tiny spring rolls.  This could easily have been a light lunch for just myself.  It had nice size prawns with a slice of chicken or some other kind of meat.  The veggies (lettuce, cilantro, mint) and noodles were fresh.  The rolls needed more cilantro and mint for flavor and less noodles. It tasted kind of bland so you had to drench it with lots of the yummy peanut sauce.

The bf's sandwich was ok according to him.  I asked the waitress if the sandwiches were bahn mi and she said they were.  My bf ordered it since he likes the grilled pork bahn mi from BC Deli in Oakland Chinatown.  It must have been an American version of bahn mi.  It didn't have the pickled veggies or mayo sauce.  It was just a sandwich with chunks of  chicken with slices of cumber and carrots.

My pho bo was delish tho.  The broth was a nice, rich, flavorful beef broth.  Like others noted, it was a little salty.  The noodle was cooked perfectly and they actually used pho unlike my last sf experience at Miss Saigon.  The slices of raw beef was nice and thin.  They seemed fresh and of good quality.  The brisket was tasty and didn't have lots of fat or connective tissue.  The accompaning veggies (bean sprout, basil, lime, and jalapeno) were nice and fresh.  Too bad the broth wasn't hot enough to cook the bean sprouts.

The service was ok.  They answered our questions and took our orders readily.  The food came quickly, in a timely manner and our table was cleared as we finished eating.  We got our bill while we were still eating.  However, when it got busy after we were eating, it took forever to get the attention of our waitress to get a refill of hot water for the pot of tea.  The pot was small and she was nice enough to refill it  with hot water.  

We left full and satisfied.  I am definately going to come back for some more pho.  The portions were good and the prices were decent, especially for SF.
author: Judy K.

description: Some mixed experiences here. Overall 4 stars because the food is great. Service is hit or miss - this place can get really busy during dinner time (expect at least 15-20 min for food to come out, and 10 min for check to get processed). Highly recommend any of the vermicelli bowls, especially the lemongrass pork. The banh mi sandwiches are pretty big here too. I'd pass on the pho. Relatively expensive ($9-10) and the broth is kinda dark and weird. Solid food option if you're in the neighborhood but wouldn't go out of the way for it.
author: Will Z.

description: Expected something much worse but was so pleasantly surprised. Imperial rolls were absolutely tops!
author: Natasha N.

description: Ordered a chicken and pork sandwich to go. It was done fairly quick and tasted really good. Recommend
author: Niosha E.

description: Thought it's not like a traditional Vietnamese food, but the bbh was pretty delicous. Service was good. Quail was crispy and delicous too.
author: Che K.

description:
Great food, horrible service.

This place really needs to get their service act together. They keep a notepad at the front for a "wait list" but it never gets filled out. A two top and 4 top table opened simultaneously. There was a couple before me, I was by myself, and there were two gentlemen behind me in line. The couple before me was immediately sat on the 2 top and then tried to seat me with the two gentlemen on the 4 top.

After I was finally sat my order was taken promptly but beyond that I wasn't acknowledged. My table was never cleared. My appetizer was still on the table when my main had arrived even though I had finished it and stacked and pushed the plate to the side for them to take. The server literally dropped the check from around a wall without saying anything, all I saw was his arm reach around the wall and the check landed on my table. I witnessed one server accidentally slip his finger into one of the guests soups and he continued to bring it to the table without acknowledging it.

The food was GREAT. Very fresh ingredients, I had the spring rolls and a pho tai (not on the menu, I just wanted only rare sliced beef in my pho). Only complaint I would have to say is the portions were small for a Vietnamese place. If you want good Vietnamese food at great prices I would head to the sunset or tenderloin. If you don't mind paying an extra buck for small portions of great food but shitty service then this your spot.
author: Orlando D.

description: Tasty food. Ordered Bo Koh delivery through Doordash and satisfied. Flavor is too strong to my liking.
author: Emo E.

description:
Good food + bad service = three stars
Pho + rare steak = tasty
Soma = walkable to Tin
author: Andy D.

description: Good pho, a little pricey, but good service. I ordered a coke and was brought a Mexican Coke for $5. Not stoked.
author: Breanna R.

description: One of my favorite Vietnamese food places in town. Bun Bo Nuong and Lemongrass Pork should are awesome !! Portion is big food is good. Not to salty or oily.
author: Tia C.

description: Outstanding Banh Mi, fresh spring rolls and a great chicken salad. Excellent service even at the peak of the lunch rush.
author: Eleanor R.

description: Great pho..ok sandwich. I tried five spice chicken sandwich which was very dry and lacked binding agent, like mayo. Chicken was well done. And pho was just great..very flavorful. May swing by again if I am in the area.
author: Nidhi D.

description:
2 stars for the food, 2 stars for the service, 4 stars for the venue. 

I had much higher expectations for this Vietnamese joint, considering the relatively high Yelp reviews overall. The first impression was quite good. The restaurant looked clean, new, and nicely decorated. Probably the only blip of life along that dreary intersection at 5th and Howard. This place was crowded (also pretty small) on a Friday night at 8:30pm, and there was about a 15-20 minute wait. No list to put your name down on, we just waited in line. There was a continuous waiting line throughout our meal and even when we left an hour later. 

We ordered the claypot catfish, Hu Tieu (xa-xiu pork, chicken & shrimp, ground pork in garlic-chicken broth), and the garlic bok choy. Both the fish and the soup broth were extraordinarily salty. I'm not sure if the chef's taste buds were shot that night, but there was just way too much sodium. I wouldn't have expected this to happen in SF were vietnamese cuisine is quite common, and customers know how it should taste. The bok choy was the best dish of the night, but it's pretty hard to go wrong with vegetable sauteed with garlic, salt, and pepper. On the upside, the food was very reasonably priced, especially compared to restaurants in FiDi (like Sai's). Most dishes were $9 or under; I approve :) 

On to the service. There were only two servers and one bus girl for the night, and it was incredibly difficult to get their attention for a refill on ice tea or to even to get the bill. I waved my hands numerous times, but they never looked to the corner of the room. They should really invest in more waiters if they have a large crowd and need fast turnaround. 

I really wanted to have another good Vietnamese restaurant in SoMa (besides Turtle Tower), but unfortunately, this was hardly it.
author: Audrey L.

description: Food was good and fresh. We had the fresh rolls and peanut sauce. The shrimp rolled in lumpia paper was a hit with the kids (as most fried foods). We were really happy they had vegetarian pho in vegetarian broth with a lot of vegetables (and some fried tofu). The kids (4 and 8 year olds) enjoyed their chicken pho. They shared one bowl and were full though they are not big eaters. We got there close to 6pm on Thursday and did not have to wait. The restaurant filled up pretty quickly afterwards. Service was pretty quick.
author: Hannah C.

description:
My go to spot for Bun Bo Hue ($10 per bowl) in SOMA, Very flavorful and fresh ingredients. And, they are able to adjust the spice level to mild or medium spicy if you don't want it too spicy. 

Good service, nice decor, and lively atmosphere. 

Parking is okay in the area, I would avoid parking near 6th Street as it gets sketchy but 5th Street usually has meters open in a lit area.
author: CL S.

description: This is what I get when I try to write a review when it's been past due. Writer's block. I remember the food being really good. Trust. We ordered some crispy spring rolls and that was off the chains good. For myself, I had the braised pork. It was very similar to Filipino Adobo, which is chicken cooked in soy sauce and vinegar. It was definitely not what I had in mind when I ordered it, but delish nonetheless!
author: Sharon B.

description:
A great new SF Vietnamese discovery (thanks Jwhoa for finding this spot via Yelp!). We started with great sauvignon blanc and ordered an appetizer of the Vietnamese crepe to share. I wasn't that familiar with this type of dish but it was so good and I haven't been able to find it as good elsewhere (usually it's too greasy!).

Then, I had the veggie pho and Jwhoa had the chicken pho. Both were great and the chicken pho had great gingery broth! We thoughts about ordering one more dish but our waitress wisely advised that we already had plenty of food coming. Even without the extra  dish, we were happily full after our delicious dinner! Jwhoa has been back and I need to find a time to head back to this random SOMA spot soon!
author: Meghan P.

description: I dropped in looking for substance after a killer run along the Embarcadero. I just found this place by literally walking around. I ordered the pho. It was really good. The broth was rich, the tenderloin slices were rare, but quickly cooked in the broth. Portion on the small side. Not the best I have ever eaten, but sure hit the spot.
author: F J.

description:
Always: Get the papaya salad. Get the five-spice chicken rice plate. Get the pho - especially if you're hungover .. or still drunk. Go home happy.

Tín is my go-to Vietnamese restaurant and I always take my friends here. It's in a convenient location and the prices are very reasonable. It's clean, it's tasty .. My only gripe is there's a wait if you don't get here before the dinner rush, and it can get pretty noisy. Ah, and it's closed on Sundays .. which happens to be when I crave it the most.
 
Tip: Takeout is always packaged nicely.
author: Louie R.

description:
I have to admit, when I was looking for this place, I was like this place should be alright, 4 stars, 1 dollar sign. Then I saw the interior and my mind went "Oh shit, this place looks a bit too nice and upscale to be a pho restaurant." 

It is a bit Americanized. Menu is quite small, only like very generic Pho Ga and Pho Bo with choice of beef balls, some vegetarian pho to cater to the health concerned population. They do offer Bun and rice plates. Again, no broken rice and typical lemongrass grilled meat. 

Portions are decent, as in enough to feed you for a meal. Still on the pricier end for what they serve (serving size and variety). I ordered this lemongrass chicken bun (vermicelli bowl). Not too bad, noodles don't stick together and become hard to mix in with the fish sauce and vegetables. I can't comment too much on how authentic the taste is since I rarely order this dish, but I can assure you that the flavors are there. 

Service is okay; they don't seat you and instantly ask what you want. That's good and bad depending on how hungry you are and how indecisive you are. Pho comes out much quickly than other dishes. I glanced at the neighboring table and noticed that they serve real coconut juice rather than the canned stuff.  Maybe I'll be ordering that next time I come here.

Not bad for a place close to the mall and not yet in the shady area. It's on the way to The Grand so it's not in the ghetto SOMA area yet. Close by that area, but not bad to avoid at all costs.
author: Connie C.

description: This place looks like it could be cool for a real meal. I've done sandwich takeout, which was alright. Less than $10 for a banh mi sandwich, which did have a fair bit of fat on the chicken. The bread was very crumbly, which is generally a good sign for taste, but was messy.
author: B H.

description:
I'm giving it a 4 star because I haven't tried their pho yet, or come here enough to give them the perfect score.

When I first heard about pho in soma, my initial reaction was "why in the world are we going to soma for pho"? "It must be over priced, super expensive for non-authentic vietnamese food." My friend insisted that this place has great reviews and that we should definitely give it a try.

street parking - pretty easy 

I wasn't in the mood for pho since i just had it for days during my hangover recovery. I decided to go with Bun or something different. I ended up ordering Mi Xao Don (check out my photo) the fried crispy egg noodle bowl with sautéed shrimp, pork and lots of veggies! I was a little worried at first because I am not a big fan of jeen meen (chinese style crispy egg noodle with beef and veggies) but the waitress insists it's very good there. When the food arrived, let me tell ya, it looks amazing with all the veggies and the fried crispy noodle shaped bowl! It was amazingly delicious and the portion was huge! The veggies, shrimp and squid were overloading the egg noodle bowl. I absolutely enjoyed it! I could barely finish the whole thing! 
fyi - try their refreshing Lychee infused iced tea (non-sweetened) with your meal! free refill! 

Decor - very modern and hipster (very soma). 
Service - Great service! The waitress was very helpful and attentive. She kept coming back to make sure i liked my order since I obviously had some concerns when i ordered. 

I will definitely come back and check out their pho and bun! I will update the review soon!
author: Mindy C.

description: Very good, very reasonable. Nice atmosphere inside for conversation. The bun with pork shoulder was delectable, the meat juicy and flavor-blasted. The scallion spring roll appetizer was terrific also.
author: Pat F.

description:
I came here for lunch on a Friday and there was a short line. If you are pressed for time, this is probably not the place to go.  Service and waiting for the food took some time.  
The food though was quite good. I ordered the caramelized catfish in the claypot.  Very rich and the fish was tender.  My husband had Pho Ga, which was much lighter/cleaner in taste and had great ginger taste.
I would come again, but maybe when I have a longer lunch hour or even for dinner.
author: Krystle L.

description:
Slightly pricier Vietnamese food here compared to other places in Little Saigon. 

I ordered pho ga. It was decent, but not up to par with Turtle Tower.

Fairly small restaurant, but nicely/modernly decorated. :)
author: Esther Y.

description: I like the vibe of this restaurant and it's really reasonable in pricing. Pho was good although they were out of tripe so that was a little disappointing. Over all I would recommend this for a quick night out if you don't want to spend a lot of money in the city.
author: Ernie K.

description:
Before I launch into my review, you should know that ya girl grew up in Westminster, CA aka Little Saigon aka an area where delicious, cheap, authentic Vietnamese dishes, desserts, and drinks abound. We've got Pho restaurants #1-99 within a 2-3 mile radius and pretty much all the fish sauce you could ever handle. With that said ...

Tin ain't the real deal. It's watered down Vietnamese food. Or something.

I get that they are catering to a very specific crowd so I can forgive them for altering bun rieu to make it a bit prettier (normally, bun rieu has lots of minced pork and crab in the soup which kinda looks vomit-y but tastes absolutely divine). I mean, I wasn't thrilled with the modification but it was still edible. 

 Their beef pho, though ... Oh, it was just so wrong. 

The whole time I was eating, I was like ... "Hmm, there is something really strange about this pho but I can't put my finger on it." Finally it hit me. THERE IS CELERY IN THIS. WHAT THE HELL?! Weird yuck blech. 

That's when I knew I wouldn't be coming back to Tin. There's better VIetnamese food in the city and for way cheaper too.
author: Kathleen N.

description:
This review is for the service NOT the FOOD.


I don't know what is going on at this place but it is either they have some vendetta against me personally or they really don't care about service anymore.


The last two times I been there my food comes out before my drinks. The server disappears and I end up with a different one. No check backs after the food arrives and I get rushed with the bill as soon as I am half way done with my meal. 

It's sad because I love the food there but I will not be going back.
author: Eric S.

description:
04/31/2013

Finally a Vietnamese restaurant that services wine!

A friend of mine highly suggests Tin for their Vietnamese delights: healthy, affordable, and situated in a trendy area. 

Though this is not authentic Vietnamese cuisine, where the reviews i've read mentioned "Americanized" - that is true: the food is good and proportioned well. 

I ordered the ginger chicken with rice and fried egg: filling, very tender chicken, however - ginger profile was subtle. My friend ordered the tamarind shrimp: that was full of flavor, and she subtitled rice for a salad - which was a nice size. 

I do want to try their other dishes, so I will make another trip sometime.
author: Alex C.

description:
I came here with a friend after we had some drinks at a nearby bar. Nothing like pho to sober up! I liked the Pho Bo and it wasn't too expensive either for SF. The staff was friendly; they seated us even though it was really close to closing time. They served us quickly and they didn't rush us or anything. 

I would come back again if I'm in the area!
author: Katherine S.

description: Stop by for dinner in New Year Eve.  Price and portion are decent and reasonable.  I like the Vietnamese chicken salad here, every else is ok.  Definitely I will come here again when I am in city.
author: Tiffany N.

description: Kinda love this place, it's in my neighborhood, clean, reasonable and you can almost always get a table pretty quickly. Everything I've tried on their menu has been pretty good - my favorite is the crepe which is light and crispy.  The salad with the pork belly was another favorite as is the cha gio.
author: Jennifer G.

description: The place gets completely packed over lunch. I got one of their broths and was disappointed, especially after liking the vietnamese cuisine so much in other places. It did not taste good and was much more watery than the stuff i had before. Not coming there again.
author: Anton T.

description: I really enjoyed the pho bo, but wished it came in a bigger size. Quite pricey for a small bowl of pho. However, the broth was super rich. I drank most of it and I never do that.. My friend ordered the grilled pork w/ vermicelli, and that was tasty as well!
author: Yanni C.

description:
So the interior is pretty sweet, nice and cozy. I went on a pretty busy night so had to wait a bit but it wasn't very long.

Now the food. The food wasn't bad. My sister had the vegetarian bun and thought it was aight. Just aight.

The spring rolls were aight too.

I got the banh xeo, which is pretty much my baseline for any Vietnamese place. I specifically ordered the vegetarian one but they ended up giving me the regular one with meat and all that. They were pretty quick to get the right one out after I pointed it out but then they forgot to bring the sauce that goes on it. Since they were busy, I couldn't really get their attention.

But!!!!! But!!!! The banh xeo was the best I've ever had. Not bad
author: Wesley S.

description:
I love this place for so many reasons (and I don't take 5 stars lightly) 
In a sentence; Price, taste and service all exceptional. 

In more than one sentence, I have been to this fun, awesomely decorated, and surprisingly traditional Vietnamese restaurant several times now. Every time I was greeted right away, and had all my menu questions answered by a caring staff.

My top choices are the eggplant appetizer, heui ti soup and lemongrass pork shoulder... God like. 

The portions are perfect. You know what I mean if you've ever ordered way too much Pho and had gelatinous reheated noodles the next day.

The bonus for me is that you get that upscale feel, without the upscale price. Try it out and don't forget the eggplant!
author: Nixie P.

description:
I used to love this place til.....

So i took a group of friends here because i liked this place. When my bun- vemicelli came out it came with the sauce- I noticed there were ROACHES floating around in the sauce. 

I asked the waitress to bring me another- i was like ok this is fine. then when she brought it back she told me oh that batch was thrown out etc. 

Then i noticed there were still ROACHES in my sauce still. She didn't even look at IT!! one thing is to make a mistake but not looking at what you are giving customers is just carelessness. 

I understand every restaurant have bugs but SERIOUSLY are you blind to not check what you are serving people. 

She again asked me if i wanted another one- and I said no- thanks.

Plus i'm a pretty divey eater- like I'm totally fine but this wasn't 1 roach it was like 13 little ones which may have looked like burt sesame seed but thats not whats in the bun- sauce. 

I have not eaten here again.
author: oth k.

description: Tasty vietnamese in SOMA.  The pho was some of the better pho i've had, although I'm not an expert and have never really found a mind blowing pho.  This one is smooth and buttery, the rare beef tender and tasty, and the noodles fresh and springy.  Nicely done.  Appetizers like lotus salad and quail are just so-so.
author: Mike L.

description: The carmelized shrimp clay pot with the fried egg and brown rice is now one of my go to meals in San Francisco. It's just so delicious!
author: Mark S.

description:
You should know from start, this is a review of the service.

I like the food, so much that I been to the place almost a dozen times.  But each time, I promise myself I would not come back because of the service.  No, the servers weren't especially rude or offensive, they simply didn't know what they were doing.

Entering the restaurant, you could be left waiting for 10-15 without anyone acknowledging you.  It seems as though no one knows who's responsibility it is.  Orders take a long time to come out, if at all.  They seem to rush you when you want to stay and never get the check when you need to leave.  Sadly, the experience really does leave a bad taste in your mouth.  The last time I was there, it took 45 minutes for a sandwich that I called ahead for.

Their sister restaurant, Mau, seems much better ran.  Same great food.
author: James B.

description:
Went there for dinner as I was staying at a Hotel nearby and it was wonderful! Had a Pho Ga with Saigon beer and it was great. Place was packed but they still had fast service. They also have pick-up so not bad to order and bring back to the hotel/home. Prices super reasonable... A must try! 
Will try a different thing today as I'm sure it will be as good...
author: Eileen R.

description: One of the best quality pho I have ever had, but certainly shown in the price. With that being said, the size of the bowl was a lot smaller also. I guess that is very expected. But really this is the first time I had beef that was well marbleized and fresh tasting. The broth of the soup also did not taste watered down. So certainly worth it.
author: Nikita K.

description:
Best pho I have met
Like delicious Viet girl
All sexy and fine
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Love the food! 5 stars on food and price.
Service has something to be desired.
Although the service has greatly improved since my first visit. 
My fave dishes are the:
Caramelized Claypot Catfish (amazing texture and flavor)
Wonton Noodles- love all the veggies in this dish (this coming from a total carnivore)
Shaken beef (safe stand by menu option)
Bo Kho- star anise beef broth yes please  the broth is very aromatic and wintery it's delicious

My only real gripe is that they always seem understaffed. Tin is clearly popular and busy can't they add an additional server to accommodate the dinner crowd? It's sad a place with such talented chefs and great menu can't get their act together with the service component. I will still return to eat here but please hire some more servers! Efficiency!
author: Kristy H.

description: This is the type of restaurant where anything you order will be delicious! This is my go-to place for Vietnamese food in downtown SF. I've tried their beef pho, chicken pho, and some specialty phos as well (garlic chicken + shrimp anyone??) and all are absolutely delicious. The seasoning for the pho is absolutely divine. My only complaint would be that the pho never seems to come out piping hot, which is how I normally prefer my pho to be when I get it. I've also tried the lemongrass pork shoulder vermicelli bowl and that is delicious as well! I highly recommend trying Tin! Beware that it is a pretty small place that seats probably 30 people max and you might have to wait in line to get a seat but it is worth it! They have a written waiting list so if there are no open tables when you arrive, be sure to write your name down!
author: Diana F.

description:
If you work in SoMa and dig Vietnamese food, Tin ought to be in your lunch rotation.

Their pho helped me deal with an unrelenting cold and I love that the menu's got a "green of the day with garlic" option. Having never met a green I didn't like I knew I couldn't go without ordering it. On the day I was there it turned out to be baby bok choy and between the two of us we polished off an entire plate of the stuff. The greens were super flavorsome and cooked just enough to leave plenty of crunch and brightness in them.

I'll surely return to Tin when I'm back in the neighb.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Sorry. I don't get all the hype about this place. I'd like to give another star because the very sweet waitress was working the whole restaurant by herself for the better half of our hour-long experience, but I had to stand up to flag her down after we'd been seated for over 10 minutes and were only two of four total people in the restaurant. (We figured a wait wouldn't be a problem at 5:30pm on a Thursday, but be warned -- said lone waitress seemed fairly busy putting all the pick-up orders together and could barely pay attention to the dine-in customers.)

The other reason I'm okay with the 1-star rating is how queasy I became about 8 hours after consuming the meal... no "results" yet (fortunately I guess?), but let's just say seeing that insanely low health score a few minutes ago hasn't helped with the nausea...

As far as the food goes:
-- I am NOT an expert in Vietnamese food, so I've tried to focus on basic principles of culinary enjoyment in this review. 

-- Meals came out in under 10 minutes of placing order.

-- I got the Vegetarian Bun Vermicelli Noodle Bowl (I'm not vegetarian, but the flavors sounded good) and opted for the crispy Cha Gio roll add-on. The bowl and roll both looked delicious, but unfortunately, that's as far as my positive remarks can go. The roll was... crispy. Beyond that, completely flavorless: extra disappointing given all the other raving reviews!! Similarly to their fried counterpart, every ingredient in the bowl was devoid of flavor, even after pouring the vinaigrette over the whole thing. The tofu was fine as far as texture goes, but the shitake mushrooms tasted kind of rancid.

-- My friend got the Bun Thit Bo Nuong (lemongrass beef) Vermicelli Noodle Bowl and also felt cheated of the opportunity to experience any kind of flavor. The effect, if any, her meal had on her GI system is pending her response to my text message.

-- In both of our bowls, the noodles were cold and the other ingredients were a variety of temperatures... not sure if that's how it's supposed to be, but I'm leaning toward no.

-- The pinot noir is decent, but considering they charge $7 a glass when it's a bottle that retails around $10 and the meals themselves cost $8-9, that's sort of ridiculous. (I know it's dumb to complain about this, but being queasy makes me grumpy.) 

K. I'm done. Hopefully y'all will have a better experience should you choose to go.
author: Justine M.

description:
The best pho place (next to Turtle Tower!) for it's french-vietnamese cuisine. 

My bf and I ordered the spring rolls to share (HUGE - I could literally eat this as a whole meal), the Pho Bo and grilled chicken vermicelli.

Pho Bo: A little salty, but the ingredients are SUPER fresh. The beef is very fresh too - the meat came raw and it looked freshly cut, not greasy like most pho places.
Vermicelli: You can add a fried eggroll for $1.50; the grilled chicken was cooked perfectly and everything went very well together!

Bill came out to around $27 (including tip) - very decently priced!
author: Stephanie W.

description: I recommend the Bun Bo Huy spicy lemongrass soup...when I'm not feeling well this always makes me feel better. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu, the ginger chicken, chili lemongrass chicken thighs, papaya salad, they are all yummy!
author: Courtney V.

description:
"Hu Tieu". That's all I have to say. Okay, also "vietnamese coffee". There. That's REALLY all I have to say. For now.

Fine, fine, I'll elaborate. I've only been here once, I had the aforementioned pork and seafood noodle soup, with a sweet coffee. Both were very, very tasty and satisfying after a long day of work. I think my favorite part was that first spoonful of broth - soooo gingery, so porky, yet also shrimpy - all without a hint of wateriness or blandness.  By far the worst part was that last spoonful of broth - staring helplessly into that empty bowl, knowing it could be hours, days, or (god forbid) weeks before I found time for another meal here. Sigh.

You may notice I gave them only 4 stars, despite such praise. What can I say, I'm no cheap trick,  I don't just give 5 stars out like candy - you've got to EARN such a score from me, mister! Show me your rice, show me your sandwiches, give me a drink or two, THEN we'll talk about 5 stars!
author: Seth N.

description:
Ordered so much on the menu and it was yummy! I got the spring rolls, lotus root salad, bun thit nuong (without broth) and the tofu banh mi. I thought the bun thit nuong was my least favorite.
We went on a weekday lunch with a baby in a stroller. Small and very busy place for lunch, but we fit comfortably!
author: Apeksha P.

description:
Good food but shitty slow service.


I usually order bok choy.

I think they could improve a lot by having more waiters on staff.

It takes forever to fill my water glass. I live right around the corner but I know if I go here I'll lose about 1.5 hours of my life.

Too slow. Only recommended if you have time.
author: Kumar T.

description:
One of the best things about travelling as a Yelper in the USA is that you have a bank of ready made friends in each city! Dorothy C had kindly taken me to the Asian Art Museum on my trip to SF last year and she offered to expand my art horizons at SFMOMA this year

We therefore looked for a lunch option in close proximity and Dorothy's friend, Ed U suggested Tin on Howard St.

Despite us both starting at Powell St BART station, I think I took the slightly less 'colourful' route to the restaurant! Teddy and I recognised Dorothy coming in the opposite direction to us and she told us about some interesting characters and shops she had encountered along the way!

The restaurant was busy with lunch service but we were seated quickly and the food came out impressively fast. Nice friendly ambiance providing the perfect atmosphere for us to catch up

Dorothy went with a sandwich and I tried the Hu Tieu noodles in broth - xa-xiu pork, chicken & shrimp, ground pork in garlic-chicken broth. It was lovely and perfect portion size for lunch. Deep flavour in the broth with enough variety of stuff to munch with each mouthful to keep it interesting

My limeade could have done with a bit more sugar syrup but was obviously freshly squeezed

The bonus was the very reasonable cost - $10 per person

Dorothy and I were fans!
author: Yee Gan O.

description: If I have never had pho the Bo Pho was a decent soup. It just didn't taste like pho but on the bright side the meatballs I added tasted fantastic. Also tried the spring rolls which were average. Sorry San Fran.
author: Eugene S.

description: I was here for lunch today with my gfs. We all ordered four bun bo nuong with egg roll. Its sad because on yelp there pictures looks really good . but in reality their beef roll is  on a dry side. I also thought its kinda weird that they put carrots instead of onion to roll up their beef. I agree with other s reviewers that their service is not that great. Especially!! That 50ish year old hostess guy that throw us the menu..he has a beard n mustache. I asked the guy for the check . he saw me n nod but never bought my check.
author: Aniko N.

description:
I was very excited to try this place because it seems to be one of the few Vietnamese restaurants around that offer vegetarian options. I ordered the veggie banh xeo and the veggie pho.

The banh xeo was delicious. Perfectly crispy on the outside and soft  inside, not too oily, and served with a vegetarian "fish" sauce.

The veggie pho was rather disappointing. It was as if the noodles were pre-cooked and placed dry into a bowl, and then the broth was added much later. The result was a noodle brick that didn't separate into noodles, but rather little clumps of overcooked and broken rice dough.

That said, I'd be willing to return just for the banh xeo, so all in all still a great discovery. :)
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Prompt and efficient wait staff.

Nice interior decor and menu choices for the price.  Most placed serving $7 bowls of pho are dirty and have the interior decorating appeal of a gas station but this place definitely looks more expensive than it is.  The food was tasty and healthy and the service was prompt and efficient.  The restaurant and bathroom were clean so there isn't much more I could ask for!
author: Megan L.

description:
Great quality vietnamese food, compares slight better than Miss Saigon which is just down the street. Often busy so plan to wait a little bit, especially during lunch time. I had the bun bo hua, pho, and spring rolls. 

If you don't want to go all the way to the Sunset or Richmond or Tenderloin for more authentic places, this is your best bet!
author: Sunny Y.

description:
You can always measure a Vietnamese place by its Pho Ga, and Tín definitely gets the job done. The ginger in the broth is a really nice touch.

The service was a bit passive, and the neighborhood leaves a bit to be desired, but I will definitely be heading back for a Pho fix!
author: Matt T.

description:
The clay pot catfish was delicious, it melts in your mouth with every bite! The soy-based chicken wings were sub-par and the accompanying pepper sauce was a little weird. my only complaint is that they charged almost $3 for a can of soda, which is a little ridiculous! Otherwise the prices were pretty fair for the quantity and quality of food (especially in SF). 

In sum, I'd come back to try the Pho!
author: Tasha T.

description: One of the best Vietnamese restaurant in SF that I've ever tried. Whenever I visited the city, my family and I usually went to this spot for some vietnamese dishes. I got to try the Hue rolls, Spring rolls, Bun cha ha noi, Hu tieu, and Bun rieu and they were delicious. If you have a chance then come here and give it a try for some traditional Viet foods.
author: Anne T.

description:
This review is NOT about the food because the food is delicious. However the service on the other hand is a whole different story. My bf and I came here once and apparently something about him offended her...our drinks came out after our food came out and she didn't even ask us if we wanted refills nor did she even check up on us. 

Today's meal review: we came back to give this place a second chance and she was working there and I guess she told our server about us and some other guy started serving us..again they didn't ask us for refills and didn't check up on us yet again. And we had another person in our party! It's safe to say we are never coming back to place this. The shitty service outweighs the delicious food.
author: Katarina F.

description: Great little eatery in soma for authentic Vietnamese food. Their clay pot shrimp and their fried egg rolls are delicious and their house made lime aid is refreshing. The shaking beef was a little but overcooked. I like that you can add fried egg or substitute brown rice to all the rice dishes.
author: Betty C.

description: No thrills service by strong lady with tattoos that hits the mark at all levels but especially the food. Check it out.
author: Tony P.

description:
This is going to go into my next list:

 "How I Spent My Summer Vacation." 

Okay, so its September, heading for October. Actually (ten minutes ago) its October. 

Summer is as summer does.

It was a glorious day, yesterday. Took BART to SF where I met 

Yee Gan "Yogi Bear" O. (London Yelper)

for lunch at Tin. The place was recommended by Ed U. as being close to SFMOMA. And after lunch, Yee Gan and I were going to tour SFMOMA.

(Life is tough when you are retired. Summer vacation tends to stretch endlessly toward Thanksgiving....)

So, about Tin. 

Fantastic! 

edu.yelp.com 
Ed "SF Travel Examiner" U.
  
 knows his stuff!

 TIn was an easy stroll from the Powell Street BART station. Not at all crowded. And in an interesting area, with painted light poles, many small artsy businesses. A few interesting people (like the lady in the Levi's jacket with the Virgin of Guadalupe painted on the back.)  

Safe. Sunny. Friendly. 

Tin was clean, authentic. Cheap. (Did I mention cheap?? We went Dutch. My bill was under $10. As was his.)

Sandwich for me. Pho for YG. Coffee, Limeade.

Perfect. 

Headed for SFMOMA with a spring in our steps. Two old friends out for a stroll on the Streets Of San Fran. 

Thanks Ed U, you are soooo right! 

Tin was the perfect place for lunch. In fact, I'm taking Mr. Frugal to Tin this weekend. 

At 10 bucks, he'll be pleased.
author: Dorothy C.

description: My favorite eatery in SOMA! Must try their Bun Bo Hue and crispy rolls. Iced Vietnamese coffee is amazing too. Food is delicious and affordable. U can't find an "all-some" lunch/dinner place like this in SOMA.
author: Shaz L.

description:
Cha Gio ($6): Not that special. I thought it would be with all that shrimp, jicama, taro, woodear mushrooms, glass noodles.... I didn't taste the taro, didn't taste the shrimp and I don't recall tasting the mushrooms... overall, nothing special. http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Wp0UYNJlUBxjppSE0eLc-g/l.jpg

Hu Tieu ($8.50): Pretty interesting broth. I actually didn't add much to it but hot sauce. The chicken was very very dry. That was the downside of this dish. http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/II6isRoodwCKNvErNVsQrw/ms.jpg

Service was ok, a bit on the slow side and it was hard to get the servers attention when we wanted to order or get our check.
author: Erica T.

description: What a RIP-OFF!  Got the Pho Bo for $9.  Yes, good quality of meat, but the bowl was teeny tiny... half the size of what my friends got (they got the veggie bowl, which was still smaller than any other pho place in the city). Never going here again. first and last time.  Screw this place! Cheap Cheap Cheap! Look I'm a birdie! CHEEEEEAP!  $1.50 worth of noodles and meat for $10.  Cheeap!
author: Justin K.

description:
The service at this place is  pathetic.   I've been completely ignored by the staff for a solid 25 mins now.  Also their health score is not good.

The soups are very tasty however which is why they get the three.
author: Beeza B.

description:
The atmosphere here seems classy. It's dark and fancy and feels higher end than normal pho places.

I don't know if it was the day we came here (Saturday around 12:30PM) but the service here was pretty slow. It seems like it was only the main guy working. When we first got there, there were plenty of empty seats. However, the guy took awhile to sit us down. I noticed that to almost everyone who came after us.

I don't know why there wasn't anyone else there working but he was the one who was sitting everyone down, he was taking people's order, taking people's order who was getting it to-go, getting people's checks, and just everything. Eventually near the time we were leaving, we noticed another lady who walked around and refilling our water and also taking dishes from the tables.

I got the regular Pho. They only have one size but it was a decent amount. The Pho was just average tasting but since there aren't many Pho places in SoMa it's decent.

Overall, the Pho is just okay but the service here on the weekend was pretty slow since it was mostly just one guy doing everything. 

Pros:
-Okay Pho
-In SoMa
-Fancy looking place

Cons:
-Slow service on the weekend
author: Paul U.

description: Pretty good Vietnamese food if you're craving it and is in Sf. Downside, it's a bit pricy for me especially since I'm from Sacramento and I could get way more food at a cheaper price. Don't snap at me about the living cost, wages, etc. I completely understand the difference between Sacramento and Sf. Its good Vietnamese food and I would come back if I was really craving Vietnamese food and in the area.
author: Mai Y.

description:
Love the food here as it was a regular place for lunch with coworkers. The wait to sit was usually short, but the service was mediocre at best. They were just short and not overly friendly. 

If I were to recommend a dish, I enjoyed the 5 spice chicken. Also, if you ever want to try a fresh coconut drink, you can get one here!
author: Tevis S.

description: Grabbed lunch at Tín with the husband while he was on a break from the SF ALA conference last month, and it was a great choice. I had Pho Ga, and the broth was flavorful w/o being too salty, the meat was tender, and they included some pickled onions along with the usual basil-and-bean-sprout fixin's, which was a nice touch. Affordable, too!
author: Sylvia C.

description:
THIS place. OMG. Seriously. Had a 3 day stay in SF and i ate here everyday. 
The pho is great. 
The vermicelli bowls are out of this world. i had the Bun Thit Bo Nuong. The grilled lemongrass beef. Are you kidding me with how good this is????
 I have no idea why they aren't more descriptive on the menu. It just states "lemongrass beef" NO NO NO! Its so much more. It's beautifully seasoned beef that has been wrapped around carrots and radishes.  Not your run of the mill sliced and seasoned beef. This is amazing! MIND BLOWN. I'll post a pic in the gallery.

It's a clean contemporary style restaurant thats a bit on the small side. Also, this place will get packed. 

Till we meet again yummy food from Tin. xoxo
author: Esther S.

description: Delicious and filling pho bo. The place gets packed right around noon, so come early if you want to skip the lunch crowd.
author: Megan B.

description: I just started working at a firm across the street and this place always hits the spot!!! I haven't ordered anything I didn't like! Their food is really, really good! I wanna say, better than Le Colonial!!! Also, very reasonably priced! Service is just as great as their food. Would not think twice about this place! I could eat here everyday!
author: Kate W.

description: The servers were very unattentive. We ordered our food and 45 minutes later it still wasnt there, which is ok because mistakes are made but no one even came to offer an explanation or an apology. They even seemed upset when after 45 minutes we asked where our food was. We got up and left after waiting close to an hour with no food.
author: Ali H.

description: I like this place.  Clean (decent service, easy street parking (the times that I've gone, anyway).  The food is pretty good - it's not perfect but I'd go back.  For example, the bun bo hue is well-seasoned, even though the soup doesn't have a depth of flavor - almost as though it didn't have enough time on the stove.   Has a nice heat.  I didn't try the pho but this is the only place where the S.O. was happy with the beef pho, so that counts for something.  I wouldn't order the squab again.  I like the shaking beef.  Crispy noodle's not great, but we still clean it up whenever someone wants to order it.  Overall, I can think of better places for individual dishes, but across the board, Tin does all right.  I'd also have to go further or dirtier for these better places.  Tin wins.
author: Erika C.

description: Good place to go to in Soma for some Pho Bo for dinner. I also had their imperial spring rolls, which were good and the catfish which was too salty. I would stick to Pho Bo and spring rolls.
author: Kai C.

description:
3.5 stars. 

Right off the bat, Tin is a lot nicer and classier than 95% of Vietnamese joints out there. Now usually for Asian restaurants, this means worse food and higher prices. It's more or less true at Tin as well, but I found Tin to be pretty good despite that. 

Here's what I've tried:

Bun rieu - Looks a bit "cleaner" than most Bun Rieus I've eaten but still good nonetheless. 

springs rolls - so so , very standard. nothing I would get again.

Bun Bo Hue - Not the best i had, but actually really good!

It's $8 ish per plate. There isn't a whole lot of customization options at Tin unlike most Vietnamese places. And not a lot of "undesirable" parts to put in your pho, which happen to be my favorite parts. It is very obviously catered to the less Asian SOMA crowd. I like my pho with tripe and tendon, thanks.
author: Julie K.

description: Had the 5 spiced chicken and emperor roll - loved it! Found the food very good and satisfying. Great to have a good Vietnamese option without going to the Tenderloin/Little Saigon area...
author: Michael K.

description:
Great spot to have dinner with friends. Sometimes there's a bit of a wait (it's not a huge place), but it's worth it. 

Good fresh spring rolls, good pho, and great shaken beef. I've been here several times and the food has never disappointed. We had a waitress drench a friend in water once, and we left the place laughing about it with the waitress, who was a doll.

The good: great food.
The bad: small waiting area, so good luck if it's raining and you have to wait outside.
author: Amanda B.

description: It's not easy finding a good bowl of bun bo hue in San Francisco, Tin Vietnamese Cuisine has the best.
author: jacob m.

description: This is a good place for a simple dinner. The presentation is a little bit more hipster than your average pho restaurant (and the portions a bit smaller and prices a bit higher). The food is good as is the service. I would come here if I wanted to eat attractively presented Vietnamese food, have fancy cocktails, and was with a friend who isn't totally comfortable with "ethnic" restaurants. However, if I wanted a giant trough of addictively aromatic pho with lots of yummy leftovers, I would venture into the Tenderloin.
author: Cat M.

description:
I had lunch several times here. Recommend to go there before noon. 
I had Shaken Beef, Papaya salad and some chicken dishes. I was not fun of some spices they used but over all, good. Next time, I will try Pho. 
Since it is a busy place, felt bad for asking a waiter for a more water.
author: Akiko M.

description: Best Pho in the city! Love the chicken ginger broth! The crispy egg rolls are also AMAZING! Great hidden spot in SoMa!
author: Natalie O.

description:
This place is awful.  

The has one of the slowest and most disorganized service staff I have ever experienced.  I put in a very simple order to-go: spring rolls and a chicken sandwich.  The host, who is also a waiter and settles people's bills, told me that my order should be ready in 15 minutes.  After 40 MINUTES, he finally came out with my order and just quickly said, "Sorry."  I have no idea whether my order actually took that long to get made or if someone forgot to bring it out.  It doesn't matter.  The restaurant obviously knows it's busy during the lunch hours, so GET MORE STAFF!  

This place doesn't even have very good food.  It's only busy because of its location.  The spring rolls had really dry and tasteless pork in them, and my fiance said his sandwich was mainly all bread.  I will never eat here again.
author: Rose D.

description:
My second experience with Tin is much better. 
This time I get to try Bun Cha Ha Noi (pork patty vermicelli), Bun Rieu, Chicken Salad, and the fried spring rolls.
I have to say all of them is very authentic, tasting exactly like the food I usually get in Vietnam. 
Kudos to the chef for making the spring rolls from scratch instead of just frying the premade frozen rolls in grocery stores. 
The Arnold Palmer (lemon iced tea) is surprisingly good, just the way I like it. I haven't had a better Arnold Palmer anywhere else except for when I actually make it myself haha.
However, I take off 1 star because of the rather generic and unenthusiastic service or lack thereof, since the waiters were very fast-paced and not apparent most of the time, and it wasn't even busy.
author: Alan T.

description:
I've had both the Hu Tieu and the Bun Bo Hue here and each had its pros -- I like the garlic chicken broth of the Hu Tieu but found it sort of lacking in ingredients (e.g. my dish came with very little shrimp), while the Bun Bo Hue comes with lemongrass soup (which might be your thing!) but is noticeably meatier. Overall, the pho is good but it's hard paying $11+ for pho when it's very much cheaper elsewhere in the Bay Area (oh SF...)

Re: the service here. I came on a Friday night once with some coworkers, and when a line started to form, I felt like we were being rushed. Not the best impression.
author: Linda Y.

description: Service has been slow there.. Waited about an hour to get our food, but their food is soooo good.
author: Kristen F.

description:
This place was super good. 
We went here on a break during a local con and found everything to be flavorful, with just the right amount of attention from the wait staff. 

I had the shaking beef and omg! So good. Probably the second best shaking beef I've had. And to top it off I asked for a fried egg and it was perfect. Super delicious. 

My brother had the pho and the broth was so flavorful with the perfect mix of herbs and spices. 

My one critique is that the servings feel a bit small. But since everything was so full of flavor, I was okay with the amount.
author: andrew c.

description: I've eaten at about 20 Vietnamese places in The City, and Tin has the best five spice chicken anywhere; including the few joints I've eaten at in San Jose (Vietnamese mecca).  Always friendly service.
author: Mitori H.

description:
Great food. Nice place. Service is mediocre. 

I had the lemongrass pork shoulder with a fried egg on top and I was not disappointed at all. I would love to go back and try several other dishes.  The ambience is great. Love the framed photos on the wall. The service left something to be desired. Sat with my party for way too long before our order was taken. Perhaps they need more hands on deck during the lunch rush...(the line starts backing up out the door)... in any case, I intend to go back. Highly recommend this place if you are looking for good eats in SOMA.
author: Judi B.

description: The chili lemongrass chicken is SO INCREDIBLE!!! I don't even live in the area and I WILL come back for that chicken!!!!
author: Kristin W.

description: Come here for the food, service sucks and takes forever to get a seat and your food. I ordered to go once and will probably do that more in the future. I actually haven't tried their pho but I did enjoy their vermicelli bowls and banh xeo.
author: Lisa P.

description: Overrated. Service sucks. So many better options in SF. I won't come back. Not sure why there are so many positive reviews. I don't get it like some of the folks here.
author: John V.

description:
This is definitely a proper Vietnamese restaurant!  Not all Vietnamese restaurants will make banh xeo (Vietnamese pancake), and amongst those who serve it, not all do it well like Tin did.  The other really authentic item on the menu is the Goi Ga which is made with Rau Ram! I was very excited to see this because I actually grow Rau Ram in my spice garden!

These items were shared, accompanied by the Cha Gio, Canh Ga Chein and washed down with a Saigon Export to round out the Vietnamese experience!

The food was so good I don't remember much about the service, but do remember that the ace did seem to be trying to turn people over rather fast, which I would expect....but which takes one star!  Prices were VERY GOOD but higher than you can find for Vietnamese because it is in a cool neighbourhood.
author: Sean C.

description:
Great place to eat around 6th and Howard! 

I've tried a variety of things off the menu, and haven't been disappointed with anything! 

The Vietnamese crepe is crisp and delicious (even though messy). I love the varieties of pho, but tend to like their chicken stock a bit more than the beef stock. Wonton is yummy. One of these days I'll try one of the clay pots...it's quick, delicious and not overly priced.
author: Angela F.

description: I had one of the worst experiences here I have ever had at a pho place.  Me and my friend came here on a Saturday afternoon. We ordered the Pho Bo, and when the waiter was bringing our food to us he spilled pho on me. He then proceeded to set down the food with no apology or anything. I asked for another one because the soup was all over the place on the bowl and on the plate. They gave me a new one, but still no apology. The pho was okay. It was a lot smaller than I thought it would be, and I wasn't very impressed with the broth. It tasted like they put celery in the soup which is not traditional for pho and  it didn't work well with the other flavors. In addition, my noodles were not heated well and they clumped and stuck together in the bowl. I don't think I will be coming back here. I would recommend Pho 2000 instead.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
This is without a doubt, the best Vietnamese in San Francisco. It's not close. I say that utterly without hesitation or fear or contradiction.  I've been in the City for three years in search of good Vietnamese and have been bitterly disappointed.  The available options range from the truly awful (Turtle Tower) to the barely mediocre (Sunflower).  Tin is simply in another universe.

First and foremost, they have got the fundamentals right.  The broth is rich and tasty.  The vegetables are fresh and fragrant.  The meats are lean and well-trimmed.  Noodles are firm and tasty.  I've had the Pho Ga and Wonton Egg Noodle Soup.  Both outstanding.  Last time I was there, my friend ordered the Canh Ga Chien (soy garlic chicken wings), which were a unique and wonderful interpretation of an old standard.  Their prices are amazingly reasonable for what you get.  I've ordered for delivery and even their web site is fantastic.  It's powered by OrderAhead and has a clean, intuitive interface that allows you to customize dishes, order, and pay right through the tool.  

These guys really have it right.  I can only hope that local Vietnamese restaurateurs are paying attention and realize that it's time to step up their game.
author: Franklin F.

description: We live next door to Tin and my roommates and I literally go at least once a week. Great selection, great service, and delicious food. Definitely a great spot in SOMA!
author: Liz B.

description:
mm...  caramelized clay pot catfish. piping hot, flaky and tender with a well seasoned salty sweet broth.  and only $10-12 or so.

their pho is pretty good too, but I come here for the catfish.

some of the staff is not that nice.  one of the hosts was a bit rude to me and it kind of put me off. but no matter, the food makes up for it!
author: Jimming C.

description:
I didn't try anything other than the rice paper spring rolls and the Pho Bo, so can't speak to the other dishes. 

First, the spring rolls were ok, these are hard to screw up, but their peanut sauce was too thick and didn't taste like the stuff you normally get in authentic Vietnamese places. Next, the Pho. The broth was somewhat bland, and the rice vermicelli was too thin. Usually good Viet places have the thicker noodles, and these were almost like spaghetti noodles. The beef was just ok. 

The service was also just ok. They were going for a more hip atmosphere, which, if you aren't screwing up the food, fine, try to something different. But with the mediocre food, it just made the atmosphere less appealing.  The servers weren't overly friendly or accommodating.  Next time I'll stick to a more authentic Vietnamese place and skip Tin.
author: Steven M.

description:
After taking TIn to go several times and really enjoying their soups, we decided to stop by being the area for another event. This place is forever ruined for me. 

The service was awful. :( Very rude. The restaurant was at maybe half capacity and we sat for 20+ minutes after we were seated with no one saying a word to us until we called someone over. 

The catfish we ordered was literally about a 4oz portion of fried catfish with a serving of white rice that was five times as large. 

The pho that we normally get came with thick rice noodles for some reason that were soggy and breaking down in the soup. This was never the case with the 4+ other times we've ordered this dish. The beef smelled fishy, which is never a good sign in a Vietnamese restaurant. 

So, Tin, I'm giving you a three here. 
5 for the times we've done take out, and 1 for the time we didn't.
author: Anthony G.

description:
We were genuine walk up's...walked past the door, looked in and saw a couple of inviting dishes, checked in on Yelp and walked in...
It is a joy when food moments like this arrive which are unplanned and spontaneous.
And the joy is even greater when the service is good and the food is better than expectation...we shared the Lotus salad, Mango salad and Catfish with brown rice and egg....and some fresh spring rolls. It was 10 out of ten from the three of us.
Great food, excellent value and definitely on the revisit calendar....
author: Mick A.

description: Great SOMA lunch time spot, try the Hue rolls! A cut above your average Viet food.
author: Steve S.

description:
This veggie Pho is groundbreaking.

The broth is amazingly flavorful--not the thin mixes you'll see from other Vietnamese places that want to pay lip service to being veggie-friendly. The veggies are fresh and crisp and the mix of tofu is just right. They give you this purple and red sauce which elevates the entire dish.

The waiters kind of suck though. I won't go so far as to say they are mean per se, but they are very much about business. If you are the type of person that doesn't want to deal with fuss, maybe this will work for you.

They also do a good takeout business, but if there's a long line waiting to get seated it's going to impact how quickly you get your food to go.
author: Paul C.

description: Decent and good flavored food.  Problem is with the staff, they are slow/lazy and careless.  I had a small hair in my lunch today, couldn't get the server's attention to report it.  Oh well!
author: Steve S.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by this place. The neighborhood is sketchy and that was my main hesitation, I did not expect a good food in this neighborhood. My friends took me here and I am glad they did. The restaurant is small but they serve good food. Efficient service and good menu selection. I work nearby so I'll definitely be back. I hope this neighborhood improves soon and restaurants like this one will definitely help that.
author: Jeff M.

description: Best Vietnamese food I've had so far on the East side of San Francisco. The soup was tasty but not salty or filled with MSG. Really reasonable prices too. Highly recommended.
author: Ronan B.

description: Really delicious green papaya salad, with plenty of garlic, chili oil and fish sauce. The egg noodle soup with wontons was just okay. The wontons were hand made, small and tender, but the broth was pretty bland.
author: Colleen M.

description: Always happy eating here. Recommend the pho, the banh xeo, and the shaking beef. Have only been here for dinner and service is always a little slow. Easy parking on the street most of the time.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Get the vermicelli with the carrots and onions rolled inside the meat! Also the vegetarian vermicelli is great. Super flavorful and the tofu is marinated to perfection. 

This is probably the best Vietnamese restaurant in sf. Hands down. I'm from Southern California and am accustomed to a certain level of taste and flavor. I had tried at least a dozen Vietnamese restaurants in and around the sf area am was super disappointed until I randomly found Tin. By far the best vermicelli in town. I may go as far as to say it's better than some SoCal Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Hieu D.

description:
Had chicken pho - very good and very reasonable.

Service was a little slow, but overall waiters were friendly.
author: Charlie B.

description: Service is incredibly slow....food was ok but not worth the wait. I should've been out of here an hour ago.
author: Jenn L.

description:
White hipster waitress. Clean chopsticks. Ninety percent white clientele. Wine list. No tripe. Skeptic mode engaged. 

All red flags aside, I was very, very pleasantly surprised. Good textured noodles, fresh broth that's flavorful without being all MSG-y, fresh produce ingredients, and good quality meat.
