Their lack of a large option for pho is ridiculous given they already have large bowls for other dishes. But other than that and the lack of tendon and tripe, I can't really complain. I was really impressed for SF pho. Not South Bay level, but quite good.
author: David C.

description:
This place quickly became one of my favorite go-to place for vietnamese food in sf.

I highly recommend:
- pho ga (chicken pho)
- vermicelli dish with grilled pork

I will definitely be coming back to try other dishes.
author: Karen K.

description:
Some of the best pho ever!

It was rainy and cold in SF the other day, so we ducked in here for a quick dinner. The pho warmed me all the way through and was incredibly soothing. The broth was some of the best stuff I've ever tasted. It was so savory and rich and light at the same time. I had the Pho Bo, which at $7.50 is incredibly reasonable for fantastic Vietnamese food in SF. I ended up in SF again the day after, and we wanted to come here again, but they're closed on Sundays. =(

In fact, thinking about it now, I want some more. That's how great this place is. 

Also, we ordered five-spice quail as an appetizer. It had this amazing peppery lemon sauce, and the quail wasn't at all gamey. I ended up dipping the extra bean sprouts I had into that sauce because it was so good. It was so incredible (though small). This is something you must must must try if they have it (I think it's seasonal). It's not on the menu, but they had it listed at the front counter.

In my opinion, it would be worth it to make an SF trip (from Berkeley) just for this place.
author: Lucy H.

description: Obsessed. My husband and I go here or get food to go at least once a week. Nothing fancy but food is amazing and cheap. VERY authentic. Our favorites are the catfish clay pot, lemongrass pork, and the garlic baby boy Choy side. Best "hole in the wall" gem in SOMA by far.
author: J H.

description: Outstanding lunch in a boisterous place. Walked in at 2 pm expecting to see it winding down from lunch, but it had a single table open out of the twenty they have. Service was very quick for being slammed, but the quality of the food didn't lack for anything. Excellent pho with tender meats and I will be back for that broth. Great place.
author: J K.

description: Pretty excellent pho joint. I pleasantly surprised by the fairly hip atmosphere of the place when I walked in. I ordered the pho ga (chicken pho) which had a nice and light tasty broth complemented with notes of ginger. The portions sizes here are pretty generous and they aren't skimpy on the protein either. We got here fairly early on a saturday night, around 6ish. There was no wait at that time; it started to get really busy at around 7. Would recommend this place to anyone looking for pho in the city.
author: Kevin N.

description: Great spot! A bit hidden but I was surprised at the clean dim-lit ambiance and quality of food. I tried the braised pork with rice and my boyfriend had the wonton soup. Personally, I didn't think the soup had much flavor however the pork dish made up for that. It was flavorful, tender, and overall delicious! We also ordered the spring rolls (without mint) which were a good size for an appetizer. If you're looking for good Vietnamese food and need a break from the hole-in-the-wall spots, this is a step up for I think just as equal quality.
author: Jamie B.

description:
Pros: Broad but manageable selection including light lunch options such as quail and chicken noodle soup
Great for one-on-one lunches or supper
Cons: Limited number of tables for parties exceeding 2 people means not great for groups
Crowded almost to the point of making you fight for space
author: Vatche A.

description: Tin Vietnamese has great Pho. The spring rolls are tightly wrapped and don't fall apart when you dip them in the peanut sauce. The Lychee Iced Tea is super refreshing too. There's a wait at lunchtime, but it clears up by 1:00 so you should get right in after that time. It's a small place with not a lot of staff, so expect slower than normal service...but the food is worth it.
author: Bianca R.

description: I got the bun cha, which I think was excellent since the last time I had it was in Hanoi. The pork meatballs and pork belly had a nice char on it and was very very flavorful. My husband had the chicken pho which he thought was a little bland, but all in all, it was a very very good meal.
author: Orchid B.

description: This place was amazing. The pork shoulder was tender and delish! We ordered the shrimp pork spring rolls for dinner and those were  decent. I wasn't a big fan of the peanut sauce. Despite the spring rolls I will definitely go to this place again.
author: Christina R.

description: Bomb Pho!  My girlfriend and I come here periodically but if you asked us, we don't eat here enough.  She is vegetarian and gluten free, I eat anything and we both get down here.  The Pho is fresh, scalding hot and totally delicious.  Good service, food comes up quick and I always leave full to the gills with pho.  Priced reasonably as well.  The place itself is very quaint, kinda small, very cool.
author: David P.

description: Great pho and a nice cozy space. The waiters are very friendly.
author: Nick E.

description:
This is one of the nicer Vietnamese places in San Francisco and it's one of the best. All the ingredients are super fresh and is worth the extra money.

The Pho is good here and it's one of the few places where I can actually find vietnamese style Wonton Noodle Soup.

This places gets really crowded around noon so go early or go late.
author: David N.

description:
I love this place! They have some very unique dishes that you don't see on other menus.

The seafood and pork crepe, amazing!!!

The spicy beef phô is the crack!
Lotus Root salad is my new favorite.
Papaya salad is flavorful and refreshing.
Banana Blossom salad is surprisingly cool, tasty, and filling.
Vermicelli bowl with lemon grass beef is a great alternative of phô.

Thank you for cooking good vietnamese in SOMA!
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Holy moley!  I got takeout chicken bun tonight.  Holy moley, the chicken was (is!  still some left!) so flavorful, so tender, so juicy.  Oh man.  I realize that this is hit-or-miss, but this is the BEST chicken bun I've ever, ever had.  In my life.

I had to post about this.
author: Chet M.

description:
This place is great. I would suggest the vermicelli pork bowl, the meat is grilled amazingly and the portion is great as well. Does NOT come with a roll, which for the price I was surprised but it well worth adding on. 

The staff is great as well! 

Taking a star away solely based on the lack of seating.
author: Mafia M.

description:
Found Tin on Yelp and it was only two blocks from my hotel, so thought I'd pop in for a quick dinner after my plane ride out from the East Coast.

I'm a Vietnamese food novice, but this place was outstanding!  It's very casual and tends to draw a local - in the know - crowd from the looks of things.  I can see why. 

I opted for something other than the traditional Pho Bo or Pho Ga (although a lot of diners were having them and they looked great) and went with the Bun Thit Bo Nuoung - grilled lemongrass beef and pork with vermicelli noodles and garnishes.  You have the option of adding a Cha Gio roll for an additional $2 - do it!  It's a very tasty, crispy fried roll (pork, shrimp, mushrooms, noodles) that goes great with the entree.

The "33" Vietnamese beer was a great accompaniment.  Service was efficient and friendly, and Tin definitely fits the criteria of "great neighborhood place" that's worth a little effort to visit.

Whenever I'm back in SF, I'll be happy to return.
author: L W.

description:
I've been here twice now and I think this place is great. The food is fantastic and is extremely well priced. You can't beat $8-9 for dinner. 

Everything I've had here is excellent. The menu selection isn't huge but who cares if everything is good. 

The service here was excellent. Our waitress was very friendly and helpful. 

Tin is a little small so it can get very crowded and have a bit of a wait. Both times I've gone around 6:30 and have had no problem getting seated, but when I walked by around 8:30 it was packed with a bit of a wait. 

I wish they delivered. I would order from them all the time.
author: Gregory W.

description: Food was generally excellent...some of the best Green Papaya Salad I've ever had. Service though, while friendly enough, was slooooooooow. The restaurant wasn't very busy when we arrived, yet we waited 10 minutes before a server visited to take our order. Another 10 before drinks arrived. 20 more for food. Then 30 minutes and three requests for a check.
author: Scott W.

description:
First time we went service was real slow.  Took and hour to get a bowl of pho and the waiter forgot about our drink order and the fried egg rolls were old and looked like they were reheated in the toaster.

Went back a second time, way earlier and wasn't as busy.  Service vastly improved and we were quite impressed with the authentic of the Bun Rieu and Bun Bo Hue.  Nothing like a warm bowl of noodles on a cold night.

Will give 3 stars for now and see how consist they are.
author: Maeling L.

description: A delicious affordable lunch spot - catfish and bok choy ROCKED. Not too busy. Fresh veggies. Strong delicious flavors. Thanks Miriam for a great selection!
author: Andrew K.

description:
This is an awesome hidden gem tucked away just a few blocks from the Westfield shopping mall.

I had lunch here with a large group, the staff handled it graciously except that they forgot to make my dish (derpity derp) but it was ok because we had plenty of appetizers and folks were generous with their own meals because the portions were so huge!

The ambiance itself is quite "hipster" (they were playing the likes of James Blake) with simple and elegant furniture and light fixtures.

We had three Vietnamese dudes in our group and they all agreed that it was authentic. I had some vermiccili noodles, claypot catfish and bok choy. All super tasty in their own individual ways. Sometimes people get lazy and different dishes end up tasting the same (ya know what I mean?) but this was not the case at Tin.
author: Cynthia L.

description: We got vegetarian phos. They were alright, nothing special, as expected. But it's nice to see a Vietnamese place with a vegetarian option, so would come here again for it.
author: Michelle C.

description: Good food. Nice place. Asian restaurant should not always associated with noisy, busy, oily, and foreign. I like the whole setting here. 2:30pm and 20 mins walk distance from Union doesn't slow the traffic. it's still more than half tables are occupied.
author: Helen T.

description:
Great pho, reasonable price ($7.50) for quite a portion. Could have had more meat, but not complaining because I loved the broth. Best broth I had since Pin Toh at Berkeley closed down. 

Near Intercontinental and Metreon! Cute interior too. Fast and efficient service. Looking forward to going back.
author: Soo Jung R.

description: Balanced portions of chicken and vermicelli for the bun. Food was really good and the wait time for takeout was really fast. Really enjoyed the food and will definitely come again.
author: Sean C.

description:
Small cozy place. Avoid peak time as there could be a wait.
Be sure to try their starter salads specially the lotus root salad w/ shrimp and poached pork belly.
author: Philip T.

description:
First time here and I have to say it is a cut above the normal pho places.  I only gave it 3 stars because the meal accounted for the lost of one star.  It would have been 4 if it wasnt for the sandwitch.

It is not the typical vietnamese sandwitch. The 5 spice chicken sandwich was good but the bread was not fresh.  You can tell wwhen bread is more than slightly a day old.  Once heated up, the crust is hard and dry.  Hard enough to scratch the roof of the mouth.  Yep...good but also painful.  Kinda like you pay the price if you want to eat it.

The broth with the pho is light and refreshing.   One of the better broth I've had.  Not salty and favored just right.

Million dollar question...would I go back.  Yes but nit fir the sandwitch until they get fresh bread or until quality gies down.
author: MickYee M.

description:
Very good pho (ordered the Pho Bo, no beef balls) that felt very clean/fresh.  The portion was a little small for me, but my girlfriend said that it was the right size and not overwhelming.  Personally, I wish it was a little bigger for the price paid.

Also, we decided to indulge on the Banh Xeo appetizer.  I've never had it before so I can't really compare the dish to anything.  It had a good crunch to it and the mixture of ingredients complimented each other.  I would order it again.

All in all, I'd come back again for my Vietnamese cravings.
author: Kevin L.

description: Price is about right, close from my place, nice interior. I love PhoBo and this place is recommended although I can feel some curry spice taste than other places.
author: Erica K.

description: Solid Choice! good food, priced fair, trendy hole in the wall. So glad we found this spot in our new hood.
author: Susan S.

description:
I just came back from this restaurant.
Their service is really bad, and slow, I waited at the table for my entire lunch break, until I had to cancel my reservation.
Of curse they still charged me for the appetizers.
While they did said there sorry, they mainly focused on explaining why is the service so slow today, instead of offering any mitigation. And just blamed me for blaming them.
The guy who seem to be in charge was obnoxious and just wants the money for the started, and prove me wrong. When I tried explaining, he just tepidly said 'good day sir'.
Please do not go there, give you hard worked money to someone with better attitude who like serving and not just charging.
P.s this is my first non positive review.
author: Yotam K.

description: I've been here twice so far and got the Pho Ba and one of the noodle dishes the second time. I'm partial to Pho in general and this didn't disappoint. The broth had good flavor and the meat was still cooking when it came out which is a huge plus for me. Good spot to check out if your in the area for a solid lunch.
author: Matt O.

description: My favorite Vietnamese spot in SF! I recommend the vermicelli bowls with lemongrass beef :)
author: Fredrika P.

description:
*On our quest to try 52 new places in 52 weeks.* 

The hubs and I came here post-work, pre-General Assembly event. I had been wanting to come here since I used to live in this part town (that sketchy section of SOMA: Mission, Folsom 5th Street and 7th Street being the boundaries) and am always excited for any revitalization of this neighborhood. Just because I couldn't hack it doesn't mean it's not good!

We came in and it was pretty dead. Maybe one or two tables taken. It was about 5:45-6:00pm though, so I'm not too surprised. By the time we left, this place was hopping. 
Truth be told we only got some beers and some appetizers, but all were delicious and the service was excellent and efficient. And they take cards!
author: Melissa N.

description:
Love everything I have ever eaten at this place...but we can never figure out when it is open...we have tried to go at 8/9pm at least 3 times and it was closed.

The food definitely keeps us coming back...love the Pho Bo!
author: Nic S.

description:
My friends and I were desperately craving pho after a night of partying so we found this gem on yelp and decided to check it out on our way to the train station!

So glad we checked it out.  The decor is modern and inviting.  The staff was friendly and attentive, and the food is delicious!  Their broth in the Pho Bo and Pho Ga is very tasty, not bland like other places. In addition, you can tell their ingredients are fresh, which makes a big difference and makes them stand out.  Their spring rolls were very tasty as well!

Overall, we had a pleasant experience, and it was just what we needed before we made our way home! We will definitely come back again next time we are in the area!
author: Reyna M.

description: So good! Have to try the braised pork with the egg here. So flavorful, perfect with rice and pickled veggies. I already really like the pork chop!
author: Xue C.

description: Came here on a Saturday night with my friends and I could already sense that the service was slow. The food took a while to make and the noodle in my veggie pho (I'm vegetarian) wasn't fully cooked and was just one big chunk of noodles. It was as if they took out the noodles from an instant noodle packaging and let it boil in the water without stirring it. Not only that the noodles were really short so it was hard using my chopsticks. I was eating with my soon practically the whole time. They also took forever to take away our bill and we had to flag someone down for that. Well that's about 7% tip money gone right there.
author: Tiramisu W.

description:
Based on the number of good reviews, you can figure out it's a quality place. I've been here enough times to give it a five stars simply because:

- Awesome food every single time I've visited
- Great services
- Fast services
- Nice ambience, especially at night
- Good mix of dinner crowd

My favorites:

- Lemon grass chicken
- Shaken beef
- Beef salad
- Grilled pork chop

Everything else on their menu are excellent, including their pho and bun. They also make killer fried eggs too!
author: Eric L.

description: The service was bad, the food took too long to come out, the catfish was salty, and everything on the menu is overpriced. Do not recommend.
author: Fred Z.

description: I could eat the Chili Lemongrass Chicken for the rest of my life...
author: Hera D.

description:
Pretty much your typical pho shop with a hipster twist to it. The food is good and everything tastes authentic. There's just something about the ambience that makes me feel just a little more of a hipster while eating there. 

I've had the pho and the grilled pork vermicelli. The broth was tasty but I consider myself a bad reviewer of pho broth because my soup is about 3/5ths sriracha. The grilled pork was tasty but just a little bit overcooked. 

All in all I'd definitely recommend trying the place out.
author: William L.

description: Tin, one word of advice. I love it here but I am not a fan of your seating system. I go here almost every week and tonight I was not given a table before my entire party was here. I understand if it's packed but it was empty and it looked ridiculous for me to stand at the door for 15 min while I wait for everyone to arrive. I came early because I know how crowded it can get and so wanted to get a table ahead of time. Please consider changing your system.
author: Amy N.

description:
I'll give this restaurant 3.5 stars, rounded up.  It has a very nice interior.  Prices are relatively higher and, for pho fans, the choices on the menu may be less for those like me who like to choose bowls with items such as tripe.  However, the soup base is good.  Most importantly, they provide jalapeno pepper slices with the bean sprouts.  Service is pretty good.

If coming as part of a party, expect the staff to tell you that everybody has to arrive first before they seat you at a table.  That's what happened to me when I arrived before my friend.
author: H K.

description: Went here in an effort to satisfy my sister's pho craving. She was happy with her meal and since I couldn't do the pho again because I had it several times in the last few weeks, I tried one of the 5 spice meals and it was very good. Tiny little space but great value for the money.
author: Aisha H.

description: Good flavors, but mediocre service. Food and all was on time, but the staff had poor customer etiquette. Our waiter was substantially rude with a healthy topping of sass. His comments were off putting enough that I was unable to actually eat for a minute. Second waiter (I think he was a waiter if not a higher up) was a bit clueless as well. Perhaps because it's a new business? To conclude, it was the first time I did not leave a tip, and I will not be returning.
author: Michaela S.

description: Broth is below average, ok portions, I enjoyed the pickled red onions. Service is like any other Vietnamese restaurant.
author: byungc k.

description: Do yourself a favor and walk one block down to Miss Saigon for better and cheaper Vietnamese food. Banh xeo was huge and therefore kinda soggy. Bun bo hue didn't have pork blood and was overly spicey. I have a pretty high tolerance for spiciness, but I was choking on the spice when trying to eat the noodles. Super disappointing and not enjoyable.
author: Whitney C.

description:
So tasty and fresh, I almost forgot I was in SF! (Everyone knows SJ has the best Vietnamese food by far)

I had the pork sandwich with soup. Yummy!

Friendly, helpful service too.

Just two blocks from the 5th and Mission Garage, and not crowded on this Saturday around 1:30.
author: Michael G.

description: Great find near Moscone. Had delicious yet quick lunch here while in town for convention. Great flavors, fresh food with good portion size and reasonable prices.  Friendly service too.  Strongly recommend.
author: jake g.

description: Love the heck out of this place!! Absolutely delicious food and great service, and I love that they use bio-degradable products!!
author: Adina V.

description:
Really nice ambience and awesome food. The broth for all of the soups were excellent and very clean. You can walk through the kitchen and see the big plastic buckets of broth ready to be served. Pork chop ok rice was nice too. If you want something a little nicer than the pho shops on larkin come here. You won't be disappointed.

They are very busy so service is like a regular restaurant, not a pho shop.
author: Sub S.

description: For their pickup only. OrderAhead notified me that my order was ready, and I walked over to pick up my food. The manager was unapologetic about the fact that none of the online orders had even been entered yet, much less prepared. No-go for a quick lunch.
author: Rebecca P.

description: Tin is around the corner from my office, so I stop in every once in a while for a quick bite during lunch. I understand that lunch rushes can get very busy, but if the pho wasn't as good as it, I wouldn't ever come back here, as the service is pretty much non-existent.
author: Anna K.

description:
I was looking for more of an authentic Vietnamese restaurants meaning they would have dishes with ingredients that are not normally seen such as tripe, liver, etc. 

However, the food was still delicious and high quality. Slightly more upscale than your traditional mom and pop Vietnamese restaurant. But if that's what your looking for than this place is great. 

I won't give them less than 5 stars because thats what I was not in the mood for but they definitely had great food that will satisfy anyone.
author: Vixay S.

description:
Great restaurant with good food, good ambiance, and very fair prices.  It's always a treat to find an Asian restaurant that serves authentic style food, doesn't inflate prices, and doesn't make you embarrassed to dine there in your fun, trendy outfits.  In fact, this may be the only one I have found in San Francisco.

1. Love love love the claypot catfish.  Some places over caramelize the catfish dish but Tin's is the perfect sweet, yet peppery balance.

2. Tamarind Shrimp - another winner.

3. Papaya Salad - yum yum, though would have preferred if the papaya was more thinly prepared

4. Beef Salad - tasted nice but I felt it was the weakest of the dishes we ordered

5. Taro Dessert - very nice way to end the meal.  Loved the gentle sweetness of the coconut milk with the taro and tapioca.

Will most definitely be returning!  Bravo Tin!
author: Lev E.

description:
This eatry was crowded at 7:30 PM when my party of 4 (with 2 to arrive) rolled in.  We were seated, but we could tell that the wait staff didn't appreciate that our full party hadn't arrived yet.

All the same, the service was prompt; the food was good.  I can definitely see why this place is crowded all the time.  I'd dine at Tin again, making sure that all party members are present less we incur the wrath of the front-of-house staff.
author: Caleb H.

description:
updated 3-7-15
I eat here about once a month and always order the pork chops. Today it wasn't so good so I told the waiter and I was billed for it anyway. I explained to him that I didn't eat it because it was horrible and didn't feel I should have to pay for it. He sent the general manager to my table who apologize and asked if I wanted something else. I was late going somewhere and said no thank you. We chatted for a little while and he took the item off my tab. I originally gave it 4 stars but am bumping it up to 5 for the customer service.
author: May G.

description:
4.5 stars! I liked this place.  Came here last week.  Found a parking spot right out front.  Small spot, crowded, had to wait for a table at almost 8:00 pm on a Saturday night.  It's not fancy or anything, but it's clean and bright inside.  Service was quick and courteous.  We shared the Papaya Salad: green papaya, poached shrimp and calamari,
thai basil.  It was delicious.  Exactly what I want my papaya salad to be.  Not too spicy.. tangy, fresh, sweet, a bit crunchy.

I got the Bun Rieu: shrimp, crab and minced pork balls, fried tofu, shrimp, tomato, chicken-tomato broth.  First time Ive had it.  There was a LOT going on in there.  It was pretty tasty. Lots of stuff to eat.  I enjoyed the stewed tomatoes in there even though they look gross.  

Pretty affordable.  Those two dishes plus a bowl of pho was around $26.  The bowl of pho wasn't a huge bowl, but probably the correct portion.  

I'd come here again anytime.
author: Easter E.

description: The food was good, but a Health Food score of "60" is just plain obnoxious! This means that (almost) 50% of the time, you're taking a gamble with your health eating food that's been prepared under unsafe practices. Shame, as the food was good. But our health is worth more than a $8 bowl of noodles.
author: Travis B.

description:
Got the Hu Tieu (thought I should try something new). The chicken garlic broth was so good and the noodles were perfect. It had pork, chicken, and shrimp in it. The pork was definitely my favorite. 

Good prices.
author: Lilian K.

description: Excellent pho. The Bo Bun Hue is stellar. Each soup we had was excellent. The price is reasonable. Only reason this is not a 5 is because service was a bit of a mess. Apparently they forgot to put in our order. Everyone who came in after us got their food. But the waitress was kind enough to waive the price of one soup. As long as the service gets a bit better this is a 5 star spot.
author: Daniel K.

description: Yes, yes, yes. If this place were in DC, I would eat there at least twice a week. Start with the spring rolls, which they can make vegetarian if you desire (filled with delicious smoke tofu, basil, mint, and vermicelli).  The clay pot catfish is the real deal - huge chunks of caramelized catfish served with sweet caramelized onions and a hint of red chili.  And the chili lemongrass chicken is equally good.  If I were doing it again, I would probably order a side of the daily green with garlic just to have more veggies with my meal, but this is as close to perfection as it gets. Our dinner for two was $25.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Delicious food, good service, nice ambiance. 

Pho is okay. I would say I prefer the appetizers and claypot dishes. I've heard the bun is also good but have yet to try any myself.
author: Jay K.

description: My favorite vietnamese place in the city.  Also the closest one to my place to boot!  I probably come to Tin once a month looking forward to get my beef pho craving. Also can't go wrong with the Pork belly vermicelli noodle bowl!
author: Eric A.

description:
Tin is the best pho I've had.  The most important part of any pho to me is the broth. Tin's broth is very flavorful.

This place is really small and packed up really quickly during the evening on a Thursday, but luckily we arrived before the crowd (started around 6:30).

I literally cannot wait to move to San Francisco so I can eat here all the time!
author: Halie B.

description: This place is amazing. The atmosphere is buzzing with great music playing and to top it all the food is fantastic. You have to eat here. Three of us ate here last night. We shared the firecracker shrimp and the crispy spring rolls. I then went for the ginger chicken rice which was so tasty. My husband had the big bowl noodle broth. My son had the five spice chicken sandwich which was crammed with delicious flavoured chicken. Every table was taken. The service is quick. I will definitely be returning.
author: Suzanne W.

description: I was in the neighborhood and getting a little hungry for some lunch, so I wandered into this place. I went for the Pho with rare beef, and what a treat. It was easily the most flavorful pho that I have ever had. The broth was delicious on its own, without addition of anything. I could have eaten it by itself, but the beef and noodles were great as well. The lemonade was also amazing. Tart and a little bit sweet. I'll definitely be back to this place.
author: Brent W.

description:
Came for lunch on Saturday afternoon.  I'm not sure if I was really early for lunch (around noon) but the place was empty (when I was leaving, there were more people in the restaurant).

I had the Pho Bo.  Pretty good.  Definitely a good portion of noodles and tasty broth.  Since I live around the corner, I'll definitely be back (assuming I can get my GF there).

*the neighborhood leaves something to be desired.  I don't think it's dangerous but it's not really pretty and looks a bit run down.
author: Larry L.

description:
Agree with the rave reviews about Tin. Friendly service from a busy staff. We had delicious claypot catfish (I asked for "not too salty," which I suggest you do), fried rolls and beef pho. With two pots of tea it was so reasonable, $31.50! Park at lot across street for $7 at night if parking is difficult. We will go back soon with friends.

We returned to Tin and I tried the claypot shrimp. The carmelized sauce is definitely not carmelized, more like a little soup in the bottom of the claypot, so that's a miss. We had to park in the parking lot again so at this point I figure that into the price of the dinner and it's only slightly less of a deal. Overall, we are happy to return since we love the fried rolls and the food is reasonable and healthy.
author: Anita B.

description: I've come here nearly 10 times over the past year or so, and must say that everything I have tried on the menu is pretty solid.  I don't think it is mindblowingly good, which is why it doesn't get 5 stars, but you could definitely do worse.  One of my favorite Vietnamese spots in the city.
author: Josh Q.

description: I hesitate to write this review because the place is so freaking busy at lunch already, but here goes. The food here is fantastic. I've had Bun bo Hue, pho, and vermicelli noodle. But Im telling you the caramelized clay pot catfish is phenomenal!  Moist catfish in a spicy, sweet savory sauce with a side bowl of rice. Everything about it is good, including the price.
author: Eve C.

description:
Good food, large portions, digging the fact they have brown rice. Do me a favor and order their grilled eggplant. Don't think I've ever had it prepared this way before and my bestie (a luke-warm eggplant enthusiast) even raved about it.

Ambiance is cool, just like most neighboring newer restaurants in the Soma area.

Service? Let's just say they have good intentions. We went on a Monday night and I don't think 2 servers are enough for the amount of tables they have. They were nice so I'll give them that. The affordable prices and yummy food saved my review from being 3 stars.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
Best Vietnamese place I've been to in a long time.  

Grilled Lemon Grass Beef - very flavorful, tender and juicy.
Egg rolls - could use a little more work.
Claypot Catfish - If there are any leftovers you might just want to smear the sauce all over your chest (it's that good).

New Golden Turtle may be gone forever, but Tin reminds me that life goes on.
author: Nobody M.

description: I don't want to bother reading what other people have to say about the food. I'm writing this review to remind myself not to come back here .  I've had better Vietnamese food .
author: Carol C.

description: My wife loves Pho, so I asked a friend in SF to point out a good spot and Tin did not disappoint.  I had the Pho Bo and my Wife had the Pho Ga, both broths were excellent. I'm definitely going back. I gave it 4 stars because the wait was kinda long and the service was OK but the food is great and well worth visiting again.
author: Edgar M.

description:
Fancy enough to take a date to, cheap enough that it wouldn't matter if it's a bad date.
Despite the modern interior, the food is traditional Vietnamese without pretentiousness. The service is very attentive. The broth in the pho was good and all the food was fresh. There is a selection of wine and beer if you want to be fancy. The price are very reasonable with with most things under 10 dollars.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: This place has terrible service. I completely felt ignored for a good 20 minutes. I gave this place 2 stars because the food is decent. Definitely sticking to Asianville for good Asian eats.
author: Gary I.

description: Catfish clay pot was amazing. I will definitely be back. The service was friendly and attentive as well. Great find.
author: Todd W.

description: Came here for some Vietnamese food before a night out drinking in SF.  It was close to the Marriot where I was staying for the weekend.  The prices here were a bit pricey but the food was delicious.  I had the sizzling beef plate which was perfectly spiced (think black pepper beef with bell peppers).  My friend who ordered the pho said it was average, but his palate is more accustomed to authentic Viet food.  We also ordered egg rolls as an appetizer.  It was savory and crispy.  My only complaint was that the egg rolls were not served with enough lettuce to wrap the egg rolls.
author: Richard L.

description: Was recommended by our hotel bellhop and definitely well worth it. This Vietnamese restaurant is amazing and good. I had the Ginger Chicken and my kids shared a chicken pho. My wife had the grilled pork chop. All the food was good and tasted fabulous. It sucks we waited until our last night. Definitely try it.
author: Nelson R.

description: All the dishes here tastes clean and flavorful. I've tried their Pho, Porkchop Rice Plate, Garlic Wings, and Spring Rolls. This place gets pretty packed during dinner hours..
author: John D.

description:
awesome food excellent pho and noodle bowls! Simply loved it all the way. 
Flavors were delicious. I am so glad to find another awesome pho place in the city!
author: Ankita N.

description:
Do it for the Pho, kids. Do it for the Thai iced coffee. Do it because it's so fresh, so good, so cheap, and wicked filling. 

I ran over here for a quick lunch with a foursome and we were in and out in under an hour, belly's full and faces smiling. While there was a bit of a wait (the sign of a good lunch spot, for sure), we were served immediately upon sitting down. 

There were noodles of various types, sweet drinks, appetizers with fragrant fresh herbs and my gorgeous, lovely, pipin' hot bowl of vegetarian Pho I'd been craving for days. It was perfect - a bowl of health and goodness so abundant I couldn't come close to finishing it. The tofu was firm and tasty, the broth flavorful and the veggies crisp. The noodles were amazing and I totally dug them. So do it, kids. Go to Tin.
author: Hilary H.

description: UPDATE: For quick authentic vermicelli bowls, I rush on over to Tin's. Glad to report that there's a little sign out front that states that they are now open on Saturdays!
author: Ann S.

description:
Once upon a time, I used to come to Tin every week and was the duchess. Alas, now my office moved and it's more of a trek to get there, but it is totally worth the walk. But hot damn, this place knows how to make pho!

I love this place. It's so small and intimate and so good. I usually only come for lunch but went once for dinner and it was just as good. Now let's be real, all you care about is what to order. Again, I have tried not that many things because once I fall in love with something, it's so hard for me not to order it but I have tried a few things here. First up, Cha Gio. Man oh man, this is good! I love that they bring you the lettuce and the mint and the basil and the pickled veggies to wrap everything up together with. It's a fried eggroll burrito and I love it!! Definitely the best Cha Gio I've ever had. Their fresh spring rolls with the peanut sauce is amazingly good too.

Now to the main event. Pho. For the longest time all I ever got was the Pho Bo with beef balls. Let's be real, I always asked for extra beef balls because they were so good! No chewy or hard pieces when you bite into them like you get at other pho places! And the broth. Let's take a second to just talk about the broth. PHENOMENAL. I hate salt and this broth is not too salty but not bland at all. If they allowed it, I would just ask for a big pot off this broth to take home with me. After 6 months of only just getting the pho bo, my friend was daring and tried the Hu Tieu. As soon as they brought it to the table and I got a whiff of that brothy goodness, I was instantly jealous. The next time I went (probably 2 days later) I took a leap of faith and ordered the Hu Tieu. Let's just say I didn't order Pho Bo for a while. I thought the beef broth was good but this broth. WOW. I would bathe in this broth. Garlicy, chickeny beautifulness. I could very well live off that broth. The meat is delicious and the little slivers of celery that they put in there just go so perfectly with it too!

I love this place. And after writing this review and remembering how much I love this place, I have to go there tomorrow for lunch. It's been two weeks since I last went and it's been too long. I am not having pho withdrawals.
author: Sabrina D.

description: The most disappointing pho I have ever eaten in California!!! Absolutely mediocre in every single way, I don't know how this place got 4 stars but I'm never ever coming back here! It's scandalous, they should make more effort with the pho as it is the most popular item on their menu :/
author: Luski G.

description:
I love this place because it is on my walk home from work and is great for a quick take out dinner.  I only wish that they would open up at 5pm instead of 5:30pm so that I didn't have to wait around at the office before my dinner is ready to pick up!

I guess Tin isn't really a secret anymore because suddenly the place is packed at lunch.  If you can manage to get there by 11:45 then your fine, but if you show up at noon get ready for a wait.  This isn't the best Vietnamese in the city, and doesn't have the menu variety of Yummy Yummy in the Sunset, but Tin serves solid Vietnamese standards at reasonable prices.  I love that the grilled lemongrass pork is relatively lean (I can't be the only person who hates biting into a fatty/grizzly piece of pork) and the veggies are nice and fresh.  Pho is tasty, but the bowl is smaller than most pho joints and only comes in one size.  The servers are friendly and work hard when the place gets full.  Not a destination place, but great when your in the neighborhood.
author: Dana H.

description: I just moved to the area and this place rocks!   Order the hue rolls, hu tieu and bun rieu. Thank u, Hung, for a great meal.
author: Dottie L.

description:
NOMNOMNOMNONOM, I think I come here at least once every two weeks.

First, their servers are so much fun. RJ, if you're reading this, drinks are a must!

I do believe their Pho is thee cleanest tasting, most refreshing pho broth I've had in the city. Their imperial rolls are sex. Their warm beef salad? doitdoitdoitdoit. So refreshing, filling and hearty! Prices are so affordable, just a perfect way to end my day after a long day at work. :) 

Parking: Howard is a one way street and doesn't have a ton of parking. There is a parking garage on Natoma (the street/ alley way one block over) that closes on 7pm and there is also a parking garage on 5th and Howard I do believe!
author: Rosa L.

description:
I like Tin, but as is the case whenever a new restaurant takes the place of an old-time favorite, I can't help but compare it to the now defunct Pho Ha Tien 2. By comparison, the two really are quite different; but overall, Tin's just not as good.

PHT2 and Tien are on total opposite ends of "the Vietnamese restaurant" spectrum. The former was a neighborhood mainstay with its hole-in-the-wall approach, while the incumbent latter has gone for the the new-agey, IKEA-like modern artsy look.  PHT2 had heaping bowls of pho and rice plates that went on for about 6 pages; Tin's selection of healthy-sized meals is limited to 3 or 4 soups, 5 or 6 rice plates, and barely fills up ONE side of a menu. Both restaurants' prices are/were reasonable, yet my dollar seemed to go further at PHT2. And though I'll certainly vouch that Tin's food is good (I've had about 4 different things there), the sleeker presentation made it no tastier than its predecessors' large portions, which definitely filled me up more.

That said, in the general area I'd choose this place over Zesty Vietnamese,  which was right downstairs from where I used to work yet I refused to patronize as I'm pretty sure it was a front for a Chinese brothel. Also, Tin is a family-run affair, and I'm all about supporting local businesses. I hope in the near future that it finds some way to jazz up its less-than-original, trendy-Asian-eatery persona, because that would really set it apart. But otherwise, I think SOMA folks are generally pleased with the new kid in town. I give it a 3.5.
author: Kate V.

description:
The Pho here is some of the freshest I've ever had. It's a bit of hidden gem, tucked away near 6th street. It seems as if they only ever have one server working at a time, which can lead to long wait times, but the service is super good otherwise.

I honestly don't know how authentic it is, but everything I've tried is nothing short of delicious. Keep away from the lunch rush, as this place is small, and seating times can take forever if you go anytime between noon-1ish. Anytime before and after? The place is pretty much clear!

I used to order my food for pickup since I worked right nearby. Highly recommend!
author: Anna H.

description:
The atmosphere and service at Tin were great. Hard to find a reasonably priced meal in SOMA and this worked well for us. One thing they could improve upon would be to PUT DOWN THE FISH SAUCE. 

When we walked in it was the first odor I noticed and the meal that was served had TOO much as well. Remember more is not always better, especially when it comes to the pungent odor and flavor of fish sauce. 

GREAT papaya salad - but again, too much sauce. Remember "less is more".

Other than that, I would absolutely recommend this place.
author: Lee O.

description:
This place is more of a 3.5 star place. The food is pretty good, but compared to other Vietnamese places that are much cheaper, Tin doesn't quite distinguish itself. Not to say that the food isn't worth the money, and the ambiance of the place is better than most run of the mill pho places.

I shared the spring rolls with a friend and ordered the grilled pork and shrimp over vermicelli plate for my entree. The spring rolls tasted very fresh and tasty. My main dish was good also, with the flavorful pork and shrimps were not overcooked. 

All in all, the food is pretty standard. Maybe I'll try their rice plates next time, as they offer clay pot fish, which is harder to find.
author: Alice W.

description: A solid 4 star review. I was pretty impressed by the quality of their food considering a number of restaurants in the bay area are known to be overly hyped. Came here for dinner on a Wed night around 630pm before the huge crowd of people waiting and ordered the grilled beef rolls with a spring roll over vermicelli and papaya salad. Here I was thinking oh.. beef rolls, should be meatier but as it turned out, it was wrapped around a carrot stick. How deceiving! Couldn't complain since it was flavorful, tender and just enough of that charcoal taste. I was equally impressed with the spring roll. It was the fattest/thickest spring roll I've had in my lifetime I tell you! Very fresh, lots of meat and just the right crisp to it. It was surprisingly a hugeeee portion considering my experience with Viet dishes in NYC. The papaya salad was delish too. Loved the hint of basil flavor and chili as well. So yummy! They probably could've used a little less of the carrot sauce (was it)? All in all, my stomach sang many praises of their food :) Lastly, one thing I wish they could do is do something about the noise level because it definitely contains in the restaurant and it is LOUD and I mean it gets really LOUD. I would only come here with a lousy date that way you can really enjoy the food and not care about the actual conversation because you wont be able to hear what your date is saying anyway unless you are literally in.each.other's.face. Lol or come to enjoy good food minus any business or real conversation.
author: Sen S.

description: Great place. The pho is good, my friend got the braised pork and egg, which was also very bomb.
author: Orion Z.

description: Great food! Everything from appetizer to entree. The spring rolls are great! The pork belly was tasty with the twice cooked egg. We liked the fried egg noodle. I will be back. Long wait after 6pm. Not the greatest area of town.
author: Alison W.

description: We ordered two soup based noodles dishes and both were awesome. The prices are very reasonable, great service and very fresh ingredients.  Loved the food.
author: Dhiraj S.

description: This is the real deal, with amaze balls Vietnamese cuisine.  Think beach front real estate for trailer park prices.  The lemon grass pork does the pig proud, served up on a bed of noodles and Vietnamese veggies. Will be coming back.  A beacon of light in a crack head neighborhood.
author: Richard B.

description:
Yum! Came here for lunch while in the city on a Saturday with our cousin and some friends and really liked it!!

I was just getting over a cold so wasn't able to share any of my tablemate's food, but my pho with garlic chicken broth was so tasty and just what I needed to kick the cold.  The Vietnamese coffee was just what I needed to kick my butt into gear too! I had forgotten how supercharged those things are!!

If we're in SF when the craving hits, we will definitely come here and make sure to order the large bowl next time :)
author: Miyako L.

description: The food was fantastic!  I can't wait to visit this place again on my next visit to San Francisco.
author: James G.

description: so surprised at how good this place was.  the ginger soup with the chicken was so perfect for when I was sick but I would eat it anytime too.  And the beef noodle soup was really tasty as well.  great to know this is close to the house and easy to pick up!  Will definitely be going back.  Already been twice.
author: a g.

description:
overall... the food was just okay for the price point.

but. I really enjoyed two things about my lunch experience:
1) the HUE ROLLS (grilled lemongrass pork, shiso, mint, cilantro, scallion oil, fried shallots wrapped in steamed rice paper) were so dope! never had anything exactly like this before. I could make a meal out of 2-3 of these badboys. 
2) the service was great. the owner's son is very friendly, and our waitress was very friendly and helpful with food recs
author: David W.

description: Awesome food, great salads, really nice alternative to Larkin street eateries for accessibility/ cleanliness/ presentation. A crowd pleaser for sure- everyone can find something they like. One star off for the fact that it is always hot and sweaty in there- please install some fans or get some ventilation going! Don't want to sweat into my pho!
author: pav V.

description:
Really good/fresh vietnamese food for a great price. 

The Pho here is good but not great, but the other options are REALLY good. I get the tomato sauce special noodle with a mixture of shrimp/beef. My wife usually gets the rice noodles with pork. 

I have to emphasize how fresh the ingredients are here.
author: Christopher K.

description:
This place was good enough that my colleague and I decided to eat lunch here TWICE during the Intersolar show at the Moscone Center.  The first time I was there, I was a little uncomfortable with how chic it was-- tasty Viet places are supposed to be run-down, dirty, cash only joints.  But, the food was surprisingly good both times.  First time I had a bowl of pho, since... how else are you supposed to judge a Viet place?  Flavorful broth and good meat (but pretty standard).  Second time I got a lemongrass pork shoulder.  BIG WINNER.  The meat is thinly sliced and very tender and soaks up a tremendous amount of flavor.  It was so good, I was trying to suck the flavor out of the meat [cue that's what she said comment].  And the fried egg addition to the dish-- unconventionally delicious.

From a value perspective, I'm not sure it gets much better than this.  This was close to 5 stars (minus 1 for an uninspiring pho).
author: Jeff J.

description:
The service could use a little bit of tweaking. It's a little on the slow side and I think it shouldn't be too much to ask to have waiting parties put their name on a list instead of standing in line waiting to be seated. Also, be prepared for a longer wait to be seated during lunch. 

Aside from those problems, though, I think they still make some delicious Pho. I tried the Pho Bo and the broth was clean and flavorful, the garnishes were fresh, the noodles were just the right texture, and the rare meat was very tender and tasted of good quality.

While this place clearly needs to make up ground in the area of service, there's not anything negative I can really say about the Pho.

If you've got some time to spare and are willing to possibly wait a while, I recommend this place. But if you've only got an hour for lunch before you have to get back to work, some place else may be a better option.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
I shall not tell a lie - when I visited Tin I had been in Dave's bar for a while first. The wine mixed with my jet lag means that my memory of the evening is somewhat hazy... I shall tell you what I remember...

The Pho Ga! Poached chicken with rice noodles in ginger-chicken broth. It was good and just what I needed to send me off into a slumber. The broth was piping hot and full of flavour and the chicken and various veg - beansprouts and onion etc - added just the right amount of bite without making it too filling. The staff were very nice and attentive too.

It was a very tasty meal and just what I needed on the chilly and blustery evening to keep me warm on the walk back to my hotel.

And then I slept... zzz...
author: Katie B.

description:
I came here for dinner on a Friday. I didn't expect to find such an authentic Vietnamese restaurant in this part of town. 

I really like their Bun Cha Ha Noi (vermicelli with BBQ pork and pork patties, and tasty dipping sauce on the side). I typically don't find this dish at most places, so it's very good to try it again here. 

Banh Xeo (pancakes) is on the thicker side, but the crepe is crispy and the fillings (pork, calamari and shrimps) are very tasty. It's so good that we had to get a second order (for a party of 4).
author: Saran R.

description: The pho bo is really good but the proportion is so small that a girl doesn't even feel 50% full.
author: Janice N.

description:
Totally random location.

But the food was good.

Spring rolls- tastes pretty fresh.
Five Spice chicken rice plate - juicy and tender chicken. Great flavor. 
Grilled eggplant= i don't they can call this grilled. No grill marks or even tastes like it was grilled. Looks more like they steamed it. But I liked it because I love eggplant.
Vietnamese Coffee- not as strong as other places.

Service was nice. Food took a loooong time though. I went there during dinner time and I was the first table to order out of 2 tables.
author: Erica L.

description: FANTASTIC!!! I cannot get over how absolutely delicious the food here is! I have only been in SF for a couple of weeks, but the other Vietnamese places I went were not even on the same league as this one. Everything tastes super fresh, and the pork shoulder vermicelli bowl was a highlight of my stay here. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! Also, the staff was very nice and helpful with suggesting what was good, which I can imagine is just about everything from how busy it gets during dinner. Stop denying yourself and go eat here, NOW!!!
author: Eric M.

description:
Aaand whoa there, people.

Before I burst everyone's bubbles, Tin *was* good. It was, undoubtedly, decent Vietnamese food. But being a South Bay fellow born and (partially) raised, I can't agree with the execution.

Cha Gio: $6 = two cha gio, each cut into thirds. That's $1 per third. That realization didn't sit right with me. Pho Vi Hoa in Los Altos charges $5 for four whole cha gio. Admittedly the skin on this one is nicer, but I am just as happy with the plain egg roll skin. It's what's inside that counts - and how many you give me for my cash, damnit!

Pho Bo: $7.50 (we got two.) Took forever to arrive, but the best thing about it is the beef on top was actually quite raw. I got the general impression that the beef at this place is more high quality than at most divey pho joints, which I guess is worth paying for. So not bad.

Still, you know what? Screw the mood lighting, the pictures of oh-my-god-it's-so-ethnic Vietnamese people, and the American Apparel-font menu, and give me Pho Ha Tien II back, with its big soda fridge, bucket of chopsticks, more friendly people, and most of all, its bun bo hue. :(

Tin's direct competition is now Green Papaya on Mission. Let's see who does better. And I will be back ... but only because I have no other choice.
author: Josh K.

description:
I've come here twice and both times I've had interesting dinners. To start, their Pho options are tiny - Pho Bo, Pho Ga, or some vegetarian Pho. As a non-vegetarian, I obviously chose one of former options. 

The waiters here are fast at delivering food, and have spring rolls cue'd up so when you order they can bring it over in 30 seconds, but as a result of this, it's not the most fresh when you receive it. It's worth noting though that during both of my visits here, the wrong order came to our table numerous times and when we notified the waiter of this, he gave us a deer in the headlight look. It was more funny than annoying actually. One more thing actually, when you're ordering, be careful about your words. We were asking about two items on the menu (that we did not explicitly specify that we wanted to order), and the waiter ended up bringing those two items to our table, essentially ordering for us. It was fortunate that we didn't have to pay for it, and the waiter didn't seem to have too big of an issue bringing the food back into the kitchen, but I don't think this is good practice. Either that or the waiter needs to be more attentive. 

The portions of the Pho, for $8, is on the small side, and I was not too full right afterwards. Pho was pretty good, particularly on that day when it was a rainy day.

Closest Pho place to my office, so despite the small things that could be improved, I'd come here again.
author: Austin W.

description: Wait is long during rush hour but the pho is the best I have tasted in SF. Reminds me of my hometown food with thick broth and hearty pieces of meat. Must try!
author: Yi Lin P.

description: Small portion. Not tasty at all. I ordered BBH it does not taste right. Do not worth of waiting.
author: Gracie L.

description: I love everything here especially the pho. Everything is so fresh! Can't go wrong with anything here .
author: Elena A.

description: I feel so traditionally yelp, but I'm going to have to ding Tin for lackluster service.  The Cha Gio was really excellent as was my Hu Thiu. I usally don't like the broths, but decided to deviate from my usual vermicelli noodle bowl.  It was a welcome new path for me.  That said, a sprite that was ordered by my friend never materialized until it was asked for 15 minutes later.  I think the problem was just that not enough people were working the floor for the 8pm dinner rush. I'd go back on a weeknight in the future.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Finding a good neighborhood Asian restaurant is like meeting an old friend for a glass of wine...satisfying!  They understand you, without having to saying a word.  Sometimes all it takes is a smile or the smell of hot lingering Pho in the air.  I have been looking for this old friend in my hood, and finally we found each other.

Now that I've found you, I will introduce you to all my family and friends!  They too will love you just as I do.  I mean whats not to love?  Clear non greasy broth with lean cuts of meat, fresh bean sprouts, basil, onions, jalapeno peppers, and lime on the side...and chewy noodles!  

You have just the right amount of variety too:  chicken pho for my sick days, vegan dishes for my lean diets, rice plate for romantic dinners with wine, and appetizers for the days I'm really hungry or just need a snack.  

Now, if you made house visits that would make me blush!
author: HY L.

description:
I hunted down Tin Vietnamese Cuisine on my visit to San Francisco after reading the SF Chronicle review of this place.  Having been raised in a VN home, and living in the Fairfax, VA area (which has a large VN population and some great VN eats), I wanted to see if Tin would deliver what was promised.  It sure did.  The food was delicious, the atmosphere warm, and the service friendly and efficient.  

We shared the cha goi--made with the "real" rice paper wrappers (more difficult to roll and fry properly) and served with lettuce and fresh herbs for wrapping and dipping into the nouc cham.  They rolls were were crispy and perfectly seasoned, with large chunks of shrimp scattered throughout the pork filling.  

We also ordered the goi ga (chicken salad) and goi cuon (spring rolls).  The salad's light and tangy flavor was enhanced by the rau ram herb in the dressing.  The presentation was very pretty!  The goi cuon is a family favorite--and they didn't disappoint, fresh with mint and poached shrimp and pork.  The rolls were quite large--bigger than those that are usually served, so that was a bonus.  We sopped up as much of the peanut dipping sauce as we could....

For an entree, I had the caramelized clay pot catfish.  Despite being a little full from all the appetizers, I couldn't stop eating it.  The seasonings were right on target, and I ate it all, except for the one bite I offered to my husband.  Being someone who doesn't like fish, he was skeptical--and surprised himself by how much he liked it.  But I didn't let him have another bite.  

My husband ordered the lemongrass-chili chicken with vermicelli.  He declared it the best lemongrass-chili chicken he's had at a VN restaurant.  He finds that many restaurants temper the flavor, so that the lemongrass is not pronounced and the chili is muted.  He liked that he could actually taste and smell the lemongrass--and got a bit of a kick from from the chili.  

My two kids (yes, this place is kid-friendly while still being a place for adults to enjoy themselves) split an order of chicken pho.  They gobbled it up--my daughter lifting the bowl up to her mouth to drink the broth.  

My husband, two kids, and I ordered three appetizers, three entrees and three glasses of wine--and our meal came to $61 and change!  

So, of course, I met up with some SF friends there a day later and, again, had a great meal.  Banh xeo, green papaya salad, lemongrass tofu with rice, and grilled lemongrass beef with noodles.  All delicious.   

You should go.
author: Ngoc N.

description: Found this on yelp while staying at the intercontinental and craving some Asian food. It was not disappointed. I tried different vietnamese dishes than what I had tried before. I tried Bun Bo hue for lunch as i read another reviewer. It was very flavorful and I am glad that I tried a new noodle dish. I always the PHO kinda girl. I went back again for dinner and tried Hue Rolls as a starter which is flat noodle roll with thin grill beef and vegetable roll. It was very very good. Then I had caramelized claypot catfish with brown rice and a side dish of stir-fried bok choy. It was a satisfying meal and we left happy. I highly recommended this restaurant both for low-key lunch and dinner.
author: Gataree N.

description:
The number one selling point here is the value. The lemon grass tofu rice dish was very good. The pork chop was very tasty, although a bit stringy (even by pork-chop standards). There are only few, but sufficient vegetarian options, and unfortunately no vegetarian appetizers to suit my partner. 

Service was average. The place was pretty busy at around 9 p.m. on a Saturday night. It was about 10 minutes before our server took a drink order.  I had also ordered the soup of the day, but it came several minutes after the meal was served. It was only $3, and a large portion. It would have been too much food if I had eaten the soup first. 

Even so, I would say I had a 4-star experience. Bottom line, the food is good to very good and the price is right. In fact, surprisingly cheap for it's location. And they have a sufficient bottled beer selection. The decor is actually too nice for this place to count as a dive, but it does from the perspective of the prices, and we like a good dive restaurant now and then.
author: David S.

description: i have been wanting to try this place for awhile.  we ordered the fried egg rolls, crepe, go gai and wonton egg noodle soup.  everything was delish!  the crepe was crispy and light on the outside and fluffy on the inside...perfectly done!
author: Mao K.

description:
I still prefer turtle tower, but it is good to know that southern style pho does exist in the SOMA.

The Cha Gio was actually really good so I would definitely recommend ordering that as an appetizer to share.  The Pho Bo (without brisket) was good but not the best I've ever had.  Selection of Pho is very slim.
author: Carli F.

description:
What a great find!!! 

Tin is a little place, very near the Moscone Center. It was near my hotel, Yelp reviews gave it high marks, so a buddy and I ran over for lunch. And damn glad we did!! 

We went right at opening for lunch, and glad we did. We got there at 11:30, and by 12:30, there was a line waiting to get in. 

The food was tasty, meat well seasoned, cafe su da hit the spot. And very reasonably priced.  I'm glad I found it and will definitely eat there more when I return to the city.
author: Marc W.

description:
-Fast service during a lunch rush
-Friendly, attentive service with a good knowledge of the menu
-Delicious vegetarian Pho, Bahn Mi, salad, and huuuuge spring rolls with the most flavorful, juicy tofu EVER
-So cheap I thought they messed up the bill
-They wrapped the leftovers just right. Yep, leftovers too.

Can't really beat that.
author: Bonnie G.

description:
On a Mon night, there was a 50 mins wait - this would honestly have been fine, except for the fact that multiple parties of two people BEHIND us were allowed to be seated first. 

Then a large party that arrived AFTER us were also seated first - because they had called, despite this place saying they don't take reservations.

We brought this up with the staff but they said that it was the way it was done. It's frustrating that people who arrived a full 30 mins after we did were seated first, and it definitely did not seem like a fair way to seat people. I saw a few people approach the staff to complain about this unfair seating issue.

Food was good, but there seems to be some sort of seating hierarchy that can be frustrating when hungry.
author: Yan K.

description: Had some amazing Cha Gio and spring rolls her, but was somewhat disappointed with the pho and the Bun Bo... The flavor just seemed a little bland
author: Kelvin Y.

description:
Ingredients are super fresh.

Everything had great flavor.

The bowl of pho is smaller than usual, but the flavor is there.

It is the first time i been to a clean and nice feeling vietnamese spot that had great tasting food.

If you go for lunch the crowd usually comes in around 12:15ish and there will be a wait.
author: Steven F.

description:
Nice decor with decent food.  Bordering 6th Street though you wonder: (1) Can nice decor really compensate for the crack heads walking by and (2) Why not just go to Miss Saigon or Tu Lan?  This place would be a 4-star if located in an area deprived of good Vietnamese food (think somewhere in the FiDi near Pho Hoa), but it is just ok given its current neighbors.

Pho Bo: Only 1 choice instead of 40 permutations of add-ins for the same broth.  Ended up being 2 of the most common ingredients: brisket & rare eye round.  I prefer flank and beef ball as well, but guess those aren't options here.  Broth was solid and they included all the standard add-ins.  Right sized portion which satiates a normal appetite, but I do miss those gluttonous bowls you can get elsewhere.

Vietnamese Iced Coffee: Freshly brewed at your table into a cup with sweetened condensed milk that you mix and pour over ice.  Authentic.  Seemed hella slow though to brew for some reason, made Blue Bottle workers seem like they are on meth!
author: Adam B.

description: Food was excellent.  Highly recommend the Hue rolls to start.  The catfish bowl also did not disappoint - it had a sweet nuanced taste while still packing decent heat.  Also was a larger portion than the bowl would have you believe.  The service felt rushed and there were a few other little things about the locale that would have improved the experience.
author: Henry P.

description: I love this place!  It's a bit "hole in the wall"/divey, like the tables and condiment bottles feel a bit gunky and there isn't any decor, but the food quality is fresh, delicious, I love the bo bun here, the chicken pho, their spring rolls are great, and the portions are pretty good.
author: Terry K.

description:
I've tried this place a few times now and have reserved judgement until now. The food is okay - possibly 3 stars and I'm giving this place the benefit of the doubt because of the lack of quality Vietnamese places in SOMA. But the service is terrible. 

1. Do not call in your order. They don't start your order until you show up. And then they lie to you about it when it's clearly their policy (this has happened more than once). You should ask them about it if you decide to order take out.
2. The soup for the Pho is never hot enough - unlike authentic Vietnamese places. 
3. The service is really slow. 

In short, I would definitely say I've had better. I thought Taste of Vietnam / Noodle Bar & Grill in Northbeach is faster and the places in Richmond and east bay are far superior.
author: Kyle L.

description:
Woohoo! As good as it'll get (in SF (for me (so far)))! Came across this place after being severely disappointed by the new Turtle Tower in SOMA. Love it when you close one shitty door and run right over to another most awesome door leading to delicious pho.

I've tried both the pho bo and pho ga. There's not much customizing you can do, which is sometimes nice and quick. I love non-soggy noodles (sometimes it's too much to ask for at some places). And the broths for both are very tasty in my opinion. Also have tried the banh xeo (satisfying), spring rolls (weird creamy mayoness going on in there, but not bad), claypot catfish (tasty!), and a bun dish with some sort of standard bun affair in it (also pretty good).

The ambiance is nice, good music, intimate. Plus, a 5 minute walk from my place. A+! (I wish they were open on weekends though, at least Friday or Saturday. Wahhh.)
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Yay, Vegetarian Vietnamese Food that actually tastes good.

That's all.
author: Helen D.

description:
Pretty much by far the best Vietnamese bang for the buck in San Francisco.  Great Room, pleasant service and a menu full of delicious choices.  I've eaten there several times not and the must haves are:
The delicious Banh Xeo
Chicken Wings Appetizer
Excellent Birds nest noodles with pork and Seafood.
Staff is pleasant and attentive.  There isn't anything I would not order.  Extreme happiness occurs every time i eat here. Wholeheartedly and soulfully recommended.
author: Kevin M.

description:
My coworkers always want pho!! Being the Vietnamese one of the lunch group, they expect me to go, and I'm always very wary of going to pho places. However, this is one spot I look forward to! It's a far walk from the office but worth it.

Get here at exactly 11:30am because it will get packed. 

The food is very authentic, high quality, and flavorful. 

Check out the Bun Thit Nuong (cold vermicelli noodle and grilled meat - no broth) or of course the pho.

Also, they are able to split cards/cash so it makes group lunches easier.
author: Mia N.

description:
It is fair to say i eat here at least once a week! I have tried pretty much every thing on the menu...

two words: rice plate. 

The chicken rice plates are the best EVER. I can't stop eating the Chili-Lemon Grass chicken with brown rice and a fried egg over the top. Everytime that I think I won't get that I end up going with it because it is famazing. I have had their soups several times as well and I must say I don't love them which is why this place is only getting 4 out of 5 stars for me. You cannot go wrong with their fresh spring rolls (I would literally bathe in the peanut sauce) and a rice plate with a fried egg over it. 

D-Lish... check it outttt!!
author: Luigi A.

description:
A tiny spot in a somewhat anonymous stretch of mid SOMA, Tin is my new lunchtime SOMA pho spot. 

Good prices, and soothing, hot bowls of pho. The meat in the pho is seriously top notch. This is no seedy side alley pho joint - it's quality - but it still manages to have that delicious just-like-grandma-used-to-make down home taste.
author: James M.

description:
I had a Bun Bo Hue and an iced coffee. I would admit that I have had tried many places and Tin be one of the best place for BBH.The broth was very tasty and flavorful. The noodles were cooked to perfection. The portion was good enough for a big appetite man, however it was missing one key ingredient which was pork blood. How can you have BBH without pork blood? 

I am a big fan of pho so I will come back to try that next time. The service could have been a little bit more attentive. Overall, my experiences were satisfying.
author: Peter H.

description:
We live near Tin and will probably continue to go there because it is close, food is decent, and price is fair.   But they just can't get their service down.  

It seems like the kind of place that would do better by just having you order at a counter, pay then and there, hand you a number, and deliver your food.  Because even though they have servers, unless you get the girl with the short hair and the tattoos on her arms who actually knows how to serve tables (she is great!), you essentially don't get waited on.  

If you just order two bowls of pho they can get it right.  But if you order anything else, good luck.  I'd say over 50% of the time we've ordered a glass of wine, or beer, or side salad or anything else, it doesn't come out and we have to ask for it.  Same goes for getting the check and then giving your check with your card.  It's consistently like this.  It's not that their staff is standing around texting on their phones or anything like that, they just don't seem to understand efficient service and are kind of just ping ponging around all over the place.  They are consistently good about refiling water for the most part, but I'm not there for the water.
author: McKenzie M.

description:
* Pho Bo / rare beef & brisket with rice noodles in beef broth ($7.50) :: I was surprised by how tasty this was, given the hipster/unauthentic appearance of this restaurant. Although the bowl it comes in looks like a "small" at any other pho place, the portion is actually quite generous and 85% of the bowl is filled with "stuff" rather than soup. The presentation this way is much nicer but I wouldn't have minded getting a bigger bowl to put this in just so I can have more more to mix in my sprouts, basil, lime, and whatnots without worrying about the contents overflowing.

* Canh Ga Chien / 8 soy-garlic chicken wings ($8) :: Also delicious but sooort of pricy. The wings are the smallest kind that you can get at the grocery so they really shouldn't be $1 a piece.

The biggest problem I have with this place is the acoustics. It was eXtremely loud and if you concentrate just a tiny bit, you can literally eavesdrop on any conversation you want in the restaurant. It was so loud that I had to yell like I was at a night club just to carry on a conversation...and it got annoying enough that after a bit, we decided to just shut up, finish eating, and get out of there as quick as we could.

Without the pricy wings and noisy atmosphere, I can see myself giving this place 4-stars. Perhaps I'll try carryout next time.
author: Amaryllia L.

description:
One of my favorite Vietnamese spots into the bay area.

I'm a huge fan of the Pho Bo, but they also make delicious noodle bowls and rice plates, banh mi, homemade beverages, and spring rolls.

Cheap, casual, delicious, great ambience, ++++++.
author: Zack F.

description: Used to be our favorite place for pho. Now I can't get my wife to go b/c of the low health score. I've eaten there may times and no issues.
author: Rune S.

description:
As a big pho eater, I want to give this place a shot.  But unfortunately, the food failed.

Banh Xeo ($7) - It's sort of like a seafood pancake.  I like the crispiness of the outside, but the inside was mostly filled with bean sprouts.  Also, half of the plate was covered in lettuce and parsley.  Was I suppose to make some sort of lettuce wrap?  Server never gave us directions.  It didn't make sense to a crepe wrap inside some lettuce to make a wrap in a wrap.  So not worth the $7 for half a plate of crepe and half a plate of unsused greens.

Pho Bo ($7.50) & Hu Tieu ($8.50).  At first I was shocked at how many noodles they gave in the bowl because it was hard to manuver and separate the vermicelli in the bowl.  So, it seemed like a lot of noodles.  But when I eat through it, I realized that the amount of noodles they give is normal.  It's just that the bowl is so small that was hard to manuver the contents.  Ah, nice visualization trick.

The soup base was okay.  The Pho Bo had some slices of beef, but I wish there was more.  Also tried the Hu Tieu.  Seem like there was too many different things in there with not a lot of quantity of any type.  Overall, the pho was okay.

Limeade ($2.50) - The drink was too sweet and it was filled with ice so that you actually didn't get much to drink from the cup.  What got me was that I was sucking up grainy sugar crystals from the drink.  Sorry, I don't like drinking grains of sugar.  Can you please mix it more properly?  Or at least use less sugar?

Service was not good as there was only one server for the whole restaurant.  You need to hire another person.

Net-net, actually not the greatest value as quoted by others, but more of an 'okay' value.
author: Jon K.

description:
A great lunch spot where $8 will get you a good quality and healthy portion.  Tin features a number of alternative noodle bowls either with or without broth.  They also offer a fair selection of rice plates.  

Tin's seating area is not spacious and there are a limited number of tables.  On my first visit there were no tables remaining available, so we decided to go elsewhere.  However, upon returning the second time a couple of weeks later we were able to snatch one of the last tables.  Of course, if they are filling their seats then they must be doing something right.

Service at Tin was very attentive to our needs.  Very satisfied with the responsiveness of the very personable servers.  Overall, Tin provided a very satisfactory lunchtime dining experience. However, perhaps the best part is the fact that I only had to part with 8 bucks of my hard-earned cash to enjoy the meal and the visit !!!
author: Joel E.

description: I had the Bo Kho, which was amazing. Never had it anywhere before, but the broth was addictive, the meat was perfectly cooked, and I will definitely go back.
author: Sam Z.

description:
my friend was hungover, and we only had about 45 minutes for lunch.  we had planned to go on some place on 6th, but this was right across the street from where i parked.

so glad that we came here!

1. service was really fast.  we were unsure at first because it looked like almost no table had their food yet, and we were on a time crunch.  we got our food pretty quickly after we ordered, though.

2. the pho was good.  i'm not really a huge fan of pho, but this place was good!  the pork i got wasn't super dry, and the entire dish was not super greasy.  i can think of a couple places that other people might prefer, but this place is probably a healthier option.  portions were a good / healthy size so that you don't overeat.

3. price was cheap!  well, i thought it was cheap for san francisco at least.  i think mine was $7.50.  my friend's was $8.50.  

4. decorations were cute :)  they had these huuuuge lightbulbs that i've seen at other restaurants.  nothing else was super special, but it was a nice touch to make this place look less dingy (considering the neighborhood).

wouldn't mind coming back!  the only thing is that there aren't that many tables, so when the lunch hour neared, people were waiting in line to be seated.
author: Jennifer L.

description: I ordered the lunch special with soup of the day and the 5 spice chicken sandwich and needless to say, as you've read from everyone else, oh my goodness, the speed of the food but also its enormous quality, low price point and just sheer deliciousness made this experience amazing. From quick business lunch to slow dinner, Tin is your place.
author: Richard C.

description:
where did this place come from?!?!?! I'm so glad my friend introduced me to such a cute little joint. We were just looking for something small and ordered from the appetizer list - spring roll and the fried spring roll. Even though they're appetizer dishes, they weren't small for sure. We were both filled up from the appetizer.
The fried spring roll came with lettuce leaves, noodles, mint leaves and cilantro. I would definitely order that again, oh, also I saw the wings, and that looked awesome.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
my new pho spot! 
I've only ordered the Pho Bo and fresh spring rolls but they were delicious. I've had the Pho Bo with egg noodles (instead of rice noodles) and its the best. I definitely recommend that.
