The nice thing about Tin is its not dirty (like most pho places) and the crowd is full of working professionals and people that live in the area. 5 stars for the pho and cleanliness!
author: Kari K.

description: I came here for lunch today and was soooo pleased. The banana blossom salad was flavorful full of crunch, light and refreshing.  I got the chicken pho which has a delightful ginger broth. I can't wait to come back gain. Also our waiter was so helpful and attentive and he suggested the salad which we lived!
author: Julie B.

description:
They must have a garden in the back because EVERYTHING taste so fresh! Quality of their food is great. I'd recommend... the entire menu. Decor has that urban feeling and the employees are casual, but still professional. 

I believe the place has less than 10 tables. Beer & wine for drink choices.
author: A W.

description:
I've been here a number of times now.  By far, best Vietnamese food east of Van Ness.  For this, they get a strong four stars.  If there was better competition, they might get a strong three stars... 

Solid food here, sauces are great and they take a lot of pride in the food preparation and presentation which most Viet places do not.  The food tastes clean and fresh and not over seasoned.  I agree with most of the other reviews as to what to order.

They really just need a better location and better floor plan.
author: Mr. E.

description: This is one of my favorite Vietnamese spots in the city. They offer the usual, but their spring rolls and house-made peanut sauce is where it's at. I often just have that if I'm dining solo :)
author: Leah C.

description:
Dudes and Dudettes!
Come try this cure lil Thai place, it totally rocks!
:)
:)
:)
author: Carey H.

description:
Caveat - I know about as much about vietnamese food as my wife does about fantasy football

What I had was tasty - Bahn Xeo: which is some kind of omlette with vegetables and calamari inside it.  And a bunch of greens on the side.  

For dinner I had a rice platter with pork shoulder.  Very tasty.  And a nice touch, they put an egg sunnyside up on top of the rice.  Meat was tender, rice with egg was good - I was happy.

I realize this review is probably borderline insulting to connosiers of vietnamese food - lol.   I tried
author: Tom P.

description: Great flavors. I tried the quail, the shrimp salad and then for the entrée, the grilled pork chop. Delicious. However if you're going for lunch, be there at 11.30 and also be prepared for it be really noisy.
author: Aravind G.

description: Had the Pho Bo. I can say it's OKAY~ish, but I wouldn't recommend it as a top choice. A little bit overrated, beef ball in it is good though. Oh, the waiter could never seem to remember who got which ;(
author: Frank L.

description:
This place is great.  Excellent service, close to my place in SOMA, great music (head nodding beat music), and very good pho for San Francisco.

The soup and the noodles for the Pho Bo were great.  No MSG flavor and the noodles were firm.  The quality of the beef was very nice.

My lady friend got the Pho Ga and the broth was great, could really taste the ginger in it.  Much better than other places where they use the beef broth and just put chicken in it.

This place has the best Pho I've had in the city so far.  I will be coming back to try out the other dishes.
author: Baek C.

description: Very fresh ingredients.  Definitely liked the pho.  The pork shoulder was quite tender.   Prompt and friendly service.  Rare to find a lunch pho place where the waiter checks on you.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
Decent food for the price, but overrated if you dine in.

To start, they made us wait while empty tables sit throughout the restaurant. Next they tried to seat the two of us at a big table right next to another couple, without asking whether we're ok with sharing. We refused, so they gave us a table for four. In the middle of our meal, they grabbed my phone that was on the table and moved it so they could seat another couple at our table. "Thank you for sharing", they quipped without asking. Be ready to bump elbows and get soup splash if you come here.

The food itself was just above average. Spring rolls were fresh but not flavorful. The pho soup was nice, while the rare beef was fully cooked and the beef balls juicy but bland. Bo bun hui was likewise mixed, with a tasty soup base but overcooked noodles. 

Lastly, this is more of a fusion place. Good and safe food, but if you want authentic you'll have to try elsewhere.
author: Keith L.

description:
Great vietnamese restaurant!  We had the sizzling beef, Lemongrass pork vermicelli & Lemongrass chicken rice lunches. All were fabulous. My fav was the vermicelli.

Small little restaurant with great food, friendly wait staff & a highchair for my baby.

If I lived closer we'd be back all the time!
author: KAT t.

description: I walk here for lunch whenever I attend a conference at Moscone Center.  Its a small place but they move the customers pretty fast.  Good, authentic Vietnamese, with a good wait staff.
author: Gil D.

description:
$40 for dinner for 4 people! Why isn't this place packed with a line around the corner? Shhh....don't tell anyone and let's keep it a hidden gem. The pho, clay pot catfish, lemongrass chicken and beef salad were dee-lish.  Atmosphere was simple but contemporary. 

One star off because they only had one server for the entire restaurant.
author: Kim W.

description:
Went to this place as a back up to not going to the Tenderloin.  At first glimpse I would have never gone to the place due to the modern dark wood floored ergonomic chair asian fusion look the place has.  To me this screams: compromise flavor to cater towards yuppies.  However, after looking at the menu and prices my sig. other and i decided to give it a try with the condition of eating at a dirty vietnamese place once we got back to southern california.  

I ordered the Pho, spring rolls and my partner in crime ordered a seasoned chicken and noodles dish.  The spring rolls were quite girthy and seemingly fresh.  Because of my prejudices of places that look like Tin I initially thought the spring rolls were pre-made.  Although, on my way back from the bathroom I peeked into the kitchen and saw a little old asian lady, sure enough, rolling up fresh spring rolls.  Well done.  

The Pho was decent.  Not the best and not average.  It gains points due to the actual RARE beef bouquet that sat atop the pipping hot broth.  The broth was missing the strong anise and cardamon spice but it was still good.  Again, the rare beef was the main focus.  It almost looked like tuna sashimi in the dim lighting.  

I took a small bite of the chicken from the noodle bowl.  I would definitely try it again.  No complaints.  Again, not the best, and not average.  

Last, we brought a bottle of  Riesling from my favorite brand wine "Murphy's Law" and normally wouldve been charged a $10 corkage fee but it was waived for some reason.  very cool.  

The trade off between possibly getting stabbed and yuppified vietnamese food was worth it.  If I'm in the area again I might consider it.
author: Kyle I.

description:
good salad and chicken wings.  broth seems to be fresher than most vietnamese restaurants I have been to... just...again...slow and hectic service...

remember to try to fresh coconut water!!!
author: Shuting Z.

description: I tried this place because it was highly recomended by a colleague.  It's a bit crowded during the lunch hour, but that was to be expected since it's a pretty small location.  I tried the Vegitarian Pho, and it was fantastic!  The tofu was perfect, and the broth was so flavorful. I also loved the onions served on the side.  I'll definately be back.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Most delicious Vietnamese spot ever!  Super fresh, interesting ingredients and an extremely reasonably-priced menu have made me slightly obsessed.  Plus, their wine list is fantastic.  No Mondavi here, but instead a more 'curated' wine list that offers some solid options (again, reasonably priced) with this incredible food.  

Basically, go here now.  It's amazing.
author: rc c.

description: Got the caramelized catfish, green papaya salad, and a bun with pork shoulder.  All were quite tasty, though the catfish was a bit on the salty side.  Fast service, and good portion sizes.  Will definitely come here again.
author: Max L.

description: Good food but they wouldn't seat me until my friend arrived. A fine policy unless the place is empty. I guess some people just need the rules so bad
author: Micah J.

description:
I wasn't feeling too well after a bad sushi lunch and was trying to find a restaurant that would be comforting to my belly. After searching through Yelp I discovered Tin was just a block from my hotel. Pho sounded like the perfect dinner option for soothing a belly on a rainy night. 

Dinner was fantastic and so reasonable. A big, big bowl of Pho Ga, a ginger-ale, and a glass of wine was only $18.

Tin helped me rediscover the joy of Pho! It is going to be a challenge to find a Vietnamese restaurant this good in Boston but I now have a mission!
author: Lauren W.

description:
I came here by review of a newly made friend in the city. I didn't wait more than two weeks to visit this place as it is less than a 5 minute walk from where I inhabit.

I've been here on three occasions. I ordered the chicken vermicelli one time, and the rice plate with Ginger Chicken (SO GREAT!!!!!) and the Pho Bo the third time. I've had the Papaya Salad twice as an appetizer.

I highly recommend the ginger chicken plate. The chicken was perfect, not hard or overcooked at all, but sweet and oh so soft. The rice and rest of the plate was delicious as well, but I COULDN'T GET AWAY FROM THE DELICIOUS CHICKEN.

The Vermicelli was good, what can one expect from a dang decent vietnamese place! 

The first time I had the papaya salad I was pleasantly surprised (as I don't order this often). It had just the right amount of kick to it, and was great to share with ONE amigo. Although on the second try, it wasn't as delightful. Regardless I've been pretty darn satisfied with this place, it's fast staff (refills water frequently), and its close proximity.

One thing is that the Pho Bo wasn't anything spectacular, but with all the other dish choices I could really care less.
author: Mikey O.

description: Don't bother writing your name on the waiting list. service was erratic. staff didnt seem to know what was going on. Food was ok. Pretentious atmosphere. Lucky for them it's the only Vietnamese restaurant in the area
author: Sushi Y.

description: Excellent service, the waitress was very attentive.  The pho is on the very small side, but the flavor is excellent.  The bean sprouts were very clean.  The meatballs and beef brisket were nothing special, but the sliced raw beef was the best i've had anywhere, very tender and very high quality meat. The restaurant was extremely clean and you can easily see into the kitchen as well.  While this is NOT the best Pho i've ever had nor the best value, this is certainly one of the cleanest and best service i've ever received in a Vietnamese restaurant.  This is a very well balanced restaurant in terms of ambiance, service, food, and value.
author: W Q.

description: One of the best bowls of Vegetarian Pho I've had. Great ingredients - really fresh veggies and really tasty tofu. Noodles good thickness and doneness. They also did the spring rolls for us without meat, made to order. Highly recommended.
author: Dylan N.

description: The dining room is small so there was a short wait for my girlfriend and I. But on a cold night after a giants game it was the perfect place to warm up while BART traffic died down. The Pho is great especially the chicken ginger. I will definitely come back to this Pho spot!
author: Joel H.

description:
A Vietnamese resto with a wine list and Edison bulbs? Suspect. White-haired woman reading a book a la cafe/al fresco? Questionable. But the smell in the place? Irresistible. This small space used to be Pho Ha Tien, I think, and that place was just fine, so we were doubly reluctant to wait for a table here (10 minutes or so). But the servers were super friendly and conscious of the wait. They even got took our order so they could get it going while we stood there. 

Would the wait be that short, or would the food take that long to come out. Again, suspect. But we were seated shortly thereafter, the Banh Xeo arrived and son of a bitch if it wasn't delicious. 

The crepe was crispy and dense with flavor, packed with shrimp and squid and beansprouts. The pho arrived and even though they only offer one size, again, it was just fine. Delicious, in fact, and when we feel like not getting the cheap shit at Miss Saigon, this is a much shorter trek than one to Chinatown, and really quite decent. Super friendly service, decent turnaround for a small space. A little pricey but so is MSG shock from some crayzee authentic stock. God, I'm such a cracker.
author: Roy M.

description: Tried cha gio and caramelized clay pot catfish. Cha gio is very good as a snack, and their clay pot catfish is just amazing. The catfish is tender and very flavorful. It's too salty, I would say, even for a real Asian (no, I'm not Vietnamese). But this place is still very good overall, definitely deserves a five-star.
author: Chenguang W.

description: I was in town and ate lunch here all week. I ordered the Pho Bo and iced coffee. The Pho has great taste and was boiling hot each meal. The coffee was excellent and cooled off your mouth from the hot soup. The place is small and gets very crowded so plan accordingly. Even if you have to wait it's worth it. Total bill with tip was $17. Great value.
author: Jim T.

description:
Great food great ppl and great design!
And also wonderful prices, which is even sweeter !!
author: Virginie F.

description:
The pho here is fantastic! I come here for lunch when I'm at work. I've had a few of the phos, the spring rolls, and the greens as a side. Everything is fresh, tasty, and never greasy. And this joint is a little nicer than the hole in the wall pho places I normally go to.

The prices are slightly higher that other pho restaurants and there is only one size of pho  (perfect for me). The other thing to mention for cilantro haters like me (it's genetic I swear! I wish I liked the green stuff becasue it would make my life easier) if you ask for no cilantro, there is another herb they use that is in the same family as cilantro and it tastes just a gross. So I was advised to ask for only onions.

This def one of my favorite lunch spots!
author: danielle l.

description: Good food, not great. TERRIBLE service. One of the worst I've had in a long time. Server was really rude.
author: Robert M.

description: Wow, what a great find. Vegetable pho with great flavor and umami! Clay pot shrimp was perfect, and the clay pot catfish even better. Affordable wines. I wanted the fish sauce brand the tiny chef used, she makes her own.
author: Dave Y.

description: Real good food, their service was all right and it was too rushed because they were closing within an hour. I had order my first Bun Tom Vermicelli and it was really good.  I got hooked on the Thai tea and the meal was well served. The only thing that grasp my attention was the tables was busted leaving water residue on the tables even after I spilled my Thai tea and the waiter cleaned my mishap and gave me another one which was cool. I like this place but it's hours doesn't suit me that it closes later in the afternoon.
author: Ahrmon R.

description: My boyfriend and I found this place thanx to yelp when we were walking around in sf. It's one of those amazing restaurants that you stumble upon. I got the 5 spice grilled chicken rice plate and I loved it! My boyfriend got Phô and he said it was really good. I do recommend this place :)
author: Jazmine O.

description:
3 stars for the pho, but an extra star for being a little different.

Food: I like more traditional pho, tripe, tendon and a bigger bowl, but Tin's had flavorful broth and a lot of meat. Bowl was a little small for my large appetite but it would satisfy most.

Ambiance: Small restaurant, but simple and clean layout.

Service: Nice staff, food came out in a timely manner.

Price: $1 or $2 more then most Vietnamese places.

Overall: Nice modern take on Vietnamese.
author: Binh D.

description:
Luckily I work near here and can go during the week, it's sad that they're not open weekends.

I'm addicted to the Vegetarian Bun; it comes with a crispy roll, tofu, noodles, mushrooms and vegetables.. fresh, flavorful, filling, it's everything I could want! Service is consistently good (not outstanding but never bad, which IMHO is more important) for both dining in and takeout.

This little spot is good for friends or business, assuming you can eat pho without splashing your companions!

Even though it is a small restaurant, the bathroom is clean and accessible, not down some weird hallway like a lot of places :)
author: Ashley L.

description: Got the bun rieu and the pho bo. Great taste. Service left something to be desired which is why I'm cutting one star. Took forever to take our order and then another eternity to get the check. Waiter did not check on the table even once. Would still go back for the food though.
author: Nelson C.

description: Surprisingly this place is good! I ordered the bun bo hue and it had really good flavors, but the lemongrass was a little too empowering for me. The egg rolls were good too. I liked the iced coffee also. Will definitely be back to try other items on the menu.
author: Cindy T.

description: I ate their lemongrass pork shoulder rice dish, which is very flavorful. The meat was tender and juicy. They add $1 for the brown-rice request. Nice surroundings and okay service.
author: Derek N.

description: Great Vietnamese restaurant in soma!  Got the noodle soup with pork, shrimp, and chicken.  The chicken soup it comes in is amazing!  We will definitely be back!
author: Tiffany C.

description: I have a love/hate relationship with this place.  The food is delicious but the wait is ridiculous.  I've been here several times in big groups and small, during the lunch rush and off peak hours and the wait for the food is always long.  Their Vietnamese coffee tastes authentic vs some other versions of it in the area but it's pricey considering the coffee to ice ratio. Service is hit or miss - sometimes we got a friendly server and other times we got a snotty one.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I typically don't review places I like a lot because I am selfish and I don't want them to become popular enough that I will have to wait. I'll make an exception for Tin...

Authentic Vietnamese in a non-authentic atmosphere. Yeah, grandma is in the back cooking the pho broth, but the front end has a chill/modern vibe. Servers are always cool. Real wine list- but I never seem to drink them. The ingredients tend to be a step up from your typical pho joint, but the prices are the same.

The hours can seem a bit odd and the neighborhood is mildly sketch, but this place really is more than just a neighborhood spot- worth checking out.
author: Kevin F.

description:
I really highly recommend Tin for a fresh take on Vietnamese Food. Its not your usual Vietnamese Pho because the portions aren't as big, but the ingredients are fresher. The food at Tin still tastes authentic Vietnamese and not Americanized like Out the Door. 

My favorite is the Hu Tieu for soup because of the garlic flavor and the mix of different meats. I also really like the Bun Tom Thit Nuong if its a hot day and you want some cold, dry and refreshing noodles. I get the Pho Ga sometimes for the simplicity of the chicken noodle soup, if your feeling a bit sick, eating a bowl of hot Pho Ga definitely makes you feel better. 

The restaurant itself has some nice simple decor and is clean compared to some Vietnamese places in Chinatown and the service is always friendly. 

Because i'm Asian and i'm accustomed to eating at really cheap vietnamese pho joints that is cheap, tastey, and serves big portions i can't give Tin 5 stars but i still highly recommend Tin because of the cleanliness, freshness, and authenticity of their food.
author: Chris C.

description: Started with the Papaya Salad which was awesome. Moved onto the Pho Go which was fantastic, especially since it's all about the broth, and Tin totally brings it. My friend had the 5 Spice Chicken Sandwich with a side salad and loved it. Great flavor and a great deal!
author: Kenton  K.

description:
Simple, fresh, delightful Vietnamese food. I had a very simple side salad that rocked my world (which is big for me. lettuce doesn't usually pull at my heart strings) and the fresh spring rolls. 

I'll be headed back for the limeade, veggie pho, and about 12 other things on the menu.
author: Heidi K.

description: Had my usual Bun, instead of pork I had lemongrass beef.  It was good but it just didn't pop with flavor, maybe it was the nouc mam cham that wasn't happening.  The spring rolls were great but the peanut sauce was bland and forgettable.  Prices are decent.  Nothing to go out of your way for but if you're in that neighborhood  the food is good and prices are right so go ahead and stop in.  Biggest complaint would be the ambience - blaring pop music.  Blaring anything makes it difficult for me to enjoy my meal.
author: rebecca c.

description: My friends and i wanted to grab quick dinner before heading to watch the lion king musical and glad we settle on this establish with the help of yelp as always :) I found this place to be a more modernized Vietnamese restaurant-nice ambiance and a very mixed crowd which i found to be really cool. Menu is simple and straight to the point. I ordered the shaken beef with brown rice (very happy that they offered BR as an option!) Everything about my meal was delicious, the arugula salad paired to this tasted super yummy. Ohh and the service was awesome; she was super friendly, energetic and attentive the whole time. I saw her helping the tables across from us and she was nothing but friendly and patient with the large groups. I didn't get to catch her name (short hair with cool tattoos) but thank if your reading this, thank you!! :) I would def visit this place again when I'm in the area!
author: Shirley N.

description: My new favorite Vietnamese spot in SF.  The pho bo is sometimes a little sweet, but usually it's spot on, with the meat still raw and the noodles al dente.  The lemongrass pork sandwich is the highlight of the menu.
author: Michael G.

description:
Love this place! 
Pho is soooooo god!!! 
Vietnamese crepe tooo
Service is pretty cool
author: Mina T.

description:
When I found out my company was moving to Howard & 5th from the Embarcadero area... my first thought was - Damn. Where am I going to eat lunch?!

Luckily...after some trial and error I found TIN. 5 stars is an easy rating b/c every dish has been delicious, fresh and comforting. Plus they are open until 3:30. 

Turtle Tower was my favorite spot for pho but these two spots are now tied :)

Staff is awesome and I've noticed many customers are on a first name basis. 

It's my can't go wrong lunch spot, don't leave without ordering the crispy spring rolls!
author: Charlene A.

description:
Upscale Vietnamese food with attentive service and a nice atmosphere, considering its location. I had no idea this even existed until it appeared in my Yelp search.

Fried rolls were piping hot and tasty.

Caramelized clay pot catfish was outstanding -- absolutely no dirty taste with the catfish, indicating proper preparation.

Pho Bo was plentiful, lots of noodles, good cuts of beef.

Sauteed greens with garlic were fresh, and just enough garlic without being overpowering.

I would walk back here, for sure.
author: Cody K.

description: The atmosphere is a bit dark, but the food is decent. Surprisingly, it tasted very authentic despite it being cater to Americans and the business lunch crowd. The lemongrass pork I ordered wasn't burn like I experienced at some restaurants, and the fish sauce was just the right kind of sourness. However, for this price I can get more at a Chinese Vietnamese restaurant, which is why I only give it 3 stars despite the decent food.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Delicious, fast and cheap. 

Had the Catfish Clay Pot Rice the first time I came and have been coming back for it ever since.  It's so good I almost can't get myself to order anything else.  The catfish was tender, and the sauce is amazing - soy sauce, onion, garlic, scallion and whatever other deliciousness they put in it.  Makes me happy just thinking about it.

Sounds like other yelpers are impressed by their pho too.

But catfish claypot did it for me.
author: Thomas L.

description: Pretty solid lunch at Tin Vietnamese Cuisine. The service was quick and friendly. The menu was pretty impressive. Cost was just a bit high and the portion was below average. I guess I was expecting a giant bowl of pho bigger than my head. Oh well.
author: Ronny D.

description: Great Vietnamese restaurant! Definitely recommend! Good enough for a mellow date. Very fresh food and nice ambience.
author: Ethan S.

description: This place is in a really shady area. I was scared while walking to the restaurant with a friend, but I trusted her judgement. I was really surprised! It had this trendy modern vibe inside. The spring rolls were so fresh, I love it when the rice paper roll is soft, not hard and rubbery. The pho's really good here as well! All in all I'm a fan of this place!
author: Maggie T.

description:
This place is trying way too hard to look like they're in Hayes Valley, but the food is really top-notch and the prices are more than reasonable for the quality. Those milquetoast "Off The Grid" lunch trucks that come around every once in a while sell many of the same dishes for much, much more money, and what you get from them is mostly flavorless gristle. Tin served me the best meal I've had since starting a job in the neighborhood and I'll be back repeatedly. 

If I have anything bad to say about my dining experience at all it's that the little salad thing that accompanies the rice plates just doesn't need to be there. Ten cents worth of grated daikon or an orange wedge would leave me just as happy as a couple chunks of truck-ripened slave labor tomatoes and some carrots that you ran over the Super Benriner.
author: Nicholas J.

description:
This place is amazing!
Very small, and hard to find, but once you are on the street, you'll find it. 
Service is Great and Food was awesome. 
Spring roll was definitely the best roll I'd prob had. 

would like to go there again if possible :)
author: Rachel H.

description:
Right next to Burlington Coat Factory. 

The restaurant opens at 11:30am during the weekdays, so we make sure that we are one of the first to get seated. It gets real busy after 12pm. This became the main pho spot for my coworkers and I since HI TEA closed. Decent pricing of $10 for pho downtown with tons of noodles and the broth is pretty good.  

I also tried the grilled beef over a bed of vermicelli noodles.  This was delicious. The beef actually wrapped around sour vegetables. Reminded me of the 7 course beef. 

Service is slow, it usually takes about 1.5 hours to get in, order, eat , get the bill and cash out.

Decent pho, will come back; unless we find another pho joint around!
author: Chanel L.

description: To me , this restaurant is the best vieniam restaurant compare with any one  in Los Angeles! It's very clean and authentic ! I Will go bk again when I'm in town !
author: M-shelle H.

description:
I went here for lunch with a co-worker today and just got take-out. I tried to call in advance, but no one picked up.

When you walk in for lunch, it's confusing as to whether you are supposed to order take out in the same place where you wait for a table. The waitress was polite and let us know where to go, but there didn't appear to be a host working that day (which would have corrected the confusion). We ordered and were quoted 20min (which is pretty long if you are just ordering take out and the food essentially cooks itself).

We waited with a group of people outside because it was really loud inside and hot! Too cramped so we decided to get some fresh air. After about 5-10 minutes, one of the waiters brought the other group their food and disappeared back into the restaurant. Another 5-10 minutes goes by and I see another guest who got there after us walk out with her take out. I went inside to investigate and saw my food and my coworker's food sitting on the counter and I immediately claimed it. The waitress was very apologetic and nice about it, but this got me pretty annoyed.

The vegetarian pho was really tasty and all the ingredients were fresh and colorful. They give you a nice moderately spicy sauce to go with your meal that gives the pho a nice kick. I usually go for really spicy but this was flavorful.
author: Maxine E.

description: Really decent pork, reasonable prices. Average service and nice decor. Funny place for this sort of restaurant, but glad it's here.
author: Bob M.

description:
This place was great the food was excellent we had 
the side greens were very tasty pho bo, pork lemongrass rice plate, and crepe appetizer all tastyyyyyyyy!!!
author: Orchid S.

description:
Love the food (fresh ingredients, nicely put together)
Love the people (friendly, helpful and knowledgeable about the menu)

We had:  
1. Spring rolls - nice, balanced assembly of fresh ingredients and flavors
2. Grilled Eggplant with Garlic-Chili Fish Sauce - this one is not much to look at but so very tasty and memorable in the best way
3. Pho Bo - finally, someone gets how the meat is supposed to be done for this dish
4. Caramelized Claypot Catfish - very flavorful dish, fish perfectly cooked (not too done, not underdone)
author: Chanimal C.

description: OMFG, excellent food!  Fresh and delicious.    Will return.  Small place, packed for lunch (understandably so), excellent service.  They don't take AMEX.
author: P H.

description:
Found Tin thanks to Yelp. It's a small, dimly lit restaurant with simple modern decor and a chill vibe.  My server was friendly and competent; attentive but not overbearing.

Food was delicious. I ordered a glass of white wine and a bowl of vermicelli noodles with pork.  The serving was generous (but because it tasted so good I finished the whole thing).  The pork itself was a much higher quality meat than the other VN restaurants I frequent. It was grilled perfectly - charred around the edges. I wish I had some leftovers so I could eat them now!

Only negative was that their fish sauce was a bit bland for my taste. But my server brought me some fresh jalapeño slices to add the punch I needed. 

Great place to go before catching a movie at the Metreon or Century theaters.
author: Sandy S.

description:
What the pho?

Been here twice now and have to say that the food so far has been really tasty. The broth they use is probably the best that I can think of. Mine was ginger-chicken but the garlic-chicken broth was even better. I've had the pho ga and the 5-spice chicken sandwich that came with soup. The pho ga here is probably my favorite now, but the sandwich and soup was decent, not the best. Go to Vietnam Village (sit-down restaurant) in San Bruno for Vietnamese sandwiches. Second place is Little Paris (grab 'n go) in Chinatown.

They try to make it a little more modern, but the floor, ceiling and furniture still needs updating. Yuppie time is during lunch hour which slowed the service down, so come before or after weekday lunchtime if you can. 

Had the yogurt & berries for dessert which doesn't make you feel too guilty afterwards.
author: May C.

description: Stopped in for lunch yesterday. Busy in a good way, clean, fast service, good food. definitely not a "little Saigon" pho joint, but that means, as I just noted: busy, in a good way, clean, fast service - and no old men showing off how loud they can slurp their soup!
author: Bowen D.

description: Yum. Loud at lunch time. Good Vietnamese food masked by trendy vibe.  Ultimately very much authentic but expect to give the waiters a non-authentic 15% tip at the end of you meal in the clean, modern dining room.
author: scott a.

description:
Tin Vietnamese is a great restaurant. It has a simple menu but has delicious food. I came with a friend once, and brought my fiance and his sister here the second time. There was no wait for a table (although we did go on weekdays), and the service was exceptionally quick. The food is not expensive at all, and the food is extremely tasty.

This restaurant has about two vegetarian entree options - but the Vegetarian Pho and the Vegetarian Vermicelli, both are tasty and delicious. We enjoyed the food and the price. 

A must try for those who want delicious vegetarian Vietnamese food.
author: Vrinda S.

description:
I'd give it 4 1/2 stars if I could. I'm a BIG fan of Tin. I'm definitely a lunch regular here now. It really is the perfect lunch spot. I'm sure it's awesome for dinner also.

The ambiance is simple, clean, and modern. Usually pretty good background music too. The food is super fresh, relatively healthy, and so damn delicious. The staff is also great. And the prices are beyond reasonable. The ONLY slightly negative thing I'd say, is that the service can sometimes be a bit slow. They could do with hiring one more server for the lunch rush.

Must tries are the crunchy spring rolls, the non-crunchy spring rolls, pho, sandwiches, claypot shrimp, ... basically everything. Because everything I've tried is bomb.com. Enjoy!
author: Betsy W.

description: When my noodles arrived, I knew from the aroma that this place had a shot at 5 stars.  It did not disappoint- excellent flavors.  My basis for judging noodle bowls is a comparison to the noodle bowls that I had on the streets in Saigon, and I would definitely say that this is the authentic thing.  Fresh spring rolls had a great consistency, and the price was right.
author: Charles C.

description:
I had a wonderful experience at Tin the other night. I was with a large group and the staff was patient and attentive all evening long. Shout out to Shai, she's the best!

Seasonings and sauces are spot-on at Tin and the ingredients are well-sourced and fresh. I loved the Vietnamese crepe. It was crisp and rich, studded with plump shrimp, and struck a wonderful contrast when wrapped in a fresh leaf of lettuce with fresh mint and cilantro, fish sauce, and thinly sliced and pickled carrot and radish. Wow. Green papaya and beef salads were also tangy and scrumptious.

We washed this all down with a crisp, aromatic white wine from the small, but well curated list. 

For entrees, the grilled pork bun hit the ball straight out of the park. These folks know their marinades and they grill the meat to perfection. Tender claypot cat fish was a sticky treat and sizzling beef was just that with tender cubes of meat and crisp, flavorful bell peppers. Did I mention the imperial rolls are addictive?

To top it all off, they wave the Rainbow Flag in their window and keep in down-to-earth, family style, and welcoming inside. Tin is a true San Francisco restaurant.
author: Kate J.

description: Caramelized claypot catfish was delicious! Flavorful but may be a bit spicy for some.
author: S T.

description:
I tried the Hu Tieu at this newish Vietnamese spot in Soma a while back. The broth was legit, homemade, complex, with plenty of depth. The ingredients were fresh as well.

The taste I had of their catfish claypot was also nice.

I'd come back sooner, but it's on a desolate block of Howard St. that I never seem to find myself near.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Tin is a fantastic little hole-in-the-wall jem of a Vietnamese eatery.  It's cheap, the portions are generous, the staff are very attentive and friendly, and the bathroom is clean.  I was able to peek into the kitchen while waiting to use the bathroom and it was also uncharacteristically clean, compared with other small restaurants in this part of SOMA.

I went with a friend, but the decor and lighting make it a cute place to even take a casual date.  It's pretty quite and you could have an intimate conversation if you wanted to at one of the small tables.  

My friend and I both had silver noodle soups - chicken and veggie.  Each was served with delicious fresh Thai basil and crisp bean sprouts.  

Our waitress never let our water glasses empty and treated us as if we were customers having a big meal with expensive entrees.  With that kind of attitude, I'm sure to return for meals large and small!  Great spot!
author: Jenny B.

description: I had the pho bo with rare beef and flank _ the portion is smaller than a real ethnic place in San Mateo, ie less soup, but plenty of sprouts, onions and chiles.  My friend had the papaya salad and enjoyed it.  At lunch time, do not be fooled, it looked dark from across the street, but it was open and full !
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Every time we are in San Francisco and are craving some Pho we make an effort to visit Tin. The Goi Ga is amazing as a starter or appetizer, we get it every time. We usually just get the Pho as the entree. The service is great, even though at times there is a line out the door. We have noticed that the place has gotten a bit messy lately. Other than that I would recommend it to anyone who's looking for authentic Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Vera B.

description:
Now this is what I'm talking about!  Came here and got the Pho Bo and it was fantastica!  The broth was perfect, good quality of meat and the noodles were just right.  Every bite was delicious and only made me wish that my mom wasn't across the country.

The Goi Cuon (spring rolls) had a small amount of mayo in it.  I wasn't too fond of that but otherwise, everything was great!  Good service for a delicious meal.

Best pho place in SF so far!
author: Nho C.

description: Went here yesterday for lunch after 2pm. So they were not packed or busy. Pho was OK, Turtle tower one block up way better.  Will not return for the POOR service. Sat down for over 10 minutes,  had to flag down someone to place an order, get water, get check!!
author: Sravanthi D.

description:
I got the hu tieu (pho) because it had the most ingredients listed (yes, this is how I order food at restaurants) and thought it was mediocre. The roasted (?) pork was the best part, but there were only a couple slices. 

There were three shrimp and a barely discernible smattering of ground pork. The pieces of chicken were pretty dry. The noodles had a slightly weird taste, like they hadn't been rinsed in water enough times, and the broth tasted somewhat watery, not rich and broth-y.

HOWEVER, this is a pretty cool looking restaurant and the service was very friendly and casual. And the rice plates looked pretty good.
author: Carolyn F.

description: I've only had the beef rolls over vermicelli and the vegetarian vermicelli but both exceed my expectations =)
author: Kurosh H.

description: Best vegetarian spring roll I've had at any Pho restaurant! The ginger-chicken broth is good, but didn't have my mouth doing a happy dance. They cook their noodles perfectly. If the broth knocked me off my feet, this would have been my favorite Pho spot.
author: Shahin P.

description:
Vietnamese food is typically really inexpensive, but being downtown this place will cost you just one or two dollars more than usual. But it's worth it! It's not the portion size that makes it worth it, because their dishes are somewhat small, but oh my GOD does it taste good! Unique dishes that I presume unless you've been to Vietnam you'll have never heard of. Definitely give them a try. Also, try their lychee iced tea!

Price: 6/10
Portion size: 7/10
Presentation: 7/10
Taste: 9/10
Service: 7/10
Overall: 7.5/10
author: Darren H.

description:
My GF and I are lunch time regulars. 

The food at Tin was tasty, the menu is limited but there are a good amount of options. 

The prices at Tin were great and the service was casual but great.
author: Gibran H.

description: It was a cold day and I wanted pho noodle soup. This was the closest one to our hotel. It was walking distance from the W. It's not as authentic as I'm use to but the portion for the beef rice was great! They gave alot of meat. But the pho was just ok.
author: Julie L.

description: This is my second time for lunch with friends. We loved what we order.  Next time, I will order to go. I'm not use to the heat while I'm eating beef noodle soup. It's too hot inside. My husband loved the shaken beef, which I ordered to go.  Otherwise, it is a good food!
author: T T.

description:
What can I say to this amazing under-rated vietnamese cuisine Tin Restaurant.  A good friend invited me to a birthday party in Noe Valley (Sugar Lounge) and was treated to an amazing array of Vietnamese deliciousness catered by Tin--lemon grass pork banh mi, fresh (uber fresh) spring rolls, deep-fried eggrolls, Vietnamese Papaya salad with shrimp and calamari, etc.  It really hit the spot.  I think I must have had 3 plate servings without feeling any guilt because it was that good!  

Hung (Tin owner) was very attentive with his smile and was super friendly and super cute.  And his lady friends were adorable.  I wish his restaurant the best of luck since they've only been open for a year.  I promised I would yelp his restaurant to show support.  

So what are you waiting for...go to Tins!
author: ismael d.

description: Pretty good Pho, but what I liked best was the claypot catfish dish... amazeballs! I find it just a little too pricey for what it is though... Then again, I'm spoiled from having tons of little crazy cheap Vietnamese places a just blocks away from my place near TL :)
author: Alexandra V.

description:
Consistently tasty pho and fast, friendly service. It may cost a buck or three more than your average hole-in-the-wall pho joint, but it's also a heck of a lot nicer and cleaner inside than a typical dive.

If you live or work in SoMA, then you really should be frequenting Tin.
author: Ziad E.

description:
Best pho I've had in months. Got the Hu Tieu, was really impressed, and will get it again when I go back.

Fantastic place to come for a simple, cheap-for-this-area lunch. Attentive and friendly service (at least, at 1pm on a monday when I'm one of only two customers in the place). Ambience is a little too yuppie for my taste, but I can get over it - this place could become a nice lunch haunt.
author: JR H.

description:
Vietnamese myths shattered today:

- Spring rolls cannot be bigger than burritos
- Lemongrass tofu cannot be better than lemongrass chicken
- Papaya shrimp salad is better without dressing
- All of the above is way too much food for two people

Quality and quantity of the food blew me away. There was enough for leftovers and Replating.

Friendly service was a bit slow but you can't rush greatness.

Some of the best Vietnamese I've ever had.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place gets 4 stars just because I've only gone once. But if it's consistent, it might just as well be a 5 given the following factors as a group: 1) it's in San Francisco, 2) it's cheap (for SF), 3) it has awesome flavor (compared to the best places I've been to in San Jose).

My boyfriend's friend recommended this place so we had to try it. We came here on a Tuesday at around 6pm. Nobody was in there, which was fine by me. We ordered the pho bo.

The food came out piping hot. The flavor was very, very good. Not too sweet and not too salty--no overpowering spices. The noodles had just the right bite (and they are the usual type you get, not the thicker handmade type noodles). It tasted a lot like the good pho I get in San Jose, but the meat seemed to actually be of better quality. The brisket in the pho wasn't anything special, but the rare beef definitely tasted better in quality than what you get in San Jose. Even though the bowl is small, they pack it with lots of noodles and a good amount of soup. It's basically enough for an adult, I think, so that you don't stuff yourself silly (and I am one who loves larges portions).

The sriracha smelled fresh and so were the bean sprouts (didn't give a lot though, but I'm sure if we asked for more they'd give us ore). All in all, I think this is now officially my favorite place for pho in San Francisco. I don't think there's anywhere else I've tried that has such tasty soup in SF, for only $7.50!!!!!!!! (And trust me, I've been on the search for the perfect, best-priced bowl of pho bo in SF--Pot de Pho, Zadin, Out the Door, Pagolac, Mangosteen, Pho Tan Hoa, etc.). 

After the meal, we were pretty full (almost at the point where you have to walk slouched) and very satisfied. No stomach troubles and not too thirsty. I will be back for more! I just wished they also were open on weekends!

Basically, if you want to eat San-Jose-like pho in San Francisco that tastes fresh and good quality (but without the ginormous bowls), go to Tin!
author: Angela H.

description: This place was dinner on my first night in San Francisco and I imagine i'd be here often if I lived here.  Very tasty grilled chicken vermicelli with lemon grass.  Got an order of spring rolls minus shrimp also, and I couldn't finish them because I was already full, but that peanut dipping sauce made me want to try to finish it all.
author: Jamarcus T.

description:
Overrated. Disappointing. Greasy, over fried, cheap meat, tasteless appetizer, canned flavor pho.

And to nitpick, why have Vietnamese restaurants stopped serving Bun rice noodle bowls IN BOWLS? This place included, they serve Bun rice noodle dishes on a plate and it's clumsy, hard to eat and it's nonsense.
author: P K.

description:
Tin is our go-to pho place. It's not the cheapest pho in town but definitely the best (and they serve beer and wine...plus one!). Their broth is delicious and it seems healthy. They also have good spring rolls and a really good lemongrass chicken with rice dish. Portion sizes are a little smaller though so don't come starving!!

Plus the servers are super nice. They have definitely changed my perspective on the fact that you can't get good pho and good service in the same place. You definitely get that at tin!
author: Margaret L.

description: Lemongrass beef rolled with carrot & onion with Vermicelli was amazing.
author: Topher S.

description:
Had recently come back from Vietnam and wanted to taste that cuisine again. Did not think that Tin was that authentic or pure Vietnamese.

Good atmospehere for small restaurant and nicely unpretentious. Food was OK but must have been very salty - had unquenchable  thirst for hours afterwards.
author: Dave S.

description: a lot of high marks for the this place, but i thought it was just "okay". perhaps i need to give the place another try and order something different. prices are good, but it's just like other places i've been to, so it wasn't anything too special.
author: Mike C.

description:
I love this place! I go there pretty much 3-4 times a week for lunch. The word has gotten out about how great the food is, so now the lunch hour can be pretty busy, but the service is great and they do their best to get you fed and back to work as quickly as possible.

The atmosphere is homey with a touch of "trendy" thrown in. The manager "Shy" is so nice and welcoming!
author: Adam G.

description: The prettiest #1 pho bo I've ever had, but not the best. Service is good, but I found a long hair at the bottom of my bowl of soup when I was done. Felt so nasty after..
author: kim w.

description:
I went here with 3 other people. The food is fine. It's a solid 3-star. Not what I would call, "authentic," but definitely good.

The service, however, drags down the rating. Badly. Note that there are 2 waiters for the entire dining area. 

The one assigned to our table seemed quite stressed, impatient, and generally like this was not his career of choice. One of my co-diners didn't have an answer immediately available when he was asked what he wanted, and the waiter curtly responded with, "I'll just come back." Now, the words themselves aren't a problem, but the facial expression and eye roll that accompanied them, are. Non-verbal communication is so very important, you see. And people really do notice it, even if you think you're being clever and subtle about it. Yes, I'm talking to you, Waiter dude.

Another reviewer described the help as, "bitchy." I don't know that I'd use that word to describe this gentleman, but I can definitely say that "friendly" is not an apt description of him, either.

The other problem with the service was how the food was delivered to the table. It's always a bad sign to have people arrive after you've already ordered, and then see them get their food before you get yours.

And yet that happened. Twice. 

After we ordered our food, one individual and later, a couple, came in. They were already eating their food before ours even arrived. The staff seemed unfazed by this blunder.

Not acceptable. At all.

The food keeps this place from getting a 1-star review. SF has many good places to eat, including more than a few worthwhile Vietnamese places. So there's no reason to put up with the grumpy waitstaff here.

1.8 stars overall. Rounds to 2.

Tell you what: I'll just come back. 

Just kidding.
author: Tim B.

description: Good pho here.  The broth is actually quite tasty, and the noodles are prepared right.  The place is small and can get a bit hot inside.  I think they need better AC, but overall the food is well prepared, and delicious.
author: Steve C.

description:
Had a wonderful lunch here today. The spring rolls were fresh n tasty. I don't know if it's just the nature of the rice paper but it's so chewy n hard to eat. 
The Vietnamese lemongrass pork sandwich is a steal at 4.50. It was really delish and i will def be back to slurp some pho soon!!
author: ella a.

description: Really delicious vietnamese food. I think this place is better than out the door / slanted door but cheaper and less crowded. They have sandwiches, pho, rice dishes, appetizers you would expect (shrimp pork fresh spring rolls, papaya salad, etc.)
author: Kathy L.

description: I love tins - it's probably my favorite restaurant In San Francisco.  Prices are great and the food is consistently awesome.  My favorite so far is the claypot catfish.  It was literally a contributing factor in my decision to move to the city!
author: Adrian K.

description:
I'm salivating thinking about the food and it's only 10am in the morning! I'm always on the hunt for a great hole in the wall place that has character and GREAT CHEAP food (and yes, I had to capitalize those two words). This place has it. I went here on a whim with my husband and a friend of mine that lives in the area. We dodged a couple of bums on the way to find the contemporary sign lit up on Howard street.  When I first walked in the smell of the food is what got me, but this place actually has a classy and easy feel about it. Weirdly it seems like it should be a bar... but I'm totally happy it's not.

It was full on a Thursday night but we were able to get seated right away. The nice thing is it wasn't all Bay Area Yuppies finding the next new thing, it was just normal people that like good Vietnamese food. It did take us a while to get our food, but I think that was because they were getting a ton of take-out orders in addition to eat-in. We got the Chicken Wings as an appetizer with a lime cilantro dipping sauce... which was amazing. And we shared two main dishes (the lemongrass chicken rice plate and the Vermicelli bowl with Grilled Lemongrass beef). Between the 3 of us we killed all three dishes. Although the Vermicelli bowl's beef was not what I was expecting, it was delicious and light. 

My friend definitely commented that whatever they add to their Sriracha is beyond amazing. We think they lighten up the mixture a bit and reuse the Sriracha bottle because the color is a little lighter than normal Sriracha... something to find out for next time. 

In any case, a GREAT place and VERY affordable. Definitely going back here again.
author: Jamie P.

description:
This place is pretty awesome. Real solid vietnamese food all around... at least from what I can gather. I'll be honest, I've only been once but I definitely plan on returning.

First off the staff was extremely nice, which isn't something I typically care about, but it stood out here. I mean, its not like it really affected my meal, but it was nice. Ok ok, I've been losing some weight lately and the waitress commented on how good I look compared to my driver's license photo. I didn't think I was really making progress and I was having a rough week at work so any amount of human kindness really went a long way. Plus she had a great laugh. Why am I talking about this.

The dinner started as an outing to get some pho, and their selection was limited, but it they all looked great and I bet you could substitute items out if you really wanted. I mean, the slight differences in meat types are pretty inconsequential if you think about it. Its really just about the broth.

Three things. (1) Try the vegetarian spring rolls. It's not on the menu but the waitress recommended it to us so we went half regular, half vegetarian and we wish we just got all vegetarian. I told her that, then she smiled and touched my shoulder. The regular summer roll had some pretty dry pork in it and it just didnt hold a candle to the veg. 

(2) The Pho Ga was surprisingly amazing. I know, I know - The two rules of Pho is that you dont get the chicken and you dont talk about getting the chicken. I was a little nervous that the cute waitress would look down on my choice of friends when they ordered it. Usually chicken Pho is an afterthought and a little boring, but this broth was delicious and more complex than the average old chicken Pho. I bet the waitress was cool with the choice.

(3) The Claypot anything is awesome. I got the catfish. It. Was. Slammin. The waitress said it was her favorite dish on the whole menu. When she told me that I'm pretty sure she winked at me, but it was a little hot in the room so a bead of sweat kind of got in my eye area and I couldn't see all that well.

So my synopsis? Really great and definitely worth going back to. Their broth was as good as the places that serve just pho and they have a whole menu of great dishes on top of that. Only complaint is that the room was a little hot, forever calling into question whether I got a wink or not. However, that may or may not be a concern to you.
author: Erich S.

description: I've been three times, and had the Bun, as well as spring rolls and the quail starter. The starters are pretty bland, and the quail is tough. The Bun is nice, the pork excellent, though the noodles a little soft. The service is terrible. They ignore you and then are cross and rude when you ask for help. If you can get to other parts of the city--nearly anyplace on Clement St, or to Lotus Garden in the upper MIssion--you can get WAY better food for a lot less money. Still, this neighborhood has a lot of really awful Vietnamese food, so this place is a bit of an oasis, which gets it 3 stars.
author: Patrick B.

description: It confuses me that this place has such high ratings.  I came here with my family (party of 8 people) and we ordered every appetizer and 8 different entrees.  Nothing had flavor!  Not a single dish!  All the dishes lacked citrus, cilantro, and heat of any kind.  It was the blandest Vietnamese meal I've ever had! I've worked in a restaurant so I know that places can have an off night but every dish?  Really??  I'll never go back.
author: Melissa M.

description: The pho and chicken wings are OKAY. Nothing special, nothing terrible. It's food. It's fuel. It works.
author: Jeanette Y.

description: This place has some very good food and was very reasonably priced.  I had the Beef Pho and it was very flavorful.  My wife had a beef salad and said it was very good.  The place is simple, but clean.  My only gripe is that our waitress was the only server in the whole place and as the place got busier, we saw less and less of her.  Still she didn't ignore us and she was very friendly and took good care of us.  On busy weekend nights they could probably have more than one waitress.  Still that won't keep us from going back and I have to try some of their noodle and rice dishes.
author: Scott L.

description: Just arrived into San Fran. First place we ate and it's awesome. Mango salad has great flavor. Bun Bo Hue was spicy and very yummy. Pho was average but meat was good. Overall a hit for the family. Nice atmosphere. Definitely go again.
author: Z W.

description:
Prices are low for San Fran. Walked down from the Pickwick Hotel.

What a great find thanks to Yelp.  I stayed at the Pickwick hotel and was looking for something within walking distance.  I've never had Vietnamese food before, this was a great introduction.  The walk was very short and the staff was very courteous.  Our food came much quicker then I had anticipated.   I am still blown away by how low the prices were, I think my entree was $10.  Wow.  I'd mark this place as best value in San Fran.
author: Scott M.

description: Delicious Vegan Pho. Super fresh veggies, savory broth.I also had the vegan tofu springrolls, and they were lovely. I am only rating this on the takeout, as I've never eaten in, but I definitely plan to. The ambiance seems great, and the service very friendly.
author: Ashley S.

description: While the food was decent, the dinner service was terrible! We waited 25 minutes for someone to come take our order and fill water glasses, and even that was after we requested a server twice. We had the 5-spice chicken and shrimp claypot. The 5-spice chicken while crispy and cooked well, was lacking in spice and flavor. The shrimp was tasty, but the portion size was really small. No one came by to check on the table until we asked for the check. Overall, I would try it again for takeout, but definitely not for dine in.
author: Eshani M.

description: I was in town for work, and my co-worker found this place the day before.  We went for dinner and the food was great!  Nice clean restaurant, and the service was good.  And you can't beat the price.
author: Serene E.

description: This was a great late dinner! A little more on the upscale vs. always going to Pho mom and pop places, Very happy with the food and service! Will come back real soon to try some more food!  Cheers.
author: Jay Y.

description:
Fantastic, reasonably-priced food. I probably eat here at least three times a week, and love both their Pho and bowls. My personal favorites:

- Chicken pho (the ginger-chicken broth is excellent)
- Cha gio
- Shaken beef
- Lemongrass chicken

The service does tend to be slow sometimes, as they seem somewhat understaffed. The quality of the food more than makes up for it, especially at such good prices -- if you order the cha gio first thing, you'll quickly forget about the wait.
author: Toli P.

description: Good cheap pho place in the city.  Good portions and pretty nice inside.  Good spot if you're going to the Metreon and are hungry after.
author: Matthew P.

description: This was my first time In San Francisco and my first attempt at Vietnamese food.  WOW!!!  I had the vegitarian pho with the side veggie of the day (bok choy).  I had vietnamese a couple days later at a different place and was a little dissappointed.  This place set the standard pretty high for me.  The prices were descent too. If I'm ever in the city again, I'll definately be hitting this place up again!
author: Christi K.

description: I like Tin because it has true vegan pho that actually has flavor. Vegan pho will never compare to the real deal... but this is pretty close. The food is affordable and the other dishes are also good.
author: Moline D.

description: Pho, vermicelli bowls and warm beef salad are delicious. This place is a lot cleaner than the two previous places that occupied the same location. I've only been during the lunch hour and usually only do take out because service can get a little slow. They have two servers running around doing their best to get all the orders in but the staff is freindly
author: German L.

description: Tin? yeah i will go back, yeah i would recommend to any vn food lovers. Their food is very authentic. Although the restaurant is somewhat hidden but their pho soup taste almost like homemade. I had the lemongrass beef roll and one bite just made me think "i'm so glad they have this" because not that many vn places have that lemongrass beef roll. However, i still give this vn place as my second best because they do not certain dishes that i want. Since this is my first time coming to TIN then i would come back again to try other dishes.
author: Justin L.

description: Best bowl of Pho I've ever had. Oh wait, they don't call it pho, the call in noodles with broth. I call delicious.
author: Jon R.

description: Great food, great prices especially for Soma! My friend's shrimp dish - her shrimp was not unshelled. My pho was pretty solid, not too salty broth. Unfortunately our waiter was a bit weird and seemed to be in a rush to get us out of the restaurant, but definitely on my list to come back for quick dinner bites.
author: Shang S.

description:
how come i've never heard of this place before? i just randomly ran into a review a few days ago and felt the need to bookmark it. if you weren't looking for Tin, you probably wouldn't ever find yourself there. it's on Howard St. in an area where there really is no reason random people should be there. but as secluded as it seems, they still had a lot of people dining there and waiting too, even. 

i had the grilled lemongrass beef over vermicelli and it was super flavorful and wrapped around a carrot, which added a nice crunch. i was really happy with that dish. my friend ordered just a side salad and some bok choy and surprisingly the bok choy had flavor and was cooked in a way that didn't make you feel like you were going to choke to death. 

i will definitely be back.
author: Regina C.

description:
Great pho and spring rolls! The pho broth is yummy (and it doesn't seem that they have that much MSG in it). The only thing I wish Tin has was delivery.

Tin is a few steps up from your hole in the wall pho joint, however that also means they don't offer pho with tripe and other traditional cow parts you may find in  less Americanized pho places.

I've only ordered their spring rolls and beef pho (multiple times) so I can't speak to their rice dishes.  The standard beef pho comes with rare thin slices of beef, if you want beef balls you have to request them.  The spring rolls are fresh and better than Tu Lan and Miss Saigon's.  Pho Bo will run you $7.50 and spring rolls $6.  It's an awesome meal for a cold rainy day.

I think I noticed that they had a vegetarian pho as well.

This is by far my favorite pho place in SOMA.
author: Becca L.

description: Good food for lunch. I had the lemongrass chicken rice dish that was super tasty. Paired it with the Vietnamese limeade. I would give it four stars generally, but e waiter was sort of weird...I asked for a recommendation on dishes, and he gave me zero advice. No inkling of his favorites, no suggestions of what is popular...nothing. Haha, it's fine, I made a choice, but some more advice would've been appreciated!
author: Melinda S.

description: I so love their southern style pho especially pho-ga and pho-bo. non broth pho was good too, but a bit huge to me.
author: Motohiro T.

description: Thank you for existing Tin Vietnamese Cuisine! Have been seeking good pho place since moving to SOMA. Have found. (had the pho bo, will be back)
author: Alex M.

description: Brilliant cheap place. Had the 5 spices chicken, really good stuff. Great service too.
author: Rohit M.

description:
Expect a long wait.
Pho was okay - I felt like the chicken was boiled though. 
The broth was delicious.
The spring rolls were delish and the service was excellent.

People were still rolling in after I left.
author: Yo M.

description: I think this place is really great. Their Pho is really good, and their rice plates are great also. Their rice plate portions are a bit small, but absolutely delicious. The service is excellent. The place smells a bit, though. Other than that, I'd continue going there.
author: Jeff S.

description:
This place is fantastic!

The Pho is unbelievably good, served in a generous bowl and the atmosphere is perfect. Not too pretentious and not too divey - just comfortable. 

The takeout comes separated so that the soup doesn't overcook the noodles, sprouts or other treats. That always makes me feel like someone's making an effort.

I'm not sure how people are claiming to spend $17 on lunch, if you look at the menu, nothing is over $8! It might be $17 for two... Or maybe they're referring to the place that used to be in the same location?

http://www.tinsf.com/menu.html

They also support vegan options and that's practically enough by itself.
author: Luke B.

description:
Ate here last night. 

I usually go to the T-Loin for Pho, but I was in the area and had a craving for it.  
I ordered a basic bowl of Pho Bo. It was good! It was hot, but not simmering, and the beef broth was tasty. 

Some places have the option of a large or smaller bowl, but this place did not have that option.

I didn't look at any other items on the menu. Overall, basic, good, and cheap. 

One thing: I did not like the lighting the dim lighting  in the place. But hey, SOMA is always a bit "darker" than the rest!
author: Leonel R.

description:
3 stars for first visit - chicken pho with a ginger undertone. a-ok.

1 stars for second visit - beef vermicelli noodles that had to be sent back because they came with ground peanuts. whatever, honest mistake, I would think (on both our ends). but it didn't end there. I got 'tude from the server about "are you allergic?" - I have a dietary restriction that forbids me to have nuts and seeds, I explain. "but are you allergic?" I had to be firm and just say "I cannot eat those nuts." that wasn't enough. my companion finally said "yes, she's allergic!" 

I know we don't need to get into the deets, but c'mon, you serve food, it's gotta go through your digestion. it's not just allergy that can prohibit that, and as a server you should know that (and for those of you that don't know, there are some of us who cannot have seeds or nuts because of intestinal surgery scars)! 

then, to make me feel worse: "well vietnamese food comes with ground nuts" - um, yes, I know that it often does. but usually it is listed, as I know to look closely. but my companion's meal did not have ground nuts on it, and for the various restaurants I've had this same exact dish at, no ground nuts came on it. 

adding insult to injury, it wasn't tasty. maybe it's the experience with a snotty server that put a bad taste in my mouth, but c'mon. I don't like you having to re-make my meal anymore than you do! and that beef was not good.

I wish I had just stuck with what I knew and gotten the chicken pho.

(oh, and the server did come back to apologize for her attitude - while I was in the bathroom! she apologized to my companion who had his meal. huh?!!!)
author: Sarah X.

description: Great casual Vietnamese restaurant.  I've tried the Chicken Pho here twice and it doesn't disappoint.  The food here is nothing amazing/out-of-this-world good, but definitely worth a try.  The spring rolls here are decent as well. Their menu is not too big, but there is a good selection of soup, noodle and rice dishes.  They also serve beer and wine.  I wouldn't say you need reservations.  Each time I've come there has been an open spot.
author: Tanichka B.

description:
tip: order the eggplant as soon as you sit down. takes 20+ min for them to prep and totally worth it! 

the Bun Bo Hue pho (Rare beef, beef shank, pork bologna, vermicelli, and spicy lemongrass broth) was delicious but really spicy - even after i asked them to make it non-spicy.

minus one star for the service.
author: Sus T.

description: Nondescript location, yet close enough to the huge Intercontinental San Francisco one block over that it feels safe. Super-fast and friendly service. Great portions of meat in the pho for the price. Full-flavored broth, and the rice noodles are wonderfully fresh. I highly recommend the beef pho!
author: Kat C.

description: I love this place for good Vietnamese food in SOMA.
author: John L.

description: Great food, great prices.  Service is hit or miss though.  If you are nice, and they aren't that crowded then you'll be ok.  But if you are there for the lunch rush, it might be a little bit of a wait.  The cold noodle bowls are amazing
author: Ryan H.

description:
From the ambiance to the service to the food, this place is Tin-tastic!  

Everything I tried from the appetizer imperial rolls to the pork bun to the banh mi i ordered to go fulfilled my palate's expectations of Vietnamese cuisine.  2 hours later into my lunch I remembered that there was work and shopping to do!  

Overall, on my next SF trip back I'm bound to wind up at this cute and hip Tin house!
author: Frangelo A.

description:
I love Tin.  I spend a lot of time around the 6th and Howard area, and it's easily the best vegan food I've found there.  The veggie bún is completely delicious.  Prices are reasonable, and portion sizes seem correct (ie. I usually have some leftovers, but I eat a bit less than the average).

Their tea selection is small but tasty, and comes in a lovely pot/cup dingus.  The staff are friendly, the music is good, and the decor is simple and pleasant.

I could eat their food every day.
author: Ian B.

description:
Went there with hubs for lunch looking for a great pho experience.  It was really good standard pho.  Hubs was a little disappointed when he asked for tendon and tripe and they didnt offer it.  Soup was good, broth was tasty.  I would visit again, but I think I would look for something a little more amazing.  

Minus 1 star for not having tendon and tripe.  Minus another star for failing to wow me.
author: Becky Z.

description: Tin is my go-to local pho place. The Bo Kho is a rich think brothed beef soup with star anise beef broth. Really killer. The Pho Bo is tasty too. Need to try all of their dishes! They are look great.
author: Paul O.

description: I think they've gone a bit downhill.  The food isn't as good as I recalled.  The service is abrupt and rushed for a place that is going for a different vibe than your typical Vietnamese pho place.  It is also loud.  I couldn't hear what my friend was saying and got tired of yelling and leaning forward.  Not a relaxed dining experience.
author: Eric C.

description: Great Viet food in a strange neighborhood with tons of vibe, and ... :)
author: Amy L.

description: After a take-out order here, I'll bump Tin up a star for the tasty food. Avoiding the slow service seems to be the way to go.
author: Eric H.

description:
We had beef pho. Pho Bo. It was awesome. On top of that we had 5 piece chicken with rice which was good. 
I will definitely come back here.
author: Ismail S.

description: The vegetarian pho is amazing here! One of the best I have ever had. It includes a lot of veggies and the broth is very tasty.
author: Vivian A.

description: It is my job to try every bahn mi in SF. This calling led me here. Unfortunately I did not fulfill my mission. After waiting 25 mins for a sandwich which never arrived, I left. You see, my job eating bahn mi does not pay the bills, and I had to get back to my day job. Extra star because I enjoyed the smell of other people's food while waiting.
author: Y R.

description:
Above average, but I'm not sure if I'll return

Pho ba with added tripe is good
The pickeled onions are amazing
author: Christopher L.

description: We came here one chilly night and enjoyed delicious soups and a bottle of Riesling.  The waiter was helpful and attentive while we ordered and then didn't butt in while we ate, it was a lovely meal.
author: Marianna K.

description:
Awesome newly opened month-old family owned and operated Vietnamese restaurant in the South of Market area. The chef assisted by her younger son, creates remarkable traditional dishes reminiscent of what I had tasted in Vietnam. What sets her apart from others are her amazing pineapple-anchovy, creamy basil, sesame-peanut sauces. The older son takes cares of the customers in this humble small place...simple yet tastfully appointed. Her husband and daughter helps out in the kitchen. Truly another gem in our beloved City! Some favorites:

1. Cha Ca Thang Long. Turmeric sole, dill, pineapple-anchovy sauce, vermicelli noodles. Evokes memories of the fish at Cha Ca La Vong in Hanoi. Definitely my favorite dish here. Amazing taste.
2.Papaya Salad. Green papaya, poached shrimp, and calamari. A winner. I am not a fan of papaya salad...but this one won my heart. So savory.
3. Banh Xeo. A rice flour and mung bean crepe stuffed with shrimp, calamari, pork, and bean sprouts. Comes with a signature creamy basil sauce that is to die for. Hella good.
4. Cha Gio. Deep fried spring rolls with pork, jicama, taro, wood ear mushrooms, and glass noodle. Comes with fresh mint and a perfectly balanced tasty fish dipping sauce.
5. Pho Bo. Rare beef and brisket with rice noodles in a delicious beef broth. Hits the spot. The broth is soul!
6. Caramelized Clay Pot Sole. Stunningly savory dish. Contrasting tastes. Perfectly prepared. This mouth-watering dish is spectacular. Order this!
7. Banh Hoi Nem Nuong. Grilled pork meatballs with pineapple-anchovy dipping sauce. Savory.
8. Goi Ga. Salad of chicken, cabbage, rau ram, peanuts, and shallots. YES!
author: aL Z.

description:
Tin has become one of our go-tos for delicious and fresh Vietnamese. We are die hard Turtle Tower customers but Tin is a great alternative if you want something else besides pho. 

The crepe app, fresh rolls, papaya salad and fried rolls are always a hit and you can taste the freshness and quality of ingredients. 

For rice dishes, the claypot catfish blows it out of the water. It has a clean and not-too-salty taste, so great with their Jasmine rice. Grilled pork is also great but nothing exciting. 

Wonton soup is awesome and the pho is ok but not as authentic as I like it. Great thing is they don't use MSG, which is hard to come by if you go to the pho places in Little Saigon, including Turtle Tower. They are skimpy on the bean sprouts and basil but I suppose you can always ask for more.

Yes, the waiters are Caucasian but the chef is straight from the homeland and just needed waitstaff that could connect with the customers better. She is a sweet woman who is always smiling. The waiters do know their stuff tho, so don't underestimate them by their appearance.

Limeade is a must, sweet and tart. Just perfect.
author: Saku T.

description:
Tin inhabits the space that was once Pho Ha Tien II.  The former establishment had great noodle soups, delicious entrees and wonderful appetizers.  Too bad it's gone.

The new Tin has a much more limited menu (i.e. fewer choices.)  We started with the fresh shrimp rolls.  We should have stopped at this point because if we had, my review would be very positive.  Unfortunately, we kept on eating.  The won ton noodle soup I ordered was composed of a bland broth and small, flavorless won tons.  My boyfriend ordered the tamarind shrimp.  The flavor was good but the portions were too dainty. 

Bring back Pho Ha Tien II.  :(
author: Eddie L.

description:
Decent enough Vietnamese food, although their pho was mediocre.  The dining area was clean and uncluttered, and the service was friendly.

There was plenty of room during the lunch break, which might concern some people, but I think it's because of the location.

PROS:
- Small menu, not a multi-page ordeal with confusing numbers
- Food (other than the pho) was well-received

CONS:
- Service wasn't all that prompt, and our appetizer came out about a minute before the entree, so timing was a little off.
author: Drew P.

description: A great little find, just off the beaten track.  What this place lacks in size it more than makes up for in amazing full flavoured food at very reasonable prices.  Most main dishes are $9-$14. It was full when we got there at 7.30 and by 8 there were people waiting outside to get in.  Service was ok, but you don't go here for the service, you go for the tastes! Can't go wrong here!
author: Stefan R.

description: I've had better pho at Burger King if that tells you anything about this place. The service was very meh. I'd say if you want legit Vietnamese, go to PPQ.
author: Michael S.

description: I am a big fan of Tin. This place is a great combination of all the things I Love about eating Vietnamese food. The price point is low, the food comes out quick and is delicious, and the service is good. Nice ambience in the place, better than with most casual Vietnamese restaurants. Their pho broth is delicious. Their ingredients are very fresh. The vermicelli bowls are also really good. Their bbq meat's have great flavor, even the sauteed lemon grass meats are delicious. We've been a few times and will continue to go to get our pho fix :)
author: Tamira J.

description: Sweet little Vietnamese place! The Five spice chicken is seriously the best jerk chicken I've had, and remember to top it with a fried egg (that's the asian way baby). It also has the unusual "veggie of the day", in this case, in the form of baby bok choy stir fried with garlic and a slightly salty broth sauce. I like my side veggies to make myself feel healthy without resorting to ordering veggie entrees. The pho and noodle soups also look quite decent. The price is unreasonably cheap, $7-$10 a dish!
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Great pho, broth was natural and noodle was fresh. Service was prompt
author: Henry L.

description: This is a nice little alternative to Miss Saigon in the same area (but without the crackhead scenery in the background). Quick, well priced, and a good ambiance.
author: Adam D.

description: I was so surprised to see the crowd at this place. I thought for sure it would be full of tourists but nope.. looked like a lot of hipsters LOL. Nothing wrong with that, just surprising. What else was surprising? Well.. how good the food was! I had the lemongrass pork shoulder rice plate.. Ok prob the best lemongrass pork EVER! Really good quality meat also, not much fat. Both of my friends ordered the vermicilli noodle bowls with with lemongrass pork and cha gio (spring rolls). Both raved about the dish. So yay another place we can frequent! Just note it can be packed.. I had no idea how popular this place is at dinner on a Tuesday night.
author: Vol T.

description:
Thurs night about 6. Got a table right away and were greeted by a charming young woman who suggested the limeade (crisp, light,sweet) and we, on advice of other Yelpers, put in our order for the eggplant (takes 20 min). We the proceeded to the enormous spring rolls, ordered shaking beef, five spice chicken and bun rieu. We liked the spring rolls so much we ordered another plate. 

The shaking beef was as good as I have at Slanted Door (do dip in S&P sauce, the 5 spice lovely, the eggplant was amazing. The bun riue had a riot of flavors. We ate till we were stuffed because it all tasted so good.
