Loved our waitress, who knew the menu, made good suggestions, and seemed to really like her work (so rare these days) and was highly competent (also rare). The guy clearing tables was a little too eager to clear but that was ok. maybe he could use his height to dust off the tops of the clear glass light fixtures!?

A great find, perfect for a feat for 4 at $70 w/o tip. Just go. .
author: Pat R.

description:
I spied this restaurant as a lone light in an otherwise dark corridor of Howard, and first noticed its clean, simple interior and inviting prices!

What a gem to be found outside of the Tenderloin, especially in SoMa, which is otherwise filled with over-priced boutique restaurants.  Apparently, as other reviewers have noted, other restaurants have tried their hand in this space, but I think that Tin's advantage is its fresh-start approach in menu and atmosphere.

I appreciate the menu (currently a uni-menu serving both lunch and dinner; a more robust dinner menu is forthcoming, no doubt), as it reads as a best-of Vietnamese cuisine.  Make that best-of-the-best as the recipes are of family origin and executed with good kitchen technique!  Before I dig into my experience, I will note that most items are available as vegetarian, which is worth its weight in a star!

I had the vegetarian noodle-lemongrass roll dish.  The noodles and vegetables were fresh, and its lemongrass tofu incredibly tastey yet delicate.  Nothing heavy or greasy about it.  Additionally, I noted (and had this confirmed by the host/server/GM) that the vegetarian dishes are intentionally distinct in flavor and textures from their carnivorous cousins.  So, for complaints that the menu seems limited, I argue that it's merely efficient as carnivores have twice as many unique dishes from which to choose.

Lastly, a note on the teas... I had an herbal, which was full of flavor and incredibly fresh.  I loved the presentation (loose leaf in a small tea pot that sit & fits into the teacup).

With a couple of months in, I hope more people take note of it and word gets around.  I expect a liquor license coming in the next few months to fulfill the intention of the owner as a casual place to enjoy a well-prepared meal with a decent wine or beer.  I look forward to the space maturing over the next few months and can't wait to enjoy the other items on its menu!
author: Nathan M.

description:
I've been eating Vietnamese food my whole life and I rarely find a place that is as delicious as mom's home cooking and as comfortable as my real home.  Tin truly is a gem in San Francisco,  I live in Oakland, but will cross the bridge for Tin anytime! If you're a vegetarian, the options are amazing!  The tofu full of flavor in both the bun and banh mi.   The banh xeo and ca kno are the best in the bay!

I've hosted multiple large events at Tin and the staff has always been very accommodating.   One of our events included a VIP delegation from Hanoi. The delegation, including the former UN Ambassador, raved about the food and service.  

Thank you, Tin!
author: Phuong Q.

description: The rolls and eggplant were excellent. Their interpretation of "Vietnamese-style coffee" is a little off though, but that's nitpicky.
author: Anthony W.

description: This place was cute, yet modern looking. It's one of the cleanest Vietnamese restaurants I've to. The food was pretty good and the service was excellent. If I lived in SF, I'd come here whenever I would be craving soup/pho I'd definitely come here. Price isn't shabby. It's a must to go here if you're a pho lover! Jussssayin'.
author: Ivadine M.

description: Food is really good. Sometimes theres a wait. But everything comes out fast. Yum Yum.
author: Aurora D.

description: Usually I really like Tin but the service is abject. There were three open tables with 4 seats, and they refused to seat us. It was 8.15pm. No reservations, no line. They just refused to seat us until a 2 person seat opened up. I would give 0 stars for this level of irrationality if I could.
author: Jireh T.

description: As an authentic VN I always have high expectation going to a VN restaurant. I liked Tin. Vermicelli noodles and papaya salad is very good. However pho is just ok. Liked the decor and staff are nice but it's a super busy place and felt a little rushed.
author: Toni T.

description: I had the chicken noodle soup today. It is actually pretty good. The price is little bit more than "usual", I guess it is because it is a little bit more fancier than usual Vietnamese restaurant.
author: Lydia L.

description:
i think i have been here at least 5 times by now and tried almost half of everything on their menu. their best dish is the claypot catfish, banh xeo, warm beef salad, shaken beef, and pho. i have to say- they have yet to let me down. you can't go wrong with anything you order. you just can't. i actually wish that i live/work closer to this place!

why?

i fricking love this place. hands down, it is one of the best vietnamese restaurants in san francisco. the food basically melts in your mouth and the price is incredibly reasonable too! it's great food that's inexpensive. if i have to summarize this place in one sentence, i would say "it's pure bloody amazingness." 

the only thing is that the area is... interesting... if you can brave walking past 5th street in soma, you have to try this restaurant. you can thank me later.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description: The 5 spicy chicken was so good along with great jasmine rice. Make sure you enjoy a tea when you are done with your meal.
author: Jtp F.

description:
Is authentic? Meh... 
Modern. No "Saigon streets" feel. 
Good food, bitchy help.
author: Ryan C.

description: Great spring rolls, beef, soups. Good wine and service as well. So why not a 4 or 5 star? My new thing is looking at food safety scores, and I think Tin has just about the lowest score I've ever seen: 56?!? I think that's about as bad as it gets. I think you have to try to have a score that low. Why can't we just have good food prepared by folks who prepare it the way they would for their families?
author: Ichor B.

description: This place is really tasty. Much recommended over anything in the Metreon. Perfect if you are near Moscone or Folsom. I recommend the VERY tasty spring rolls - fresh or fried, I've tried both. I have also ordered and enjoyed the lemongrass chicken as well as ginger chicken. I still have to come back for the Pho. They have Vietnamese beer. The service is kind of slow, but friendly! It gets packed.
author: Aaron W.

description: The food here is so AMAZING, plus they are uber cheep! When we don't want to cook this is our go-to place. Even when they are really busy, we have never waited more than 10 min for a table.
author: Kristy L.

description: May be difficult to fine though right on the street. Small restaurant near Mosconi center. Very affortable and great vegetarian pho.
author: Yvonne W.

description:
Amazing.  I think I've found my go-to lunch spot.

I'd heard from several coworkers that this place was great, but had been satisfied enough with nearby Miss Saigon to feel motivated to try it.  I finally did - and am kicking myself for not going sooner!

Whenever I go to a Vietnamese place, I can't help but get the vermicelli with pork and rolls.  And Tin did not disappoint.   Their lemongrass pork was delicious, and they definitely don't skimp on the ingredients.  My meal was filling and tasty, all for $7.  

My coworker got the banh mi, and I totally had cross-table food envy.  The sandwich was stacked - lots of meat, veggies, and he was pleasantly surprised to find fish sauce as well.  I know what I'll be getting next time.  That and the fresh summer rolls, which looked insanely huge and delicious!  And yes, there will definitely be a next time!

-Edit-

i have since also had the banh mi and can verify that it is quite delicious.  What really surprised me, though, was the side soup ($7 all together w the sandwich).  I was expecting a broth with maybe a few simple elements floating around, like some scallions, but was extremely pleased to find that it's actually chock full of spinach and what seemed to be ground pork.  It's a great complement to the sandwich for not too much extra $$.
author: Allison B.

description: Fan of all the claypot dishes and the lemon/pepper sauce that comes with the shaking beef dish. Cute little spot with good service.
author: S P.

description:
Only got take out from here.  The neighborhood is dumpy, but this restaurant is a diamond in the rough.  The food was high quality, with that wonderful collision of fresh flavors that is typical of Vietnamese food.  The staff was really nice too, and everything was reasonably priced.

This could be my new go-to Vietnamese place...
author: Jon S.

description:
This is a place where you will rarely just "happen by".  This restaurant is on a block of Howard where there is just about nothing nearby.  The restaurant sign is also dark and nearly imperceptible, but when it comes to food nothing escapes my eagle eyes.

This place is on another level for Vietnamese food.  Their vegetarian roll and catfish in clay pot were best in class.  Their Pho is also delicate and using only the best ingredient.  You don't get the mini-bathtub size pho, but the portion was plenty and it's about quality at the end of the day.

There is still some hiccups in the operations but the waiter had a great attitude and was attentive to our needs.  When the roll order was mixed up, he quickly made it right and gave us a whole discount on an order.

This is a place to come back to.
author: Laurence H.

description:
We just followed the Yelp app and lo and behold, Tin Vietnamese Cuisine showed up. 

Coming In: 
It's SHADY looking outside; the stores next to them have closed. After hours may be dubious. However once you're inside, it has a very contemporary vibe. I daresay they pulled an IKEA on this store. 

Food: 
The portions were what was expected, and we needed a light lunch, so it was perfect. The beef with onions rice dish was well seasoned, and the salad had an excellent complementary taste with the meat. 

Takeaways: 
- It's cheap and I was SURPRISED at the quality of food (I was preparing for the worst because we were just walk-in's). This visit MAY HAVE BEEN A FLUKE, but initial impressions were positive! 
- The waiter was very attentive (converse sneakers, slick vest and all), but it was rather slow. Regardless, kudos for the initiative. 
- When you order the Viet condensed coffee/iced tea, they serve it in awesome containers. We want to buy them now, haha.
author: Abel L.

description: Not the easiest place to find but very authentic and affordable Vietnamese food. The staff are also very friendly and willing to explain their dishes to you. Great Pho and spring rolls. Will definitely recommend if you're looking for a spot to eat near the AMC  at Metreon
author: Jonathan W.

description: Came here on early a Wednesday night and there were four people total in the place. We had a friend coming and were a party of three total. We were not allowed to sit until the last person showed up- in a nearly completely empty place. I understand that policy being in place when it's busy but that was ridiculous. Shame because I love this place a recommend it to lots of friends, but management needs to get this message. Love love this place so only going to go down to three but seriously... Saw two groups walk out after me when they did the same thing to them.
author: Alice A.

description: The service is consistently a bit slow and the place is pretty loud, but the super-friendly servers and awesome food more than makes up for it. The pho is arguably the best in the city, which is pretty hard to believe considering where they're located. I would definitely recommend it.
author: Tim C.

description: I am a fan of this Vietnamese restaurant. I love "bun thit nuong cha gio" and Pho. Amazing good, very similar to original Vietnam taste. Highly recommend  !
author: Suabot J.

description: sanitation is 60/100 people, with high prices too, i'm vietnamese, but no thanks once i learned their health scores history; risky stomach gourmet for dummies!  goods lucks.  can't believe 4 stars averaging??? With 56/100 health score in 2013 inspection, this restaurant should've been shut down, period. Because it's the lowest score I'very seen as far for an overpriced Vietnamese SF restaurant, SHAME for SF HEALTH DEPT.
author: Jake H.

description:
the first time we went here, the food took way too long but at least the food was decent. the portion can vary depending on what you get. the price is decent for the area considering there isnt too many choices for good vietnamese food in the immediate walking area. 

the second time we came the food arrived faster. the 5 spice chicken with rice was pretty decent. overall, its not a bad place if you happen to be in the area. also dont expect it to be authentic vietnamese food either as its more of an americanized place.
author: Alex H.

description:
Yum yum yum! Though the menu is limited, this is a GREAT place to grab lunch or a casual dinner. Family run, the service is always friendly and appreciative. The decor is minimal, but clean and modern. Overall a huge improvement over the old restaurant that occupied the space.

The lemongrass tofu is delicious, and they recently increased their portions, which was greatly appreciated. 

The lemongrass beef is also delicious, and they obviously take great care in preparing it - each strip of beef is individually wrapped, garnished and cooked - yum. 

The caramelized catfish is also a fantastic dish, and a favorite at our office. 

Keep up the great work Tin!
author: meredith t.

description: This place is small and located a little off the beaten path(about 1/4 from Metreon) but not really near other restaurants.  The device was good.  The atmosphere was simple modern, in a good way.  We started with the spring rolls and they were very good.  It came with 2 large spring rolls cut I to 3 pieces and peanut sauce on the side.  I had the shaken beef.  The beef was very tender and had salad greens on the side.  The salad had a simple dressing, but left me wanting more salad after I finished.  My wife had the lemon grass beef over vermicelli.  She said it was excellent.  Also had a Vietnamese coffee, and it was strong for my wife's tastes but standard for that style of coffee.
author: Tony K.

description: $71 for a party of 4?  cray.  service is extremely shitty.  food was ok.  Portions are too small for my growing boys.  This place was packed but it had to be because of the lack of good Vietnamese in SF.
author: Lady K.

description: I didn't know about Bun Cha before coming here. I'm definitely going to be coming back for it. Their imperial rolls were also pretty good. The only downside was they didn't serve enough lettuce with the imperial rolls and the service was a pretty slow even though they weren't very busy.
author: Jeff L.

description: Small restaurant with a typically long line but the food is amazing!  Had the catfish claypot and it was tender and flavorful.  Pho's were distinctive and well portioned.  highly recommend
author: C W.

description:
Papaya salad: 5/5
Chili chicken lemongrass vermicelli : 5/5
Service: 5/5!
Hard to find parking though
author: Cindy L.

description:
My new favorite Vietnamese in the city! 

The WonTon noodles are life affirming. I looked down to my spoon and whispered "I love you" - not kidding. The carmelized catfish is also a highlight. 

Looking forward to them running desserts, even ice creams and sorbets would work.

The coconut water they have somehow tastes better than any other I've had.

Good for groups, as they are currently rarely crowded. I expect this to change as word spreads. Parking(metered) is decent too, since they are a bit off the beaten path. Also very affordable considering the quality of the food.
author: emily m.

description: Surprisingly decent Pho for such a trendy place, but not a good place to do if you need to be seated fast. There's usually a wait.
author: Labs P.

description: 5 stars for quality, price and service. Had the spring rolls , vegi pho and brothless chicken pho. Food was excellent!
author: Alex G.

description: Really a fan for vietnamese food this month! So I found this place close to the shopping mall, and decided to give it a try. The papaya salad is really good( can't believe this was my first time to try papaya salad). It's not so papaya at all, which I always fear some fruity flavor in the food( yes, not a fan of thai at all). We also ordered pho, which is really cheap and good as well. As for the chicken sandwich, all I can say is it is definitely not the best banh mi I ever had. But after all, only banh mi is a little disappointing, the  rest is really good. And the people work there is really nice and sweet. Will give it another try if in the neighborhood, perfect for a quick lunch.
author: Ning L.

description:
Tín (not Tin) has a limited menu, but what its kitchen does, it does well, including Banh Xeo (often called "Vietnamese crêpe") with seafood and sprouts, pork, and a mung-bean wrapper.

I love the grilled lemograss pork on vermicelli (without soup stock). Pho lovers can have other meats.

The service is very friendly and efficient and willing to help if you want to learn the names of the dishes in Vietnamese.

Vietnamese coffee and a variety of teas and Thai iced tea (called only "iced tea") are available.

Close to Moscone Center and to Market, the main drawback for me is parking... and not being open Saturday or Sunday. Highly recommended!
author: Steve M.

description: I ordered pho bo( beef ) and thought it was okay. I've had better pho... But great service tho :-)
author: Ronni K.

description: Amazing pho! Wasn't digging the spring rolls, but the portions were good. Got here at 11:30 and was able to snatch a table before the lunch rush.
author: Hector R.

description: A trendy version of the Vietnamese standard "hole-in-the-wall". I enjoy the music and the low key ambiance along with the food. 3-stars for the food and 1 for the making me feel hip!
author: Tom A.

description:
I appreciate the polite service, cleanliness, and more stylish decor that you don't usually get at Vietnamese places. However, I wish that this could be balanced with delicious pho but it never seems to be. And $17 for lunch? yikes! And I didn't even have a beverage, though I did take home leftover spring rolls. 

Pho Bo -  not great! 
The meat was wonderful, the rest a mess. The steak was sliced magnificently thin, and served in a nice rare blob on top so I could control just how cooked it got by dunking it in the broth. However, the broth was not as hot as I would expect and the meat barely lost it's pink. The brisket was lean and tender - in fact too tender to get a whole piece of it into my mouth with chopsticks! 

The broth was fairly bland, and had a cloudy pinkness to it that kinda freaked me out. Without the usual stash of condiments on the table, I couldn't even salt up the broth to try to improve it. The noodles were woefully overcooked and simply broke into bits when I tried to pick them up. I was served about half the amount of bean sprouts I would like but because the broth was not hot enough, they did not soften up the way I expect them to. 

And the small bowl, which gives the impression you are not getting your money's worth, is actually too full to stir everything together without making a huge mess. Even by the time I was done there was still a lump of noodles in the middle of the bowl that I couldn't break up. I normally like to slurp down a lot of the broth but there was so little of it and so little room I couldn't have if I had wanted to - which I didn't because it wasn't tasty and the look of it made me a little worried.

Spring rolls - tasty and slightly larger serving than usual. I expect one shrimp per half a spring roll and these had 3, so when cut in thirds, there was a whole shrimp in each section. I had to ask for sriracha to augment the peanut sauce.  

I might have gone back to try some other dish but I'm moving out of the neighborhood. Until then, I'll stick with Miss Siagon for slightly less mediocre pho and Tu Lan (lack of cleanliness and all) for bun thit nuong.
author: Laura B.

description: Awesome! Really tasty, cheap and fast. Great lunch venue!
author: Jonny P.

description: awesome Vietnamese food for a relatively cheap price. Became very popular lately (for a reason), so at rush hour expect a wait.
author: Daniel V.

description: Love this place!  Best chicken Vietnamese sandwich!  The favors were spot on.  Came here for the first time last week.  We were in a hurry so just ordered sandwiches to go. It was so good so we came back next day for lunch.  I had vegetarian pho and ask them to put egg noodles in there instead since I am not a fan of rice noodles. The broth was full of flavor and was not heavy.  Our friends got hu teu and pho ga. Both are exceptional as well.  My favorite was the vegetarian spring rolls. You would think it would be boring and bland but they were warm with tofu and mushrooms.  This place is definitely on my lunch list to go.
author: BXN B.

description:
I love Tin! Delicious, fresh and authentic Vietnamese food! I am not a vegetarian but their Vegetarian spring rolls are delicious, better than the non vegetarian options. They are packed during lunch hour and the place is small. These are the dishes I have tried and loved:

1. Vegetarian Spring rolls 
2. Clay pot Catfish
3. Clay pot Shrimp
author: Lisa M.

description: Came for lunch during a convention nearby; braised pork was awesome and the wait for a table only 20 min or so-
author: Jesse U.

description:
I wish I could give Tin a better rating, but the service was so horrible that it overshadowed the fact that the food was pretty good.  

I don't mind waiting when a restaurant is busy, and given that it was the middle of many people's lunch hour I expected Tin to be busy.  But for the 10-15 minutes my friend and I waited for a table not one of the three waiters even acknowledged our presence.  During that time, a few other people came and left -- I guess not wanting to wait, particularly given that no one who worked there was even showing an interesting in the growing queue.

Finally two tables opened up at the same time, and then a couple of other tables opened up within the next few minutes.  They were able to seat everyone who had been waiting.  Unfortunately we had to wave someone down to even place an order, despite the fact that we had been waiting the longest and some of the waiters were already taking orders from customers who came in after us.  When we ordered, my vegetarian friend tried to ask a question about whether a particular side dish was also vegetarian and the waiter answered "yes" and walked away before the question was even formulated enough for him to know what was being asked.  Fortunately, the roll did end up being vegetarian.

Food was good -- not great -- but again the service was lacking when trying to get a check so we could leave.  Many people who had arrived after us had already paid and left and we were still waiting for a check.  I actually timed it and we waited more than 10 minutes for our check after we requested it -- and I could tell the waiter had obviously forgotten about us because when he saw me raise my hand an embarrassed smile came across his face and he went to retrieve our check.

Given that two of the three waiters served us at different times, I assume that all three waiters share responsibility for waiting on every table.  I have to say that my experience at Tin was the worst I've had in any restaurant in many, many years.  Even though I thought the food tasted good, I'd never go back because the service was so poor.  I know that waiting tables is hard work, but all three of the guys there seemed to be operating in slow motion.  The two who served us both lacked reasonable service skills.  

I don't know whether this place has a manager, but they really need to focus on what's going on in the front of the house.
author: Jeff S.

description: Lunch time at Tin was great there on a Tuesday in late Sept ..... Great food and fast service.... will return and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys Vietnamese Food.....  great pricing as well, value for your money!
author: Gary H.

description: I can get as good a pho at FreshRoll, with less of an attitude from the servers, the crowds, and the price here has actually gone up! But the portions have not.
author: L V.

description:
This place has some good pho.  Comes out of the kitchen pipping hot, which I love.  There are few things more discomforting than getting lukewarm pho!  The soup had two elements of which, I am not a raging fan.  The use of white pepper, and what tasted like celery.  They, in my opinion, are non-authentic touches that don't necessary detract from the taste, but don't make it all the more special either... 

The service at this place is great!  A bit on the pricey end.  The bowl is very small, and the extra side veggies are sparse (compared to places where they just pile things on).  As a college student, I would say this place is not the economically wise choice to go to (for that I would recommend Tulan, not too far away).  

My recommendations: eat slow, enjoy your time there.  That small bowl for about $8 will certainly fill you up without making you bloated.  I had the beef pho - the meat in that is cooked quite well!
author: Andrew P.

description: Extremely disorganized. We asked for a server for at least five times and didnt get to order food until we have been sitted for 20minutes. Dont come here unless you have a life to spare.
author: QS C.

description:
Came across this place on my way to get my favorite beef stew noodle at my favorite vietnamese hole in the wall, only to find that its been replaced by this modern vietnamese joint with SMALL bowls.  I couldnt get my head around it...a vietnamese place that charges $8 for a cup of pho?

To my surprise the broth was excellent.  Spring rolls were decent.  Decor a little too sterile and portions too small.  I would, however, go back.
author: dion c.

description: My boyfriend and I were in San Fran and really craving Pho so we yelped and found this place.  It's like finding gold in a little hole in the wall! The atmosphere is very modern and the staff was really friendly.  Our waitress was awesome, they were closing soon, but she gave us great customer service and didn't try to shoo us off like most people would at the end of the day.  Not to mention the vegetable pho was definitely one of the best I've ever had!
author: Alexa M.

description: Tin hosted a group of 12 of us last night and it was splendid.  The service was attentive and warm and the food was super good.  The crepe with shrimp and pork was crispy golden deliciousness and the Chicken Cabbage Salad was vibrant.  The Catfish Clay Pot was rich and luscious and the Grilled Pork was crisp and flavorful.  The wine list is small but very well put together.  We particularly enjoyed the Joel Gott Sav Blanc.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Elena E.

description: There we were perched upon on the Pho-scal cliff, hoping for a compromise. The Server (Ryan?)  balked at my suggestion as if I were I being a Boehner to suggest increasing the Medicaid age from 65 to 67 when I suggested we switch out the chicken for the Lemongrass Pork in the Pho Ga. Yes, take the Ga out of the Ga. I had had their lemongrass pork in my first visit and I needed it. It was a need, again. Yes, not the traditional idea to put grilled meat in the Pho, but you know... sometimes you look at the traditional austerity measures and you take risks to benefit the every day man (me). Thus, a compromise reached: a side of lemongrass pork for me to do with whatever I choose. And so it happened and, yes, the Server was right in that the grill char flaked off into the soup broth -- but it added a stellar dimension to the bowl. The Ga remained but was overpowered by the pork. And, if I were ever to have a sit down with someone to strike a deal with them, I'd bring them to Tin to share the Banh Xeo. Sharing that Banh Xeo would always seal-the-deal.
author: Jon A.

description: This is a small restaurant but a place where you can find very authentic food clean and all there food is so good... Every one should come and try this restaurant don't go based and how it looks but how the food taste like ....they have the best pho ever and only gets better...  I could have there food every day
author: Karina L.

description:
One of the regular places I dine at in San Francisco and my #1 Vietnamese restaurant in SF.  With all things considered, I think it is even better than my fave Vietnamese restaurants in LA.

Here's why I love this place:

- Ambiance: clean, nice minimalist decor, quiet and tranquil, minimal smell as is usually the case in other Vietnamese restaurants

- Food: fresh ingredients, authentic flavor for most dishes, great taste, healthier and less greasy than other Vietnamese restaurants, clean appearance and visually appealing arrangement of food, strikes the right balance between being authentic and appealing to Americans without selling out on true flavors, been here probably 8+ times for dinner and it is consistently good

Value: if you are used to the prices at those cheap Vietnamese joints around the Bay Area and possibly Tenderloin (I don't dare venture there to eat so I don't know how the prices are there), you might think this place is somewhat more expensive, but I think the quality makes up for that and actually their prices are very decent for SF city

- Service: never have to wait for a table, friendly and unpretentious, doesn't feel cold and impersonal, can kindly accommodate large groups (should make arrangements for large groups in advance so they can make sure they have enough staff on hand)

- Access: not too difficult to find street parking and if you come after a certain time, parking is free

Only one thing I'd want for them to improve is their hours of operation such as being open on weekends- I've gone many weekends with unfulfilled Tin cravings!

A note to potential diners: once I have convinced you to dine here, please read below for bonus content ;-)

- What to order: make sure to get an appetizer of the crispy egg rolls with your order.  The wrapper skins they use lend themselves to a special crispiness with fresh and great tasting but not overpowering filling.

- Interesting note: one of the waiters is Caucasian and can also speak Vietnamese.  I just find that interesting since I have never met a white guy who can speak Vietnamese- usually if they speak any Asian language at all it is Chinese.  If you know how to speak Vietnamese, feel free to order in Vietnamese with him- he'll know what you are saying.  You'll recognize him by that he is the only white fellow who works there and he wears hoodies and t shirts on the job.


Keep up the great work Tin!  Hope the word on you doesn't get out too much and you get too popular or else I will have to start waiting for a table on my Friday night visits.
author: N T.

description:
It's ok.  It's slightly above average from your typical pho / viet food place in sf.  I still think the top TL places are better.  I think San Jose is better.  I think Santa Ana is better.

The decor is very bland, very simple.  Not much on the walls, lots of white space.  That's what I really noticed there.  Not that it is much to complain, I mean I shouldn't be expecting an art gallery whenever I go eat a bowl of phat noodles.
author: Yup S.

description: I ordered pho bo and spring roll. Both of them are good, suace for spring roll is a little too sweet but still tasty, purple orion for pho bo is too sweet, I would not put it into pho bo next time.
author: louisa c.

description:
Good: Pho & Spring Rolls 
Bad: Limited Menu, Price

I've seen this neighborhood joint go from a Chinese to Pho to Vietnamese restaurant now.  They had a makeover to the joint which turned it from your typical no decor place to something a little bit more stylish although simple.  Too much white space though another picture or some plants will do the place great.  Although it had a very intimate atmosphere with the dim lighting and being family owned made the service great.

The food is pretty solid.  It's decent enough pho and Vietnamese dishes, I just wish it was a little cheaper and also more on the menu.  If  I'm craving some Vietnamese and don't want to travel far then this will be the spot.  However if i want something cheaper or a bigger selection I would probably hit up Miss Saigon down the block or venture into the TL and Little Saigon.

:::Breakdown:::
Place: 4 Stars
Service: 4 Stars
Food: 3.5 Stars
Overall:  4 Stars
author: Manohak S.

description:
I LOVED the food! and super friendly service :)

I ordered the freshly squeeze limeade, Pho Bo, and some interesting salad. I can't remember the name and unfortunately the menu on their website isn't up to date so I can't find the name. I was very happy with the food, I think one of the best Pho I've had in SF.
author: S H.

description: I have increased my rating to four stars -- the past few times I have been there the food has been substantially less salty.  And the Pho Ga (chicken soup) is the best around.  I like TIn and am glad they are finally pulling back a little with the salt shaker.
author: John M.

description: A cool place that feels like an update on Vietnamese food, but actually turns out to be pretty traditional. But it's good traditional! A lot of dishes seem to have two components, such as sandwiches with soup, which is a nice mix for a single meal. Everything was tasty and I heard no complaints from any of my large party of 8.
author: Alexander J.

description: update!  I like it.  Decor is still weird, serivce is awkward because I think the waiter is afraid of me now, but the soup be the best in the area.  So what?
author: Mari C.

description:
if i could rate the 3.5 stars, i would, but i can't so i'm rounding up.  came here on a friday night around 9pm and got a parking spot right in front of the restaurant. score! we got:
spring rolls:  good-sized portion, pretty standard.big shrimp
pho ga - i thought this could use a bit more flavor. the chicken was also not very tender.  but it was decent
pho bo- husband thought it was solid 
sauteed greens - basically garlic bok choy which was fine.

4 dishes came out to about $30 which was a little above average for vietnamese but by no means overpriced.

really liked the waiters - really nice and friendly.

definitely  will come back to satisfy my pho craving since we live in soma!
author: Eleanor C.

description: Gringo-ized pho that somehow lacks the fragrance and nuance of the better pho spots in town. Want pho ga? Go to Turtle Tower.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
High quality meat in the Pho. Good noodles, not greasy broth but clean, clear and tasty! The Hu Tieu is good and the Wonton Soup is excellent! I've had half their menu and everything is natural, fresh and delicious. Ohh... the pineapply anchovy/peanut sauce is amazing..!!!

Very homey, cozy, clean atmosphere with excellent family service! Thank god, I get so sick of hole in the wall icky places.
author: Evie D.

description: Really really really good Pho. Great location for me, hard to find a nice restaurant and parking.  Only downside is they are not open on weekends.
author: Christopher K.

description: The food at Tin was about what I expected for the affordable price. Frankly, there's better tasting Vietnamese food in San Francisco (like Sunflower) but this meal was adequate enough to satisfy our hunger. But the most noticeable issue with this meal was the service. Our waiter just didn't care. He was inattentive. He bussed tables and cleared glassware by putting his fingers in the glasses, then returned to the dining room with our food in hand, almost immediately. There's no way he washed his hands in that short of a time. When he brought our meal, he had plates stacked on his arms and made us take the plates from him and place them on the table. I've never seen this before, even in dive restaurants. I might try this place again if I'm in the area since the food is cheap, but it won't be a destination spot for me.
author: Foodie F.

description:
Ok put them to the Pho test.  I have to say that *is* good.  The ingredients taste fresher (i.e. organic mint/cilantro), the meat in the Pho is leaner; the noodles are well done.  

However it is not like the Pho experience one would get on Larkin St (aka Little Saigon) where the broth has the sheen typical of submersed fatty meet.  Also the portions are much large in Little Saigon shops vs. Tin.  

At the end of the day, I would go here again b/c the quality is good and the prices are pretty reasonable.  Extra kudos for blue bottle coffee in their Vietnamese iced coffee; I think that a little like making a mimosa with Krug champagne.  

Overall still recommended...just don't expect the hole in the wall experience you'd see on Larkin St.
author: Amitabh S.

description: Delicious.  The banana blossom salad was all I could hope for and more.  While the shrimp vermicelli bowl was the perfect size, with plenty of shrimp, and equally as good.
author: Mariah K.

description:
Veggie spring rolls were superb... possibly the best spring rolls I've ever had. I'm not sure they're actually on the menu, but they'll make the regular spring rolls veggie if you ask!
They have delicious warm tasty tofu in them! They don't have much basil/mint, so don't be expecting the regular freshness of a spring roll, but it's a different and equally awesome taste!

Will definitely be back!
author: L B.

description: A few of us took the boss here and she loved it. I ordered the chili lemongrass chicken rice plate and it was quite flavorful. My coworkers ordered the Pho which they liked so much, I just had to taste...goood Pho! I will be back, this place is pretty small but we came right at 11:30 when they open so we could avoid the rush. The service wasn't outstanding but the taste food helped me live through it.
author: Brandi W.

description: Yum! Wish we had Vientnamese food like this at home. Hot spot for lunch in SF! Come early bc there was definitely a wait by the time we finished up. We had the cha gio to start which are basically a variant of a spring roll with pork, shrimp, mushrooms and various other flavors. They come sliced and accompanied by a plate of aromatic herbs (mint and cilantro) and some vermicelli noodles. The chia gio were fried perfection, especially when accompanied by the freshness of the herbs. For my main I had a vermicelli bowl with the lemongrass pork. The pork is clearly their specialty and they do it well. Very substantial serving and the flavors were wonderful together. Both of my friends had bahn mi. One with the pork and one with the 5 spice chicken. Chicken was a bit fatty and not as good overall as the pork. But both were absolutely stuffed with meat. Vietnamese coffee was on point. Not much for atmosphere, but you don't need it, bc you'll be too busy enjoying the awesome food.
author: Becky K.

description: Now open on Saturdays!!!!  My go to place for Vietnamese. Absolutely unassuming but dishes made with love. Forget the decor and know that you will be dining on authentic and well made dishes. The crepe is oustanding and any noodle dish is well crafted. NO MSG... no bloated feelings and no hunger 2 hours later. The top-notch friendly service and management make you feel at home. It has been a neighbood secret that is just gaining ground.
author: C K.

description: A little gem that I'm glad we found.  Everything we order was almost perfect.  The soup base was really tasty; the eggplants were delicate but very flavorful, and the service was great.
author: Bo T.

description: Delicious! We walked in the door at 11:30 when they opened, and with in 15 minutes, the places was packed!! Wonderful lunch menu with many affordable options.  We all had very tasty dishes, no complaints!!
author: Bendice G.

description: I want to start of by saying that I am far from an expert when it comes to Vietnamese food, so I don't really have much else to compare this experience to.  I ordered the grilled shrimp and lemongrass pork vermicelli with broth and it was just OK.  My husband ordered some sort of sandwich which he thought was pretty good but nothing super special.  However, we both enjoyed the spring rolls and the coffee.  As other reviewers said, the decor is simple but cute without any frills.
author: Anna K.

description: I have been here about 5 times and I enjoy this place - affordable, fresh food, and friendly service. My favorite dish is the claypot catfish. I also like the lemongrass tofu, 5 spice chicken sandwich, and the beef pho. The only negative aspect of Tin is that their grilled pork shoulder was fatty and I couldn't eat it.
author: Kevin C.

description: Absolutely worst service ever. To go orders are consistently messed up, so be sure to check everything before you leave the restaurant if you are going to get takeout. The last time I ordered from them, they forgot to add chicken with the pho ga dish (Vietnamese chicken noodle soup). When I went back, they had the nerve to argue with me that the dish doesn't come with any chicken. I've ordered this dish many times, so I know what it comes with! This is beside the fact that the menu describes the dish as containing poached chicken and everyone in the restaurant is eating this dish with chicken. It wasn't until I finally pointed out that they also forgot the noodles that they finally acknowledged the mistake and provided the dish with both the chicken and noodles. What arrogance! I'm pretty forgiving about mistakes, messed up orders, etc....except when they are made consistently and not remedied promptly.
author: Sam R.

description: They flavor the food very well here.  Very authentic Vietnamese.  I like the banh xeo, bun tom thit nuong, bun cha gio thit nuong and bun cha ha noi.  I wish that I live close to them and that  they open during the weekend so I can go there more often.
author: Bob S.

description: I'm disappointed. Ordered claypot catfish, which comes with sticky rice. Ordered side of greens o' the day. Catfish was SUPER salty. The greens were really good - garlicky. I think the server said they were water spinach.
author: Alyssa A.

description: Casual breezy atmosphere perfect for casual breezy lunches. I had the vermicelli with pork. It was pretty good. Not a lot of vermicelli noodles but the pork was super tasty albeit a little greasy. The fried rolls they gave me looked really good but the fried casing was like biting into brittle plastic. The texture was totally off. It's like they fried something that started out stale. I'd come back for the pork but leave the fried rolls in the kitchen. I hope it was just a fluke.
author: Michael H.

description: Ok first of all very friendly place totally laid back. Good music playing. I ordered the Vegetarian Bun, great price,
author: Junebug J.

description:
- clean
- Fresh
-excellent Pho
-Ok Service
- good prices
author: Nick S.

description: Service was quick but food was just so so. The fresh spring rolls didn't really seem very fresh. The vermicelli dish I had was ok but nothing spectacular. The place also desperately needed some ventilation as it got very stuffy in there.
author: Jake M.

description: Went there today for lunch the first time and I have to say that I was VERY impressed with what I ordered.  The brisket Pho is delicious and so are the vegetarian spring rolls (2 huge rolls cut into 6 bites).  I will be going there again for sure!
author: Gabriela Y.

description: I live in the neighborhood.. A cute clean very friendly place. The food is not expensive and extremely fresh. I have eaten here several time and have had excellent food and excellent service.
author: Robert O.

description: Had to get the food to go, so the experience wasn't as great, though the spring rolls tasted really good and the ginger/garlic soup base was a nice change from the normal bases I've tasted at other Pho' restaurants.
author: P W.

description: I've been here twice. The food is excellent, the price is excellent, but my Lord the service is so absurdly slow! So, so SLOW! It seriously takes like 20 minutes just to get your drinks, and then waiting for the food leads to believe that they must be slaughtering the animals fresh for each dish. The kicker? It's never even that busy! I have NO idea what the deal is, but while I really like the food it just is not worth the time investment you need to be willing to make to eat here.
author: Kathryn M.

description: Pho ga times two perfect for feeling sickie (or not). Packed for take out; noodles, Thai basil, onion, chicken, lime, bean sprouts and spice don't get mushy. Prices equivalent to prepackaged soups at Wholefoods, at $7.50 ea., but obviously a much better choice! Maybe I'd like some jalapeño or sriracha, not sure if it's offered, didn't ask.
author: Mandy S.

description:
Sometimes my friend and I agree and sometimes we disagree. For instance, I ID as flexitarian (sp?) and she thinks that word is an assault on the English language. But we agree on Tin, and she doesn't like too many Asian restos. 

I was eating vegan that day and so we ordered the vegan spring rolls and the lemongrass tofu. 

Short menu, no dessert, but the food is excellently prepared. 

The rolls were so fresh and the peanut dipping sauce yummy. 

The lemongrass  tofu had a slight char, so I was a bit concerned, but dipped in the vegetarian "fish" sauce it was delish. Came with raw veggies and I got it with the brown rice.

Friendly service and no attitude for us getting one app and one entree and no drinks.

We will definitely be back.
author: Charles B.

description: I was reluctant to try this place at first, since the last two restaurants here sucked major ass, but I am glad I did! Not only was the food delicious, the place was clean, I didnt sit asshole to elbow with the person behind me, (like the previous restaurant here) and the service was great!  RJ is always pleasant and helpful! Sometimes, if we are in a rush, we will get the sandwiches to go. The chicken sandwich rocks in particular! I love the fresh spring roll sauce and the vingarette for thier salads. This place rocks!
author: Andy C.

description: Yes, the floors are a bit sticky at times. Yes, the service can be overwhelmed. Yes, the line can be out the door. Yes, they threw us out when I took too long reminiscing with an old friend. Still, the food, prices and drink selection never let me down. Best veggie pho in the city (be sure to ask for less noodles, more veggies).
author: Ara S.

description: Particularly tasty BBQ pork. My onlybreal complaint is that they're not open on weekends when I'm often in need of a nice bowl of pho to ease my pain, so then I have to fight my way through deaconess he'll to miss Saigon.
author: Lager K.

description: Seriously amazing vegetarian-friendly Vietnamese food! The tofu at Tin is one of the best preparations I've ever had, it was so flavorful and the texture was spot on. We ordered the veggie spring rolls, loaded with still warm tofu, served with delicious peanut sauce that I happily swirled with sriracha.  Finally a veggie spring roll that's meaty! So many Vietnamese places put out mediocre rolls that they stuff with cabbage filler instead of real, fresh ingredients. The veggie vermicelli bowl also did not disappoint- it came with the delicious super flavorful tofu strips, shiitake mushrooms, shredded lettuce, a few peanuts and other veggies. The soy vinaigrette was a nice light addition to the bowl and is fish sauce free. Our service during lunch was quick, friendly and attentive, even with the entire place full with the lunch rush. The neighborhood in this area can be uncomfortable at best, be on alert and watch where you are walking (feces and needles, joy!).
author: Cori W.

description: Really loved this place. Atmosphere is really nice, about 12 tables inside. Staff was super friendly and helpful explaining menu options. Most importantly the PHO was authentic and delicious. I have been to many different Pho restaurants in the city and this one really does it right. The meat was fresh and tender, the broth is so tastey. The prices are just right. You will love this little neighborhood spot.
author: Kelly K.

description: Not impressed.  Had the papaya salad and bo luc lac ("shaken beef").  Overall more salty than the typical Vietnamese food.  Saw a lot of people waiting on a week night.
author: Grace T.

description: The food was fantastic, the Papaya Salad and the Pho were both the best that I have ever tasted. The quality of the food for these prices is unheard of back East here in MD.
author: Kevin R.

description: Tried the spring rolls. Pretty standard. Nothing to write home about.
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description: Great food and quick service. There was a queue snaking its way down the street during workday lunch  time and you know there is good reason locals go there despite the crowd. I had the house greens salad and the shaken beef. Both were very tasty. The beef tender and the sauce not too overpowering,
author: BB A.

description: Their food is good. It could have been 4 stars. However, the service made me lose my appetite - not much use for good food then, huh? Firstly, our waiter was DRUNK. That's right: D-R-U-N-K. His asian glow was eminent, slurred words, and he reeked of alcohol. He tried to do the thing where he didn't write our order down and memorize it... I get nervous when my sober waiters do that, let alone when they're intoxicated?... He came back to review our orders and literally had screwed up every single one (party of 3) orders. He started naming items we didn't even say. The worst part, while we were ordering, we had just finished telling him our appetizers (we hadn't named out entrees) and he - I kid you not - snatched the menus out of our hands while we were talking and proceeds to walk away. I literally had to shout, "HEY! We're not done yet!" Lastly, during our meal, I wanted some small bowls to portion out my noodles to my family. They paid no attention to our table.. I walked literally to the kitchen and asked for 2 small bowls.. One lady was there and didn't even look at me and shouted behind her, "someone get this guy some bowls.." I swear. I have never been subject to such horrible customer service.
author: Michael T.

description: This is a great little lunch spot! It has a family vibe to it. Delish, fresh, Vietnamese Cuisine. I enjoyed the 5-spice chicken and there was more than enough to take home for dinner later. We also tried an egg omelet situation that came with mint leaves...If we were closer we would be here all of the time. About $40 for three people and we ordered wayyyy too much food.
author: Sarah M.

description:
You know how, way back in the day, if you found the guy shooting an arrow at the star on the Tootsie Pop wrapper,  people said you could get a prize?  While eating the pho ga I ordered, I almost asked our waiter for my prize when I finally found a piece of chicken in the bowl!

The dish tasted good enough.  Portions weren't massive; I was able to finish the dish without feeling overloaded afterward.  I was, however, disappointed in the nearly complete lack of chicken.

Overview:
-Service was decent, if a little noobish.  
-The restaurant was quiet, one table of two was there before we got in at 11:30am, and one other person came in about 12:10.  No lunch rush.
-My friends enjoyed their dishes (pho bo, wonton soup, hu tieu).  
-The restaurant was cleaner than your average inexpensive Vietnamese fare in the city.
-There were no condiments on the table, but some pre-dished condiments were brought out (which was nowhere near enough for 5 people).  We asked for more and promptly got it.

If I could get 2.5 stars, right smack in the middle of mediocre, I would.  Will I be back?  Likely not, unless they pump up the meat in the pho ga.  I wish 'em the best of luck, though!
author: Josh C.

description: Really good (and cheap) Vietnamese in the heart of SOMA.  A young and hep kinda place.  My favorite is the soup broth, which is one of the best I've had anywhere.  The rest of the menu is great with high-quality ingredients - haven't had a bad meal here.  And did I say it was cheap? Yeah, that counts.
author: Steve S.

description: I came here for the rare beef pho, I usually drink all the soup but waiter confirmed that there was MSG, that was a huge disappointment. I'm still searching for all natural pho as good as Montreal. The spring rolls & fried egg rolls were good & the sandwich was also very tasty. But I'm all about the pho & the MSG was no go for me.
author: Ennie L.

description: This neighborhood place is a quaint little Vietnamese cuisine restaurant. The decor is modern and nicer than most Vietnamese pho places. Pho was ok with a bit of a kick on the herbs. Aside from that, the meat and noodles were pretty decent. Their crispy Cha Quon was interesting but lacking a bit in flavor. Their rice plates look pretty good so I will have to give this place another try!
author: Eva Y.

description: Great place!  Good vegetarian pho!  RJ was most attentive.  Overal agreat place!   My friend I got there at 5:10 but they wernt open.  However they let us come in early and order drinks.  That earned two stars immediately.  RJ took good care of us and we were able to make a good selection.  He had the seafood claypot.  I had the vegan pho.  The food came out fast and the pho was very good.  Prices were very appropriate.  The atmosphere was warm and sassy and the background music was very good with some club kinda theme going on.  I highly reccomend this place to any one!
author: Troy M.

description:
real pho in SOMA! don't let the decor of this place fool you, it's not your typical sf pretentious overpriced "asian fusion" - this place is legit!

hubby and i got the beef pho and lemongrass pork vermicelli. both were authentic and delicious. cheaper AND bigger portions than the TL. the place is spotless, the service warm and attentive.

their hours seem to be spotty tho. i've tried coming here twice before and each time they were closed. this time around, i wised up and called ahead. glad it worked out cuz i've finally found good pho in SOMA.
author: Rose J.

description: Really liked the food here, had the ginger chicken with brown rice and bok choy and everything was very flavorful and fresh tasting. Too bad you have to order sides like bok choy to make the meal more complete, otherwise you just get rice and chicken. To me that makes it a $$ instead of $ but if you're cool with just rice and chicken then it's a great deal and great tasting. Nice staff, very attentive. Kind of lost in the middle of Howard St in SOMA, but a good find!
author: Jenelle H.

description: I tasted their grilled pork chop. It was good.
author: Steven S.

description:
updated and yummy! only $19.71 for two huge bowls of pho and some tea. place is simple, they are making an effort. so glad this is nearby to my office.
Simple, good food and service.
author: Moira N.

description: Amazing vegetable pho! Their broth is the best..
author: Manjiri M.

description: What are ppl thinking? I've had pho etc in many places in the Bay and they say this is the best? Hardly. The pho was a chicken stock and lacking in any flavor and the bun Bo hue was not even close to what BBH should be. I think that this place has been westernized for the American palate.
author: Sadie F.

description:
Best meal I had in SF, and at a fraction of the price.  

My wife's Vietnamese, and we live in DC (where there are a lot of good Vietnamese restaurants), but this is the best I've had outside of her mom's house.   I hate seafood, but tried my wife's catfish dish and frankly could see ordering it next time.  

While perhaps not the most convenient location, factoring in the quality of the food, the prices and good wine selection, this place is well worth the effort.
author: Thomas E.

description: Every variation of pho is great -- beef, chicken and especially the vegetarian. Want to try a different soup? The won ton noodle soup is good too. But the best soup for my money is the hu tieu! Who knew pork-squid broth could be so inviting? The spring and imperial rolls are awesome (the sesame-peanut sauce with the spring rolls is divine). The bun bowls are also very good. My other favorite dish is the claypot catfish -- it's kinda salty but still very yummy. I am the Foursquare Mayor of Tin and I have decreed Tin a place fit for a king.
author: Jason L.

description: Had the rare beef Pho - delish, and vemicelli noodles with pork belly and shoulder. So delish!!! Also ordered the chicken wings were amazing. Beware: a can of ginger ale was $5.
author: E S.

description: Very nice Vietnamese food - and right around the corner from our loft - and the prices are extremely reasonable!
author: Peter S.

description: I've gone to Tin dozens of times and am always thoroughly impressed. The food is delicious, the service great, and the prices perfect.
author: Mike D.

description: Great beef pho! Fresh meat and savory broth. Also liked the vermicelli with lemongrass pork. The imperial rolls were okay. Probably will try the fried rolls next time.
author: F. P.

description: Got take-out.  Medium-sized but extremely tasty portions.  Had the pork belly which was delicious.  Also tasted the catfish which was great.  Would definitely stop by here again.  The pho is okay.  It's near to the Moscone center so can get rather busy for lunch when conferences are on, fyi.
author: Steven C.

description: Just came back from lunch so very, very yummmmie...We had the rolls in rice paper, the only thing on the menu so far (because we are going back tomorrow) to skip.  They were rather ordinary but....everything else so tasty. You know when silence falls at the table an noone is offering to share...that tasty...I had the glass noodle dish and it was so good particualrly when I poured the broth into it.  Another person had the clay pot fish (that's why I am going back tomorrow) and a third person had the vegitarian dish, he too is going back tomorrow.  So glad we work in "the hood" and parking was excellant.  Loved the clean minimalist interior and service was good.  4 people main course and 2 appetizers for $ 55.00  a true bargain.
author: rassors T.

description: SOMA needs more places like this!  Most of the restaurants are American or Italian.  Not much representation of the Asian influence in SOMA.  All the other Vietnamese places (3) in the area are mediocre to just plain bad.  The atmosphere here is not your typical Pho place.  It's hip and very clean.  Tin's Pho is the best!  I love this place!
author: George C.

description: There is one waitress here on occasions that is really rude. She is just so unaccommodating in every-way. But the place is great, just avoid her!
author: m K.

description: This is our local go to viet place, it's hip and makes good, filling plates. Great for dates and small groups. I recommend crispy noodles and grilled pork plate. $10-$15 entree.However, it's small so it can be quite packed at night but the service is speedy.
author: Sophie S.

description: This was a great experience. My friend and I got there around noon and the place wasn't crowded. I ordered some pho and I can honestly say that it was one of the best I've tried. Tin has a very nice atmosphere and my total bill came under $10. I can honestly say that when I'm in SF next time I'll go there again.
author: Andrey D.

description: We went here twice on our vacation- very good bowls. Service was good, as was the price.
author: Julie H.

description: nice place, service was prompt.  we ordered wonton noodle soup and five spice chicken.  the food came out pretty quick.  chicken was not as tender as it was freshly made. the wonton noodle soup was delicious.   the broth was nice and the noodle was yummmmm,
author: Pikachu P.

description: Good food, not great though.  There is much cheaper and better vietnamese pho & bahn mi elsewhere in SF.  Look in little Saigon in the TL.  Service is curt.  Our waiter worked hard but comes across as disingenuous.  We will not be returning there.
author: James T.

description: This place was too nice and clean to be in the neighborhood.  Very relax, calm atmosphere.  Love the decor and the service.  The waiters are very nice.  Their food was just ok (more like borderline between mediocre and plain boring).  I got a Pho and it was mostly noodles with not enough meat.  But the broth was very tasty and served very very warm.  Unlike other Vietnamese places I've been to, I feel like this place did not give you enough (or at all) side dish veggie.  I didn't try their rice dish, but it looked pretty good.....again I've seen much better. Can't complain much for $7-$8 dish though.
author: Numrin T.

description: I love this place, reminds me of my parents cooking. The pho broth is to die for! Best in SF!
author: Anthony C.

description: kind of obsessed with vietnamese food right now & this place contributes to my obsession.  i will never sate my vegetarian vermicelli noodles and spring roll craving but this place helps.
author: Tina H.

description: Consistently outstanding food; affordable; friendly waitstaff; cute atmosphere
author: Andrew W.

description: Very good. Much better than the previous two restaurants in this location. We live 1/2 block away and come here from time to time. For the last year, it's always packed. Food is delicious, especially the Pho and other soups. Pho Ga uses all white-meat chicken and is delicious. Tofu dishes are also great, and the fresh spring rolls are a treat.
author: T.J. K.

description: This is a great spot for Vietnamese rice plates!  My two favorites are the Catfish Claypot & the Veggie Lemongrass Tofu! Reasonably priced, friendly service and kinda stlyie too.  I love Vietnamese food but not usually a fan of the the neighborhoods they're in...this SOMA spot is perfect!
author: Ramon L.

description: I frequent Tin at least twice each week so I think it deserves another star... the food has gotten much better since they first opened and the service is friendly.
author: Phi T.

description: Such a good place! I get tattooed up the street and I always come in to get a bite to eat after. So good. The grilled lemongrass pork cha gio* is SO good!!! It has the pho noodles, with no broth, but has grilled pork on it with fried veggie egg roll..cut up. So noodles, pork and a yummy egg roll. YES..thank you, and I'll have another please!!! So if you need a great feel you up. Come here. You'll be thankful, and be coming back soon like I do.
author: Holly L.

description: The food here is yummy and always fresh - I've eaten there 4-5 times and not been disappointed. They pack many amazing flavors in every dish. My favorite pho in SF. Prices are great and so is the service (family run - the mom cooks and her son waits tables). Contemporary interior; good music.
author: Jon R.

description: Good Vietnamese food in a more upscale setting than most. Chicken rice dish and pho were both above average. Only surprise were the "spring rolls" which we expected to be fried, but were the soft wrap ones (which were tasty).
author: Betty L.

description:
my neighborhood lacked a good home-y spot to grab a fresh, delicious dinner without having to drop half a days pay or be scared to go to the bathroom in fear of what one would find may in the kitchen/bathroom.  thankfully tin is now in the hood and already improving the dining scene. i've been twice and each time the meal was delicious, nicely plated and well portioned. 

last night i did the ultimate test, the mom test... not only did she go on and on about how good the food was (and she is a restricted diet vegetarian) she also had to tell me how clean the kitchen and bathroom areas are. sighs of relief all around people since when she visits i sweat bullets about where i can bring her to eat.

the beef pho was delicious with a really meaty broth and the lemon grass tofu had robust flavor not typically found in alot of tofu dishes.
author: CTP p.

description: Spring rolls were great and the Pho Bo (beef pho) was great
author: Alex D.

description: haven't really been to very many vietnamese restaurants in norcal, but tin is among the better ones. price was a little higher than expected but the shaken beef was pretty good. the servers were also very responsive, overall enjoyed my meal here.
author: Mark G.

description: I wish it was closer cause it's a great little lunch spot. I love what they've done with the place, it's not as divey as it was in its previous iteration as a Vietnamese restaurant. It was clean and nicely decorated and the service was very fast and efficient. Had the noodles with grilled pork and egg rolls. Super tasty and very big portion. Prices are reasonable and I will probably venture out here when I have a little more time for lunch or am particularly craving some Vietnamese food.
author: Cathy T.

description: I'm not a Pho expert, but this is some of the best I've had. In fact, ties with a little place in LA as THE best I've had. Granted, my Pho experience is limited to maybe 8 places tops, but this place stands out. FRESH veggies, strong but subtle flavors, delicious meat. I tend to grade on food alone, but the service was also excellent. Atmosphere is okay, not bad.
author: Chris J.

description: not sure what i would do w/o tin. girlfriend and i come to this place at least once a week, sometimes twice a week. great tasting, authentic, delicious vietnamese cuisine
author: Justin W.

description:
We had dinner at Tin tonight and I'm full.  

Like others have mentioned, I wasn't aware of its existence until tonight, and I'm a bit embarrassed about that.  Now that I've been, I will go back.  I don't know why people compare it to the other Vietnamese place nearby, that other place is not even close to clean and the food is greasy and gross.

Anyway, Tin is good.  We had veggie spring rolls and veggie bun, both of which were decent sized portions and tasty.  The veggie bun in particular had really nice, fresh ingredients, and a complexity of flavor that I would expect to pay more for.  Please don't raise the prices though, I love that there is affordable, good Vietnamese so close to home.

The only reason I'm not giving them 5 stars is because they only have three veggie options for dinner (lemongrass tofu and veggie pho), two of which are actually kinda the same veggie option, except one comes with noodles and extra yummies and one comes over rice.  Whatever though, I'll keep coming back for it, it's good stuff.  

Prices seemed decent too.  One order of veggie spring rolls and two orders of veggie bun, plus one glass of wine came out to $32, which seems like a good deal to me.

The server was also friendly and accommodating of our 6 month old daughter +stroller.

Thanks guys, I'm glad you're only a few blocks away!
author: judah m.

description: Pretty good Pho Ga, nothing spectacular, quite good lemongrass chicken. Served adequately well as a neighborhood restaurant with pleasant and enthusiastic service and mellow diners.
author: Ramaswamy A.

description: Great lunch spot in SOMA for very fresh and well prepared Bun and Gha and other Vietnamese specialities.  Can be a little crowded at peak lunch time, but always good and fair priced.  Lots of Vietnamese restaurants in the neighborhood but this is the best by far
author: Rick A.

description: This is my first review on Yelp.  In fact, I joined Yelp just to review this restaurant.  I have been a Pho fan for years, but this place had by far the best Pho, Green Papaya Salad, and Claypot Catfish i've ever had. Not only was this place good, but it was inexpensive....I ordered two appetizers, two main dishes, a side of bok choy and had two pots of amazing jasmine tea for all under $35.  Honestly, you can't go wrong here and don't let the location phase you, there is easy parking....
author: Adam M.

description: Our go to take out Vietnamese restaurant. The menu is limited, but what they have is tasty. The Ambience is a little dreary however the staff more than make up for the lack of decor.
author: Scott R.

description:
Tin provides one of the best dining values for my husband and me. The food is clean, freshly prepared, tasty, and more importantly, has no MSG, except for the beef pho (however it's possible that the hoisin and hot sauces that you add to the pho may contain msg).  
I sincerely believe Tin serves one of the best fried egg rolls in the City.  The lemongrass chili chicken and the chicken pho are amazing as well.  The lemongrass pork is equally delicious.  
The service is good and we have gotten to know the 2 servers who work tirelessly to cover the entire restaurant.  The place is spacious, simple and clean.   
For $23 before tip, we would typically enjoy the eggrolls, a pho and a meat dish over rice.  It is plenty for 2 people and very satisfying indeed.  We come here for lunch or dinner frequently and we feel nourished and satisfied after each meal.
author: Chris D.

description: Delicious pho. The crepe appetizer was also awesome. We had to wait to get seated at 8pm on a Saturday
author: Lúcia C.

description:
Very friendly staff. Decor is fairly simple.

Had the bun cha gio thit nuong which was very tasty and authentic (both the cha gio and the thit nuong). 

Prices are a bit high, but comparable to the area. The decor might be spruced up, though, to match the prices.
author: M S.

description: Earl and RJ service? Need I say more?  Not to mention the catfish bowl was incredible.  Thanks
author: Chris A.

description: excellent vietnamese vegetarian cuisine options!! very flavorful, chill ambiance and extremely reasonably priced! had the veg pho and the fresh rolls (that have tofu in them and are a proper appetizer, not the typical overload of veggies) with a lovely sauv blanc. Hope to see some more items like vegetarian fried spring rolls on their menu! can't wait to go back!
author: sue c.

description: Quickly resurrected from the prior Pho spot this use to be the menu is a more complete one from any Vietnamese spot I'd go to these days.  Once again my laziness for proximity is a factor here since it is close to my work.  I was coming down with something last week and was able to kick it with a nice hot Oolong tea and the veggie pho.  I'll will be coming back for more after this test drive.
author: Casey H.

description:
i love PHO place that's not expressing their authentic-ness through the cheap Asian greasy loud clutter decor. instead. a nice clean table with chairs. Because most important of all. the FOOD COUNTS.

- Hu Tieu: Hands down best soup noodle i have ever had. reminds me of home. (i'm from Taiwan)
- Shrimp clay pot: OMG. I can just drizzle the sauce on my rice and eat this all day.
- Lemon Grass tofu: cannot believe that i would love tofu like this
- Garlic Eggplant: MOUTH EXPLODE! garlicly but not salty. flavor awesome! 

just to inform you. that was 4 dishes that we 4 girls ordered. but i have to say i never been to a place, that i liked ALL of the dishes. especially my noodle. (i always end up liking what other people ordered)

This is def the one place that deserves all the foodies out there to try!
author: jungshih w.

description: For months to come, I will fall asleep thinking about Tin's vegetarian bun. And the lemongrass tofu. And the shrimp claypot. And the grilled eggplant. And. And. And. Just go there, all of you, especially all you vegans who are hurting for a nice sodium-y tofu dish or spring rolls or whatever. This is a perfect lunch spot if you're meeting someone on 3rd street for a museum day. Service is prompt and attentive. Tin, I love you. I miss you already.
author: Dolores K.

description: Delicious food, excellent fast service, and great value - doesn't get better than that!
author: Joris P.

description: Un-Fo-Gettable.  I went in expecting a cheap meal but left pleasantly surprised.  My wife and I ordered the Fo Ga.  Excellent dish.  The broth had a great ginger taste and the fresh vegetables were awesome.  You should definitely try this place.
author: Michael S.

description:
This is one of those great local finds that you generally done come across when you are aa tourist.
So glad that I checked yelp prior to deciding on dinner.
Located about 10 blocks south of Union Square we walked from Hotel Abri.
This is a quaint little place that does not have much curb appeal. Unless you've read these reviews most would probably pass right by. So glad we didn't.
Service was great and the food was fantastic.
I tried the Chicken Pho for the first time and it was good, not as strong spice/flavoring in the broth as i had hoped for. Got a good tip from a regular who was sitting next to us to try the beef or veggie pho next time.
GF had the lemon grass beef with rice fettucinne and she loved it. Especially yummy with the sauce that comes with it.
Portions were very generous, prices are very reasonable and the service is attentive.
Just do not expect a fine dining experience with tables clothes and atmosphere (we didn't).
First time ever that we had asian type cuisine and were not hungry the rest of the night.
Terrific! Will go there again.
author: Robert B.

description: We (2) ate here on a Tuesday night. I liked the casual, even family-friendly, atmosphere, and good service. We were seated immediately. Server was very personable; I felt welcomed. A very short wait for appetizers & the meal. It was my first time eating Pho Ba. It was delicious and filling, in a good, hearty way. All ingredients were very fresh and appealing. I did struggle a bit with the glossy plastic chopsticks, but I was out of practice too.There is a versatile mix of single tables and roomy larger tables. Quality food for very reasonable prices. Not pretentious.
author: Anita S.

description: I really enjoy Tin's food. They are so clean, non-greasy and quality foods. I love their clay pot fish. It's the best dish they have.
author: Gloria B.

description: legit food, was very surprised to find a good viet joint in this part of sf.  solid 4 stars
author: Michael R.

description: A great place for a great price. I give Tin high marks. Hard to find a place with consistently good food at such great prices. Try the Warm Beef Salad, delicious. I've also had Ginger Chicken, Won-Ton Noodle soup and a few others. All good and great price.
author: Rick M.

description: Very good food. A cut above just about any other Vietnamese I've had. The only reason I don't give it a 5 is price/decor/location are so-so, but food is killer.
author: Jamie M.

description: Fast, yummy but it is kind of expensive but worth it compared to the other vietnamese places in the area!
author: Vanessa N.

description: I think this is the best Pho in SF right now. The quality of the ingredients is what seperates Tin from the pack. I also really enjoyed their small plates and my wife really enjoyed their rice dishes. A must go in SF.
author: Quinn R.

description: My BF and I tried this place out, based on yelpers good reviews and were sorely disappointed. Usually we stick to the tried and true Larkin street places, Pagolac, Bodega, Turtle tower,Ngoc Mai, but we thought we'd branch out a little. Granted, we only tried 3 items, but still I think that was enough to get an idea of what the kitchen puts out and to dissuade us from returning. We started with the Cha Gio which were quite ordinary and tasted of old frying oil. Ive had much better versions at Turtle Tower and Yummy Yummy. Following that we had The Shaken Beef and Ginger chicken. The beef was nice and tender, though the sauce was bland and lacking in depth. As for the ginger chicken ( which I ordered based on another Yelpers RAVE review), was really unpleasant with a scorched quality to the sauce. The portions were quite small as well, which was totally fine since I didn't really want to take any of it home. Maybe we chose badly or it was an off night, but no matter, we won't be back.
author: J. T.

description: Excellent spring rolls. The peanut dipping sauce was great. The beef pho was also great. The bad side: A little pricey.
author: Elliott G.

description: Finally, a great Vietnamese restaurant with reasonable prices!  I've searched for decent Vientmaese food for such a long time and my friend and I stumbled upon it on Black Friday, after a bit of shopping.  The menu is well balanced for both omnivores (me) and vegetarians (my friend).  Their deep friend spring rolls were yummy and were on par with my favorites like Tulan.  The lemongrass pork shoulder was tender and grilled to perfection and m friend was delighted by the fresh spring rolls.  He raved that is vegetarian pho was substantial and didn't have to deal with chicken or beef broth with lots of delicious veggies and tofu.  The wait staff was friendly and very helpful along with knowledgeable.   Unlike Tulan, it was clean, spacious and although they are still in the proces of putting together finishings touches to the place, shows great potential, but the food and staff are definetly the stars.  I will definetly go back again and again to try the new additions to the menu, which we were treated to a preview of seafood (shrimp/calamari) and tender pork crepe with beansprout and onions.  This was juxtaposed by a crispy and savory crepe.  The waiter let us know that they would be adding this to their regular menu with your choice of either seafood or veggie options. Great portions left us both satisfied and wishing that I hadn't eaten as much the previous thanksgiving day.   Although it's in a transitional neighboorhood, it is definetly worth the drive there and will be coming back to try their other menu choices.  Great family atmosphere, good food and excellent service - what else could a SF foodie want!  - Hopefully it won't get too busy.... :)
author: Paeng C.

description: Just went back for a second time last week. The caramelized catfish dish is UH-mazing. And the service is great, too. Highly recommended.
author: Robert M.

description: Great lunch place near the Westfield Mall. The tamarind soup with shrimp was nice (could have been spicier for me). The dry noodle with lemongrass pork and fried spring roll was very tasty.
author: Manny Y.

description: I've been coming here since they opened and unsurpisingly word is getting around. The food is excellent and the staff is amazing, friendly and efficient. If only they carried fresh coconuts, they would be about perfect...
author: David P.

description: Great simple vietnamese cuisine with a clean minimalist ambiance.  Service can be a bit on the slow side even when they're not busy, but well worth it.
author: Kevin O.

description: Yummy lunches at a pretty reasonable price.  My go to dish is the 5 spice chicken sandwich.  YUM!
author: Ben G.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Phenomenal food that doesn't make me all tired afterwards, and really tasty. Great family style vibe, very friendly. Hung takes your order while his mother cooks your food in the kitchen. I go here pretty much every time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Alec B.

description: prices are great - food is OK - i got crispy noodles with squid, shrimp, pork and veggies on top, perhaps a bit too much corn starch in the sauce - my friend got the pho ga and the taste i had was very very good with delicious slightly spicy broth - service was very friendly if a bit slow - if i worked in this neighborhood, i would love this place since it's a very good deal for the price
author: Nancy M.

description: not a better place for me to get lunch .... tasty and excellent service .... i can't wait to go back tomorrow and get the claypot catfish with a vietnamese ice coffee
author: gavin b.
